name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: The first item on the agenda is the debate on the report by Jarosław Wałęsa, on behalf of the Committee on Petitions, on the European Ombudsman's annual activity report in 2013 (A8-0058/2014) [2014/2159(INI)] I would like to extend a warm welcome to the European Ombudsman Mrs O'Reilly. The rapporteur has the floor for four minutes.

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: rapporteur. - Mr President, first I would like to underline the fact that the year 2013 was a special one in relation to the post of European Ombudsman. Taking over from the long-standing and well-respected Mr Diamandouros was definitely a great challenge for Ms O’Reilly. Thanks to her great experience as an Irish Ombudsman, the newly-elected European Ombudsman started her work efficiently from the very beginning of her mandate. I would like to thank the shadow rapporteurs for their valuable input during all stages of preparing this report: our cooperation was very fruitful and I tried to accommodate most of their ideas. I think we all share the view that the Ombudsman has taken up her duties with admirable commitment and has managed to accomplish a lot, considering her short time in office in 2013. I would like once again to congratulate the European Ombudsman on her efforts to make the institution accessible and user-friendly. An example of this was demonstrated in the preparation of the annual report. It is divided into two parts: the first includes the most important statistics and the second a more detailed examination of cases of 2013. Topics at the top of the list of the Ombudsman’s inquiries in 2013 included transparency-related issues and other key topics such as ethical issues, citizens’ participation in EU decision-making and fundamental rights. In my opinion, it is crucial for the work of the Ombudsman, and the European institutions as well, to observe the tendencies regarding the complaints. I appreciate the fact that the number of complaints about the European Personnel Selection Office (EPSO) more than halved in 2013, and the volume of complaints against Parliament also significantly declined. On the other hand, it is important for the Ombudsman to examine the significant rise in inquiries based on complaints against the Commission – and the same applies to complaints against EU agencies – and especially to monitor developments and indicate the reasons why complaints were lodged. I would like to stress that the European Ombudsman took a very proactive attitude during the preparation of this report. Her report mentioned the statistics on incoming complaints and, on the basis of 100 exemplary ones, indicated the next steps. This is an interesting way to explain the process but, in my view, including raw data is also crucial so that it is easier to spot the tendencies over the years. This recommendation was taken into consideration and full data will be incorporated in 2014. Moreover, I think it is important for the European Ombudsman to strike a balance between the traditional and digital communication channels. It is still possible to address a letter just with the title ‘The European Ombudsman’ and it will reach her office. At the same time it is crucial to further develop social media strategy. From what I recall, the official Twitter account has tripled and now has over 9 000 followers. Also worth mentioning is the fact that the services of the Ombudsman are available in 24 official languages, which is quite impressive considering that her office consists of 67 posts. Last, but not least, as a PPE Group coordinator on the Committee on Petitions, I have a special interest in improving the timeframe for processing complaints. Therefore I am fond of a mechanism that is used by the European Ombudsman., namely the interactive guide, which enables her to answer requests successfully. I hope we will achieve similar goals in our committee. To sum up, I am very content with the propositions of Madam Ombudsman and I wish her all the best in her future work.

name: Emily O’Reilly
text: Ombudsman. - Mr President, I would like to start by putting on record my deep appreciation for the overwhelming vote of support I received in this Chamber for my re-election last month. It is a huge source of support for me personally, for my strategy and for my colleagues, who work hard on a daily basis to implement that strategy. Such wide parliamentary support is crucial to the success of any ombudsman, and I promise to build on that support by continuing to work closely with this Parliament. I cannot operate without your support, and equally I work to ensure that the people you represent will have access to an independent source of investigation and redress if they feel they have been unfairly treated by an EU institution. Our work is complementary. Thank you, Mr Wałęsa, and all the shadow rapporteurs, for your work over the past months on the report before us today. The report shows a clear understanding of the challenges and opportunities facing the Office of the European Ombudsman as we attempt to keep pace with the evolving expectations placed upon us by European citizens. And, as their directly elected representatives, you know how fast the hopes, expectations and concerns of people in Europe today are changing. Honourable Members, this is my first time addressing you in plenary. However, since coming into office in October 2013, I have addressed you in committee a total of eight times, including before the Committee on Petitions, the Committee on Budgetary Control and the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs. Each time I have benefited from your expertise, your advice and support, and from that of the staff who support your work. These committee hearings and our many one-on-one meetings have strengthened my understanding of our work together at European level and have fed directly into the strategy I have developed for my office. My task as the third European Ombudsman is to take the office to the next level and make sure it continues to succeed and to thrive. My work at the end of 2013, when I took office, and over the past year of 2014 has been about putting those words into action. Recently, I published our five-year strategy entitled ‘Towards 2019’, which you refer to in paragraph 21 of today’s report. My strategy is to combine three objectives – to ensure relevance, to increase visibility and so to achieve greater positive impact. To begin executing this strategy, I first undertook, as promised, an internal audit of the procedures and practices of the Ombudsman’s Office. This involved consulting with staff at every level and is leading to a number of internal changes, including the introduction of a modern complaint-handling system, a process begun by my predecessor, which will enable us to achieve greater internal efficiencies in complaint handling; a review of how we draft our case decisions to make them more citizen-focused; a review of our key performance indicators; and a review of our complaint inquiry processes, which will allow us to identify the key cases early and to prioritise them. These changes will, I believe, lead to an overall better service to citizens. With an office of around 70 staff, I see it as my duty to use the resources at my disposal to the maximum possible effect. To ensure our work becomes more relevant to the major concerns of ordinary European citizens and residents, I have made greater use of my power to launch inquiries in the public interest without necessarily a specific complaint as basis. To that end, I appointed an Own Initiative Investigation Coordinator, whose job is to drive the own-initiative inquiries in collaboration with her colleagues and to ensure that the outcomes are both speedy and effective. Last year we opened own-initiative inquiries into the transparency and balance of Commission Expert Groups, the transparency of the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership negotiations, the way in which EU institutions are implementing the new rules on protecting whistle-blowers, the Commission’s handling of the European Citizens Initiative, the way in which fundamental rights are protected in the EU cohesion fund programmes, and how Frontex ensures compliance with the Charter of Fundamental Rights in its important and difficult work. Two other major ongoing inquiries of significant relevance concern how the Commission manages potential conflict of interest when EU officials leave for employment elsewhere – the so-called ‘revolving doors’ issue – and an ongoing inquiry into how the European Medicines Agency supports the transparency demands of Parliament in relation to clinical trial studies for medicines in the EU. I appreciate the fact that the Committee on Petitions welcomes these inquiries in point 24 of its report. To achieve greater visibility, I have focused on ensuring that our work is better communicated to you, the elected representatives, to our stakeholders and to the public. Media commentary and media monitoring suggest that that strategy is having a significant impact, with details of our cases and other work now regularly featuring in the Brussels media outlets and also in mainstream Member State media and further afield. In addition, I now send you, the Members, a digest of our work, and I hope I have demonstrated my willingness to have ongoing dialogue with you on subjects of mutual concern. We have also focused on our social media outreach and have trebled our Twitter followers in one year. I hope many of you have seen our new-format annual report, which uses many new media technologies to make it more readable and attractive. I believe the new strategy has already had a positive impact and I am very grateful to all of the officials in the institutions I have dealt with for their largely positive engagement with my office. In December 2013 we had a positive response from the Commission in two major cases. One concerned an unreasonable delay in relation to a state aid investigation into certain professional football clubs; the other concerned an alleged conflict of interest for the former chair of the Ad-Hoc Ethics Committee for Commissioners. The chair stepped down after my intervention, and the Commission has since made the work of the Ad-Hoc Ethics Committee more transparent, which I welcome. In relation to the European Medicines Agency, I believe the intervention of my Office, together with concerned Members of Parliament and civil society, helped to make sure that their new transparency policy was not rolled back, as it had appeared it would be when details of the new policy were announced in 2014. Following, again, the strong intervention of a coalition of concerned Members of Parliament and civil society and an inquiry by my office into the lack of transparency around the TTIP negotiations, the Council released the mandate for wider public scrutiny, which I welcome. The Commission, as you know, has also announced other steps forward on transparency. Recently we made further constructive suggestions, and I expect the Commission’s response to those suggestions in March. In recent weeks I have also listened to the new Juncker Commission. I have been heartened by the commitments on, and the real progress made toward, greater transparency, openness and accountability, particularly by Vice-President Timmermans on my right here today, and I pledge to work as collaboratively as possible with the Commission at all levels to help them achieve those goals. Indeed, the Commission is actually leading on many issues of good administration in the EU today, and for that they deserve our recognition. To conclude, can I put on record again how impressed I am by the high standards of the European civil service, the thousands of dedicated people who work in the EU institutions and agencies all over Europe? The vast majority work hard to achieve high standards in their work and display a true ethic of public service. However, as we know, trust in both the EU and national levels of governance is not always very high at the moment in Europe. There are reasons to hope that we are slowly beginning to emerge from the painful recession and banking crisis. The people of Europe will regain trust in their governing administrations when they begin to see, for their families and in their daily lives, positive changes deriving from the decisions made. However, unlike most nation states in Europe which are largely legitimate in the eyes of their citizens, the EU administration has not yet achieved the high levels of popular legitimacy which, in the eyes of many Europeans, it should enjoy. Today’s report correctly recognises, in paragraph 3, that ‘wide gap’. This is why it is so important for the EU administration to be not only of the highest possible quality, but indeed to be the ‘gold standard’ in ethics, transparency, accountability and effectiveness. My task as European Ombudsman is to work with the institutions and agencies to help make that happen. As you, the Members of the European Parliament, have recently trusted me to continue as European Ombudsman, I promise to do my best to continue working to fulfil that task. Finally, let me conclude by again thanking the rapporteur, the shadow rapporteurs, their staff and the secretariats for all the work on the report, and I look forward to listening to your contributions and questions.

name: Frans TIMMERMANS
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. - Mr President, first of all I want to thank Mr Wałęsa for his report. I congratulate him on the excellent work he has done on behalf of your Parliament. Secondly, of course, congratulations are due to Ombudsman Mrs O’Reilly for being re-elected by your Parliament. You appreciate her work and so does the Commission, and I look forward to working with her along the same lines as she has just expressed. I am really very proud to be part of the leadership of what I would call one of the best administrations public service has in the world. But I am also committed to improving the way it works, to making sure that we work more transparently, that we are more accountable and that we also change the situation when the situation is not up to the standards both Parliament and the Commission want. We have examined the Wałęsa report with great interest. Transparency, openness, access to information, respect for the rights of citizens, high ethical standards: essential building blocks for creating greater support for European institutions at large. I fully concur with what Mrs O’Reilly just said, namely that the level of quality of our institutions is not reflected in the level of support from European citizens, and we need to work on that if we are to get the mandate from our constituents to do what needs to be done to create more prosperity and to create more jobs and to create more security for European citizens. I also note, and Mr Wałęsa referred to it, that the share of complaints against the Commission has risen, and I have listened carefully to his call that we should reduce that, and I agree with him. I just want to, very briefly, tell you that in actual numbers, complaints between 2012 and 2013 have gone down. It is the share that has gone up – and this is unacceptable, so we will work on that – but just to make sure we do not misunderstand that there is actually, in numbers, a reduction in complaints. I would just like to point out that if you compare the institutions, the highest compliance – 84% – by institutions with the Ombudsman’s recommendations is by the Commission, and let me just note very briefly that 100% compliance will for legal reasons probably never be possible. But I strive to have the highest possible compliance. I also want to salute and welcome the approach of the Ombudsman to focus on strategic investigations, because strategic investigations can discern patterns, and patterns are the things we need to change if we want to improve the way we run our administration. I will support her and work with her very closely to make a success of her recommendations emanating from these strategic investigations. I also note that Mr Wałęsa calls for common binding rules and principles on administrative procedure, and I just want to reiterate what I said at my hearing: that we will discuss the best possible way of implementing that. I know that a European law on administrative procedure is one of the options that could work there, but let us work between the Commission and Parliament on that to see what would be the best possible solutions. I have noted also the conclusion that the percentage of complaints concerning EU agencies has almost doubled. Here again I offer cooperation, within the possibilities we have legally, to improve that on the boards of these agencies etc., and there again I would like to work closely with the Ombudsman and with Parliament to ensure improvement. Finally, the complaints against EPSO have indeed decreased significantly, and I think I would echo Mr Wałęsa’s conclusion that this is to be applauded. Once again, I look forward to working closely with Mrs O’Reilly and her team. She has an outstanding team. They have a strong dedication to improving the quality of our administration and to answering enquiries and complaints from European citizens, and it is in all our interests to make sure that her work is successful. I will certainly guarantee you my personal commitment to making that happen.

name: Peter JAHR
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, I would like to thank the First of all, I would like to congratulate the Ombudsman once again on her election last December. The fact that there was no opposing candidate in this election can certainly be seen as a positive testament to their work so far. Speaking of choice, I will continue to work for the reintroduction in future of the practice of the Ombudsman being allowed to address a few words to Parliament immediately after the election. Thank you again to the rapporteur, Jaros-awWa'sa. I would like to support the report 150%. In that sense, I have three brief comments or clarifications to add. Firstly, in her short term of office, Mrs O'Reilly has already succeeded in intensifying cooperation with the European Parliament and, in particular, with the Committee on Petitions, and, above all, to reduce distance from the citizens. Secondly, I look forward to working very well with her in the future, for example on the subject of children's rights. We have many complaints in the Committee on Petitions, particularly on the subject of custody. Mrs O'Reilly has already assured us that, from her point of view and with her responsibility, she would also like to address this issue. It is precisely in the enforcement of the rights of vulnerable people, such as divorcechildren, that European authorities should cooperate more closely and make better use of the resources available. It is good to know that, with Mrs O'Reilly, we have a dedicated and highly competent ombudsman at our side.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, I too would like to begin by welcoming the election of the Ombudsman, as well as the hard work done not only by the rapporteur, Wassa, whom, as I say, I congratulate, but also by the various shadow rapporteurs, who have allowed us to draw important conclusions in this report. Ladies and gentlemen, at this time of difficulty, it is obvious to say that Europe needs More Europe. To this end, we know that it is crucial that citizens are or feel within the heart of Europe and to do so they have to feel at the heart of their institutions. Ensuring the proper functioning of the European institutions is of paramount importance and that is the cardinal function of the Ombudsman's own office, as well as the Committee on Petitions, the role of which we must also recall. And it is because citizens must feel us, as I say, close and really consider that their problems are our demands and our task. In this regard, I have nothing more to congratulate and say that this is a good report because the work of the Ombudsman's office has been good. Although I want to say that this should not be a sign of complacency, but a new impetus in this work and in this line of work. Indeed, as regards the report in particular, as regards the functioning of the institutions, I have to say that the launch of the website in twenty-four languages is welcome, although I regret that the report is not available in all languages, but only in English. I must congratulate the fact that access to people with disabilities has begun to be improved, although I also hope that it will be done for children or that it be done for gender equality, improving their language. I must also congratulate the fact that the European Network of Ombudsmans has been launched, as well as that work has been done on the transparency of the European institutions, although I would like to demand that all those bodies, formal or informal, which take decisions affecting the rights of citizens be included in this improvement of transparency , either the troika or the Eurogroup itself. I have to demand, as Mr Wassa has done, the need to set deadlines and guarantees in the response by the European institutions to all citizens' requests, in order to reduce political interference. And, on the substance, I would like to say that I agree with the different issues addressed ex officio by the Ombudsman, although I would delve into the need for the price of innovative drugs, as well as the impact of fundamental rights on the crisis.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Mr President, we welcome the presence here of the European Ombudsman, Mrs O'Reilly, and congratulate her on her solemn re-election. The European Ombudsman's annual activity report in 2013 highlights the important action of this Institution in ensuring good administration and protecting citizens' rights. We believe in the cooperation of the European institutions and attach the utmost importance to the Ombudsman's control of cases of maladministration of the institutions and bodies of the European Union, especially at this time when the economic crisis has led to the questioning of the European institutions themselves. Citizens now call for strengthening accountability and transparency institutions at European Union level, including FRONTEX, the Troika and the Eurogroup, in order to improve the quality of democracy. At the same time, the millions of poor citizens of the countries put into budgetary adjustment programmes, i.e. memoranda, consider it necessary for the European Ombudsman to carry out an investigation into compliance with the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union by the Troika.  Also, following the decision of the plenary of the European Parliament in March 2014 on the disastrous role of the Troika, the European Ombudsman must investigate the conflict of interest in the European Commission between its role in the Troika and its responsibility as guardian of the Treaties of Community law.  Finally, the Ombudsman must examine the conflict of interest between the role of the European Central Bank in the Troika, where she participates as technical adviser and creditor of the Memorandum States, and the mandate it has under the Treaty. That is why, and in closing, Mr President, I call on colleagues to vote in favour of the relevant amendments that I have tabled. Finally, I would like to thank the rapporteur and the shadow rapporteurs for the cooperation we have had. (The speaker agrees to answer a question with a blue card (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: blue-card question. – Would you agree with me that in this, as with many other things in life, size matters? What we have here is tens of thousands of civil servants trying to be involved in every part of life, with hundreds of billions of euros involved. It is simply impossible to run an effective organisation with such a huge remit, with so many great ambitions to be involved in so many things. This cannot possibly ever be run efficiently. Would you agree?

name: Notis MARIAS
text: "blue card" answer. – Mr Etheridge, the role of the European Ombudsman - I have been involved in this institution for many years as a professor of the institutions of the European Union - is to be able to limit cases of maladministration at European Union level and especially at Commission level. I believe that it can help to protect the rights of the citizens of the European Union by choosing strategic areas and making concrete observations. There is already an effective functioning of the Ombudsman's institution and this has been demonstrated in the past by the role played by the Ombudsman, Mr Diamandouros.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, thank you, Mr Timmerman, for your presence and your express commitment. Congratulations, Mrs. O'Reilly, on your re-election. On behalf of the ALDE Group and the Committee on Petitions, I would like to expressly thank the European Ombudsman, Emily O'Reilly, for the excellent work done in the term of office and the precision and self-demand reflected in her report.  It is a great example of how to develop rigorous institutional work, with a proactive and ongoing approach to operational efficiency, teamwork and accountability.  As this report reflects, most citizens' complaints clearly point to a shortfall in transparency in the European institutions and that is the area of improvement that we must highlight the most.  In this regard, I would like to recall the investigations initiated from the Ombudsman's Office, such as those relating to transparency in the TTIP negotiations, the reporting of irregularities in the institutions of the European Union and the cases of 'revolving doors', the requirement of transparency in clinical trials of new medicines and also, of course, tireless work in the defence of fundamental rights in cohesion policy and support for improvement of the European Citizens' Initiative.  The Ombudsman's main priority is to ensure full respect for citizens' rights. We must review the concept of 'good administration' on the understanding that the objective is a 'better administration', understood as a process of continuous improvement, as the gold standard to which Mrs O'Reilly refers, which is already under way and is based on an excellent civil service. This requires not only compliance with legal obligations, but also that we act willingly to serve by en ensure that citizens are treated correctly and can fully exercise their rights. Mrs O'Reilly, the first woman elected to the post of European Ombudsman, has also expressed her willingness to work for excellence through her 'Towards 2019' strategy, based on three fundamental pillars which I enthusiastically endorse: Impact, Relevance and Visibility. I would like from here to endorse all support for the work of this institution which, together with the Committee on Petitions, embodies the main channel for the participation of European citizens. That is the area where they can express their concerns openly and directly. Let us all put it, Parliament, Commission and Council, at the heart of our activity, which is nothing but service to citizens.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, first of all, indeed, to congratulate the Ombudsman on her work, as well as for her activity report, for which we produced this document. This report that we are going to vote on is clearly unsatisfactory for us because, when we do not make up reality, what we do is directly ignore it. To give an example, I miss the fact that there is no talk of 'revolving doors', which is one of the issues highlighted by the Ombudsman in her report because of the very high number of complaints made. And, by the way, in Spain, thanks to pp and PSOE, we know a lot about all this. However, we prefer to ignore it, and I wonder why it causes them so much allergy and they prefer to ignore it when the Ombudsman herself approaches it? I miss the Ombudsman's role in investigating Frontex's investigation of the violation of fundamental rights. An investigation, at the Ombudsman's own initiative, while a stark reality is being buried in beautiful words that thousands of people, especially immigrants, with no solution other than to play their lives at the gates of our borders, suffer in their flesh. Why do we put on, again, this veil of hypocrisy? I miss the public report that the TTE negotiation is one of the most shameful in the history of the European Union. And you don't have to remember that we can't even access the reading room of the documents with a pen. But it may seem normal to the rapporteur of this report that the negotiation of an agreement of this magnitude , which will undoubtedly impoverish us all more , should take place as in the worst times of the war. Needless to say, I also miss mentioning cuts, austericide policies, which attack people's right to a dignified life. It is no coincidence, ladies and gentlemen, that most complaints come to the Commission. Barroso or Juncker. It doesn't matter what we call them, because, in the end, they're exactly the same. I could keep talking about other issues, but what's clear is that we keep playing reality makeup. That is why we have tabled from our group a series of amendments which we hope will be adopted, since they are in line with the issues we have just explained.

name: Margrete AUKEN
text: verts/ALE Group. Mr President! First of all, thank you to Jarosław Wałęsa for a good report and a very good cooperation, where we have met good will to get as much from all of us as possible, and I can also feel here how united we stand, also in our thanks to Emily O'Reilley for a very nice piece of work. She has continued to work on the work of Nikiforos Diamandouro and, I think, in the happy situation in the European Union, we have a real Ombudsman. In particular, we have been pleased with the emphasis on the fight for openness, which we saw to make a powerful impact on the demands of the TTIP negotiations, where the Commission had been completely closed down. We also look forward to working on the Ombudsman's special report on Frontex.  After all, when we have tabled a number of amendments, it is mainly because we think we need to get even more force behind the demand for a proper regulation of good administration. We have promised the citizens. It is stated in the Charter in Article 41. It is in Article 298 of the Treaty. It is time we started to get this legal! Thank you to Mr Saunders. Mr President, I would like to say to Mr Timmermans here today, so that we are so clearly agreeing that we are actually strengthening the work of ensuring good governance in all the EU institutions. Let me call here for us to have the service principle at the heart of it, where it is the citizens who must be protected, not the officials, and that we have a true fight against conflicts of interest, that is, against incapacity. It is difficult in all our countries - including Denmark - to get a proper understanding of what capability is and to have it respected. In addition, I would like to mention, since Mr Schroeder has also mentioned the need for a more Mr Wałęsa said: 'Of course we would like to have a good working relationship with the Ombudsman and the Commission. But we must have more resources! I think our resources should match those of the Ombudsman. Not that her resources should be cut, but we need more. We cannot handle all our many complaints by simply stifling as many of them as possible, and I think i can sometimes sense that this is happening, not least on the part of the EPP. If we can strangle them, it'll be quicker - that's clear! Finally, let me say, and it was also mentioned by Peter Jahr, that I find it rather shameful to find that this Parliament did not give O'Reilly a proper welcome. Many of the big old countries do not even know what an Ombudsman is. They don't have any. The Scandinavian countries have, it has England, it has Ireland, it has the Netherlands - and happily many of the new Member States too. You have experienced what a real, independent, qualified Ombudsman is. That is why I would like to thank Wałęsa again for having strengthened us in the fact that we have made it work, and I would like to call on the Presidency to come together and to ensure that we are given a better welcome and that we never again see a President who shuts down access to information about who has recommended the Ombudsman. It is baroquely contrary to the whole ombudsman's work that members are suddenly protected from standing by who they have recommended. So let's get a good welcome. We have a good Ombudsman, we should also have a parliament that can live up to the Ombudsman's best standards.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I too very much welcome the work that the European Ombudsman Emily O'Reilly has done so far and to trace in her work the real will to bring the citizens and institutions she represents closer together, an institution that has been designed for citizens and with the citizens alive. I would also like to thank Mr Wałęsa for his report, but I would like to make a few comments on a fact that I found very important: some 68 of the 100 requests that come to the European Ombudsman do not fall within the scope of his competences.  This fact perhaps tells us that the accessibility and publicity of the European Ombudsman must be improved, using every means that new technologies make available to us both to promote the very figure of the Ombudsman – not known to most – and to raise citizens' awareness of their rights and no less important to clarify what the real competences of the European Ombudsman are.  In this respect, I would also like to address my own country in order unfortunately to recall some records that it sadly holds: Italy is the only State that has not established the figure of the National Ombudsman, it is among the very few that does not even have a parliamentary committee on petitions. As if that were not enough, to point out the lack of attention that our institutions have towards the protection of citizens, I would like to point out that the 2010 Finance Act also cut a very important figure, which is that of the municipal ombudsman, thus depriving citizens of the closest territorial references they had.  I hope that Italy too will be seriously urged to remedy this situation, as, moreover, following the recommendations in the 2012 annual report of the Committee on Petitions aimed at establishing a network of committees on petitions that includes all those present in the Member States. I would therefore like to thank the European Ombudsman and wish him a fruitful year of work to protect citizens' rights.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the masks are falling. There needs to be real public control of the Commission. 64% of the investigations opened by our Ombudsman concern the Commission. The number of complaints against the Commission has increased. However, it acts directly on European citizens. We have to put an end to this situation.  For the past eighteen years, the Court of Auditors has refused to endorse the Commission's accounts. Here, Parliament votes with the same lightness the discharge. Worse, you refused to vote on the motion that we tabled a few weeks ago, not to mention the mystery surrounding TTIP. Neither the Council nor Parliament has shown itself capable of controlling the Commission.  So I have only one piece of advice for you, Commissioner. A wind blows and rumbles, here, over Europe. Be careful because people are very dissatisfied.

name: Rosa ESTARÀS FERRAGUT
text: Mr President, first of all, I would like to congratulate our Ombudsman, Mrs Emily O'Reilly, and also the former Ombudsman, whose 2013 report we value today; also Mr Wassa, our rapporteur in this report and all the shadow rapporteurs.  Indeed, we value how citizens want to combat mismanagement in some cases of certain bodies, bodies and institutions in the European Union, and turn to the Ombudsman's institution to act as an intermediary between them and these institutions. This requires not only enforcing the law, but also that there is a will to serve, so that it is ensured that citizens have an immediate response and for citizens to be treated correctly. It is a unique opportunity for the institutions of the European Union to be effective and beneficial to citizens and to regain confidence in each and every one of them: in short, to be open and effective institutions. Looking at the report, the main issues of concern to citizens are issues around transparency, access to information — an important issue — ethical issues, "revolving doors" that may be – a problem closely linked to the issue of transparency – and also the commission's management as guardian of the Treaties, fundamental rights and all projects and programmes of the European Union.  Although the Ombudsman's own recommendations are not binding, they are certainly heard at a very high percentage and are a unique opportunity to solve a problem. I conclude by saying that, as far as accessibility issues are concerned, I must congratulate the Ombudsman, although I would ask her to ensure that the implementation in the Member States of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities is a reality, because even though it has been signed by the vast majority , the reality is very poor.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: Sur President, Sinjura Ombudsman, Nixtieq l-ewwel nett nawguralek talli erżajt żejt elected bťala l-Ombudsman Ewropew gťal din il-leżiżlatura. Kemm ilha f'din il-kariga, Emily O'Reilly uriet determinazzjoni, enerťija u effièjenza fil-kariga tagťha. Konvinta li f'dawn il-σames snin li żejjin - flimkien mal-Parlament Ewropew u l-kumitat PETI - ser isir progress fil-kwalità tal-amministrażzjoni gťall-gid taè-żittadin Ewropew. Is-sena l-oťra kienet sena tranżitorja, however r-rapport tal-Ombudsman hu wieťed tajjeb ťafna, innovattiv u wkoll user friendly. Iżda ma rridu bla ebda dubju naťsbu li l-Unjoni Ewropea laťqet il-levelll aʻettabbli ta' akkontabilità u trasparenza. In fact, in-nuqqas ta' transparency u aèèess gťall-informazzjoni huma l-ilmenti l-aktar spissi li jsiru. Barra min hekk, żewż third taè-σittadini Ewropej jaťsbu li l-vuèi tagťhom ma tiswiex. Hu important li-żittadin ma jitlifx il-fidużja fl-istituzzjonijiet tagťna, speżjalment fi żmien meta x-xettiżiżmu fil-Prożett Ewropa qed jikber. Mod biex dan ma jsirx, u biex nimxu 'l quddiem, hu li nżommu liż-żittadin fil-qalba tad-deżiżjonijiet tagťna u nintegraw l-interess taż-żittadin fix-xogťol tal-Ombudsman u l-institutionalzzjonijiet kollha Ewropej. Irridu niżguraw governanza serja u rridu niżguraw li-żittadin jaraha u jťossha din is-serjetà. Ninnota bi pjaʻir, li aktar minn 23 000 eittadin sabu gťajnuna mill-Ombudsman. But ninnota li sfortunatament, minority biss tal-ilmenti jaqgťu taťt il-kompetenza diretta tal-Ombudsman. Gťalhekk, biex dan l-uffièju important jkun ta' servizz aktar effettiv gťaè-σittadin: • Irridu ntejbu l-kanali ta' informazzjoni lejn i-σ-σ biex ikunu aktar mgťarrfa fuq id-drittijiet tagťhom • Irridu niżguraw li kull cittadin ikollu aèèess gťall-uffièju tal-Ombudsman, mingťajr diskriminazzjoni ma' min mhux abilitat b'sistemi diżitali u [li] gťalhekk ma jistgťux jikkomunikaw onlajn • Irridu naraw follow up effièjenti gťall -ilmenti biex b'hekk iż-żittadin ma jťossux injorat • Irridu fuq kollox inqassru ż-żmien ta' dawk il-każi taťt investigazzjoni , biex b'hekk issir żustizzja, jew tinstab soluzzjoni mingťajr dewmien. Fl-aťar nett nixtieq nawgura ťidma tajba lis-Sinjura O'Reilly u nirringrazzjaha tal-kooperazzjoni u impenn tagťha lejn din il-pożizzjoni tant oneruża.

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking Congratulations to the Ombudsman, too. Its report shows that the Union suffers from a transparency deficit and very often it is the national institutions that are more transparent than the Union institutions. In this case, we need to move from words to consistent actions. I propose that the Ombudsman, without waiting for the European Commission, develop a code of transparency – a set of rules that will make the EU institutions more transparent.  Finally, the second point: we have a new citizens' right, a citizens' legislative initiative. The Ombudsman has taken care of this, but it is not a matter of mere interest, it is about standing on the side of those who exercise this right. On the side of the biggest initiative, which was "One of us". Unfortunately, the Barroso Commission rejected this initiative supported by nearly 2 million citizens. I expect the Ombudsman to be clearly, unequivocally on the rights of citizens, residents of the European Union, in such cases/cases.

name: Cecilia WIKSTRÖM
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratul First of all, I would like to thank Mr Wałęsa and also to the Members and the secretariat who have worked on this report, which is important to all of us. As Chairman of the Committee on Petitions, It is, of course, a great pleasure for me to congratulate the Ombudsman today on the renewed confidence. I look forward to continued good cooperation. The role of the Ombudsman is a very important part of creating a European Union that can enjoy respect and bring confidence back to our citizens. As Mr Wałęsa writes in the report which I hope we will adopt by the widest possible majority very soon in this plenary, transparent decision-making processes and accountability of those who have power and responsibility are a very important cornerstone and cornerstone and one of the most important aspects of modern democracy. In this context, I thought that I would once again address the demand that Parliament has made several times to the Commission, namely that it should present a full, effective administrative law for the European Union. Such a law would easily and clearly regulate not only our institutions, but also how all eu authorities should act in relation to the citizens of our Member States. Only with the legal basis introduced in the Treaty of Lisbon did this become possible. However, it has been possible for a number of years now. I think it is high time that you made use of this opportunity, because it could help to facilitate the ombudsman's work as well. That is why I am now addressing you with confidence, Commissioner Timmermans, and asking you to get to grips with this matter as a matter of urgency, which is about a European effective administrative law. Because our national institutions and authorities are already subject to these laws, and it is high time that we had uniform rules in place at European level as well. Here, the code of good administrative behaviour can certainly form the basis for further work.  Finally, I would like to wish the Ombudsman, the Commissioner and all colleagues and our colleagues in the committee good luck. I look forward to our continued cooperation in this still fairly new year.

name: Liadh NÍ RIADA
text: A Uachtaráin, ar dtús báire ba mhaith liom mo chomhghairdeachas a ghabháil le Emily O’Reilly as ucht an obair mhaith atá ar bun aici mar an tOmbudsman.  Aontaím leis an tuairisc sa mhéid agus go gcuirtear béim ar thábhacht na follasachta agus an dea-chleachtais laistigh de hinstitiúidí na hEorpa agus ba chóir go mbeadh na prionsabail seo mar dhearbhthosaíocht i gcónaí. É sin ráite, measaim go raibh an rapóirtéir lag go leor i leith an Choimisiúin agus gur sheas sí leo maidir leis an méid gearán a tháinig isteach fúthu. Is cúis áifeála é go bhfuair oifig an Ombudsman an méid sin gearán maidir le droch-chleachtas. Mar aon leis sin, ceapaim go raibh sé lag maidir le Frontex agus is beag tagairt a rinneadh don  ‘revolving doorʼ agus do chásanna coinbhleachta sna hinstitiúidí AE. Gan dabht, gan trácht ar na fadhbanna ollmhóra atá againn le TTIP agus tá sé scannalach nach bhfuil a fhios ag na Feisirí Eorpacha cad go díreach atá ar bun acu ó thaobh na gcainteanna sin. Mar fhocal scoir, ba mhaith liom a chuir in iúl gur chúis bhróid é domsa gur bean Éireannach thú agus guím gach rath ort sa todhchaí agus san obair atá amach romhat.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: Mr President, dear colleagues and dear European citizens, who may be following us! Or a very important position in the European Union, the position of the Ombudsman. This is a serious legal activity which involves examining the enforcement and enforcement of the rights of the 500 million European citizens, among whom there are more and more disenfranchisement sufferers. It is therefore a question of the extent to which their rights under law, judicial practice and principles of law are exercised. I have such a strange feeling, because I have two CVs in my hand, one for the Ombudsman, and it shows that the other is that of our reporter, and from this we have this strange image that would probably surprise the seekers that he is our ombudsman, and this is obviously a mistake, so my request, my question, is to be kind enough to tell us what legal qualifications you have acquired in your life. and how it continues to form itself in the field of law. Your cv shows that you have never studied a semester of law and your work is monitored by a colleague of parliament who has also never studied a semester of law in his life. I'm sorry if this is a misunderstanding, that's what your résumé says.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: Nixtieq nibda billi nirringrazzja flower-collet Wałęsa tar-rapport e大大ellenti tiegħu. Nixtieq ukoll nieħu l-opportunità biex nirringrazzja lilek, Sinjura O'Reilly, għall-ħidma tiegħek bħala Ombudsman tal-Unjoni Ewropea. Naf li l-ħidma marbuta mal-Uffi大大ju tiegħek mhijiex għall-wita; xejn I hu fa大li, iżda inti rnexxielek tnaqqas id-distakk bejn i大-yidadidini tal-Unjoni Ewropea u l-istituzzjonijiet Ewropej billi toħloq u tkompli taħdem fuq uffiħjuju li sar aktar a大大essibbli, miftuħ, u li jitħaddem b'modħ ajar. Nixtieq ukoll nirringrazzjak stable żammejt kuntatt regolari mal-kumitat tagħna tal-petizzjonijiet u mal-MEPs kollha; kont disponibbli hawk meta kien hemm bżonn. Għandna bżonn, għaldaqstant, li nsaħħu t-trasparenza fl-istituzzjonijiet Ewropej jekk irridu li 大-ikeittadini Ewropej ikollhom iktar fiduħja fl-Unjoni Ewropea u l-istituzzjonijiet koll taghaħha.  Għalhekk m'għandniex bżonn lil xi ħadd jikkonvin大ina li hemm bżonn li nsaħħu l-uffi大大ju tiegħek u li dan l-uffi大ju jkollu r-riżorsikollha meħtieġa biex jitmexxa b'mod effettiv. Nagħmel punt ieħor: aħna għandna nagħtu wkoll l-appoġġ kollu lil kull Ombudsman fil-pajjiżi tagħna tal-Unjoni Ewropea. Fil-każ ta' Malta l-Ombudsman qed jieħu l-inizjattiva biex iwaqqaf l-International Ombudsman Law Insititute f'pajjiżna. Din hija inizjattiva tajba u li jien nagħti l-appoġġ sħiħi għaliha. Sinjura O'Reilly, nirringrazzjak u jien ninsab ħerqana li nkomplu nsaħħu l-koperazzjoni tagħna tul is-snin li ġejjin. (Il-kelliem qabel li jwieġeb għal mistoqsija "karta blu" skont l-Artikolu 149(8) tar-Regoli ta' Pro大edura).

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: Question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. – I agree that it is a very important institution for us, for each country and for the European Union. My question is: do you not think that this institution should look more at the situation of the Member States of the European Union where budgets are poor because human rights lawsuits are lost in the country and are earned at the Court of Human Rights and, in practice, money is paid from the budget and not by those who are wrong?

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: tweżiba karta blue. – L-ewwel nett naťseb li mistoqsija bťal din tista' titpożťa wkoll lill-Ombudsman, imma nista' nirrispondik, iva. L-ewwel nett, il-fatt li aťna nallokaw żafna riżorsi lill-Ombudsman ma jfissirx li fl-istess ťin m'gťandniex inpożżu pressjoni biex il-prożess żudizzjarju quddiem il-qrati tal-pajjiżi tagťna dejjem imur gťall-aťjar. Jiena fil-fatt kont dejjem fuq quddiem li nargumenta li anki fil-pajjiżi l-oťra tal-Unjoni Ewropea gťandna niżguraw li jkun hemm transparency, reform żudizzjarja u l-possibilità li kulťadd jingťata d-dritt li jiżi rrappreżentat b'mod korrett quddiem il-qrati nazzjonali.

name: Lidia Joanna GERINGER DE OEDENBERG
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking I would like to warmly congratulate Emily O'Reilly on the First Report of the European Ombudsman. The report relates to the year 2013, in which the previous spokesman, Professor Nikiforos Diamandouros, was very positively assessed by us every year. I am pleased that his method of cooperation with Parliament, in particular with the Committee on Petitions, is also currently continuing.  In 2013, more than 23 000 citizens turned to the Ombudsman for help. Of this number, nearly 20,000 have received online advice. 2420 complaints were registered, a decrease of exactly 22 compared to the previous year. 350 new investigations were opened, 461 investigations had already been closed and 77% related to complaints from individual citizens. The most common were those concerning transparency in the EU institutions and citizens' participation in the EU decision-making process. Making the Ombudsman's institution as citizen-friendly as possible should become the guiding principle of this term of office. And you, as the first woman in this position, wish you very warmly. Finally, I congratulate the rapporteur, Mr Walesa, on a fair report.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the report on the activities of the European Ombudsman is a measure of the extent to which the European Union is completely out of place with the concerns of the citizens of the Member States.  In 2013, less than 24,000 citizens consulted the Ombudsman's services and only 461 investigations were closed, which is ridiculous compared, for example, to the activity of the French rights defender, who handled nearly 90,000 cases in 2011 alone. This figure proves the disinterest of the citizens of each Member State with regard to European procedures and institutions.  Moreover, almost 20% of the Ombudsman's proposals have not been implemented by the European institutions. As such, it would have been appropriate to ask why these proposals were not followed in fact. For example, the Ombudsman asked the Commission to respect the basic rules of transparency regarding the TTIP and CETA negotiations. However, it appears that the Commission has not heeded these recommendations or communicated to MEPs the ins and outs of the negotiations for this free trade treaty.  So no, the European Ombudsman is not up to the challenge and weighs almost nothing against the all-powerful European Commission.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: Mr President, I would also like to thank colleague Wałęsa for the work that has been done. I welcome the honourable Ombudsman and wish her every success in her work. I asked for the floor in the debate in order to confirm what was described in the parliamentary report. It is important to stress that the European Ombudsman's institution is a key institution for strengthening EU democracy. During the elections, we promised EU citizens a more humane Europe, and strengthening and respecting EU civil rights is essential to achieve this promise. The ultimate goal is to strengthen confidence in the European Union, and if we succeed, we have all succeeded. And if, in the course of his work, the Ombudsman achieves that the Eu institutions become more efficient and citizen-friendly, we will all be able to see it as a success, and, dear Ombudsman, you can, of course, count on the support of all of us on this journey. I also welcome the fact that the concept of 'visibility' is one of the pillars of the Ombudsman's strategy for 2019. As a Central European MEP, I see this as one of the biggest challenges: to make EU rights visible and visible, including the role of the European Ombudsman. We must do everything we can to ensure that our message reaches the citizens. For example, it is important to make documents available in multiple languages. We must also continue down this path, my dear Ombudsman, and I say this not to increase the workload of you and your office, but to make the European Union a community of consciously active, informed citizens. (The speaker agrees to answer a blue card question under Article 149(8) of the Rules of Procedure).

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Blue card question. – Mr President, I would like to ask Mr Csáky a question, saying that he referred to Central Europe. I would like to know, if you could shed some light on the typical central European problems affecting the European Ombudsman, because I myself am from Central Europe, and I feel that there is a difference between the different regions of Europe.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: Blue card answer. - Mr President, I would like to reply to the following. By central Europe, the concept of Central and Eastern Europe is primarily defined as post-communist countries. I said that it is very important that the role of the Ombudsman and the role of human rights be made clear to the public because people in former communist countries have been socialised differently. Their democratic acumen is not as developed as in western European countries, where there has been no interruption for 40-50 years. That is why I believe that it is of the utmost importance that we, the representatives and citizens of the 10 Member States that joined in 2004, become more aware of this and talk about these issues at home in the media.

name: Jude KIRTON-DARLING
text: Mr President, I welcome today’s report, as it emphasises the crucial role that the Ombudsman has to play and the importance of her three key pillars for the next five years: relevance, visibility and impact. The EU can sometimes appear as a faceless bureaucracy, and as parliamentarians we share a common duty with the Ombudsman to make European democracy a tangible reality. Our Ombudsman has been leading from the front in this regard as her actions, particularly on TTIP, demonstrate. A lack of transparency in the TTIP negotiations has generated tremendous frustration across Europe; it only reinforces people’s concerns. Our Ombudsman has responded proactively, investigating, requesting and obtaining greater transparency. This achievement bears testimony to the commitment and efficiency of our Ombudsman. I will be voting for this report today as a sign of my support and recognition.

name: Heinz K. BECKER
text: Mr President, Ombudsman, Mr Vice-President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has had on First of all, I would like to congratulate and thank the rapporteur, Mr Wasa, for the excellent report, which we in the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats fully support.  As a member of the Committee on Petitions of this European Parliament, I would like to emphasise that we in Europe can be proud that we have an institution such as the European Ombudsman – as the direct point of contact for all 500 million European citizens. Complaints about the functioning of public authorities and administrations have been demonstrably and successfully investigated, and control has been exercised and improvements and changes have been demonstrated in the results in the EU. In this context, I also welcome the inquiries initiated by the Ombudsman and her team on the subject of ethical behaviour and transparent lobbying. This annual report shows that these issues are at the top of citizens' list of problems. I believe that Mrs O'Reilly's efforts to make the Ombudsman's institutions even more accessible must be supported. You are sure that the Committee on Petitions will support it.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: Madam President, i voted in favour of this report. Madam Spokesperson, i would like to thank you very much First of all, the picture that we have from your report is simply positive, and that was a good reason, because Mr Walesa has also prepared a very decent report. So, if you can, there are two moments in the discussion that have died here. First, the question is that the Ombudsman is working well, even though she is not a lawyer. Let's add that the symbol of the law is Temida. Temida has her eyes obscured. You are supposed to keep your eyes open, because you represent the interests of the citizens! And it is good that you are not a lawyer. There was also a second allegation that there are tens of thousands of cases under consideration in France. You have only informed a few hundred of those under consideration. Firstly, you cannot order thousands to influence and justify your existence. Ba, moreover, if no matter is received, the right to be ombudsman is still absolutely justified, because you are to be a representative of citizens, but also a kind of guardian of the European Commission's compliance with standards.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: Mr President, Madam Ombudsman, Mr Vice-President of the Commission, ladies and gentlemen. Madam Ombudsman, I share the views of my colleagues and, in particular, my colleague Wałęsa, who congratulated her on the excellence of the work she has done. I would like to recall his predecessor, Nikiforos Diamandouros, who has left us an extraordinary legacy. The institution you represent is of the utmost importance. The proper functioning of public administration is not only a fundamental pillar of a democratic system, as a right of our citizens and the fact that more than 23 000 citizens have addressed the Ombudsman is revealing not only of this importance, but also of the trust they place in it. In 2013 I saw very much the special report on Frontex, which should be encouraged by the systemic approach you want to print in certain surveys. Moreover, I look forward to the results of your strategy towards 2019.  However, transparency issues dominated 2013. We have recently seen with Europol that these problems persisted in 2014. I therefore hope that your future action will be intensely dedicated to this subject. I can no longer agree with you that it is intolerable that international agreements allow third states to limit the powers of our institutions, powers that are set out in the Treaties, or create obstacles to the free exercise of their powers.  I hope you continue to work hard. Thank you. Continuation of good work.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: I thank the rapporteur, as well as the Ombudsman, for presenting her first annual report and for the work she has done in helping to strengthen accountability and transparency structures and institutions at European level, and by promoting truly good administration for the benefit of every citizen of the European Union. I also appreciate the fact that the message is now available in an interactive version without a traditional paper version. This really makes the European Ombudsman's institution more accessible, attractive to consumers and should continue to work in this direction, while at the same time leaving our citizens who may not yet have access to the Internet. I also appreciate the Ombudsman's good cooperation with Parliament, in particular with the Committee on Petitions. Of course, it is positive that in 2013 the number of complaints about the European Personnel Selection Office decreased, but it is worrying that the number of complaints has increased with regard to the Commission and the Agencies of the European Union, so I very much ask the Ombudsman to look into what causes this happened and what measures do we collectively have to take? Indeed, transparency, openness and access to information for our citizens are very important.

name: Emil RADEV
text: I would like to congratulate Ombudsman Emily O'Reilly on the key role in making the work of the European institutions more understandable and transparent, and the European administration more effective for all European citizens, including Bulgarian citizens. The separate report on good administrative governance is an important innovation to the annual report, and I would like to encourage Ms. O'Reilly to make it a tradition. I would like to make two recommendations. First of all, I would like to call on the Ombudsman's office to deepen its cooperation with the European Ombudsmen within the European Network of Ombudsmen. I believe that the exchange of experience and successful practices between Mrs O'Reilly, national and regional ombudsmen will inevitably contribute to improving the quality of the services of national administrations in different countries and the European institutions. Secondly, I would like to encourage her to devote even more effort to protecting the rights of persons with disabilities and to ensuring that the Administration of the European Union is aware of its responsibilities with regard to these rights. I believe that the role of the European Ombudsman is central to the newly established European Union network to monitor the implementation of Article 33(2) of the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. I believe that it is also our duty as European legislators to ensure that people with disabilities can enjoy their rights and freedoms of European citizens with dignity and full dignity.  My last recommendation to you is to pay particular attention to the application of European legislation on the treatment of animals in the Member States and, in particular, to examine whether the European Commission and the Member States are complying with their obligations under the Zoos Directive, the Regulation on the protection of animals during their transport, and the Wildlife Protection Regulation.  The Ombudsman's decision on unnecessary laboratory tests on animals and the need for better coordination by the European Chemicals Agency is a first step in this direction.

name: Péter NIEDERMÜLLER
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank you for your support. We all agreed here that the Ombudsman institution is one of the most important European institutions and that Mrs O'Reilly has done quite a great job in recent times. It is this institution that protects the rights of European citizens, this institution that stands up for the predictability and transparency of the European institutions, thereby working to improve the quality of democracy. Allow Me, Mrs O'Reilly, to draw your attention to the importance of your institution representing the rights and human dignity of all those who are marginalised in society. Those who do not have a strong political advocacy capacity. I call on you and your institution, in the spirit of a welcoming Europe, to pay close attention to the legal capacity of these people, to stand up for their rights and their human dignity.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: – Mr President, I thank Mr Diamandouros and Mrs O'Reilly for the results of their offices. As a new MEP, I went through the annual report because I wanted to know how much the European Union deals with transparency, ethical issues, fundamental rights and the overall involvement of citizens in European Union policy. I must say that I was pleasantly surprised by the European Ombudsman's activities. That is why, Mrs O'Reilly, I supported you in obtaining another mandate. No institution of the European Union can be successful without the strong, hardworking and charismatic personality that you have demonstrated during your mandate and during the hearing.  Of course, the Ombudsman has a number of tasks ahead of her that need to be implemented as quickly as possible in order to make her institution more accessible to European citizens in particular. As guardians of transparency, Mrs O'Reilly and her office should also be more involved in transparency in the negotiation of basic directives, such as the TTIP example.  Finally, Ombudsman, let me make one smiling remark. In the report, you note that the 2013 Annual Report has taken on a new form and that an interactive version in the form of an e-book is also available for download. I personally consider this "progress" to be a smiley one in the 21st century and ask that it be carried out automatically for the next period. I wish you all the good.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I too would like to congratulate the Ombudsman on the work that has been done by the Ombudsman, which has been carried out by her office, and I believe that an in-depth reading of the report clearly convinces us of certain elements that are of deep satisfaction. I too am a new Member and I come here to Parliament with the desire to see an open Europe, a permeable Europe, a Europe with which the citizens, especially the smallest, the simplest, the weakest, can talk.  I see with great favor, great positivity the fact that this office and the role of the Mediator is increasingly becoming a constant reference in people's lives. Sometimes when you look at Europe you think of something far away, with which it is difficult to talk, like a monster of bureaucracy. That is why this role is extremely important, because it is concrete proof that this is not the case, because it is concrete proof that this is a Europe in which, if you want to know, you can know, if you want to know you can know, if you want transparency you can have transparency.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: Madam President, I take this opportunity to raise two elements that are of great importance. The first is that of overall transparency and accessibility, if information needs to be increased and if we want to keep, or indeed restore, the reputation of our institutions. Secondly, I want to suggest a greater focus, in the work of the Ombudsman, on the struggle of traditional minorities in Europe. Specific measures should be developed to inform these communities, which account for 8% of European citizens, about the work of the Ombudsman. Their rights as enshrined in the EU Charter and the Council documents, and especially their vulnerability, should be kept in mind. I therefore call on Ms O’Reilly to undertake an own-initiative inquiry on the subject of persons belonging to traditional minority communities and their access to information provided by the European institutions, along the same lines as a past own-initiative inquiry that focused on people with disabilities. It would be extremely useful to verify how sensitive the Commission is in its dealings with these issues.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I congratulate Mrs O'Reilly on her work. The statistics on the role played by the European Ombudsman show a participation in a meaningful but certainly improveable direct dialogue with citizens. I welcome a number of important inquiries that the Ombudsman has launched such as the TTIP and CETA negotiations transparency inquiry, employee reporting of wrongdoing in the EU institutions and transparency in the Commission's expert groups. For the institutions, this implies a further stimulus to respect for the rule of law, the principles of good administration and fundamental rights, operating a citizen administration dialogue based on mediation, without recourse to the judicial phase, representing an appropriate valve for decompression of quarrels in relation to the institutions.  I also think that social media as a channel for communication is essential and I therefore encourage the Ombudsman's offices to make greater use of these tools to raise public awareness of the Ombudsman's activities and to make his work more usable. Public confidence in the institutions is essential in the difficult economic context, so the new strategy towards 2019 is welcome with the proposal of investigations into problems of impact and relevance and visibility, and I join in the desire to see the Ombudsman as the guardian of the Union's transparency.

name: Ingeborg GRÄSSLE
text: Madam President, Mr Vice-President, I would like to thank the commissioner for his I would like to compliment you, Mrs O'Reilly, and also to thank you, including the Committee on Budgetary Control, for a really good cooperation. They are a strong point and a strong pillar of credibility and a very important point of contact, not least for EU officials. You did half a dozen OLAF cases in 2013. There is not all day evening. And you have a lot of influence – it is not true what is said here today, you have a lot of influence! How much influence you have – and we are grateful for it – can be measured by taking the last decision of 2013, namely the ad hoc Ethics Committee and the Presidency. The Commission has not moved two or three years after Parliament's criticism, but according to your report it has moved. Thank you very much for that, too. Vice-President Timmermans, there are many questions about lessons learned. It would be nice if there were no always need for any lengthy procedure, but for the Commission to react independently. That is what I would like to see today.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: Madam President, firstly congratulations to the Ombudsman on her reappointment: she is worthy of the position. Ombudsman, I would like to bring to your attention a matter that has been totally ignored by the Irish and the European media: the destruction of thousands of millions of euros. It began in March 2011, when three billion was destroyed, and resumed last year with the destruction of a further one billion in two tranches of 500 million each. This obscenity is the legacy of the bail-out in 2010 of the failed institutional investors in two failed non-systematic Irish banks. It served its purpose, bought some time for the euro, prevented the onset of the feared contagion had those banks been allowed to fail. There was a fall-out, however. The insistence by the ECB that, because the Irish Central Bank printed that money, that must now be taken back into circulation. So you have this obscene situation where a broke, hugely indebted country, where the austerity programme has already wrought havoc, especially among those who can least afford it, is forced to borrow thousands of millions to destroy. The social repercussions of the bank bail-out cost in Ireland have been horrendous: record numbers lying on trolleys; growing numbers suffering from depression; growing numbers taking their own lives; a quarter of a million emigrating. I ask you, please, as a priority, to have a look at this abomination. You talk about confidence in the European institutions; people in Ireland cannot have confidence until this changes.

name: Milan ZVER
text: I would like to thank my colleague from the Group of the European People's Party to the rapporteur, Jarosław Wałęsa, for preparing a balanced report on the activities of the European Ombudsman, Emily O'Reilly and her predecessor.  The ombudsman's work is important because it gives citizens of the European Union the opportunity to appeal in the event that European institutions break the law and rules. Unfortunately, much more infringements happen in countries, national institutions, than in European institutions.  In the event of a serious violation of human rights in the Member States, citizens of the European Union must apply to the Strasbourg Court, the Council of Europe. The European Union is completely powerless on these issues and the efforts made so far to improve things in this area are very slow. I am pleased that there is a European Ombudsman, but unfortunately the name of this institution gives too much empty hope. We need a genuine full-fledged European Ombudsman who will also be able to respond to the many violations in the Member States and to fully protect human rights and freedoms in the European Union.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I wanted to congratulate both the rapporteur, Mr Wałęsa and the Ombudsman, Mrs O'Reilly. , often and willingly, the European Union is seen as an external thing, distant, difficult to understand and therefore to reach, therefore, probably, if we manage to centralise and make good use of the figure of the European Ombudsman, the citizens themselves can feel closer to this institution and can better understand its function. In this respect, we should try to publicise, to make it more familiar and easier for ordinary citizens, who are not interested in international politics, to have access to complaints and access to the Ombudsman.

name: Seán KELLY
text: A Uachtaráin, mar Éireannach, ba mhaith liom a rá go bhfuil mé bródúil as an obair atá á déanamh ag an Ombudsman Emily O’Reilly agus gan dabht ar bith tá na Feisirí go ginearálta an-sásta leis an obair atá déanta aici agus dar ndóigh ós rud é gur glacadh léi arís mar Ombudsman don tréimhse atá romhainn d’aon ghuth, taispeánann sé sin go bhfuil jab an-mhaith á dhéanamh aici.  Tá sé an-tábhachtach go mbeadh duine sa bpost sin, duine a bheadh éirimiúil, tuisceanach, ciallmhar agus tá na tréithe sin go léir ag Emily agus tá moladh tuillte aici. Nuair a thagann daoine go dtí an tOmbudsman, bíonn siad in ísle brí. Ceapann siad nach bhfuil cothrom na Féinne ar fáil ina dtír féin nó san Eoraip agus is iontach go bhfaigheann siad cothrom na Féinne ó Emily O’Reilly agus Oifig an Ombudsman.  Dá bhrí sin, molaim í agus an fhoireann atá aici agus mar fhocal scoir, ba mhaith liom a rá le Ming Flanagan cé go bhfuil drochrudaí b’fhéidir ag tarlú in Éirinn tá a lán dul chun cinn á dhéanamh ann chomh maith agus is fiú é sin a aithint freisin.

name: Frans TIMMERMANS
text: Member of the Commission. - Madam President, I have listened carefully to the Members’ contributions and I have a number of reactions on some of the points made. First of all, this Commission is strongly committed to improving transparency and accountability. We have taken measures to that effect in the first weeks of coming into office. Obviously this is not reflected in the report about 2013, which is now two years ago. So, if you want to hold us accountable, also hold us accountable on our actions. I am glad to be accountable in that respect, and I would actually urge this Parliament to follow the example the Commission has set on transparency – for instance, on contacts with lobbyists. This is something on which Parliament could follow suit, and that would be my suggestion. Secondly, I note that we still need to do much to improve our situation. I would not agree with those of you who have argued that the situation in national administrations is better than at European level. There are many Member States where the levels of transparency and accountability are not the same as in the Commission and the other EU institutions, but still I do acknowledge that we need to improve the situation and I will work very closely with the Ombudsman to that effect. I also want to point to the fact that, in relation to the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership, we did exactly what the Ombudsman required, and I thank her as well as Mr Wałęsa for acknowledging that. I also acknowledge that most complaints are about the Commission, and that is because most of the legislation and decisions affecting citizens directly are indeed acts taken by the Commission. So there is a correlation with the fact that we are the biggest institution and that we have the most effect on citizens: citizens will then complain. I want to try and increase, as much as I can, the level of compliance with the Ombudsman’s recommendations. As pointed out before, we are at 84%, which is the highest level among the institutions. I will try to get it even higher, with the proviso that, in certain cases and for legal reasons, we may not always be able to implement the recommendations of the Ombudsman. In conclusion, let me say that I am very much looking forward to working closely with Ms O’Reilly and her team. They are making a strong contribution to creating a more accountable Europe, a more transparent Europe and a Europe that is closer to its citizens. Thank you once again Mr Wałęsa for an excellent report.

name: Emily O’Reilly
text: Ombudsman. - Madam President, honourable Members, I would like to thank you all very much for your contributions and the thought that you have brought to them. I take everything that you say on board. I take the compliments, obviously, but I also take the criticism because, without feedback from you, who are even closer to the people than I am, I cannot really know what their true concerns are. I see you as a very valuable resource in relation to that. There were many issues raised, and obviously I cannot deal on an individual basis with all of them, although of course you are more than welcome to come to me as individual MEPs and discuss any matter that you want. But there are a number of general issues that I want to discuss. A lot of you talked about the visibility of the office. I hope that I am demonstrating that this is certainly a priority for me and that, if people do not know that I am here, the service that I can provide for them is fairly redundant. I have made a very big effort to make the office more visible through a number of techniques. What is also very important – and some of you have alluded to this – is your own national ombudsmen, Member State ombudsmen, the Petitions Committee or regional ombudsmen and the work that I can do to improve that. As you probably know, as European Ombudsman, I chair the European Network of Ombudsmen, and just yesterday I had a strategy meeting in relation to how they can help me. Equally I can also help them with their own situations. Two of the things I am doing include, for the first time next year, producing an annual report on the work of the Network, in which I will highlight not just my own work but also the work of the Member State ombudsmen. Hopefully, if they agree with this, then they too can present that alongside their annual reports to their respective parliaments. I am also just about to start for the first time a joint investigation with a number of Member State ombudsmen in relation to Frontex, on one particular element of their work which is bringing people back, i.e. deporting people from countries. We are going to be looking at how Frontex deals with human rights issues that arise in the context of those flights. So for the first time, the European Ombudsman is working with Member State ombudsmen, we are pooling our resources in our respective jurisdictions in order to make an even bigger impact on that. I will be looking for more areas in which to work on that. Some of you have challenged me and my office in relation to compliance, and also challenged the Commission and the agencies. I set my own challenges as well. Right from the start, I have said that the compliance rate of 80% + is not high enough, because in many Member States, including my own – Ireland – the compliance rate for the recommendations of the Ombudsman is often as high as 95% or even 100%. That is a very high target, but it is one that I will strive to achieve. In relation to effectiveness, a lot of you have pointed to the fact that many of the complaints that come before me are outside of my remit. Obviously most complaints that European citizens have are with their Member States, but one of the functions of the office is to be as helpful as possible and to direct anybody who comes to us to where they can have their problem resolved.
