But this is partly why I have begun to focus very intensively on the own-initiative investigations, to see what systemic issues I can deal with which my office and the resources that I have can add greatest value to. I suppose my overall ambition for the office is simply to be useful – more useful to the citizen, more useful to Parliament, more useful to the Commission and so on. To do that, I need to collaborate with you. You have to support me if you find that my recommendations are rational and that you wish to support them, because without your help I cannot succeed as I might. I also need to collaborate well with the Commission and with the agencies. They have to trust me, just as the citizens have to trust me. So I thank you all for your contributions. I will take them on board. I just want to make one point about the Troika. Many people have come to me over the last year to see what I can do to investigate the Troika. The Troika is not an EU body per se, even though the ECB and the EU Commission are critical parts of it. What I have said to individual MEPs is that, if they wish to work with me and if there is a particular issue or facet of the work of the Troika, as it relates to an EU institution, that they feel I could legitimately investigate, then that is something that I would be very happy to do. At the moment, as the Irish Members know, there is an investigation into the banking collapse and the financial crisis in Ireland. They are trying to get the ECB over to explain itself to the Irish people, and we will see how that evolves. Thank you all very much for your contributions and your support.

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: rapporteur. - Madam President, I would like to thank everyone for joining today’s discussion. I think it is safe to say that we have the right person in the right place, and I am very grateful for that – and I am very grateful to you, Ms O’Reilly, for all your work. You are doing a splendid job and I wish you all the best in the future months. I would like to say one thing, because there were a few voices of discontent, but most of them, I think, misunderstood a very crucial point. This annual report refers to the year 2013; there are lot of issues that came up last year which are going to be addressed in future annual reports, so maybe the debate on this report is not the place to address these. Once again I would like to thank everyone for joining in the discussion, and all the best to Ms O’Reilly.

name: Adina-Ioana VĂLEAN
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place shortly. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. The role of the European Ombudsman is very important in showing citizens that the institutions are doing everything possible to ensure that their rights are respected. The Ombudsman is also a faithful bridge between European institutions and citizens. The European project cannot only be built in Brussels. All citizens must be able to bear a stone to the edifice that is the European Union. I congratulate Mr Diamandouros and Mrs O'Reilly on their work in 2013.

name: Barbara KUDRYCKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – In just the last year, the Ombudsman has taken action in 2 354 cases and as many as 19 418 people have received advice through an interactive guide on the website, which demonstrates the effectiveness of the system for responding quickly to citizens' complaints. However, the report shows that access to documents of the Union institutions and the transparency of certain procedures remain insufficient, given that as many as 25.6% of closed investigations were related to this. The publication of a new edition of the European Code of Good Administrative Practice deserves special attention and praise. All Union institutions should implement and fully comply with the principles of this Code, and the newly established Commission should adopt jointly binding rules of administrative procedure for eu administration structures and present a draft regulation on the matter.  Several important inquiries initiated by the Ombudsman deserve particular approval: in particular, the refusal of the European Agency for the Management of Operational Cooperation at the External Borders of the Member States of the European Union (Frontex) to implement the complaints mechanism, which resulted in a special report by the Ombudsman, an inquiry into transparency in the negotiations of the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP) and the reporting of irregularities in the EU institutions. I would like to congratulate Mrs O'Reilly on her successful mission to increase transparency in the institutions and to deepen dialogue with citizens and to inform them effectively on the full exercise of their rights.

name: Adina-Ioana VĂLEAN
text: The next item is the debate on six motions for resolutions on Russia, in particular the case of Alexey Navalny.

name: Tamás MESZERICS
text: author. - Madam President, I would like to welcome the High Commissioner to this debate. Every time we discuss a case of human rights problems or a lack of the rule of law in Russia, we hope and wish that it will be the last such case we need to discuss in this Chamber. In this case too I hope it will be the last one, but I am very much afraid that our hopes will be betrayed yet again. The case itself is very clear. Alexei Navalny was accused and tried on trumped-up charges for no other reason than because he dared to expose corruption at high levels of the Russian state apparatus; for no other reason than the fact that he dared to run for office in opposition to Putin’s rule and Putin’s Government. His brother, Oleg Navalny, was sentenced to three-and-a-half years in prison for no other reason than that of being the brother of Alexei Navalny. So, as I say, the case is clear, and I am sure that my colleagues could list a number of similar cases, as we do in fact in the resolution. Threatening and intimidating political opposition through persecution and harassment of family members is one of the oldest tricks in the handbook of autocrats. It can work from time to time, but I am absolutely sure it is not going to work for all time, because it is a practice that violates our most basic sense of justice. An autocratic government running on an extreme nationalistic ticket will most likely present all these charges as being basically anti-Russian. This is far from the truth. I know that there are many of us in this Chamber who love and admire the achievements of the Russian people and who wish for Russia the sort of future in which such cases will never be mentioned in this Chamber again because there will be no need to be looking for human rights violations in Russia. This is, unfortunately, not the real future, and as long as Alexei Navalny and his colleagues are imprisoned and sentenced for depicting their vision of Russia’s future, we have this duty, and we must be firm and thorough.

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: author. - Madam President, following Russia’s illegal annexation of Crimea and its current military aggression in Eastern Ukraine, attention has largely focused recently on Russia’s foreign policy rather than its domestic affairs. The case of Alexei Navalny reminds us, however, of the internal problems that Russia also faces and of the increasingly authoritarian regime over which President Putin presides. As one of the faces of the opposition movement at the forefront of many of the mass demonstrations recently seen in Moscow, Navalny’s placement under house arrest since February of last year on the basis of trumped-up and spurious charges is seen as a way to silence one of Putin’s most outspoken critics. The arrest and sentencing of Navalny’s brother is even more shameful, bearing in mind that he has no role in the protest movements and has been implicated by association, a tactic that we more familiarly associate with totalitarian regimes like North Korea rather than with a full member of the Council of Europe. This case paints a painful picture of Putin’s Russia, and it should serve as a reminder of the regime we are dealing with. Sadly it also has echoes of the Khodorkovsky case a decade ago and demonstrates a serious lack of independence of the judiciary and the increasing role of the FSB – i.e. former KGB – in running Putin’s Russia. It is a very sad situation and we do hope that he is released immediately.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: Author. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the purpose of this resolution, in my opinion, must not be to continue to attack Russia and its government for violations. Yes, we are warning the Russian Government to respect media freedom, pluralism, freedom of association and to clarify certain cases that happen in so many places around the world. However, let us always remember that Russia is our neighbour, with whom we should have a dialogue, because it is necessary that the diplomatic role of the European Union, which is a great force, must not be to slam the door in the face of one on a matter of fanbase or a pre-established issue.  We should try to exercise our peacemaking role, as we have done within the European Union between states that had been at war for hundreds of years, such as France and England, such as France and Germany, we should also do so with regard to Russia, not have a pre-established attitude of closure from a political point of view.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: Author. Madam President, we are going to vote today on two resolutions, one on Russia and the other on Ukraine. In both of them, we find what I would gladly call the monomanias of some Members of this House, which are much more cautious when it comes, for example, to certain Gulf countries in which a young blogger of thirty years can be sentenced to a thousand lashes without causing any emotion.  What does the European Union want? To bend Russia or to work towards a genuine improvement of the human rights situation in this country? Within the GUE/NGL group, we made our choice. Once again, here, we express our support for Russian citizens who demand that their government respect the most basic rights. In particular, we call on the Russian authorities to stop harassing NGOs and to undermine the necessary independence of judges. We recall that respect for the rights of the opposition is the prerequisite for effective democracy. I am not sure that the case of Mr Navalny, who is making sulphurous remarks, is a very good example.  But precisely, for all these reasons, as is also the case, we call for the resumption of dialogue with Russia, without concession, but without the will of domination, hegemony or humiliation, as is done with many other countries in this Chamber.

name: Guy VERHOFSTADT
text: author. - Madam President, first of all I apologise, but I was at a Conference of Presidents meeting and that is the reason why I am here only now. Alexey Navalny is one of the many Russian citizens who work to uncover corruption in the system of Vladimir Putin, and the system of Vladimir Putin is capitalism for friends. The fabricated process against Navalny’s brother is in my eyes yet another step to intimidate and silence his public activity. I find it particularly cynical and also very much like Soviet-era tactics that they are now sentencing Oleg Navalny with the aim of controlling a political opponent by taking a relative as hostage. That is what is happening. It is important that we condemn this practice today and also encourage the court responsible to handle the appeal procedure in line with Russia’s international obligations to hold a fair trial, free from political pressure. In that sense the resolution is deemed absolutely necessary. It is even more important to develop an EU strategy which would not only enable us to get Russia out of Ukraine and bring peace to Europe but also give us tools to challenge the sense of impunity with regard to Putin’s regime and support the Russian people when they stand up for their rights. It is in that context that I want to conclude. High Representative, I am pretty disappointed by what I have read in the press, reporting that the paper on better relations with Russia that you have presented for the next Foreign Affairs Council does not mention the human rights issue in Russia.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: Author. - (DE) Madam President, I would like to thank The conviction of the Navalny brothers is another link in a long chain of obstruction and elimination of disliked political rivals in Russia. As in the other cases, non-political reasons are constructed, on the basis of which judgments are then made which mean that these persons can no longer be politically active. This is a systematic violation of fundamental political freedoms and, above all, hinders Russia's development into a developed parliamentary democracy. The reactions of the population, who demonstrated spontaneous support for Navalny in the difficult conditions, show that people are looking for alternatives. But that is precisely what they wanted to prevent. There is an urgent need to improve our relations with Russia, and this requires respect for democratic practices.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: Author. Madam President, the proposal to discuss Mr Navalny's case comes from our group. I supported it and I'm glad we were discussing it. I am sorry to see that Mrs Vergiat described Mr Navalny's comments as sulphurous.  What Mr Navalny is saying in Russia is that Mr Putin's regime is corrupt, that there are crooks and that we must fight the corruption of the elites. I don't think it's sulphurous. I believe that in this chamber we must not insult men of courage. On the contrary, we must protect people who have the courage to tell the truth in Russia and to go against the regime.  Let me tell you that Mr Navalny's candidacy for mayor of Moscow, which won 27% of the vote, is a victory, because you cannot win elections in Russia without being the client of the regime.  That is why Mr Navalny must be defended, especially since the Kremlin's reaction is a repetition of Stalinist practices. He was accused, as in the days of Stalin and the other Bolsheviks in all communist countries, of having committed crimes. He was charged with defrauding in timber cases, cases related to the distribution of the products of a French company, and so on. This is outright Stalinism, Mrs Vergiat. I know you're touched every time we discuss the crimes of communism!

name: Jaromír ŠTĚTINA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, former Soviet dissident and human rights defender Sergei Kovaljov once said that 'defending human rights cannot be an internal matter for any state'. I am afraid, ladies and gentlemen, that the European Council has not heard it.  When the Russian military annexed Abkhazia in the early 1990s, Europe could only express concern. When the Russian army slaughtered 80,000 civilians in Chechnya, Europe could not call the culprits of these massacres war criminals. When the Russian military occupied South Ossetia in 2008, many European politicians identified Georgia itself not as the culprits of the war. When Russia occupied Crimea last year, Europe's protests were already much stronger, but they were just protests. Russia has occupied Crimea for almost a year. It was, dear colleagues, our fear that led us all the way to donbas. This is one of the reasons why we must support the new Russian dissent, which includes Alexei Navalny.

name: Ana GOMES
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – In October 2013 this Parliament adopted a resolution, of which I was rapporteur, on the impact of corruption on human rights. In it we propose extending the definition of human rights defenders in the Guidelines of the European Union in order to extend it to anti-corruption activists such as Aleksej Navalny, who, with courage, have consistently exposed corruption within the highest levels of the Russian apparatus of state and the Putin oligarchy. The conviction of the Navalny brothers, part of the strategy used by the Russian power to instrumentalize laws and courts to silence opponents and civil society, reaffirms the need to support those who denounce corruption both in Europe and abroad. Today we are asking for a strategy by the European Union and the Member States that promotes democratic principles and the rule of law in Russia. In my view, this will have to include a Magnitsky law, now extended to the conviction of the Navalny brothers. A law establishing lists of officials, prosecutors and judges who, in violation of their constitutional obligations, forge charges and convict activists. That law should impose specific sanctions, such as a visa ban in the European Union and the freezing of any financial assets that they or their close relatives have in European Union countries.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. I can only repeat what many members have already said. The dissident blogger Aleksei Navalny has become one of the figureheads of the Russian opposition. The way he's challenging his house arrest is unseen in Russia. His prison sentence may have been suspended, but his brother was imprisoned under the same charges.  Unfortunately, he is just one of many political dissidents to face the continued intimidation of the Putin regime. It is almost impossible for Russian NGOs to operate independently of the Kremlin.  Bloggers with more than 3000 visitors per day must come forward and take responsibility for published information. Foreign NGOs must defy an almost Byzantine bureaucracy and far-reaching bullying measures. Anyone who does not comply with the rules is automatically a traitor or foreign spy and risks heavy fines and penalties.  It is our duty to continue to support all Russian dissidents and freethinkers. Fortunately, the regime's media blockade will never stop the exchange of ideas.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, i would like to thank – Unfortunately, the situation of both human rights and human rights defenders is deteriorating in Russia. Navalny's case is yet another example of a selective trial. At the same time, the inclusion of human rights organisations in the list of so-called foreign agents continues. After, for example, the Sakharov Prize was handed over here in the European Parliament, the Russian authorities placed the Sakharov Centre, which deals with human rights, on the list of foreign agents, and twenty other organisations.  It should not be forgotten that, for example, the St. Petersburg Soldier's Mother's Organization is, in the opinion of the Russian authorities, a foreign agent. However, the status of a foreign agent makes it essentially impossible to continue to defend human rights. That's how power acts, who's afraid of his own people. The European Union must take these developments very seriously and also take this into account in its future Russian policy-making. Finally, I would like to recall that in early September an Estonian police officer, Eston Kohver, who is still in a Moscow prison, was captured by the Russian security services on Estonian territory. He, too, must be released immediately.

name: Jiří MAŠTÁLKA
text: on the part of the GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, I think it is right that we feel the need to comment on the fate of individuals facing prosecution while taking political action. There is always a risk that this is a criminalization of opponents of power. At the same time, however, it is always necessary to give voice to all parties.  In my opinion, without evidence, the court judgment on the Navalny brothers cannot be considered rigged. Yves Rocher's statement is certainly not such proof. At the same time, I do not share the belief that registering NGOs receiving money for their political activities from abroad is automatically flawed. The Russian law was modeled on the US, and I don't recall ever protesting the US law. I also do not believe that we would tolerate, for example, NGOs funded by Islamic State sources. Let's measure all the same meter! Justice for the Navalny brothers must bring a judicial appeal, not further politicization of the process on our part.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, there must be Putin syndrome here in this Parliament, because every time I come to this House we talk about Putin, but you do it under for Putin? You always talk – now in this case about this guy who knows what happened to him? But why don't we talk about the marò? What happened that we talked about here at midnight and there were four cats! The Italian marò, don't you give a tube of Italian marò?  Or, you don't know about the Imam of London who came to say – beware the imam of London, not of a lost country in Africa! – who says that those who speak ill of Muhammad must die – and I do so to the Imam of London. Or, we don't want to talk about this other – dear Europeans who look like wet rabbits, you're wearing it! This is what he said that the massacre in Paris is thanks to them, to Al-Qaida Zawahiri, this was, and this too! You have the courage of a wet rabbit, you must wake up dear Europe and you, Mogherini, wake up, do not say that you have been here for 8 hours, because an Italian worker for 8 a day takes 1,000 euros, You must stay here to work and save the marò and give a wake-up call and make sure that Islamic terrorism is no longer there , which is a disgrace, and you Europeans, wake up, this is a Parliament of living dead!

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Madam High Representative, I rise to support the joint resolution negotiated by the main political groups with which the European Parliament is once again concerned about freedom of expression and association in Russia. The trial and condemnation of Alexei Navalny are surrounded by too many shadows to leave us without reaction and Europe, which must work, as the High Commissioner for the resumption of relations with Russia is doing, cannot in this case but make its voice heard in order to reaffirm respect for rights and freedoms. Europe is also committed, with this resolution, to increasing its financial commitment to support independent NGOs, so as not to allow the stalemate between Brussels and Moscow to damage – and that would be truly paradoxical! - also those organisations that are at the forefront of freedom of expression.

name: Dawid Bohdan JACKIEWICZ
text: Madam President, i voted in favour of this report. Human and civil rights and the rule of law in Russia are constantly being restricted and violated. The right to freedom of expression, to peaceful assembly, to association is violated. Any person uncomfortable with power can today in Russia be wrongfully accused, arrested and convicted in a show trial under any pretext. One of the victims of such a policy is russian opposition leader Alexei Nawalny , a man who openly opposes Russia's ruling corruption, making public numerous embezzlement and abuses by Russian authorities. He was blacklisted forever by Putin, persecuted and unlawfully arrested, and sentenced to five years in prison in July 2013. However, he did not bend to the pressure and strength of the Russian regime and still has the courage to publicly criticize the Russian President. We are very much separated from Alexei Nawal. It is difficult to agree with his position on Crimea or Georgia. However, I hope that, whenever human rights and the rule of law are violated in Russia, we will protest loudly and decisively and stand up for the victims of this regime. Let us not be afraid to demand respect for the people and the law from the Russian President. Let us not be naïve, let us not be blind and fearless. Russia is not a democratic country.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen! What does the example of these two brothers actually show? It shows that freedom of expression, freedom of the press, the legal system, democracy and equality are being trampled underfoot in Russia. What does this actually mean for us? Well, first of all, of course, the duty to draw attention to these abuses, and that is what this resolution does. Secondly, it follows that we must also expose the fair-talkers and white-washers of this regime. I think it is a disgrace that we have some of them in this Parliament as well. We have had to hear some unfortunately here on the far right and over there on the far left. Incidentally, these also exist in the nations, for example in my own country, we have a former Chancellor who is still paid by Mr Putin today and who is still in a state of disrepute to call him a 'pure democrat' against this background. Ladies and gentlemen, dialogue with Russia is important, but it must always be accompanied by criticism of the conditions there.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: Madam President, today we are discussing one more disappointing case concerning Russia’s policies. The Kremlin’s patrons have created a system which enriches very few at the expense of the whole country. Today’s Russia in no way complies with democratic countries’ criteria, and this is of great concern for all of us. The European Union has no right to neglect abuses of democratic values and human rights in the Russian Federation. Support for the observance of human rights must become one of the cornerstones in building future relations with Russia and a consistent and united strategy towards Russia. With the Alexei Navalny case in mind, I call on the Council of Europe to keep the present policy of no voting rights for Russia and, especially taking into account the European Union Member State representatives, to keep a united line in the 29 January vote.

name: Giulia MOI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Navalny case requires the full attention of the European Parliament and the Commission, as it is seen as an abuse of free speech rights and russian corrupt justice is being used to keep it indoors and silence the political opposition. That is not right and the European Parliament should do something to protect this injustice.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: Madam President, this Alexei Navalny appears to be the Russian George Budaházi, who is facing criminal proceedings and jail for his civil rights activities. I would like to stand up for his human rights just as much as I stood up for György Budaházi, who, by the way, was not willing to deal with parliament at all. I have one problem, though. Here's point I of the preamble. It reads as follows: 'given the growing need to introduce a coherent, coherent and comprehensive EU policy against Russia, supported by strong and fair criticism, supported by all Member States'. This is why the report therefore introduces action against an alleged human rights violation. I also ask you, Commissioner, the reporter, and my colleagues, what exactly is the objective-tool relationship between the growing anti-Russian sentiment in this chamber and the straining of cold war sentiment and possible well-founded human rights action.

name: Federica Mogherini
text: VPC/HR. - Signor Presidente, onorevoli colleghi, dispiace non vedere in quest'Aula l'onorevole Bonanno perché credo che come lui anche gli alti membri del suo gruppo sia soltanto un mio specifico dovere essere qui a parlare non soltanto del caso dei due marò, ma anche di casi molto importanti in alti paesi ma come è mio dovere farlo è anche dovere credo dei membri del Parlamento europeo partecipare ai dibattiti così importanti.  Let me thank this Chamber for the opportunity not only to focus, as we did yesterday, on the external or foreign policy implications of Russia’s behaviour but also on the internal dimension as well. On 30 December Moscow courts delivered a verdict against Alexei Navalny and his brother Oleg, giving him a suspended sentence and jailing his brother. This new court case against Navalny, an opposition leader and anti-corruption activist, as you mentioned, is illustrative of the flaws which persist in the judiciary in Russia. Procedural irregularities were plentiful from the moment the case was built until the verdict, which was announced in the absence of most press and international observers. I reacted publicly and immediately when the verdict was announced. I stressed that judicial decisions should be free from political interference, independent and in full compliance with the rule of law. For years, through our Partnership for Modernisation, the European Union worked on ways to professionalise and reform Russia’s judiciary, notably by the establishment of an appeal system. On what Mr Verhofstadt referred to – and I would like us to refer not to leaks from newspapers or from the media but to what we say in this official place – it is a fact that we also need to work and focus on the human rights dimension and on the rule of law dimension in our dialogue with Russia. In fact, in the paper that we will discuss with the ministers on Monday – and again I would invite you not to refer to leaks in the media but to what we do and what we actually say in official places – there is an option of a partial resumption of these forms of cooperation to promote the rule of law. This is mentioned in the paper that has been leaked – and let me mention also that leaking official documents or issuing papers that are intended to contribute to a discussion of ministers is possibly not the best way of having a serious political discussion. But I think that we need to have, as we are having this morning, a serious discussion about, for example, the ways in which we could think of partially restoring options and instruments for cooperation on the rule of law and the judiciary in Russia, because this obviously affects the internal situation of many people in Russia and the respect for basic human rights. In recent years in too many instances, from the Magnitsky case to the Bolotnaya convicts, from the Kosenko case to Pussy Riot, we have witnessed serious violations of basic human rights, which courts were unable to redress – which they even rubber-stamped. We call upon the Russian authorities to uphold human rights. We will also extend available financial means to Russian NGOs which keep working in that endeavour, as this House has repeatedly asked, even this morning. Russia’s membership of the Council of Europe, which was mentioned by the last speaker, carries a number of obligations. It is our duty, as the European Union, to hold Russia accountable when it ignores those obligations. On Tuesday I discussed with Secretary-General Jagland the ways in which the European Union can provide more and better support for the Council of Europe in these efforts. All relevant instruments should be fully mobilised to respond to human rights violations. We will be looking forward to forthcoming European Court of Human Rights rulings involving Russia, notably on the case of Mr Navalny and, I should also say, on the case of Mr Magnitsky. The conviction of Mr Navalny; the wave of harassment against civil society, labelling as foreign agents 30 organisations such as Memorial or the Sakharov Centre, which was mentioned; and the threats against human rights defenders dealing with Chechnya are the most recent instances to which we firmly reacted, all of this happening over less than a month. Human rights are core elements of our policies and our relationships in all countries in the world, and we should always react firmly, as this House did today, when abuses take place, and we should take measures on this. (Applause)

name: Adina-Ioana VĂLEAN
text: The debate is closed. The vote will be held at the end of the debates. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Eduard KUKAN
text: in writing. – The situation in Russia, with regards to respecting human rights and legal procedures, is worrying. Apart from its violent international excursions, annexation of Crimea and support to paramilitaries in eastern Ukraine, Russia has been continuously and systematically curtailing its own political dissent and civil society, contrary to all international obligations that stem from its membership in the CoE and the OSCE. Basic freedoms of its citizens are constantly challenged. This time, the target is Alexej Navalny. His biggest ‘guilt’ and ‘fault’ is that he is someone gaining in popularity, possibly endangering the political dominance exerted by President Putin and his allies. While jailing might not be on the table for the moment, different innovative tactics are used by the government to assure that all opposition voices are effectively marginalised and, eventually, silenced. This contributes to creating a society which is forced into auto-censorship. I believe that this House is the right institution to strongly oppose moves by the government which lead to creating an atmosphere of fear in society. We stand with those who want to see Russia move away from authoritarian practice and those who want to see a functioning, impartial and independent judiciary.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: in writing – Political coercion and influence of courts and judges undermines the functioning of the judiciary in the state and the legal certainty of citizens whose constitutional and legal rights become arbitrarily interpreted, relativised and ultimately denied.  The case of Alexei Navally has become another of many disturbing cases suggesting that the administration of justice has been manipulated in trials in Russia.  It should be in Russia's interest to remedy such a situation promptly, thus aligning the judiciary with its international obligations arising from full membership of the Council of Europe and the Organisation for Security and Cooperation in Europe and the United Nations.  For these reasons, I will support the adoption of the European Parliament resolution in question on the situation in Russia.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. – I support the debate on human rights and democratic principles, as these are fundamental European values, and we are witnessing that they have often been violated recently. It is not a novelty to violate human rights and democratic freedoms in Russia, but recent events are further causing concern. Media content is created according to orders of ruling structures, and any deviation from this means exposure to repression. Alexei Navalny is a journalist who has been critical of Russian authorities and has been convicted under controversial circumstances of corruption and money laundering. He was sentenced to house arrest and banned from his blog, and all media outlets that shared his content were suspended. Russia should be encouraged to develop democratic principles and the rule of law, as other forms of violations of European values such as the war in Chechnya and the persecution of Chechens, condemnation of dissidents and confiscation of their property are also known. I will support the appeal to Russia to initiate the development of a democratic society and the rule of law with respect for man and his freedom.

name: Adina-Ioana VĂLEAN
text: The next item is the debate on seven motions for resolutions on Pakistan, in particular the situation following the Peshawar school attack.

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: author. - Madam President, the ISIS-affiliated Pakistani Taliban is intent upon trying to impose its warped and medieval view of the world on the people of Pakistan, particularly in the tribal areas on the Afghan border. Its latest barbaric, murderous attack against a school is symbolic for much of what it stands, irrationally, in opposition to – enlightenment, education, progress and equal rights for women. It is tragic that so many people, particularly children, have had to lose their lives at the hands of such a vile ideology. The Government of Pakistan obviously needs to do more to combat this form of home-grown terrorism, looking more carefully at the options and capabilities at its disposal. I would also like to take this opportunity to look at the broader human rights situation in Pakistan. The Ahmadi Muslims, for instance, continue to be discriminated against by law and face hardships, some even paying with their lives. The Hudood Ordinances and the blasphemy laws are also of particular concern to this House. Pakistan’s GSP+ status is directly linked to its commitment to upholding universal human rights and, in my view, more needs to be done to ensure that Pakistan is fulfilling these obligations it has made to the European Union.

name: Jean LAMBERT
text: author. - Madam President, all of us in this House share the profound shock and revulsion at the horrendous attack on the army public school in Peshawar. It is the latest and bloodiest attack on schools in Pakistan, and there have been over 800 of those attacks since 2009. There is quite a high level of illiteracy still in Pakistan, and education is valued by many. Therefore, an attack on education is actually an attack on the country’s future. I think we can understand, too, the anger of the people and the desire of the government to be seen to take strong action against those committing terrorist offences. Nevertheless, the resolution reflects the fact that all of us, I think, regret the lifting of the moratorium on the death penalty in Pakistan. The resolution has no number for those recently executed: it is now up to 19, as of this morning. The EU has a principled position on the death penalty, and we have expressed this in meetings in Pakistan and in other countries of the world. I chair the delegation for this House to the countries of South Asia, which includes Pakistan, and I have raised this issue when we have been there. I find myself particularly uneasy about a number of the convictions of those currently being executed. Some of those date from the times of the military regime, with allegations of confessions under torture and the use of military courts which do not have a full system of justice. Such convictions do not meet the standards of justice to which Pakistan is now committed under a number of human rights instruments which it signed up to and which are now linked to its Generalised System of Preferences (GSP) Plus status. However, there is much to be welcomed in terms of the government’s move on education – universal and inclusive education for all children in Pakistan. There are a number of other things to welcome, which we point out in this resolution.

name: Fernando MAURA BARANDIARÁN
text: Author. - Madam President, I add to the condemnation of this senseless attack, which undoubtedly surpasses— in its cruel cowardice — everything a sick mind can imagine. I would also like to ask all members of this House to ponder the complicated situation in which Pakistan is located, in the event that events like this could be repeated. Pakistan is on the edge of being a failed state and its stability means the stability of all of South Asia. If Pakistan loses the battle against terrorism, the whole world and the values we stand for would be seriously compromised. Therefore, we must work shoulder-to-shoulder with the Government and people of Pakistan in their fight against terrorism and extremism. We must support the Government of Pakistan for the consolidation of democracy and the establishment of a civilian government with all guarantees. We must also encourage the strengthening of democratic institutions and the rule of law in all areas of public administration, in particular security forces and the judiciary. We must, in conclusion, offer them our help in overcoming the situation in which they are immersed.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: Author. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we are talking about a truly terrible situation, the situation that happened in Peshawar because, in my opinion, it is not even akin to mankind that such an attack can be made. We are talking about teachers burned alive in front of pupils, children burned alive, we are talking about 150 innocent victims, children who have been taken from their lives for no reason, in the name of a principle that cannot be understood.  I think we are all united, all agreed, in having to fight a battle that is not a battle of Pakistan, but it is a battle against a type of human race that is diverted, against a type of human being that cannot probably even be considered human beings. I welcome Mr Bashir's proposal that we should make a symbolic effort to ensure that the same number of victims – 143 – are made in a hospital to give a symbolic signal to those who take the lives of those children.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: Author. Madam President, it is in a particular context that this unbearable massacre of 148 people, including 132 children, reminds us that Muslims are the first victims of terrorist violence. In Pakistan, as elsewhere, it is imperative to understand that it is not by exceptional laws and courts that freedom is defended against one's enemies.  Pakistan has set up military courts to try terrorists and has just lifted the moratorium on capital punishment. Since the attack, 16 people have been sentenced to death and another 500 are expected to be sentenced in the coming weeks. Eight thousand people are reportedly on death row. Fear and security oversupply can only aggravate an endless cycle of violence that amounts to falling into the trap set by those who exacerbate tensions, inflame hatreds and recruit new followers. While the status quo is not acceptable, shouldn't the Pakistani government also look at its army's relationship with various tolerated or even exploited jihadist groups? In this kind of game, civilians are always the first victims. This horror is here to show us.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: Author. - (DE) Madam President, I would like to thank This is the second time that we have dealt with the situation in Pakistan in the context of the urgent resolutions. It is always about religious extremism. The tragic events at the school in Peshawar, when 140 innocent people died, have once again made it clear to us how dangerous the situation is. Terrorist groups, which are in no way inferior to ISIS in their radicalism and delusion, threaten the future of the country.  Pakistan is a very important and important country, a nuclear power. The country must take a firm stance against this threat: rigorous and wise. This includes appropriate prosecution of the terrorists – they deserve harsh punishment.  Treating criminals lightly as terrorists sets in motion a spiral of revenge. A reform of The Pakistani judicial system, which respects human rights, should be the real consequence of the tragic events.

name: Jeroen LENAERS
text: Author. - More than 140 people, including 134 schoolchildren, have been massacred. Schoolchildren, whose only wish that day was to simply go to school. The Dutch language does not have enough words to express my disgust and my thoughts go out to the parents, families, boyfriends and girlfriends of the victims and of Pakistani society as a whole. Pakistan's fight against terrorism is also our fight. This is a fight against all terrorist groups, without exception. We must be ready to help Pakistan in this fight. But the fight against terrorism and religious extremism is also a fight against its breeding ground. This includes combating poverty, safeguarding religious tolerance, strengthening the rule of law and free access to education. As Malala, Sakharov Prize winner, said here in this House: "There is poverty, there is a lack of freedom, there is fear, there is terrorism, but there is also hope!"

name: Bogdan Brunon WENTA
text: On behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for his excellent work. First of all, I would like to express once again my sincerest condolences to the families of the victims, especially as innocent and vulnerable people, namely children, have suffered in this manifestation of brutality. I therefore want to strongly condemn the perpetrators of this bestial act and express my concern at the escalation of aggression in Pakistan. Perpetrators of terrorist attacks on children deserve no excuse and should be punished with all the severity of international law. Everyday activities, such as going to school, become a manifestation of courage in the current situation and carry a huge risk. I therefore call on the High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs to put pressure on the Pakistani authorities in order to strengthen their efforts to ensure the safety of ordinary citizens, including children, of the country.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, just over a year ago, a young woman addressed this House with an impassioned appeal, arguing that a country's strength is measured not by its army but by the education of its people. These kids don't want an iphone, an xbox, a playstation or chocolates, they just want a book, a pencil and a pen. I apologize to all these children because we have not been able to protect them!  What has changed, Mr President, since the day the Sakharov Prize was awarded to Malala, because today we are still commemorating 134 young students and innocent victims who are guilty of exercising their fundamental right to education? How many boys and girls do we have to cry before the Pakistani authorities develop a real strategy for preventing radicalisation and combating the crisis in education? Every school destroyed and replaced by radical schools is a defeat for civilisation and the premise of further rooting of Islamic extremism in the country.

name: Sajjad KARIM
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, I would like to say to the Vice-President/High Representative that her commitment to our parliamentary procedures is truly appreciated by the majority of Members of this House. This resolution comes in truly tragic circumstances. They slay Pakistani children to break their will. They slay our journalists to break our values. The perpetrators are of the same mind-set – Mumbai or Madrid or Peshawar, Pakistan, the perpetrators are one, and we must stand in defiance as one. Let us send a clear message from this House to the people of Pakistan that we stand firm and united with them at this time. High Representative, we must safeguard measures we have already put in place in terms of our relationship with Pakistan and actually start to build upon them. Strengthening the Pakistani economy is one prong that we must explore further. Recent events demonstrate that we are all on the front line, but the front face is the people of Pakistan, who have carried a very heavy burden on very weak shoulders on behalf of the international community.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to express my dismay and revulsion at the attack by the Taliban movement in Pakistan, which on 16 December killed 148 people, 130 of them student children, at a school in Peshawar. This repugnant terrorist attack - one of the bloodiest in Pakistan's history - add up to more than 800 other attacks on schools in Pakistan. The education of young people, and girls in particular, is crucial for the development of Pakistani society and economy. Education is still essential to prevent the radicalisation of society. I would therefore like to praise the Swedish Academy of the Nobel Prize by awarding this award to the Pakistani girl Malala. I believe that the Pakistani Government must take effective measures to ensure the safety of schools and prevent intimidation and terror. This massacre followed the tragic events in France and now the human carnage carried out by Boko Haram terrorists in Baga, Nigeria. Combating fundamentalist terrorism is a European and international problem.  I therefore call for an international commitment to cooperation in the prevention of the fight against terrorism and for the defence of human rights and democratic values.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, first of all I would like to transfer our condolences to all those who suffer the havoc of violent fanaticism. These attacks are negligible without exception. However, the pain caused should not lead us to respond with measures of repression and cut of freedoms, which only fuel a spiral of violence that serves as justification for the arguments of fanatics. Measures such as the annulment— by the Prime Minister of Pakistan in response to the attack — of the existing moratorium on the death penalty may involve the execution of hundreds of convicts in the coming weeks.  To move towards a real solution, we must pay attention to geopolitical, economic and social causes. Among them, the poverty and misery that we allow to advance in Europe and the rest of the world, and which are creating spaces of marginality and exclusion among which extremism of all kinds springs. Only by fleeing fear and hatred can we build strong and free peoples with justice and democracy.

name: Amjad BASHIR
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, the cold-blooded and barbaric attack in Peshawar resulted in over 145 deaths and an even greater number of injuries, both physical and psychological. Most of the dead were children, along with some brave teachers, like the principal, Tahira Qazi, who was deliberately and brutally burned alive in full view of the pupils. Tehrik-i-Taliban has claimed responsibility for this atrocity as revenge for the military offensive launched by the Pakistani army. Since 2003, when Pakistan joined the American-led war on terror, over 60 000 Pakistanis have died. That is the equivalent to twenty 9/11s. I have visited Peshawar and the Lady Reading hospital where most of the injured and fatalities were brought. I can report that the facilities there are basic, and they can do with our help and support. I urge you to send a team of observers to see for yourself and to make good on our promises for support following the attack.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Madam President! The attack on the school in Peshawar was certainly one of the worst attacks ever carried out in Pakistan, with 145 people killed.  But it was not the only attack on schools, and it was not the only attack on children. In the last year alone, there have been 12 attacks on schools in Pakistan – out of 372 attacks in total. I would remind you of the cowardly attack on the Nobel Peace Prize laureate Malala in October 2012, who was also awarded the European Parliament's Sakharov Prize for her commitment to education. The Pakistani Government has reacted with full force to this attack and has suspended the moratorium on the death penalty, a measure which is only rejected in the motion for a resolution before us. Europe, too, is affected by terror. I recall the Paris attack last week. It is almost ironic that in Peshawar the two Kouachi brothers who carried out this attack on Charlie Hebdo in France were awarded a special funeral ceremony by a Muslim cleric as heroes of Islam. That is bad, and Europe is reacting differently, with an anti-terrorist strategy. Europe must take decisive action against terror – the whole world must take decisive action against terror.

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: Madam President, I, too, deeply regret the attack of 16 December. I believe that we need to work towards respect for the fundamental principles of the rule of law and the application of fundamental human rights even in crisis situations. We have all rediscovered in recent days that we must not abandon these fundamental principles. This idea should also be at the heart of our approach in Pakistan and should lead to the support of all those who are discriminated against or advocate respect for freedom of religion, free access to education or a fair trial in that country. It should lead to support for Asia Bibi, Malala Yousafzai and all others.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the attack by Taliban fundamentalists on a school in Peshawar in Pakistan has killed more than 140 innocent people, mostly children, and has caused great horror and dismay in all of us. The world must react with great determination and religion cannot be the key to explaining such violence, in many cases it has been the language of leaders who have promoted progressive change, I remember the Dalai Lama, Martin Luther King, the Buddhist Aung San Su Kyi, the Lutheran poet Dietrich Bonhoeffer, unfortunately that is not the case in Pakistan. In this country, after the massacre, the army regains a political role, it is claimed that democracy does not work and that the only institution that can really govern the country is the army.  I find it regrettable, for example, that hateful laws such as blasphemy and also the recent decision by the Pakistani Government to lift the moratorium on the death penalty following the attacks on the School of Peshawar remain. It is clear that Europe has not done everything it could, this is the time to show that this institution has the strength to deal with a terrible evil such as terrorism and, at the same time, to defend fundamental rights.

name: Aymeric CHAUPRADE
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we are at war with a form of Islam: global and fundamentalist Islam, which knows only the umma as a nation and the Koran as its constitution.  In this war, we need allies. The Pakistani army is waging a merciless war fighting the Pakistani and Afghan Taliban and we must support it. Unfortunately, fundamentalists have no limits. In revenge, on 16 December 2014, they massacred more than 130 children of Pakistani soldiers at a school in Peshawar.  But Pakistan must be consistent. If he is really at war with us against fundamentalism, he cannot tolerate his judicial system remaining under the influence of fundamentalist behaviour. Christians cannot be sentenced to death for blasphemy or Shiites abandoned to popular vindictiveness. Efforts must be made on both sides.  We are ready to recognize an alliance with Pakistan against fundamentalism and to accept its relentless firmness against the Taliban, provided, however, that Pakistan mitigates the punishment against blasphemy and protects its Christian and Shia minorities.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: Madam President, nothing can justify the brutality we witnessed a month ago in Peshawar. It was an act of cowardice to attack a school and kill 132 defenceless children. Unfortunately, Pakistan is the biggest victim of terrorism: more than 70 000 people have lost their lives. This is the price Pakistan is paying in trying to keep the world safe. Afghanistan must assist and cooperate with Pakistan in its fight against terrorism. A renewed international commitment to fight the financing and sponsorship of terrorism is needed. Pakistan plays an important role in fostering stability in the region and should lead by example and strengthen the rule of law and human rights. The EU must not stand aside. We have to support Pakistan in our fight against terrorism. As we walked arm in arm in Paris in solidarity with France, we now also need to walk arm in arm with Pakistan. We need to unite globally against radicalisation and extremism. No form of terrorism should be supported, and the EU must assist Pakistan in tackling the threat of terrorism.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Madam President, this event has really caused shock and disgust in everyone, including me. The Pakistani Taliban use medieval methods that are absolutely inappropriate today. This is the second time in this forum we are talking about Pakistan - last time about Asia and Biba, today about the school in Pešavar. I think it's inadmissible for this to go past us. We as politicians are responsible and we must act, we must help the Pakistani government to finally bring the democratic institutions in that country to life.  We remember here, last year, Malala when she was awarded the Sakhar Prize, we all admired it and thought it would be some kind of boost. Unfortunately, it's not. With this resolution we are trying in some way to point out and judge not only this heinous act, but to point out the positive things that the Pakistani government is doing. In any case, human rights must be respected and blasphemy laws must be abolished. This is what we here in the European Parliament must insist on.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: The brutal massacre of 132 innocent children on December 16 at a Pakistani school deeply saddened me. It was carried out by the Taliban, the offshoot of ISIS in Pakistan, and that is something brutal, unacceptable. There is nothing sadder in the world than the death of a child. It is an act of violence against schoolchildren, it is an attack against the future of children, against the future of this country. I would therefore like to express my sincere condolences and solidarity with the families affected and to honour the memory of all the deceased children. This heinous act of terrorism in Pešávare has become an urgent challenge and an urgent solution to the global problem of terrorism and violent extremism and, above all, to the aggravated security situation in Pakistan. I therefore join, and I also appeal to the Commissioner, so that the European Parliament's commitment should also be heard in the Commission, so that we can all act together.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, more than 140 dead, 134 victims were students, indeed only children, as many were injured, the scars of the body will perhaps heal those of the soul, perhaps never! The Peshawar massacre is not just the massacre of fanaticism, brutality and violence, it is the massacre of fear, because Taliban extremism knows that the only weapon they can never defeat is the weapon of culture.  That is why the answer cannot be the summary justice called for by many in Pakistan, I understand the anger, I understand the feeling of revenge of the family members, we send them our condolences and our closeness, but the State of Pakistan cannot police democracy or eradicate the rule of law, it must not lower itself to their level. The real message to send, ladies and gentlemen, to those who make violence a tool of government, of propaganda, is to work with Pakistan so that for every dead child there is a new school in the country, so that it is clear that the spirit of Malala lives and will live forever in our consciences.

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs. - Madam President, thank you for this debate that I think helps us to focus on a couple of important points after the terrible attack by the Pakistani Taliban against the school in Peshawar on 16 December. First of all, there is the fact that the attack was deliberately against children – boys and girls. But it was also an attack against the right to education for every boy and girl. As many of you said, not only the Sakharov Prize but also the Nobel Peace Prize going to Malala Yousafzai was a strong reaction to that. Let me say that the best news we have had, in reaction to what happened, was the re-opening of the school in Peshawar this week. I think this is the strongest sign of the fact that the right to education of girls and boys cannot be stopped by such terrible attacks. The second thing that this attack reminded us of – and someone mentioned this – is the fact that the first victims of terrorists are Muslims. Yesterday we discussed Nigeria and today we are discussing Pakistan. I think part of our counter-terrorist measures is the narrative and the awareness that it is not only us we care about, but it is also about all others. Pakistan has paid a high price to terrorism and extremism, with up to 50 000 people killed by terrorists since 2001. A new Comprehensive National Action Plan has been approved. Key elements include regulating madrasas, blocking financing mechanisms of terrorist organisations, and measures against religious persecution. We have set up a specific EU-Pakistan political dialogue on counter-terrorism, the priorities of which are the rule of law and anti-radicalisation. The EU, through a number of different projects, already supports the Pakistani Government’s counter-terrorism activities aimed at reducing the threat from militant groups operating in the territory. This includes support for capacity-building of law enforcement, community policing, promoting dialogue between different communities and strengthening resilience to violence. But, as many of you have said today, counter-terrorism alone does not stand. We have to start from the root causes and from prevention. In 2008 Pakistan started its transition from military rule to democracy. In 2013 the country experienced its first ever handing-over of power from one democratically-elected government to another. The EU has consistently supported the democratisation process. Our election observation missions were in Pakistan in 2008 and 2013. The transition to civilian democracy led to closer EU cooperation with Pakistan in different fields and to a more structured partnership, including political dialogue on sensitive and complicated issues like human rights and counter-terrorism. Let me stress this, because it is also a coherent part of our work on security, disarmament and non-proliferation, especially in a region crucial for peace and security. The key priorities in our human rights engagement and dialogue with Pakistan – and let me remind you that the EU Special Representative for Human Rights, Stavros Lambrinidis, made his first ever visit to Pakistan this year – include freedom of religion and belief, women’s rights, the death penalty and the rule of law and access to justice. The issue of religious minorities remains a central aspect of our human rights dialogue. Freedom of religion and expression are constitutional rights in Pakistan, but discrimination remains, severely affecting, for instance, Shias and Ahmadis, but also Christians and other minorities. The use of the blasphemy law has become a reason for particular concern. The overwhelming majority of cases are filed against Muslims, but Christians are also targeted – such as in the case of Asia Bibi, which I know this Parliament has been following particularly closely. Let me say that I am following it closely with you. Pakistan needs to strengthen civilian courts and institutions. The judicial system has to be adequately resourced, trained and equipped, in order to deal effectively with terrorism. Harsher punishments or the temporary expansion of the jurisdiction of military courts do not address a weak judicial system. Developing an effective, efficient, professional, independent and credible civilian legal system remains a key priority for Pakistan, and the EU is ready to support and train police, prosecutors, defence lawyers and judges. After Peshawar – as some of you mentioned – Pakistan also lifted the de facto moratorium on executions that had been in place since 2008. Let me conclude by saying that the European Union remains – and will remain – opposed to the death penalty in all circumstances. The death penalty is not an effective tool in the fight against terrorism, and I sincerely hope that the moratorium will be re-established.

name: Adina-Ioana VĂLEAN
text: The debate is closed. The vote will be held at the end of the debates. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. As a member of the Delegation for Relations with South Asian Countries, I am particularly concerned about the situation in Pakistan. A study trip is planned soon. I hope that it will enable European parliamentarians to better understand the complex games of influence in this country. More than 130 children of Pakistani soldiers were massacred at a school in Peshawar. This attack, claimed by tehrik-i-Taliban Pakistan (TTP), is particularly frowned upon in the Muslim world. Nearly 60 radical Islamists have recently been arrested on the back of inciting hatred.  Is this a turning point in Pakistani politics? It's still too early to tell. It should be noted that the armed forces of that country are fighting fiercely against the Afghan and Pakistani Taliban.  However, we may regret that the Pakistani judicial system continues to adopt fundamentalist behaviour on many issues such as the conviction of Christians for blasphemy or the lynching of Shiites. We are ready to help Pakistan in its fight against fundamentalism. But it is appropriate for this country to make efforts to protect its minorities.

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: in writing. The attack on the military school in Peshawar on 16 December 2014, which led to the deaths of more than 140 people, most of them children, shocked the world with its cruelty and inhumanity, once again revealing the dramatic situation in Pakistan. With this resolution, therefore, we wish to express our deep concern for a country in which terrorism and religious extremism are taking over fundamental rights. It is therefore necessary for the European Union, and in particular the Commission, not to remain helpless and to take concrete action to combat these phenomena, demonstrating that it is a real force in favour of peace, freedom and human dignity, not least in order to give a concrete and real follow-up to the words spoken by Pope Francis in Strasbourg.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: in writing. – I will vote in favour of this resolution strongly condemning the Peshawar school attack, in which Tehrik-i-Taliban terrorists killed at least defenceless 130 children. This horrific attack on children is an inexplicable inhuman act attaining the highest level of human barbarity and must be universally condemned. I consider this act a crime against the future of all children and the nation of Pakistan. The EU and the international community as a whole must assist the Pakistani authorities in the fight against terrorism that has affected the Pakistani people for too long now. The Government of Pakistan must urgently take the necessary measures to prevent the occurrence of attacks and threats against educational institutions. These acts undermine fundamental rights, and in particular the right of women and girls to education. The Government of Pakistan must ensure that perpetrators of these cruel acts are promptly investigated, prosecuted and punished.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: Writing. – The Resolution reflects the universal appalling crime committed by the Taliban in Peshawar. The children of Pakistan, boys and girls, have the right to be educated in security conditions and the Pakistani Government must guarantee this right. However, the Resolution does not refer to the destabilizing role played by attacks by American drones that kill indiscriminately, thus provoking popular anger, in which extremists invest. Nor are the responsibilities of the United States and the Pakistani regime, which in other times have variously supported the dark Taliban, to the detriment of the people of Afghanistan and the USSR. It is only on the basis of these assumptions that the fight against terrorism can be sincere. The aim must be to eliminate the causes that lead people to religious extremism, i.e. the despair caused by poverty, illiteracy, authoritarianism and corruption of power and indignation about foreign interventions. We do not consent, in the name of combating terrorism, to human rights being violated or to reactivate the death penalty as Prime Minister Sharif has decided. It is the popular struggle for national independence, social prosperity, democratic freedoms and gender equality that will also eradicate terrorist religious extremism.

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: in writing. – Mr President, I must say, the tragedy in Peshawar had left me utterly devastated, and I would like to express my deepest condolences to the survivors, the families of the victims and the whole Pakistani community. Free, compulsory and good quality education must be regarded as a fundamental human right and a crucial means of realising other human rights, as it plays a key role in lifting people out of poverty, enabling them to obtain the means to participate fully in their society. I acknowledge the recent positive change in Pakistan’s Constitution establishing the right for children to access free, compulsory education. In my opinion, ensuring this right even in emergencies, such as during a conflict, should be done not only within the individual state’s responsibilities, but should also be addressed within the framework of our international cooperation. I encourage Pakistan’s development of protective measures against terrorism and religious extremism. Nevertheless, it is extremely important for this widespread learning crisis in Pakistan to be resolved by abiding by the minimum conditions of the international standards of the rule of law and human rights. Especially, methods which disregard the right to a fair trial cannot be accepted.

name: Tadeusz ZWIEFKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Ten years after the tragic terrorist attack on a school in Besłana, where 334 people, most of them children, were killed, there was an equally bloody attack by the Taliban in Peshawar, one of the Pakistani schools. It is difficult to pass indifferently to this tragedy, in which 132 children were left without their lives. There has never been and will not be an agreement on the part of the Countries of the European Union for such attacks. Children should be particularly cared for and cared for by adults, not mass murdered and "used" as hostages in civil wars, conflicts between states or secessive clashes. No ideology or religion justifies the planned killing of children. I strongly oppose this type of terror, where the lives of vulnerable and innocent children are measured by categories of desire for revenge, equalisation of accounts or the achievement of one's own purposes, and I refer to this with deep disapproval.  From here, I would like to strongly appeal to all Heads of State or Government not to hesitate to take all possible preventive measures and measures to exclude the emergence of similar mass carnage of children. The events in Peshawar are a warning to the whole world, but above all a tragedy for the Pakistani people, who have once again seen what the Taliban are capable of going in the name of religious extremism, for whom even the lives of children are of no value.

name: Adina-Ioana VĂLEAN
text: The next item is the debate on six motions for resolutions on Kyrgyzstan: homosexual propaganda bill.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: author. - Madam President, first of all let me say that Kyrgyzstan is the country in Central Asia that has achieved most progress in its democratic development over the last years. It also decriminalised male homosexuality in 1998, and these are positive things that we respect in the resolution we have prepared. But we also know that the situation is still very difficult. The Human Rights Watch report in January 2014 found widespread violence by police against LGBT people. There are, time and again, political and religious leaders who speak out against same-sex relations, against lesbians and gays. And now on 15 October, the Kyrgyz Parliament has passed, at first reading, a draft bill which contains amendments to the criminal code, the code of administrative responsibility, the law on peaceful assembly and the law on mass media, aimed at prohibiting the promotion of non-traditional sexual relations in an open or indirect way and providing for up to one year of imprisonment. That means they are prohibiting talking about facts of human life. This will have huge consequences: for journalists – if they write about the existence of lesbians and gays they might go to prison for one year; for human rights NGOs; for the fight against HIV and AIDS; and of course, specifically for lesbians, gays, bisexual and transgender people, who will face more discrimination and violence, as we have seen in other countries where similar bills have been passed. I would like to say here, from the European Parliament, to Kyrgyz MPs: people fall in love with whoever they fall in love with. You do not decide on that. It can happen to your daughter, to your son. It happens in families, in parliaments, in ministries, in sports associations, so please do not put lesbians and gays into jail for living a life that has been happening all over this world in all cultures, in all regions. Please respect your own constitution, and respect the recommendations of the Council of Europe’s Partner for Democracy status that you have, which clearly call for non-discrimination on the basis of sexual orientation. Let me also thank all those shadows and the parliamentarians of all seven groups in this House who have come together to formulate this resolution. I do hope that the Parliament of Kyrgyzstan will take this law off the agenda and let lesbians and gays live freely in Kyrgyzstan too.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: Author. - Madam President. Mrs Mogherini, 'laws denying or repealing the rights and freedoms of man shall not be adopted in the Republic of Kyrgyzstan', so read Article 16 of its Constitution. Today, the representatives of the citizens here send a clear message for the Republic of Kyrgyzstan to step back, respect its Constitution and stop the process of criminalizing homosexuality that is taking place in your country. I would like to remind your authorities that respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms, including freedom of thought, conscience, religion or belief, is an essential element of the Agreement on Collaboration and Cooperation between the European Union and your country. Passing this bill means failing to comply with your obligations. We have seen the horrific consequences of a similar law in Russia. We therefore urge Kyrgyzstan not to follow the path of state-sponsored homophobia and to support the fundamental rights of all its citizens. We will be vigilant, as are the thousands of citizens who in a single day have raised their voices against this human rights grievance. In this regard, I would like to congratulate and support initiatives such as those of the All Out organization, which in one day have collected tens of thousands of support firms against the gay propaganda law in Kyrgyzstan, in defence of the fundamental rights and freedoms of every citizen, whatever their sexual status.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: Author. - Kyrgyzstan is actually a beacon of hope in a region where the heads of state are without exception ex-Soviet despots. The country has a thriving civil society and could oust two corrupt presidents. But we are particularly concerned about this new discriminatory legislation. This anti-LGTBI law threatens to undermine the country's democratic and constitutional achievements. If this bill comes into force, it will be at the expense of essential human rights: equality, free expression and the right to protection from discrimination and violence. That is why I believe that we and you, Mrs Mogherini, the Kyrgyz Parliament and the President should call for a moment in the debate on this bill as to which way the country intends to go. Does the country want to continue to take over laws from the Russian Parliament, with the support of the Kyrgyz Grand Mufti? Or does it want to preserve freedom in Central Asia? I sincerely hope that it chooses freedom.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: Author. - (DE) Madam President, I would like to thank The Kyrgyz Government is committed to building a parliamentary-democratic system. It has also committed itself to complying with international human rights conventions. There is a regular human rights dialogue with the European Union. This dialogue is a very positive one, because there is a number of progress. There is no doubt that there is no doubt that there is an effort to establish an independent judiciary. The Kyrgyz Parliament's attempt to restrict the rights of people with same-sex orientation and to criminalise propaganda for non-traditional sexual relations is all the more astonishing. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report, which Human rights are not a catalogue of wishes from which one can make use of it at will. They are universal and indivisible. With this resolution, we want to persuade Kyrgyzstan to reconsider the legislation that was envisaged.

name: Tunne KELAM
text: author. - Madam President, it is the first time in my memory that the High Representative has attended urgency debates. This is highly inspirational for our further cooperation, especially after her ordeal yesterday evening. But, as for Kyrgzstan, we must also have in mind that this country has achieved considerable parliamentary democracy and has made progress in that way. The resolution in question has for me a preventive message, as the draft law has not yet been adopted and we are addressing possible damage to the equality and security of same-sex people. The positive sign is that the Kyrgzstan authorities have already reacted to Parliament’s draft in a cooperative way. The latest message we have got is that the bill in question has been considerably changed, with interested NGOs involved in preparing the final text. Hopefully it will not present any real threat to the security and equal rights of LGBTI people, but of course we continue to watch developments carefully. At the same time, we should welcome the progress made by Kyrgzstan in the domain of human rights and in cooperation and joint dialogue with the European Union.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: proposers. - (C) Despite the progress made in Kyrgyzstan, it now risks joining the ranks of countries that portray gays, lesbians and transgender people as the threat to tradition and nation. That's how you whip up the lawsuits against an imaginary enemy. We have seen this development and the currents in several other countries, such as France, where hundreds of thousands of people took to the streets in a completely absurd protest against rainbow families, saying precisely that these families were threatening tradition, nation and culture. So much violence and hatred – and so little love. To invent an enemy when we have so much else that we politicians have to deal with, namely how best to live in a pluralistic society, which stays together by not oppressing any of its parts, to build something positive, a society that works, prosperity, ecological sustainability, faith in the future, joy and why not love.  Going after us lesbians and faggots is paly, it is irresponsible and it violates our human rights.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, I would like to point out that Kyrgyzstan has recently abandoned the shameful criminalisation of persons of other sexual orientations. While it is surprising that women could still be prosecuted six years after men for their sexual orientation, I, too, welcome the democratic progress made in Kyrgyzstan over the past few years. Despite these partial improvements, there were bills last year against the alleged spread of homosexuality. It's undoubtedly a step backwards. These laws are certainly inspired by the Russian model and are unfortunate. Instead of helping young people realize their own direction, society is exacerbating problems, such as rejecting their loved ones, making things worse. If the Kyrgyz Parliament thinks that the main problem of his country is persons with minority sexual orientation, I deeply regret it. I believe that Mrs Mogherini will find time to address this urgent problem as well.

name: Tanja FAJON
