text: on behalf of the S&D Group.  Kyrgyzstan has made significant progress in recent years. Nevertheless, democracy in the country is still fragile. The draft anti-propaganda bill adopted is indeed a step in the wrong direction. Intimidating vulnerable groups by the media, the public, political and religious leaders is unworthy of democracy.  Today we are sending a very clear signal to the country and the whole region that any discrimination on the basis of sexual orientation is unacceptable. However, freedom of speech must not and cannot be compromised. The events of the past week have once again warned that freedoms are not taken for granted. Finally, I call loudly on all those responsible to refrain from actions that would further endanger them and push vulnerable groups further to the edge of society.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: gue/NGL Group. – Homosexuality should not be considered propaganda. It is a sexual orientation and no human being should be persecuted or suffered violence on grounds of sexual orientation, gender identity or the expression thereof. No lesbian, gay, bisexual, transsexual or intersex person should be criminalized or forced to hide.  We cannot look the other way or silence against any law that, anywhere in the world, attacks people's dignity and freedom by their gender identity, by their sexual identity or by expressing it. We cannot allow any setback in the rights of LGBTI people.  Kyrgyzstan must comply with what it says in its own Constitution: No law should be adopted that denies human rights and civil liberties.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it seems quite absurd to me, in 2015, we still have to discuss laws that discriminate against sexual orientation or gender identity, and it is really bad to think that in 78 countries around the world this is a crime, to be part of the LGBT community, and that in 40 other countries of the world this community suffers violations and discrimination.  We are talking about a draft law of the Kyrgyz Parliament which is represented by many colleagues as a parliamentary democracy in progress and which has tabled such a law which is absolutely medieval. We should use our diplomatic strength, including through the High Representative who is here in this House, to make it clear to the Kyrgyz Parliament that it is totally unacceptable to carry out laws of this kind, which discriminate against a human right, because the right to love is simply a human right.

name: Agnieszka KOZŁOWSKA
text: Madam President, i voted in favour of this report. Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for The resolution we are about to vote on calls on the Kyrgyz Parliament to withdraw a bill banning the so-called promotion of homosexuality. This law is modelled on the Russian Law of 2013 and is contrary to international standards for the protection of human rights, violates civil liberties and human dignity. Such laws have been repeatedly condemned by UN leaders, the European Union and human rights organisations. The very drafting of this law in Kyrgyzstan has already exacerbated acts of intolerance, aggression and violence against non-heterosexual people, as this work in Parliament is read as an consent and even an incentive for the highest authorities of the state to treat LGBT people worse. Kyrgyzstan decriminalised homosexuality in 1998 and enacting this law would undermine progress achieved and increase attitudes of contempt and hatred against sexual minorities that are alien to democratic states of law.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: Grazzi Chair, Viikei President Mogherini Li fis-sena 2015 għad għad għandna nies li jridu jaħbu l-orjentazzjoni sesswali tagħhom għaliex inkella jispiħ大aw ippersegtati mhuwiex a大大ettabbli. Aktar u aktar, meta dik il-persekuzzjoni ssir mill-awtoritajiet jew addirittura mill-pulizija li suppost jipproteġu lil dawn i大-ikeittadini. Li jkollok gvern fil-Kirgiżistan li jippreżenta abbozz ta' liġi biex jikkriminalizza t-tixrid ta' informazzjoni dwar orjentazzjonijiet sesswali differenti jmur lil hinn minn hedge u ta' min wieħed jikkundannah bil-qawwakollha. Dan huwa abbozz ta' liġi li jattakka flower-komunità LGBTI u anki lill-ġurnalisti u jpoġġiihom f'sitwazzjoni fejnstgħu jaffa大ja w sena ħabs bl-akkuża li ffurmaw attitudni pożittiva dwar dawk li jissejħu "relazzjonijiet sesswali mhux tradizzjonali." Mhux se noqgħod nidħol fil-mertu ta' x'inhu tradizzjonali imma għaddej diskors ieħor ukoll ħażin kontra din il-komunità; discoors ta' min qed jgħid li dawn il-persuni għandhom marda psikoloġika u għandhom bżonn il-kura. Irraġunar li rridu fuckingndannaw. Li nħaħħdu l-libertà lin-nies li jesprimu mingħajr biża' min fir-realtà huma qatt ma jista' jkun a大大ettabbli.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, dear High Representative, the ban on the promotion of non-traditional sexual relations, an unsuccessful linguistic attempt to disguise absurd discrimination! I still find it hard to believe that in the third millennium it is still possible to end up in prison for a year, simply to want to be oneself. It is already intolerable that there should be creeping discrimination in society, to imagine that it is a State that is going to take up this right, among other things, in violation of its own Constitution in Article 16, is simply abhorrent.  And to say that Kyrgyzstan was one of the least backward states in Central Asia, having decriminalised male homosexuality in '97 and female homosexuality in 2004. In many cases they were taking refuge there, fleeing Turkmenistan and Uzbekistan, and now they no longer have any safe havens. I believe that we must all stand against this draft, which is contrary not only to human rights but to common sense, and put pressure on Kyrgyzstan to get back on track, we must support its vibrant civil society and remind the Kyrgyz Government that in order to have a solid and healthy relationship with the Union, we must also take on the spirit of our motto: Unity in diversity!

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: Madam President, much has been said here on this subject. I will just say that I am very happy that we are discussing this point here today and that The High Representative, Mrs Mogherini, can hear our unequivocal and clear views on this point. Like others, I see Kyrgyzstan as the country that has made the most progress in Central Asia in its path to democracy. Worse still, this medieval law now sits on the table of the Kyrgyz Parliament. Unfortunately, I see here the very strong influence of Russia, which has already adopted a similar law, and the practice of this law clearly shows how strongly it can be abused against minorities and how strongly it suppresses human rights. And let us please remember that the Kyrgyz bill is even worse than the one that is in place today in Russia, because for the dissemination, promotion and expression of freedom of speech, someone can be sentenced to prison for up to one year. Please consider this law and, if adopted, it is clear that we must continue to do so and the European Union must take a clear position towards Kyrgyzstan, including in the form of a possible coolness of relations.

name: Goffredo Maria BETTINI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the European Union has concentrated a great deal of resources on the development of Kyrgyzstan, but today we are debating an aberrant draft law proposed by that government on the dissemination of information on non-traditional sexual relations. It is a homophobic proposal, it is a proposal that goes against our principles, we are not kidding about these issues, our idea of freedom and rights is fundamental. Everyone must be able to express themselves without suffering threats or limits except those of not having to harm other human beings. The right to express one's sexual orientation is not a concession to the so-called different, but an enrichment of society, of its overall life, which chooses not to mutilate a part of its energies and potential.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, some may ask us why we feel the need to write this resolution. They might argue that it is not interesting to deal with a country lost in the heart of Asia. We are interested, ladies and gentlemen, because the task of the European Union, of this institution, which is the fruit of thousands of years of history, is also to protect the principle of equality and non-discrimination against people.  That is why I express my strongest regret at the adoption at first reading by the Kyrgyz Parliament of the law prohibiting the direct and indirect promotion of non-traditional sexual relations. We cannot look away from a campaign of clearly homophobic discrimination. Too often, Europe has made respect for human rights conditional on economic partnerships, and that is why we hope that the European institutions will officially demand the withdrawal of the law.

name: Adina-Ioana VĂLEAN
text: There is no catch-the-eye today because we are delayed.

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs. - Madam President, yes, I have been told that this is the first time a High Representative has taken part in the urgency debates on human rights, but that is exactly because I believe that human rights are a crucial part of our foreign policy. I was told that urgency debates on human rights are normally not attended by the High Representative. I think it is my duty and also in my interest to be here, as human rights are a crucial part of foreign policy. I said that and I meant that. (Applause) Let me also say that we will have to work on the coherence of our internal policies on human rights, because today we are debating something extremely important concerning countries that are not our own Member States, and in our internal work on human rights, and in particular on LGBTI, we have to be coherent internally also. The Parliament of the Kyrgyz Republic is working on legislation that would discriminate against the LGBTI community, and we regret that the draft law has been approved at the first of the three readings necessary for final adoption. This draft legislation, if adopted, would restrict freedom of expression and association. The title of the law – ‘on the promotion of a positive attitude towards non-traditional sexual relations’ – is totally misleading. In reality, it is designed to undermine efforts by human rights NGOs, including LGBTI organisations, to advocate equal treatment for LGBTI people. Since this legislative initiative was initially proposed in March last year, the European Union has raised its concern about the draft law and insisted on the principle of non-discrimination, including in the Human Rights Dialogue in April 2014, and in subsequent high-level discussions with the parliament and government of the Kyrgyz Republic. The EU has reminded the Kyrgyz authorities of the guarantees for freedom of expression and non-discrimination in the Kyrgyz Constitution, as was mentioned before, and of the Kyrgyz Republic’s international commitments. A joint letter from the Heads of Missions and EU Ambassadors was sent to the Speaker of the Kyrgyz Parliament in June, and during the Cooperation Council meeting last November the point was raised. During the Cooperation Council meeting, the Kyrgyz Foreign Minister stressed that the presentation of the draft laws by members of parliament was a democratic right and asserted that the government was not favourable to these draft laws. The EU has also recalled that the Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe, when it granted Partner for Democracy status to the Kyrgyz Parliament earlier this year, expressly stated that this should not be followed up. In line with the Human Rights guidelines of the European Union to promote and protect the enjoyment of all human rights by LGBTI persons, I will personally continue to use all possible means to warn against the risks of adopting the draft resolution and I will coordinate my work with that of Vice-President Timmermans to make sure that we adopt coherent measures internally to protect the enjoyment of all human rights by all LGBTI persons, including in Europe. (Applause)

name: Adina-Ioana VĂLEAN
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place shortly. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Jiří MAŠTÁLKA
text: Writing. – I would like to point out that the economic and social downturn following the collapse of the Soviet Union is a fundamental reason for the deterioration of women's status and the spread of what might be called 'cultural nervousness'. Its manifestation is the law prohibiting the propaganda of homosexuality. Although I see it as a step backwards, I would like to make two comments.  First of all, I recommend balance sheet. While we must heed the universality of human rights, the road to understanding LGBT rights (Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, Transgender) has been complex and long everywhere. It was only in the 1970's that the West became asserted that homosexuality was not a mental disorder. It wasn't until 1993 that the World Health Organization removed homosexuality from the list of disorders. Moreover, we must not forget that European colonialism has also complicated many in the world. The infamous section 377 of the Criminal Code, for example, Since the 1960s, India, as well as other former British colonies, has criminalized sexual activities that are "against the order of nature." According to available data, 80 UN member states criminalise homosexuality, and in six countries it is a capital crime. Kyrgyzstan is not exactly an example of the greatest injustice against LGBT people. The second point concerns the very promotion of homosexuality. While I defend everyone's rights to freedom of expression, I consider sexual exhibitionism of any kind to be a non-cultural expression of freedom. And the source of just as unnecessary and growing conflicts.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. – Conservatism tends to see society through dualisms that function as stereotype (reason - emotion; man - woman; heterosexuality - homosexuality; me - another) and in which one concept always appears as superior to another. This builds a logic of domination, alterity, and denial. The struggle for gender equality, including the LGTBI struggle, is a direct attack on the hegemony of heterocentrist and patriarchal conservatism on which those above base their privileges and justify the exploitation of those below. This struggle occurs not only in Kyrgyzstan, but on a daily basis in our societies, because it is about deconstructing and building something new really based on equality and human rights. In addition to condemning any conduct contrary to LGTBI groups, such as Kyrgyzstan's LGBT anti-propaganda law, the Union, which is often presented as a champion of freedom and human rights, must take concrete steps to ensure the freedom of these groups. In this case, the idea of asylum should be explored by gender identity and sexual violence.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: in writing. " We are open to freedom of ideas. Friendship and unity are in our hearts. The land of Kyrgyzstan, our native state, shining in the rays of consent. These are some of the verses we can hear in the Kyrgyz stanzstan anthem. What a contradiction with the recent bill passed at first reading by the Parliament of that country. If adopted, the proposed legislation will be a significant setback not only in the process of opening up to the LGBT community, but also in safeguarding human rights that still distinguished Kyrgyzstan from other neighbouring countries. The right to transparency and freedom of expression in the LGBT community needs to be supported. We should encourage Kyrgyzstan not to take a step back in protecting these fundamental rights, but to strengthen those rights.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: Mrs Gomes, I would like to thank Mrs Gomes for her You have come forward.

name: Ana GOMES
text: Mr President, we are going to vote on the urgent resolutions on human rights, but there is also another case that I would like to call to the attention of the President of Parliament. An urgent intervention is required to stop the flogging of Raif Badawi in Saudi Arabia. This is illegal. This is barbaric. This is medieval. (Sustained applause)

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: This was obviously not an objection to yesterday's Minutes. The Minutes of yesterday's sitting have been approved.

name: Elmar BROK
text: Mr. President! I would like to thank Mrs Mogherini. From noon yesterday until last night at 11 p.m. and from this morning, it was available to the House. This is not self-evident. (Applause) As a second point, Mr President, I would like to ask you to discuss in the Bureau whether we cannot conduct foreign policy debates more concentrated and do not have one-on-one debates, but rather concentrate a clear debate every two months, but not over several hours each individual debate with a new debate.  I believe that this would serve this House, serve Mrs Mogherini and also serve the visibility of this House. We should think about that.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: Thank you very much, Mr Brok. We take note of that. I am reluctant to correct the chairman of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, but the Vice-President of the Commission and High Representative was here yesterday not until 11 a.m., but almost until midnight. In this respect, this point is indeed remarkable. Parliament's thanks go to you. (Applause)

name: Anna Maria CORAZZA BILDT
text: Mr President, many of us have been wondering why we did not vote yesterday but are voting today. Statistically, Wednesday is the day when most Members are present, so this is a matter of democratic legitimacy. If this trend should continue – and it is absolutely possible that we will have less to vote on – I would ask Parliament to assess the cost of working here when we could hold the debates somewhere else. We do not want to work less; we want to work more efficiently. (Applause)

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: Thank you very much, and indeed I myself have been wondering about this. The reason is that the political groups have decided on the dates and times for the submission of resolutions and amendments that made it impossible to vote on these resolutions that we vote today. Let me say, however, that as the Vice-President in charge of human rights, I am very satisfied that we will vote on the urgency resolutions now with a large presence. I think this underlines the role of this Parliament as a defender of human rights. The next item is the vote. (For the results and other details of the vote: see Minutes)

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: The next item is voting time. (For results and other details of the vote: see Minutes.)

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: author. - Mr President, I have to move an amendment to recital F, where it reads, ‘whereas the Kyrgz Republic decriminalised male homosexuality in 1998 and female homosexuality in 2004’. We have to delete ‘and female homosexuality in 2004’ because, I regret – and we had false information – that was never the case. So please support this oral amendment.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Herr Präsident, sehr geehrte Kollegen! Ich bitte um folgende Ergänzung der Ziffer 14:  ‘Calls on all parties in Libya to guarantee the safety and freedom of Christians and other religious minority groups who are facing increasing discrimination and persecution and find themselves in the crossfire; calls on the EU and its Member States to ensure that future bilateral agreements include effective monitoring mechanisms for the protection of the human rights of religious minorities’.

name: Victor BOŞTINARU
text: Mr President, I would like to put forward the following oral amendment for insertion before paragraph 4: ‘Welcomes the fact that Yasser Ali, the former spokesperson of the ousted President Morsi, and prominent figure in the Muslim Brotherhood, has been released and acquitted of charges; calls for the swift release of all political prisoners’. This is the oral amendment on behalf of my group.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: author. - Mr President, we want to replace, at the end of J, ‘killed 1 150 pro-Morsi demonstrators’ with ‘according to an independent Egyptian fact-finding committee, killed 607 pro-Morsi demonstrators’.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, very quickly, a new recital must be added to recital H which reads as follows: 'whereas on 14 January 2015 the Supreme Court granted Sergeant Latorre the extension of his stay in Italy for medical reasons'.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we simply need to add a vowel to paragraph 5, in order to prevent the two bodies from being alternatives, between the jurisdiction entrusted to the Italian authorities or to international arbitration; it is a matter of adding "and/or", therefore a simple vowel, but it does not make the two things alternative.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: That concludes the vote.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: Mr President, I would like to point out, under Rule 162(6), that last night in various debates, including the one on Egypt, blue cards and catch-the-eye were cancelled. We did not have genuine debate but a series of prepared statements. These things need to be scheduled better in future, but I would just like to draw your attention specifically to the wording of Rule 162(6), which says ‘shall’, not ‘may’. I believe that there is no rationale which entitles Parliament to cancel catch-the-eye. This is a part of parliamentary debate and people should be allowed to have their say. I just wanted to make that point.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: I take note of your point and we will come back to discussing it. However, let me say that there was a very lively debate and it lasted until midnight, and whoever is in the chair, whether it is myself or a colleague – and we had this little exchange yesterday as well – has a responsibility to ensure that the debate does not last until 3 in the morning. There is some discretion that the chair can exercise in allowing blue cards or not. We will also always ensure, and that is correct in Rule 162(6), that there is a diversity of views in both the blue cards and the catch-the-eye procedure, but we have taken note of your point and we will happily discuss it in the Bureau.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: Mr President, I supported this report because both the debate and the report clearly show that the Ombudsman's institute within the European institutions has a purpose, it fulfils its purpose. Twenty-three thousand requests, 80% of the ombudsman's recommendations to the European institutions, clearly show that this is not a formal institute, but that it is an institution that improves the work of the European institutions vis-à-vis citizens. What I want to say is that there has also been a debate, which is why I also supported the report that, in the future, European citizens should be more informed that the Ombudsman's institute exists, and in the future, in my opinion, citizens could turn to it even more and use it even more.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: Mr President, I wish to congratulate the Ombudsman on the publication of her first Annual Report and also on the dynamism that she has brought to the role. It is important that the European Institutions be very concerned about the actual number of complaints being received by the Ombudsman’s office and, obviously, one of the most common themes of complaints is the lack of transparency. We are moving towards a very important period in the lifespan of this mandate. There is a real threat to democracy, in terms of international trade agreements and specifically the ISDS mechanisms and, with a certain regard, towards TTIP. I want to commend the Ombudsman on the initiation of a report on transparency around the TTIP negotiations and I would stress that, if these agreements are ratified, they will not only compromise democratically-elected Member States’ governments, they are also going to be setting a very dangerous precedent for how the EU Council and Commission view the issue of transparency in the long term.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: Mr President, I also supported this ombudsman's report because, in my opinion, the key role of the European Ombudsman is to help the Institutions of the European Union to increase their openness, efficiency and friendliness to citizens, which strengthens citizens' trust in the European Union.  The fact that Mrs O'Reilly has made the Ombudsman's annual report available online for the first time and is also successfully leading the advice provided through an interactive adviser on the Ombudsman's website shows her progressive style of work, which I very much appreciate. As I fully support the ultimate objective of Mrs Obudsmanka, namely to contribute to strengthening the structures and institutes of accountability and transparency at Union level in order to promote good governance for all citizens and persons residing in the European Union and to improve democracy in the European Union, I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution.

name: Peter JAHR
text: Mr. President! I, too, was very pleased to vote in favour of the Ombudsman's report. If you like, the Ombudsman, together with the Committee on Petitions, is close to the people, very close to the citizens, and he embodies a little , depending on how you see it – a good conscience or a bad conscience. It should at least embody the good conscience or bad conscience of our Parliament and, in the end, it also shows us the shortcomings. The demand for transparency, for example in the case of TTIP, was also a great wish of the People of Europe. I am always particularly pleased when these things are not only taken up by the Ombudsman, but also implemented. Secondly, I was particularly pleased that the new media are also increasingly being used to meet this requirement. That was always a stepchild until 2013. The new Ombudsman is moving forward very strongly, and that is a good thing. That is why we look forward to continuing to work with her.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: Mr President, like my colleague Matt Carthy, I also want to congratulate Emily O’Reilly on her first annual report, and indeed on her very positive start to her tenure in office. There are many issues raised in the report, but because of time constraints I will only deal with one. I support Amendment 3, which raised the importance of resources, both for the Committee on Petitions and for the Ombudsman’s Office. The number of petitions continues to increase, as indeed do the queries to the Ombudsman’s Office. I believe that citizens look to the Ombudsman’s Office and the Petitions Committee as their conduit to the EU institutions. It is hugely important that any queries or petitions or investigations are conducted in a timely and efficient manner. In order to do that, adequate resources are required. So in my view it is a crucial issue, because a smoothly-functioning Ombudsman’s Office and Petitions Committee help create a much more positive image for the institutions.

name: Lucy ANDERSON
text: Mr President, the Ombudsman’s remit is limited in legal terms to tackling maladministration but, in doing so, she has successfully had an impact, directly and indirectly, on enforcing EU law and helping EU citizens in this way, both individually and collectively. For this reason in particular, I am very glad to vote for this report. In my view, we do not have a democratic deficit in the EU so much as an enforcement deficit. Citizens have vital rights that this Parliament and its predecessors have voted through, and – whether it is passenger rights, environmental safeguards, the right to a paid holiday – these are not often enforced in the way that they should be. I am pleased that, when Member States and the Commission do not take infringement proceedings, as they should, in some cases the Ombudsman has had an impact in those types of processes indirectly. I hope that she will do more in the coming years in this respect, both through critical remarks, special reports and in whatever other way is appropriate.

name: Seán KELLY
text: A Uachtaráin, ní rachaidh mise thar mo chuid ama ach an oiread ach a rá go bhfuil an-áthas orm gur glacadh leis an tuarascáil seo – díreach anois – le 572 as 675 a vótáil ina bhfabhar. Tabharfaidh sé sin an-ghríosú don Ombudsman Emily O’Reilly agus tá sé tuillte aici mar tá sí ag dul faoina cuid oibre le fuinneamh, le féaráilteacht agus le crógacht mar a thaispeáin sí go háirithe lena coinne maidir le TTIP. Luadh freisin go bhfuil an chuid is mó de na hagóidí ag teacht de bharr daoine a bheith míshásta faoi obair an Choimisiúin agus má laghdaítear an obair sin mar atá ráite ag an Uasal Juncker, b’fhéidir nach mbeidh na hagóidí an méid céanna ag dul go dtí an tOmbudsman agus caithfidh go dtiocfaidh laghdú ar an obair a bheidh le déanamh aici amach anseo. Tugann sé sin, is dóigh liom, gríosú do gach duine agus beidh rudaí níos fearr amach anseo.

name: Janice ATKINSON
text: Mr President, I have to explain to my voters why I voted against Amendment 18 in the Chamber today. The EU should have nothing to do with this. It is up to the individual nation states to seal their external borders. I am heartened that the nation states are deporting migrants onto flights organised by Frontex. I only wish my government would do the same.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. — The Spanish Socialists voted in favour of the Ombudsman's 2013 activity report.  I would like to clarify that we voted against Amendments Nos 5.6 and 7 of the ECR Group because, although we share the need for an end to the troika, and the harmful effects of 'austericide' policies, the troika is not part of the Treaties of the Union and is therefore not under the supervision of the European Ombudsman. Eurosceptic parties want to weaken European institutions through demagoguery and that cannot be supported; that is why we voted negatively on these amendments. We demand greater transparency in the functioning of all institutions in order to build a socially committed, just and equal europe.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. — The democratic shortcomings of the European Union are an integral part of its project to reformulate the policy and economy of the Member States. The presence of an Ombudsman does not alter this situation, but it allows at least a small control of the activity of the European institutions.  At the time of the report, the Ombudsman investigated such sensitive and opaque issues as the violation of the human rights of migrants in Frontex, the lack of transparency in the activity of the European institutions, including their negotiation of the ATCI, or the system of 'revolving doors'. The report values this activity and calls for a deepening of the citizen participation and democratic scrutiny of the European institutions, so I voted in favour.

name: Louis ALIOT
text: In writing. — On 30 June 2014, Emily O'Reilly declared that her ambition was "to encourage the EU institutions to become more efficient, transparent and accountable, by strategically increasing the visibility and impact of the work of the European Ombudsman". Much work remains to be done, particularly with regard to the European Commission, which has a record list of complaints to the Ombudsman. 64% of the cases dealt with by the institution concern the European Commission, as my colleague Mr Édouard Ferrand said in the Chamber. I abstained on this annual report, which I do not think is sufficiently concerned with the opacity of the working methods of all the EU institutions. An opacity that interferes with democratic functioning as it would be conceived.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. - Despite having some concerns I voted in favour of the Ombudsman’s annual report 2013 as I recognise the good work that Emily O’Reilly has carried out in her role as Ombudsman, and so as to place on record my full support and confidence in her for the time ahead. I agreed with this report in the sense that it stressed the importance of transparency and good administration for the EU institutions. These principles should always be an absolute priority. It was worrying to note that 64.3% of the complaints received by her office concerned the European Commission. I thought the rapporteur’s approach in relation to this was soft and found that he was trying to justify the number of complaints received. A strong line should have been taken against the actions of the European Commission. I also believe that it was pretty weak on certain aspects, in particular as concerns Frontex and TTIP. In addition to this, there is little mention made of the ‘revolving door’ and cases of conflict of interest within the European Institutions. The ‘revolving door’ practices in the European Commission should absolutely be denounced, as should the lack of transparency and public participation in the TTIP negotiations.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. — The European Ombudsman (or European Ombudsman) investigates complaints about maladministration in the institutions and bodies (with the exception of the European Court of Justice) of the European Union. These include, for example, administrative irregularities, discrimination, abuse of power or even non-response to letters. Any EU citizen, as well as any company, association or association or other body established in the EU, can lodge a complaint. Emily O'Reilly has been the EU Ombudsman since 1 October 2013. For 2013, 23 245 citizens used the Ombudsman's services. He dealt with 2 354 complaints, carried out 350 investigations and completed 461 investigations. Most of the complaints and investigations came from Belgium, Germany, Italy, Poland and Spain, mainly concerning the European Commission. I welcome the 2013 annual report and Mrs O'Reilly's work and congratulate her not only on the achievement, but also on the good cooperation with Parliament. Their efforts to ensure the transparency of the TTIP negotiations are commendable.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. — This report contains various criticisms of the European Commission. Much of the text of the report can be supported; however, as with many such resolutions, there also appears to be a call for greater EU action. I therefore abstained on the motion for resolution.

name: Inés AYALA SENDER
text: in writing. — The Spanish Socialists voted in favour of the Ombudsman's 2013 activity report unanimously. I would like to clarify that we voted against Amendments Nos 5.6 and 7 of the ECR Group because, although we share the need for an end to the troika, and the harmful effects of 'austericide' policies, the troika is not part of the Treaties of the Union and is therefore not under the supervision of the European Ombudsman. Eurosceptic parties want to weaken European institutions through demagoguery and that cannot be supported; that is why we voted negatively on these amendments. We demand greater transparency in the functioning of all institutions in order to build a socially committed, just and equal europe.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. — The Ombudsman's 2013 report highlights that transparency and ethics are the main topics covered in complaints. This demonstrates once again the importance that should be given to transparency, openness, access to information and respect for citizens' rights and ethical standards in order to strengthen citizens' confidence in the European public service.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: in writing. — The objective of this initiative report is to assess the activities of the European Ombudsman in 2013. In particular, it highlights the great work carried out by the current Ombudsman, Emily O'Reilly, to improve transparency in the Community institutions, see the investigations initiated in this regard: negotiations on TTE, irregularities in the EU institutions, the system of 'revolving doors', etc. For all this and for the will to work for the sake of excellence through its towards 2019 strategy, based on three fundamental pillars (impact, relevance and visibility), I voted in favour of the report.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. — I support the report because, in the first place, it presents a more orderly and accessible format, which promotes transparency. I very much agree with the comments made even if they are not binding and I believe that this effort can improve the transparency and accessibility of the European administration, which remains one of the main causes of complaint. It also provides a good reference for measuring progress in this area in future fiscal years.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This annual report on the activities of the European Ombudsman in 2013 allows us to know that 23,245 citizens sought the Services of the Ombudsman for help in 2013 and that 2,420 applications were registered as complaints (compared to 2,442 in 2012). Complaints focused on access to documents, institutional or political issues, staff, and competitions and selection procedures. This report shows the progress to be made in terms of transparency, whether within the EU or the Member States. EU agencies are directly affected by this lack of transparency, as the share of complaints against them has almost doubled, from 12.5% in 2012 to 24% in 2013. Those relating to the European Office for Staff Selection (EPSO) have fallen sharply, as have those on the European Parliament, but this is of course a sign that the EU, so quick to give lessons in good behaviour and transparency, should first and foremost learn to sweep at its door. I therefore abstained on this report.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. — (IT) I did not intend to support with my face the annual report on the activities of the European Ombudsman in 2013 because I consider it unbalanced and partly exploited by the rapporteur.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. — The Spanish Socialists voted in favour of the Ombudsman's 2013 activity report.  I would like to clarify that we voted against Amendments Nos 5.6 and 7 of the ECR Group because, although we share the need for an end to the troika, and the harmful effects of 'austericide' policies, the troika is not part of the Treaties of the Union and is therefore not under the supervision of the European Ombudsman. Eurosceptic parties want to weaken European institutions through demagoguery and that cannot be supported; that is why we voted negatively on these amendments. We demand greater transparency in the functioning of all institutions in order to build a socially committed, just and equal europe.  Of course, the Ombudsman contributes to her work to strengthening the structures and institutions of accountability and transparency at European level, promoting good administration for all citizens and residents of the EU and improving the quality of democracy in the EU, developing an essential role in managing citizens' concerns.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. — I voted on this report because it endorses the Report on the Activities of the European Ombudsman for 2013. The main task of the European Ombudsman is to help strengthen accountability and transparency structures and institutions at European level and to promote good administration for the benefit of every EU citizen and resident. In its report, Parliament welcomes the fact that complaints about the European Personnel Selection Office (EPSO) more than halved in 2013, but expressed concern at the increase in complaints about the Commission and the European Union agencies operating in the Member States. In this report, Parliament therefore called on The Ombudsman, Mrs O'Reilly, to investigate the possible causes of the increase in complaints, namely whether this increase was due to the public being more aware of the complaint procedures or other factors. After all, transparency, openness, access to information, respect for citizens' rights and high ethical standards are essential to develop and maintain the confidence of citizens and citizens in the European Union's public service.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: in writing. — Despite having some concerns I voted in favour of the Ombudsman’s annual report 2013 as I recognise the fantastic work that Emily O’Reilly has carried out in her role as Ombudsman, and so as to place on record my full support and confidence in her for the time ahead.   I agreed with this report in the sense that it stressed the importance of transparency and good administration for the EU institutions. These principles should always be an absolute priority. It was worrying to note that 64.3% of the complaints received by her office concerned the European Commission. I thought the rapporteur’s approach in relation to this was soft and found that he was trying to justify the number of complaints received. A strong line should have been taken against the actions of the European Commission. I also believe that it was pretty weak on certain aspects, in particular as concerns Frontex and TTIP. In addition to this, there is little mention made of the ‘revolving door’ and cases of conflict of interest within the European Institutions. The ‘revolving door’ practices in the European Commission should absolutely be denounced, as should the lack of transparency and public participation in the TTIP negotiations.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. — I voted yes because I agree with the content of the report on the activities of the European Ombudsman.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. — Respect for the fundamental rights of European citizens in relation to the Community institutions and the promotion of the principles of effective administration are essential conditions for preserving the democratic standards of the Union. I consider it important to increase the credibility of the Ombudsman's institution as a European body that contributes to strengthening the European institutional framework and increasing transparency by facilitating access to information for the benefit of citizens. According to Eurostat statistics, the Community institutions enjoy a high degree of confidence among citizens in many Member States, surpassing the trust placed in national governments. Ensuring the easiest access to its digital platform as well as the exchange of information and effective communication with citizens are some aspects that contribute to increasing the visibility of the institution. I have expressed myself in favour of this resolution because I am convinced of the importance of the European Ombudsman's institution which, through its independence and impartiality, ensures the proper functioning of the European institutions and agencies.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. — I am voting against because the text mentions the fact that in 2013 the Ombudsman presented a special report on the absence of a mechanism in the Frontex agency to deal with complaints about alleged violations of asylum seekers' rights. This issue has been exploited by the extreme left (which has also tabled an amendment referring specifically to the special report on Frontex). The Lega Nord is aware of the limitations of Frontex, but believes that they are certainly not those of the absence of a mechanism to which immigrants should appeal.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: in writing. — The Spanish Socialists voted in favour of the Ombudsman's 2013 activity report.  I would like to clarify that we voted against Amendments Nos 5.6 and 7 of the ECR Group because, although we share the need for an end to the troika, and the harmful effects of 'austericide' policies, the troika is not part of the Treaties of the Union and is therefore not under the supervision of the European Ombudsman. Eurosceptic parties want to weaken European institutions through demagoguery and that cannot be supported; that is why we voted negatively on these amendments. We demand greater transparency in the functioning of all institutions in order to build a socially committed, just and equal europe.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of the report on the activity of the European Ombudsman during 2015. It was an opportunity to salute the work of the previous mediator Nikiforos Diamandouros and to reiterate my support for Mrs O'Reilly. The task of the European Ombudsman is paramount. It is a bridge between the European institutions and the citizens. It protects the rights of European citizens and strengthens the democratic character of the European Union. I appreciate the fact that the Ombudsman is implementing new strategies to address the many questions about transparency that our citizens are asking, particularly with regard to the negotiations for the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. — (IT) Today I voted in favour of this report because I approve of the annual report for 2013 presented by the European Ombudsman. The role of the Ombudsman is crucial because it brings citizens closer to the institutions of the European Union, which is particularly important in view of the disconnect we are currently experiencing.  I welcome a number of important inquiries that the Ombudsman has initiated, such as those on transparency in the negotiations for a Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP), the reporting of wrongdoing by employees in the EU institutions and transparency in the Commission's expert groups.  I believe that social media is essential as a channel for communications and I therefore encourage the Ombudsman's offices to make greater use of these means to raise public awareness of his activities and make his institution as accessible as possible.  I note with concern that the share of complaints relating to the European Commission has increased sharply compared to 2012. The reasons for this increase should be examined by the Ombudsman in order to strengthen the Credibility of the Commission itself.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. — I have voted in favour of this report as it serves to congratulate the Ombudsman for the work carried out, but it also gives one important reminder. It shows that the end user can always be treated better, and through measures such as better administration and social media the Ombudsman can be accessed more easily and better serve European citizens.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. — The Work of the European Ombudsman in 2013 focused mainly on the Work of the Commission (accounting for 64.3% of open inquiries). This can only reassure us about the role of the Ombudsman himself. The vote is in favour.

name: Nessa CHILDERS
text: in writing. — There is much room for improvement on transparency standards across all EU institutions. This is reflected in the fact that the most common complaint from EU citizens received by the European Ombudsman related to EU institutions’ refusal of access to documents. I particularly commend Ombudsman Emily O'Reilly’s investigation into the lack of transparency in the TTIP talks, and the vigorous conclusions and recommendations addressed to the Commission, on foot of her own-initiative inquiry.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. — (IT) As I said in my speech during the debate, I find that Mrs O'Reilly has done an excellent job during her first term of office, and, as far as she points out today, particularly in 2013. The statistics on his work are encouraging and show excellent skills, but I would like to make his work even more public so that this figure becomes more and more an important reference for citizens who interface with European institutions that, at physical distance, often add a sidereal distance in terms of languages and bureaucratic snags. Thank you, Ombudsman!

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. — I congratulate Mrs O'Reilly on the excellent work she is doing as Ombudsman and pay tribute to her predecessor who has left a very positive legacy. The number of citizens who turn to the Ombudsman is proof that their existence is known and respected. I believe, however, that work should continue to be made to give more visibility to this powerful instrument for the defence of European citizens. I recognise that the European Commission is the institution most scrutinised by citizens, but the unusual of more than half of the cases that reach the Ombudsman is related to that institution only can be mentioned. I also agree with Mrs O'Reilly's reaction to the unacceptable limitation of the Ombudsman's investigative powers at Europol. I hope that the Ombudsman will not resign himself to the idea that the Treaties can be revised or amended through International Agreements.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of the annual report of the European Ombudsman's work in 2013 because it shows that the Ombudsman has opened 350 inquiries to investigate possible maladministration by the main European institutions. These numbers justify a positive assessment of the Ombudsman's work, since, under Article 228 TFEI, every citizen can apply to the Ombudsman if he or she wants to be protected in the event of maladministration by European bodies or institutions. On the other hand, its role is crucial in improving the Union and strengthening the relationship of trust between citizens and the European institutions.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. — I have voted in favour of this report, taking note of the valuable work being done by this office in the interest of EU citizens and of Ms O’Reilly’s wish to make the Ombudsman institution as accessible and user-friendly as possible.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the annual report on the activities of the European Ombudsman in 2013. However, I call on the Ombudsman to follow up his efforts to improve communication channels and improve information to European citizens so that they know the Ombudsman's services and his area of competence. I also welcome a number of important inquiries that the Ombudsman has initiated, such as the transparency investigations in the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP) negotiations. I hope that this work can follow the line of transparency as requested and desired several times by me and the 5 Star Movement.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. — The democratic shortcomings of the European Union are an integral part of its project to reformulate the policy and economy of the Member States. The presence of an Ombudsman does not alter this situation, but it allows at least a small control of the activity of the European institutions.  At the time of the report, the Ombudsman investigated such sensitive and opaque issues as the violation of the human rights of migrants in Frontex, the lack of transparency in the activity of the European institutions, including their negotiation of the ATCI, or the system of 'revolving doors'. The report values this activity and calls for a deepening of the citizen participation and democratic scrutiny of the European institutions, so I voted in favour.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. — This report approves the annual report for 2013 presented by the European Ombudsman. It also congratulates Emily O’Reilly on her first annual report as Ombudsman and welcomes her approach in terms of keeping up positive working relations and cooperation with Parliament. The 2013 Ombudsman report also demonstrates the efforts made towards advocating respect for human rights and transparency and the promotion of European institutions. Hence I voted in favour of this report.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. — Since taking office in October 2013, Mrs O'Reilly has started to reflect on the role of the European Ombudsman and his role in serving European citizens. As an essential element of the democratisation of the European political and administrative system, in 2013 the Ombudsman opened 341 investigations at the request of European citizens and nine initiative investigations and closed 441 investigations as well as 20 initiative investigations. It also published a new version of the European Code of Good Administrative Conduct, while calling on the new Commission to adopt binding rules and principles on the administrative procedure of the European institutions and to present a draft regulation in this regard. This work was praised and Ms. O'Reilly was confirmed in her position at the plenary last December. For these reasons, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. The European Ombudsman, ensuring good administration in the institutions and bodies of the European Union, plays a key role in improving the much-degraded link between the European Union and the individuals or legal entities of the Member States. That is why I support its action and the necessary means associated with it. Transparency, ethical issues and citizen participation in EU decision-making are essential elements in re-establishing the link that is now broken. The ambition of the new European Ombudsman Emily O'Reilly to help strengthen structures and institutions in terms of accountability and transparency at European level is therefore moving in the right direction. Nevertheless, it is important to include concrete figures in all annual reports, so that year-to-year comparisons can be made.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. — I abstained on the report on the European Ombudsman's activity report, as I believe that nothing particularly positive can be noted in the past period's activity. The spirit of the Ombudsman's report is administratively command-style. Of the 100 complaints, only 15 were assessed as relevant. The complaint admissibility rule is a formal criterion which does not guarantee that the Ombudsman has properly assessed or does not have poor administrative practice. A formal approach to the examination of appeals leads to a refusal to adjudicate on the petitum of the appeal.  The low number of complaints and the number of citizens who have turned for assistance shows that the institution is unknown to citizens, they do not expect it to solve the problems. The low number of complaints does not mean less bad administrative practices. I do not share the Ombudsman's view that frontex should establish a mechanism and rule on individual migrant complaints. This is within the competence of the administrations of the Member States. Frontex cannot seize this competence, the Agency coordinates and sub-pumps, but does not directly manage the process. What the Ombudsman has proposed is legally inadmissible.  Given that, however, the current Ombudsman has been in office since September 2013. these observations are findings and recommendations, not a rebuke.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. — We disagree because it wants to give illegal immigrants an additional tool that they can use to give them asylum, whereas in most cases they are not entitled to it. In general, however, we believe that this institution works for the benefit of European citizens.

name: Rosa ESTARÀS FERRAGUT
text: in writing. — The European Ombudsman has successfully fulfilled during this period his mission to investigate complaints against EU institutions, agencies, offices and agencies. As you know, the European Ombudsman's Office launches investigations following complaints received (341 in 2013) or on its own initiative (9 in 2013). I believe that the European Ombudsman is an example of independence and transparency, and guarantees full respect for the rights of citizens, as well as the right to good administration. I would like to highlight in this regard the presentation of the new version of the European Code of Good Administrative Conduct, which urges the new Commission to adopt binding rules and principles on administrative procedures in the EU and to submit a draft regulation.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. — 23 245 citizens sought assistance from the Ombudsman's services in 2013, with 19,418 citizens receiving advice through the interactive guide on the Ombudsman's website, while 1407 requests were made for requests for information, 2420 applications (2442 in 2012) were registered as complaints. I consider it important for the Ombudsman to provide more detailed information on the types of complaints format in order to make comparisons over the years between complaints received in electronic form via the Ombudsman's interactive website and complaints received offline; I therefore congratulate Emily O'Reilly on her first annual report as Ombudsman and I welcome her approach to maintaining positive cooperation and working relations with Parliament, in particular with her Committee on Petitions.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing — The annual report in question covers only part of the office's activities under the authority of the new Ombudsman, since it was only elected in mid-2013 and is therefore also the work of its predecessor in this post. It is very important that the institution of the European Ombudsman is as open to the public as possible and that citizens feel that this institution is helping them and that it is available to them at any time. Citizens are turning to this institution with more and more applications and it is therefore necessary for it to work quickly and efficiently. It is very important that the Ombudsman's office is more visible, relevant and influential in the future, taking into account his budget of EUR 10 million.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. — (IT) This year I cannot vote in favour of the report because it has been exploited by the inclusion of provisions on Frontex which I consider inappropriate. That is why I shall be voting against it.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. — I vote against and disagree with the Ombudsman's 2013 annual report because he wants to give illegal immigrants an additional tool to exploit in order to be granted asylum, when in most cases they are not entitled to it. In general, however, I believe that this institution works for the benefit of European citizens.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report after assessing the work done by the European Ombudsman, Mrs Emily O'Reilly, during 2013, and of seeing how the daily work of this institution contributes to subsuming situations of maladministration in the actions of the Union institutions, bodies or bodies with regard to citizens. In my opinion, this institution must play a key role within the Union, always offering the citizen maximum accessibility and ease of contact. In 2013, the Ombudsman registered contacts with 23,245 citizens who requested their services through the Ombudsman's portal. It shows the growing impact of this institution is that, with regard to the distribution of claims by country, Spain topped the list of 416 claims.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: in writing. — The Spanish Socialists voted in favour of the Ombudsman's 2013 activity report.  I would like to clarify that we voted against Amendments Nos 5.6 and 7 of the ECR Group because, although we share the need for an end to the troika, and the harmful effects of 'austericide' policies, the troika is not part of the Treaties of the Union and is therefore not under the supervision of the European Ombudsman. Eurosceptic parties want to weaken European institutions through demagoguery and that cannot be supported; that is why we voted negatively on these amendments. We demand greater transparency in the functioning of all institutions in order to build a socially committed, just and equal europe.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: in writing. — The Spanish Socialists voted in favour of the Ombudsman's 2013 activity report.   I would like to clarify that we voted against Amendments Nos 5.6 and 7 of the ECR Group because, although we share the need for an end to the troika, and the harmful effects of 'austericide' policies, the troika is not part of the Treaties of the Union and is therefore not under the supervision of the European Ombudsman.  Eurosceptic parties want to weaken European institutions through demagoguery and that cannot be supported; that is why we voted negatively on these amendments. We demand greater transparency in the functioning of all institutions in order to build a socially committed, just and equal europe.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the Walesa report because I believe the Ombudsman plays a vital role in bringing the EU closer to its citizens by acting as a guardian for transparency, good administration and quality democracy. Recent statistics show that the number of UK citizens who feel positive towards the EU has risen to 52%. Now we need to pull the other 48% aboard, and we will only succeed if citizens are genuinely enabled to be part of the European project. I therefore deeply welcome the Ombudsman inquiry into the implementation of the European Citizens’ Initiative, a tool launched in 2012 to increase citizens’ direct involvement in the EU decision-making process, to make sure it is working to full potential. Her decision to investigate transparency in the TTIP negotiations – an issue on which constituents write to me on a daily basis – moreover proves that the Ombudsman is serious about addressing issues citizens are truly concerned about.  However, these actions will only make a difference if the Ombudsman’s recommendations are acted upon swiftly and decisively. Together with colleagues, I intend to make sure this message is heard loud and clear by every single institution and agency working for the EU.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. — We voted abstention. We can greet the work carried out by the Ombudsman and support any changes leading to improving the effectiveness, efficiency and impact of her fundamental work. However, it abstains when voting on this resolution because it understands that the Ombudsman's task with regard to the audit of transparency processes must be able to be carried out without limitation and must be enforceable to the institutions themselves. The Ombudsman must not only be able to access more information and documentation than that provided by the Commission, but must be able to access 'all the information' of the ongoing negotiations, so as to ensure that both the form and content of the negotiations do not infringe the legality or infringe on the rights of citizens. The Ombudsman should place particular emphasis on investigating and being able to act against troika-driven austerity policies, both from a formal point of view (as they violate any process of legitimate foundation of them) and from the point of view of their impact on guaranteeing the economic and social rights of Europeans and Europeans.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. — I voted in favour on the Ombudsman’s annual report 2013 because I welcome the Ombudsman’s activity and efforts to raise public awareness of the Office’s work and the efforts to decrease maladministration by EU institutions and bodies through inquiries and reports, with recommendations to the respective institutions and the European Parliament.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. - We voted abstention. We can greet the work carried out by the Ombudsman and support any changes leading to improving the effectiveness, efficiency and impact of her fundamental work. However, it abstains when voting on this resolution because it understands that the Ombudsman's task with regard to the audit of transparency processes must be able to be carried out without limitation and must be enforceable to the institutions themselves. The Ombudsman must not only be able to access more information and documentation than that provided by the Commission, but must be able to access 'all the information' of the ongoing negotiations, so as to ensure that both the form and content of the negotiations do not infringe the legality or infringe on the rights of citizens. The Ombudsman should place particular emphasis on investigating and being able to act against troika-driven austerity policies, both from a formal point of view (as they violate any process of legitimate foundation of them) and from the point of view of their impact on guaranteeing the economic and social rights of Europeans and Europeans.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. — I voted for a motion for a resolution on the Ombudsman's annual report on action in 2013, as I believe it meets criteria and standards that contribute to respect for the rights of European citizens and the principle of good administration. I believe that Ms. O'Reilly has focused her work well on the more efficient and transparent European institutions at the disposal of citizens in order to raise their trust in them.  It follows from the report that one of the main problems is the lack of transparency of institutions that surely need to be opposed by providing easier access to information and documents. In this regard, it is important that the reports also contain quantitative data on complaints so that various annual reports can be compared. In addition, I support the fact that in 2013 The Ombudsman's Office published a new version of the European Code of Good Administrative Treatment and that the report is available in an interactive version.

name: Danuta JAZŁOWIECKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. — The European Ombudsman's 2013 activity report very clearly shows the European Union's main problem, namely distance from citizens. A significant proportion of complaints during this period concerned the refusal of access to documents and information, as well as the lack of transparency in the functioning of the Union institutions and agencies. This is an extremely important problem that has not been solved for years.  It is important to be aware that it is impossible to build trust in the Union without increasing its openness and transparency. The decrease in support for the integration project is, among other things, the result of citizens not knowing on the basis of what conditions decisions are taken directly concerning them. And the lack of this transparency increases support for anti-EU movements and parties. That is why I also supported the report, which contained not only elements on mechanisms to improve responses to citizens' questions, but also new ideas for further improvements. I congratulate the rapporteur, the European Ombudsman, and I look forward to further and more positive reports.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. — The European Ombudsman plays a key role in democratic control within the European Union. It is in fact responsible for investigating cases of maladministration in European bodies, thereby strengthening the rights of European citizens. I welcome the adoption of the ombudsman's report on the Ombudsman's activities in 2013 as it underlines the work done by Mrs O'Reilly, Ombudsman since October 2013, to make the function more accessible to citizens.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of the annual report on the activities of the European Ombudsman in 2013. Independent and impartial, the European Ombudsman examines complaints against EU institutions, bodies and agencies and investigates cases of maladministration. In 2013, 23,245 citizens sought the services of the Ombudsman and 2,420 complaints were registered. Ms. O'Reilly has done encouraging work in promoting the transparency of institutions and the protection of citizens' fundamental rights.

name: Jarosław KALINOWSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. — The European Ombudsman, whose office has been under Emily O'Reilly since 2013, is responsible for tackling the problems of citizens and businesses that have experienced 'maladministration' by EU institutions, offices and agencies. In response to complaints of violations, non-compliance with the principles of good administration or violation of human rights by these authorities, in 2013 the Ombudsman completed 441 inquiries and 341 new investigations. As many Polish the Same Year, 248 complaints were received by the Ombudsman, confirming the need to continue bridging the gap between citizens and the EU institutions. In addition to dealing with complaints, the European Ombudsman must also guard the transparency of the EU institutions in order to achieve this, as the rapporteur has emphasised. Indeed, facilitating the processes for citizens to control and assess the activities of public authorities is essential to increase their confidence, which is essential for the proper functioning of a united Europe. Furthermore, in order to increase its importance and impact, it should be more involved in matters of public interest, such as the negotiations on the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership.

name: Georgios KATROUGKALOS
text: Writing. — I voted white in the relevant vote, among other reasons, and why the EP voted against the proposal to instruct the Ombudsman to examine the Troika's responsibilities in enforcing the austerity policies of the Memorandums contrary to the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights and other rules of primary law. Failure to control the activity of such extra-institutions seriously affects both the rule of law and the European social model.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. — I supported the report, as it seeks to establish the EU Ombudsman as maintaining continuity in tackling systemic issues across all EU institutions.

name: Jude KIRTON-DARLING
text: in writing. — Whilst I am sympathetic to the substance of the amendments tabled in relation to the economic crisis and scrutiny of the work of the Troika, this issue is beyond the scope of this report. I therefore could not support the amendments tabled today, but hope to address this issue in dialogue with the EU Ombudsman and in the context of my work in the European Parliament’s Committee on Petitions.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: in writing. — On 15 January 2015, I supported the European Ombudsman's 2013 report on the work of the European Parliament. It must be said that this institution is very important from the point of view of protecting rights within the EU. From the point of view of EU law, it deals with complaints and complaints about situations that can happen in the daily life of each citizen. The European Ombudsman's work can greatly affect citizens' trust in the European institutions. Above all, the EVOP report must lead MEPs to think about how to improve both their activities and those of the EU institutions so that we all get closer to the EU citizens themselves. Especially in the light of today's crisis of trust and legitimacy of the EU institutions. Personally, I find the greatest alienation and absolute lack of transparency, especially in the operation of the so-called troika. EVOP should focus in the coming year on examining the Commission's involvement in the so-called trout, in particular in view of the fact that the Commission is also responsible for the implementation and guarding of the Treaties. In particular, I see other huge errors by the EU institutions and the Commission in opposition, as the public, or even the MEPs themselves, report in detail on the preparations for the TTIP. I am therefore very glad that the European Ombudsman has made it a priority in the exercise of her mandate to strengthen her role as guardian of EU transparency, also in the context of the ttip proposal under discussion.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I am voting in favour of mr McKenna's report. Walesa as I consider the contribution made by the European Ombudsman in 2013 to be appropriate. It has been aimed at ensuring that EU citizens are properly included in the European decision-making process. In 2013, the European Ombudsman established contact with 23,245 citizens from different EU Member States, who received appropriate online assistance. Topics covered during 2013 include issues related to transparency, ethical issues, EU-funded projects and programmes, fundamental rights and a culture of service, and citizens' participation in EU decision-making.

name: Jérôme LAVRILLEUX
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of the WALESA report on the European Ombudsman's annual report for 2013. This report perfectly highlights the issues that must guide the Ombudsman's action in collaboration with the European Parliament, the Council of the Union and the European Commission. He also stresses the quality of the Ombudsman's work in 2013, which led to Emily O'Reilly being re-elected as the European Ombudsman by the European Parliament in December 2014.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: in writing. — The Spanish Socialists voted in favour of the Ombudsman's 2013 activity report unanimously.  I would like to clarify that we voted against Amendments Nos 5.6 and 7 of the ECR group because, although we share the need for an end to the troika, and the harmful effects of 'austericide' policies, the troika is not part of the Treaties of the Union and is therefore not under the supervision of the European Ombudsman. Eurosceptic parties want to weaken European institutions through demagoguery and that cannot be supported; that is why we voted negatively on these amendments. We demand greater transparency in the functioning of all institutions in order to build a socially committed, just and equal europe.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. — The democratic shortcomings of the European Union are an integral part of its project to reformulate the policy and economy of the Member States. The presence of an Ombudsman does not alter this situation, but it allows at least a small control of the activity of the European institutions.  At the time of the report, the Ombudsman investigated such sensitive and opaque issues as the violation of the human rights of migrants in Frontex, the lack of transparency in the activity of the European institutions, including their negotiation of the ATCI, or the system of 'revolving doors'. The report values this activity and calls for a deepening of the citizen participation and democratic scrutiny of the European institutions, so I voted in favour.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. — The European Ombudsman, Emily O'Reilly, was elected by the European Parliament on 3 July 2013 and took the oath of office before the Court of Justice of the European Union on 30 September 2013. Consequently, the 2013 Annual Report covers only part of the work of the European Ombudsman's Office under its mandate. It was presented to the President of the European Parliament on 15 September and to the Committee on Petitions on 24 September 2014. The Annual Report has been modernized to provide maximum accessibility and ease of contact. In addition, the Ombudsman outlined her new strategy "Towards 2019". This strategy is based on three fundamental concepts: impact, relevance and visibility. It aims to conduct more strategic research on systemic problems, strengthen the Ombudsman's role by actively contributing to key discussions in the EU and increase the visibility of the institution by encouraging its rapprochement with stakeholders and highlighting and demanding the public's attention to important issues.  That is why I voted in favour of this proposal.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. — Emily O'Reilly was elected by the European Parliament to the post of European Ombudsman on 3 July 2013. The Ombudsman is an independent and impartial body that can hold the European administration to account. The Ombudsman conducts an investigation into complaints of irregularities in administration work in EU institutions, bodies, offices and agencies.  The investigations opened by the Ombudsman's Office in 2013 are mostly about transparency in the EU institutions, ethical issues, citizens' participation in the EU decision-making process, EU-funded projects and programmes, and fundamental rights and culture of services.  I support this report, as transparency, respect for citizens' rights and high ethical norms are the key to trust between the EU institutions and its citizens, and Ms O'Reilly's work shows that in 2013 she really improved this relationship and the level of democracy in the Union.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. - I voted in favour, except for the amendments that the Socialist Progressive Alliance group opposed. But in general, I voted in favour of my colleague Valens' report, because the European Ombudsman is an extremely important institution in the European Union. Listening to the debate and observing the reality of EU citizens turning to the Ombudsman with their complaints, it is clear that this is a real instrument of democracy and human rights in the European Union. In general, its work provides the basis for optimism, and this mechanism needs to be strengthened.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: in writing - The European Ombudsman's Institute is an important tool for investigating and verifying the transparency, impartiality and regularity of procedures to the EU institutions, bodies, offices and agencies. It is therefore important for the EP to be kept informed in detail of the results of the Ombudsman's work. It is one of the control mechanisms that examines how the individual EU institutions operate and progress and how the Office of the European Ombudsman itself operates. In the interests of the EU population, it is necessary to raise awareness of the tasks and competences of the European Ombudsman and of the results of her work, so that this institute can be used to increase the protection of rights and legitimate interests. It is also important to strengthen communication within the European Network of Ombudsmen.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. — I am voting against the report because the amendments I tabled as shadow rapporteur were not accepted and voted for by the plenary of the European Parliament, according to which: 1. The institutions of transparency and accountability at European level must be strengthened, including with regard to the Eurogroup and the Troika. 2. An investigation should be carried out by the European Ombudsman into compliance with the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights by the Troika. 3. An investigation should be carried out by the European Ombudsman into the conflict of interest in the Commission between its role in the Troika and its responsibility as guardian of the Treaties and the acquis communautaire. 4. An investigation should be carried out by the European Ombudsman into a possible conflict of interest between the ECB's current role in the Troika as a 'technical adviser' and its position as a creditor of the four EU Member States set out in a memorandum, on the one hand, and the ECB's mandate under the EU Treaty and the Treaty on the Functioning of the EU, on the other.

name: David MARTIN
