text: in writing. — I voted for this report, which notes that overall compliance with the Ombudsman’s recommendations stood at 80% in 2012, slightly down from 82% in 2011; supports the Ombudsman in her ambition to improve the compliance rate; urges the Commission, in particular, to make all efforts to improve its compliance rate; is concerned at the 20% non-compliance rate, and urges the institutions, bodies, offices and agencies of the Union to respond and react within a reasonable time frame to the critical remarks of the Ombudsman and to make all the necessary efforts to improve their follow-up rate by prompt implementation of the Ombudsman’s recommendations and critical remarks; looks forward to the specific information that will be provided in the Ombudsman’s upcoming annual report on compliance in 2013.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the annual report on the activities of the European Ombudsman in 2013.  We support the activities of the European Ombudsman, an essential role in helping the Institutions of the European Union to become effective transparent and, above all, close to the citizens. It is essential to ensure that citizens' rights are fully respected. Respect for rights is one of the essential principles for building and maintaining confidence in the European civil service.

name: Jiří MAŠTÁLKA
text: Writing. - Today we discussed the 2013 Annual Activity Report of the European Ombudsman. I personally attach great importance to this institution, because it deals with complaints and complaints about situations that can happen in the daily life of each citizen. The European Ombudsman's work can greatly affect citizens' confidence in the European institutions, which, as we know, are now at their highest level. I found with interest that transparency, citizens' participation in the EU decision-making process, fundamental rights and the culture of the public service were among the main topics discussed in the 2013 cases. The European Ombudsman's report must lead us, MEPs, to think about how to improve our work in order to get closer to the main priorities and interests of the citizens we represent in the European Parliament. As the European Ombudsman has made it a priority in the exercise of her mandate to strengthen her role as the 'guardian of EU transparency', for example in the context of the present proposal for a TTIP treaty, where the European Parliament has long complained about the lack of transparency and information from the negotiations, I supported this report in the vote.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. — (IT) I have decided to support, with a vote in favour, the Wałęsa report, which endorses the terms of the Ombudsman's work in 2013, as I consider the contribution made by the European Ombudsman during the year in question to be adequate.  It is to be welcomed that, during the reference period, the European Ombudsman has offered his advice to almost 24 000 EU citizens, who wish to demand the affirmation of their rights in areas such as transparency, ethical issues, and fundamental rights.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. — As the innovations have been demonstrably positively received by the citizens of the EU Member States and the TTIP negotiations must now also be in favour of transparency, I would have voted in favour.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. — The European Ombudsman investigates complaints against EU institutions and bodies in case of maladministration. The right-wing MP's report forgoes any political assessment of his annual work. Fortunately, many of my group's amendments address this, starting with highlighting the cases of slippers and conflicts of interest within the Commission revealed by the Ombudsman. Amendments also call on the Ombudsman to investigate the troika's compliance with the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union. I am voting for this report to support the political significance of these words on the eve of a likely Syriza government in Greece.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. — In 2013, the Ombudsman recorded contacts established by 23 245 citizens who used his services through the Ombudsman's portal. The vast majority (19 418) received online support through the interactive guide available on the Ombudsman's website. The other contacts concerned requests for information (1 407) to which the Ombudsman's services responded or complaints.( 2 420). In presenting his annual report to the Committee on Petitions, the Ombudsman outlined his new strategy, Towards 2019. This strategy is based on three main concepts: Impact, Relevance and Visibility. On the basis of these concepts, the Ombudsman intends to carry out further strategic investigations into systemic problems (Impact), strengthen the role of the Ombudsman, contributing to key EU (Relevance) debates and increase the visibility of the institution itself, promoting its intervention with stakeholders and drawing attention to important cases (Visibility). To promote transparency, it is advisable to initiate investigations of significant public interest. Therefore, a close observation of the negotiations on the transatlantic trade and investment partnership would strengthen the Ombudsman's role as the EU's transparency guardian.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. — As Vice-Chair of the Committee on Petitions, I enjoy good working relations with Emily O’Reilly and her office. I fully support the Ombudsman’s efforts to strengthen the structures and institutions’ accountability and transparency at European level and look forward to continuing to collaborate with the Ombudsman in the coming years. Therefore, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: writing — I warmly welcome the Ombudsman's annual report for 2013, which delivers many positive results, which was jointly contributed to by Emily O'Reilly and her predecessor Nikiforos Diamandouros. I particularly appreciate the Ombudsman's activities in the area of publication of information and texts relating to the EU-US transatlantic trade and investment agreement, the so-called TTIP, given the potential impact of this agreement on many areas of life for European citizens, including health and food safety. Like the Ombudsman, I believe that it is necessary to guarantee the transparency of the negotiations, to allow wider access to other documents and to ensure that citizens are sufficiently informed about the impact of the agreement on their rights and legitimate interests. I therefore voted in favour of adopting the Ombudsman's annual report.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. — As shadow rapporteur for the S&D Group, I recommended a vote in favour of the Walesa Report. During the negotiations in the Committee on Petitions, I proposed a number of amendments that were taken into account, amendments calling for a proper follow-up mechanism for citizens’ complaints, measures to improve non-compliance with the Ombudsman’s recommendation, and actions to speed up the process of inquiry and improve information channels to our citizens. Nevertheless, I did not support the amendments which fall outside the scope of the European Ombudsman.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. — This own-initiative report is an analysis of the work carried out by the European Ombudsman in 2013. Since current Ombudsman Emily O'Reilly did not take office until 30 September 2014, this document focuses on the work of her predecessor Nikiforos Diamandouros.  The European Parliament considers it important that the annual reports drawn up by the Ombudsman express concrete numbers of citizens' requests, whether they are related only to contacts, requests for support and/or complaints.  According to the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU), Articles 20, 24 and 228 the European Ombudsman is competent to receive complaints about possible cases of maladministration in the actions of the institutions and bodies of the European Union, intervening on its own initiative or on the basis of complaints lodged by EU citizens.  I voted in favour of this own-initiative report because I support the new Towards 2019 strategy, based on these three premises: Impact, Relevance and Visibility.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. — the report on the activities of the European Ombudsman is a measure of the extent to which the European Union is completely out of contact with the concerns of the citizens of the Member States.  In 2013, less than 24,000 citizens consulted the Ombudsman's services and only 461 investigations were closed, which is ridiculous compared, for example, to the activity of the French rights defender, who handled nearly 90,000 cases in 2011 alone. This figure proves the disinterest of the citizens of each Member State with regard to European procedures and institutions. the Ombudsman also called on the Commission to respect the basic rules of transparency regarding the TTIP and CETA negotiations. However, the Commission has not taken these recommendations into account or communicated to MEPs the ins and outs of the negotiations of these free trade treaties.  So no, the European Ombudsman is not up to the challenge and weighs almost nothing against the all-powerful European Commission.  That is why I abstained on the vote of this report.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. — I voted in favour as the report seeks to establish the EU Ombudsman as maintaining continuity in tackling systemic issues across all EU institutions, especially with regard to the TFEU.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of this text on the activity of the European Ombudsman in 2013. The European Ombudsman, Emily O'Reilly, in helping more than 23,000 European citizens, did an excellent job in 2013. It has also extended and enhanced its relationship with the European Parliament. This work therefore deserved to be praised and encouraged.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. — (IT) We fully support the activities of the European Ombudsman, as it plays an essential role in helping the institutions of the European Union to become more transparent, effective and close to the citizens, thereby strengthening citizens' confidence in the Union itself. Indeed, we consider it a priority to ensure that citizens' rights are fully respected and that the right to good administration reflects the highest standards, as is expected of the Union's institutions, bodies or bodies. Transparency, openness, access to information, respect for citizens' rights and high ethical standards are essential principles for building and maintaining confidence in the European civil service. Transparency is a cornerstone of advanced democracy, inso that it allows the activities of public authorities to be examined, their performance assessed and called to account. We also agree with the openness and public access to documents, while reaffirming our firm support for citizens' right to privacy and the protection of personal data. Finally, we wish to reaffirm the importance of the European Citizens' Initiative – first provided for in the Treaty of Lisbon – as a new instrument that allows citizens to participate directly in the decision-making process during the drafting of European legislation.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. — The essence of the Ombudsman's institution is to draw attention to citizens' concerns, and it is clear from the reports of recent years that the transparency of the European institutions has gone in a positive direction. We all know the principle that any CITIZEN of the European Union is entitled to access the documents of the institutions and offices of the Union.  That is why I believe that the attitude of the other party in the case of the Terrorist Finance Tracking Programme Agreement (TFTP) between the European Union and the United States is impermissible, where documents do not allow the European Ombudsman to check and look into them under the treaty adopted. In the future, we will have to develop and sign international treaties with much greater care. The European Parliament must play a much greater role in the preparation of international treaties.  Learning from the mistakes we have made, I hope that in the future we will be more careful when signing conventions that have a major impact on our citizens, including TTIP. That is why I think it is good that the European Commission will publish more documents on bilateral negotiations, and possibly on the lobby groups involved, so that citizens and all members of Parliament are well informed and that the aforementioned fiasco can no longer take place.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. — I voted for this resolution because it supports the Ombudsman's main objective of helping to strengthen the structures and institutions of accountability and transparency at European level. With its text, the resolution encourages the Ombudsman to strengthen his channels of communication and improve the information of European citizens so that they are properly informed about the Ombudsman's services and scope of responsibility.

name: Liadh NÍ RIADA
text: scríofa. — Cé go raibh mé buartha faoi ghnéithe áirithe den tuarascáil seo, chaith mise vóta i bhfabhar Thuarascáil Bhliantúil an Ombudsman 2013, mar aithním an sár-obair atá ar bun ag Emily O’Reilly agus í mar Ombudsman agus chun a chur in iúl go bhfuil muinín agamsa aisti don téarma atá romhainn. Aontaím leis an tuarascáil sa chaoi go gcuirtear béim ar thábhacht na follasachta agus an dea-chleachtais laistigh d’Institiúidí na hEorpa. Ba chóir go mbeadh na prionsabail seo mar dearbhthosaíocht i gcónaí. Ba chúis buartha é áfach go raibh 64.3% de na gearáin a fuair an oifig sin aici bainteach leis an gCoimisiún Eorpach. Is cúis aiféala go bhfuair a hoifig an méid sin gearán maidir le droch-chleachtas. Measaim go raibh an rapóirtéir lag go leor i leith an Choimisiúin agus gur sheas sé leis maidir leis an méid gearán a tháinig isteach faoi. Mar aon leis sin, ceapaim go raibh sé lag maidir le Frontex agus is beag rud a thagair don ‘revolving door’ agus do chásanna coinbhleachta in Institiúidí AE.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which provides a positive assessment of the European Ombudsman's activity in 2013. This report highlights the problems of transparency within the European Commission, and in particular the opacity of the transatlantic treaty negotiations, conflicts of interest among senior officials and issues of ethics or fundamental rights.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. — I supported the Ombudsman's annual report. The Ombudsman has cooperated well with the European Parliament, strengthened the accountability and transparency of structures and institutions at European level and thereby promoted good administration.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. — I agree with the report submitted by the Ombudsman. The European Ombudsman plays a key role in addressing citizens' issues, helping to fill major gaps between them and the EU institutions and preventing conflicts. The Ombudsman shall act independently and impartially. It represents the common interests of the EU and its citizens. In view of this and the current state of the EU, it is appropriate for the Ombudsman to initiate an inquiry into compliance with the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union, as well as a possible conflict of interest between the Commission in relation to its role in the Troika and the possible conflict of interest of the ECB in relation to his technical adviser as a troika adviser. In view of the number of complaints received, I believe that the posts of regional ombudsmen should not be abolished, as the opportunities for European citizens to exercise their rights effectively would be restricted. In order to make public governance more open, responsible and flexible, all Union institutions and bodies need to work more closely with the Ombudsman to ensure that his recommendations are followed, as well as to respond appropriately and in a timely manner to critical remarks. In view of the functions of the European Parliament's Committee on Petitions, I support the proposal that more resources should be allocated.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. — Considering that the annual report on the Activities of the European Ombudsman in 2013 was amended to reflect the desire to make the institution of the Ombudsman as user-friendly and user-friendly as possible, given that when presenting his annual report to the Committee on Petitions, the Ombudsman outlined his new strategy "Towards 2019", which strategy is based on three main concepts Impact , Relevance and Visibility, given that on the basis of these concepts, the Ombudsman aims to conduct more strategic inquiries into systemic problems (Impact), to strengthen the Ombudsman's role by actively contributing to key EU discussions (Relevance), and to increase the visibility of his institution by improving its openness to stakeholders and by highlighting and drawing the public's attention to important cases (Visibility) For these reasons, I am voting in favour.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. — Only 23,245 citizens were used by the Ombudsman's services in 2013. The European institutions do not work to the next perfectest, this shows that citizens do not see the point of calling on the Ombudsman. It is therefore an institution that is far too expensive for its usefulness. Nevertheless, this is one of the few remedies against the Commission, the main focus of the complaints. That is why, not wanting to endorse this costly system or deprive people of a relay that carries their voice, I abstain.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. — I support a report by fellow MEP Jaroslaw Walesa approving the European Ombudsman's Annual Report on Action in 2013 and joining mrs Emily O'Reilly's congratulations on her first annual report since she took office.  Given that the issue of transparency ranks first in investigations concluded by the Ombudsman's Office (64.3 %) and that a significant increase was found (52.7 %) compared to 2012. Year, we can conclude that transparency is a priority for EU citizens.  To strengthen public confidence in the political system and the EU institutions, transparency needs to be placed at the high priority of all EU institutions, as this continuously strengthens their democratic legitimacy. Citizens have recognised the European Ombudsman as an impartial and independent body investigating their complaints about the work of EU institutions, services and agencies. In my view, the European Ombudsman's action contributes to establishing a dialogue that builds citizens' trust and achieves the highest standards of action in the institutions. By eliminating irregularities in the work of officials and preventing mismanagement, we are improving the quality level of EU administration.  I support the "Meet 2019" Strategy and continued cooperation within the European Network of Ombuds Ombuds workers, as I think it is important to share experiences and best practices and maintain regular contacts of the European Ombudsman with Ombudswomans in Member States and accession countries.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. — The current European Ombudsman, Emily O'Reilly, was elected by the European Parliament in July 2013 but was sworn in, as usual, on 30 September. It is therefore clear that the annual report we are voting on can only relate to the work of his predecessor in office, Nikiforos Diamandouros. In my opinion, the report is clear, but it could be improved to make it more and more comprehensive. The issues covered in 2013 are of absolute importance, such as transparency, ethical issues, citizens' participation in EU decision-making, EU-funded projects and programmes and fundamental rights. I also welcome the new 'Towards 2019' strategy, the main and most important of which are: Impact, where the Ombudsman intends to make more strategic inquiries into systemic issues, Relevance, strengthens the role of the Ombudsman by actively contributing to key EU discussions and Visibility, namely increasing the visibility of his institution where he draws the public's attention to important cases.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. — The European Ombudsman is an essential institutional cog in ensuring the rule of law in Europe. Through it, citizens have direct access to legal channels when they consider themselves disadvantaged in relation to the administration of the European Union. In this respect, I welcome the immense work of the European Ombudsman, as well as some of the elements brought by his report, such as greater transparency in the European administration and in the negotiations on the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. — The European Ombudsman submitted to Parliament, in accordance with Article 220 of the Rules of Procedure of the European Parliament, the report on its activities in 2013. I note that transparency problems once again lead the list of cases dealt with in 2013, together with issues of ethics, citizens' participation in the decision-making process in the Union, fundamental rights and the culture of service. I welcome the ombudsman's new strategy, Rumo 2019, which is based on three main concepts: Impact, Relevance and Visibility and the publication of a new version of the European Code of Good Administrative Conduct and i also welcome the opening of the inquiry into the lack of transparency in the negotiations on the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP) , as well as Emily O'Reilly's aspiration to make the Ombudsman's institution as accessible as possible. I voted in favour.

name: Robert ROCHEFORT
text: In writing. "I voted in favour of the resolution on the Ombudsman's report. Mediation plays an essential role in our societies, and the establishment of a European Ombudsman was a good thing: citizens, businesses, must be able to uncover possible cases of maladministration on the part of EU institutions and agencies. This annual report has the merit of providing us with valuable information on the urgent need to improve in order to be more effective and closer to the expectations of citizens and businesses, including by respecting procedures, removing discrimination, or introducing more transparency into the European policy-making process. Beyond this report, it is all the work of the European Ombudsman on which we speak: more than twenty thousand complaints were lodged with his services in 2013, not to mention the investigations opened on his own initiative. Some of the points raised should prompt us to sweep our doors, such as the suspected cases of former European officials who hold positions in the private sector in their area of expertise and could thus face potential conflicts of interest.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report on the activities of the European Ombudsman in 2013, which validates the good management of Nikiforos Diamandouros, outgoing European Ombudsman, and Emily O'Reilly, the first woman elected to the post in July 2013.  In 2013, 23,245 citizens requested the assistance of the Ombudsman's services, 350 investigations were initiated and another 461 were completed. I would like to highlight some important investigations initiated by the Ombudsman, such as those relating to transparency in the TIC negotiations, whistleblowing in the EU institutions, transparency in Commission expert groups, cases of 'revolving doors', fundamental rights in cohesion policy or the European Citizens' Initiative. The Ombudsman contributes to her work to strengthen the structures and institutions of accountability and transparency at European level, to promote good administration for all EU citizens and residents and to improve the quality of democracy in the EU, developing an essential role in managing citizens' concerns.

name: Teresa RODRIGUEZ-RUBIO
text: in writing. - We voted abstention. We can greet the work carried out by the Ombudsman and support any changes leading to improving the effectiveness, efficiency and impact of her fundamental work. However, it abstains when voting on this resolution because it understands that the Ombudsman's task with regard to the audit of transparency processes must be able to be carried out without limitation and must be enforceable to the institutions themselves. The Ombudsman must not only be able to access more information and documentation than that provided by the Commission, but must be able to access 'all the information' of the ongoing negotiations, so as to ensure that both the form and content of the negotiations do not infringe the legality or infringe on the rights of citizens. The Ombudsman should place particular emphasis on investigating and being able to act against troika-driven austerity policies, both from a formal point of view (as they violate any process of legitimate foundation of them) and from the point of view of their impact on guaranteeing the economic and social rights of Europeans and Europeans.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of presenting the European Ombudsman's Annual Report for 2013 and I congratulate Emily O'Reilly on her approach to maintaining cooperation and positive working relations with Parliament. I also pay tribute to Professor Nikiforos Diamandouros, who left office in 2013 for his legacy as European Ombudsman. I believe that the noble function of Ombudsman must be based on supporting the strengthening of structures and institutions of accountability and transparency at European level, promoting the good administration and quality of democracy that European citizens deserve, because they are the ones to do their work. A final word of appreciation for the Ombudsman's new strategy towards 2019, based on three main pillars aimed at solving systemic problems, under the trilogue of Impact, Relevance and Visibility; finally, I would just like to welcome the importance of the European Citizens' Initiative, which will give citizens greater direct involvement in the decision-making process related to the preparation of European legislation.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. "I voted in favour of this report in order to highlight the work done by the European Ombudsman in the first year of taking office.  This text reminds us that the subject of transparency is at the top of the investigations carried out by the Ombudsman (it represents 64.3% of the surveys). The lack of transparency in the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP) negotiations was one of these surveys.  Finally, it should be noted that it is important that each body or institution of the European Union takes into account the Ombudsman's remarks and reacts quickly. To do so, the Ombudsman must continue his efforts to communicate with European citizens.

name: Matteo SALVINI
text: in writing. - (IT) I have chosen to vote against because the text mentions the fact that in 2013 the Ombudsman presented a special report on the absence of a mechanism in the Frontex agency to deal with complaints about alleged violations of the rights of asylum seekers. The Lega Nord is aware of the limitations of Frontex, but believes that they are certainly not those of the absence of a mechanism to which immigrants should appeal.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. — We voted abstention. We can greet the work carried out by the Ombudsman and support any changes leading to improving the effectiveness, efficiency and impact of her fundamental work. However, it abstains when voting on this resolution because it understands that the Ombudsman's task with regard to the audit of transparency processes must be able to be carried out without limitation and must be enforceable to the institutions themselves. The Ombudsman must not only be able to access more information and documentation than that provided by the Commission, but must be able to access 'all the information' of the ongoing negotiations, so as to ensure that both the form and content of the negotiations do not infringe the legality or infringe on the rights of citizens. The Ombudsman should place particular emphasis on investigating and being able to act against troika-driven austerity policies, both from a formal point of view (as they violate any process of legitimate foundation of them) and from the point of view of their impact on guaranteeing the economic and social rights of Europeans and Europeans.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. — The democratic shortcomings of the European Union are an integral part of its project to reformulate the policy and economy of the Member States. The presence of an Ombudsman does not alter this situation, but it allows at least a small control of the activity of the European institutions.  At the time of the report, the Ombudsman investigated such sensitive and opaque issues as the violation of the human rights of migrants in Frontex, the lack of transparency in the activity of the European institutions, including their negotiation of the ATCI, or the system of 'revolving doors'. The report values this activity and calls for a deepening of the citizen participation and democratic scrutiny of the European institutions, so I voted in favour.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. — Today I voted in support of the report on the activities of the European Ombudsman 2013.  The European Ombudsman, Emily O’Reilly, was elected by the European Parliament on 3 July 2013 and took her oath before the Court of Justice of the European Union on 30 September. The Ombudsman’s Annual Report 2013 therefore covers partly the work of the Ombudsman’s Office under her leadership and the other part consists of the work of her predecessor Nikiforos Diamandouros. The Ombudsman’s strategy ‘Towards 2019’ is founded on three main concepts: impact, relevance and visibility. In addition, observing the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership negotiations closely would strengthen the role of the Ombudsman as ‘guardian of EU transparency’.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. — I believe that the Ombudsperson's work so far demonstrates her willingness to work towards increasing the transparency and openness of the Institutions of the European Union. The report presented clearly points to concrete steps taken to close the gap between citizens and institutions, which consequently leads to an increase in the quality of democracy in the European Union. The report said that in 2013 23,245 citizens sought help from the Ombudsman's Office and 19,418 received advice. Also, in 2013, the Ombudsman's Office opened 350 investigations, with the main topics being transparency in the Institutions of the European Union, ethical issues, citizens' participation in the decision-making process, but also issues related to projects and programmes financed by the European Union. I support the Ombudsperson in her efforts to increase transparency in the NEGOTIATIONS on trade and investment between the US and the EU. Namely, it is an Agreement that will affect the lives of citizens of the European Union. It is of great importance to bring the negotiation process closer to the citizens, which the Ombudsperson encouraged with her efforts.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: writing — First of all, I would like to congratulate Emily O'Reilly on her first annual report as Ombudsman. I appreciate her efforts to maintain positive relations and cooperation with the European Parliament, and I firmly believe that in future cooperation with the European Parliament and the other institutions will only increase. I also support her efforts to strengthen structures and institutions in order to increase transparency in the EU and improve governance, as well as to improve the quality of democracy.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. — I welcome the approval of the annual report, taking into account that the Ombudsman's top priority is to ensure that citizens' rights are fully respected and that the right to good administration reflects the highest standards, the application of which is expected of the Union institutions, bodies, offices and agencies. The European Ombudsman plays a key role in helping the European institutions become more open, efficient and citizen-friendly, in order to strengthen citizens' trust in the Union, and in 2013 23,245 citizens sought help from the Ombudsman's Office. Following the instructions on the Ombudsman's website as part of the interactive guide, 19,418 citizens received advice. 1,407 requests related to information, 2,420 requests were recorded as complaints (and in 2012 there were 2,442). In 2013, the Ombudsman's office took 2,354 actions in relation to complaints received. The investigations opened by the Ombudsman's Office in 2013 can identify the following main topics: transparency in the EU institutions, ethical issues, citizens' participation in the EU decision-making process, EU-funded projects and programmes, fundamental rights and a culture of services. Today, I would like to stress the importance of social media as a communication channel and encouraging the Ombudsman's Office to make greater use of this media in order to better familiarize citizens with their activities and promote the rights of EU citizens.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: writing — I voted in favour of adopting the annual report as I believe that Obmudsmanka O'Reilly is doing a good job in her capacity. Despite the relatively limited powers of the post, O'Reilly is trying to make the most of his office. I particularly welcome its 'Towards 2019' strategy, which is built on impact, relevance and visibility. It is precisely the lack of public awareness of the possibilities of obmudsman that I consider to be one of the biggest obstacles to the full realisation of its potential.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. — The Ombudsman must address matters relating to the EU institutions relating to the external and internal security of the member countries with particular attention and sensitivity.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of the European Ombudsman's 2013 Annual Report, which also includes the activities of the previous Ombudsman. In my opinion, the Ombudsman system is an important element of European democracy, the Hungarian equivalent of which has unfortunately been restricted. Since 2012, hungary has had one in place of the previous four Commissioners, and among the posts that have been abolished is the Data Protection Commissioner, the role of which has been taken over by an authority. I was pleased to see that the European Ombudsman also investigated cases relating to GMOs. I must note that a great deal of attention must be paid to this subject, as it is conceivable that cases on the subject may multiply in the future, even in the light of this week's new GMO Regulation. According to the report, most complaints were received in relation to EU projects. In my opinion, this is also a very serious form of organised crime, in which government figures are often involved. The fact that EU funds, which should make improvements in people's lives, are often used by criminal groups. This will cause deep and long-term harm to the whole community if these cases are not thoroughly investigated and properly punished. Let the Ombudsman system be a partner in this fight. I trust that the Ombudsman system will continue to pay due attention to these issues in the future.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. "I voted in favour of the conclusion of My Colleague Waleza's report. We approved the annual report on the Ombudsman. I regret, however, that the Ombudsman does not speak to the elected representatives after his election, but he has committed to reintroducing the practice of inviting the Ombudsman to the plenary immediately after the election.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. — I supported the 2013 European Ombudsman's Work Report, which contains positive results on dealing with citizens' complaints and responding to inquiries about their fundamental rights. I consider further efforts to strengthen the position of European Ombudsperson justified, as they will open up space for the defence of the rights of citizens, associations, companies and NGOs and a space for communication with the European institutions. I find particularly useful the new strategic steps from the "Towards 2019" programme, where under the "Visibility" strategy, all important institutional processes will seek to bring them closer to citizens. The new programme brings better cooperation with national authorities, in particular national ombuds ombuds workers, in order to make citizens legally eleased with the powers and services provided by the European Ombudsman in eu Member States.  I hope that the Ombudsperson will continue to work for the benefit of European citizens and point to cases of opaqueness and mismanagement of the Institutions and Bodies of the European Union in order to deal with citizens' complaints efficiently and as soon as possible.

name: Traian UNGUREANU
text: in writing. — It is welcome that, during her short term in 2013, Mrs Emily O'Reilly, the European Ombudsman, elected on 3 July 2013, had a remarkable job, making every effort to strengthen cooperation with the European Parliament, in particular the Committee on Petitions of that institution. The Ombudsman's annual report is a particularly useful tool, as it contains, inter alia, information on referrals by European citizens to matters relating to the misadministration of the institutions and bodies of the European Union. This is ultimately a real opportunity for the European institutions to be effective and really benefit European citizens. The European Ombudsman's 2013 annual report is concise and comprehensive. I believe, however, that, in future, this report should contain accurate figures as regards the percentage of complaints that are within and fall within the Ombudsman's competence. At the same time, a clear procedure is needed to monitor complaints transferred to other institutions or bodies in order to ensure that citizens' problems are dealt with impartially, fairly and within a reasonable period of time.

name: Viktor USPASKICH
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of the Annual Activity Report of the European Ombudsman and I believe that the work of the current Ombudsman is to be welcomed– not unnecessarily today the activity report was adopted by such a large margin of votes.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: in writing. — The Spanish Socialists voted in favour of the Ombudsman's 2013 activity report.  I would like to clarify that we voted against Amendments Nos 5.6 and 7 of the ECR Group because, although we share the need for an end to the troika, and the harmful effects of 'austericide' policies, the troika is not part of the Treaties of the Union and is therefore not under the supervision of the European Ombudsman. Eurosceptic parties want to weaken European institutions through demagoguery and that cannot be supported; that is why we voted negatively on these amendments. We demand greater transparency in the functioning of all institutions in order to build a socially committed, just and equal europe.

name: Marco VALLI
text: in writing. - (IT) I support the statement by the new Ombudsman, who has expressed his willingness to help strengthen the European institutions with regard to transparency, which must be at the top of the list of priorities, as well as ethical issues, citizens' participation in THE EU decision-making process, EU-funded projects and the culture of service. I firmly believe in the importance of the citizens' initiative as a new instrument that allows direct participation in the decision-making process during the drafting of European legislation and I support the various inquiries that the Ombudsman has initiated, such as the transparency investigations in the negotiations for a Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP), the reporting of wrongdoing by employees of the European institutions , transparency in the Commission's expert groups and the fundamental rights of cohesion policy.  In this direction, it is important to stress the fact that social media is increasingly a key issue at the communication level, which should be strengthened in order to raise public awareness of the activities of the European Ombudsman, while ensuring equal access to information for those who are excluded from this type of channel. For the reasons described, I therefore supported the report.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. — The democratic shortcomings of the European Union are an integral part of its project to reformulate the policy and economy of the Member States. The presence of an Ombudsman does not alter this situation, but it allows at least a small control of the activity of the European institutions.  At the time of the report, the Ombudsman investigated such sensitive and opaque issues as the violation of the human rights of migrants in Frontex, the lack of transparency in the activity of the European institutions, including their negotiation of the ATCI, or the system of 'revolving doors'. The report values this activity and calls for a deepening of the citizen participation and democratic scrutiny of the European institutions, so I voted in favour.

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the Ombudsman’s annual report as the main priority of the European Ombudsman is to ensure that citizens’ rights are fully respected and the right to good administration reflects the highest standards as expected of the institutions, bodies, offices and agencies of the Union.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. — The vast majority of open surveys (64.3%) european commission (a significant increase in 2012 accounted for 52.7%). This report endorses the 2013 Annual Report, welcomes the approach to maintaining cooperation and positive working relations with Parliament, in particular its Committee on Petitions. We believe that transparency, openness, access to information, respect for citizens' rights and high ethical values are essential to generate and maintain trust between citizens and residents and institutions. However, the report takes an apologising approach to the European Commission's action, trying to justify the large number of complaints received, with the same position on complaints relating to FRONTEX, TTIP and the issue of Revolving Doors (shifting public sector officials to private sector jobs closely linked to the functions they previously performed, and vice versa), which we strongly criticise.

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: in writing.  - I voted in favour of the report on the annual report on the activities of the European Ombudsman in 2013. As a rapporteur on this dossier, I would like to underline the fact that the year 2013 was a special one regarding the post of the European Ombudsman. Taking over office from a long-standing and well-respected Mr Nikifiros Diamandouros was definitely a great challenge for Ms Emily O’Reilly. Thanks to her experience as an Irish Ombudsman, the newly elected European Ombudsman started her work very efficiently from the very beginning of her mandate. Within just a few months, she was able to turn this institution into a more accessible and user-friendly one. I would like to welcome the Ombudsman’s important investigations, e.g. into the transparency of the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP) talks, whistleblowing in the EU institutions and ‘revolving door’ cases, which raise concerns that senior EU officials taking private sector jobs in their fields of expertise may be subject to conflicts of interest. It is also important to stress that the whole European Parliament demonstrated support for Ms O'Reilly when electing her for a new term in December 2014.

name: Janusz ZEMKE
text: I would like to write to the Commission. — I support the annual report on the Activities of the European Ombudsman in 2013. This is a solid document indicating that in 2013 23 245 citizens asked the Ombudsman for help, including 19 418 people received advice through an interactive guide, and 1 407 requests were informative. The Ombudsman treated complaints as complaints and dealt with 2 420 applications. It is worth noting that among these 2 420 complaints, the most were received from Spain (416), Germany (269) Polish (248). The main topics raised in the complaints concerned the lack of access to EU documents, objections to the procedure for the recruitment of EU officials and the lack of participation of citizens in the EU decision-making process. The European Ombudsman has intervened in a number of interventions in the EU institutions, in particular in the European Commission. I believe that the Ombudsman should strengthen his role by actively participating in key EU debates and by paying attention to important issues for the European public. Indeed, the Ombudsman's position will increasingly be due to his activity in the European forum and not only to dealing with his or her affairs.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. — The Ombudsman opened 350 inquiries, of which 341 were based on complaints and 9 inquiries on his own initiative. The vast majority (64.3 %) commission (a significant increase as they represented 52.7% in 2012). The EP rapporteur approves the Annual Report for 2013, welcomes the approach to maintaining cooperation and positive working relations with Parliament, in particular with its Committee on Petitions.  While i believe that transparency, openness, access to information, respect for citizens' rights and high ethical values are essential to generate and maintain trust between citizens and residents and institutions, there is a legalistic approach that covers up the action of institutions such as the European Commission (and the policy it pursues in the troika) or FRONTEX , which daily takes attention to the rights of migrants and refugees when deporising them to their countries of origin, policies that are at the heart of the action of these institutions and which do not happen for accidental reasons. Still, we voted for it.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of the Jarosław Wałęsa report on the European Ombudsman's activities for 2013, as the report is correct, presenting both the positive aspects of the Ombudsman's work and possible improvements. At the same time, I would like to draw attention to the shortcomings of the basic concept of the European Ombudsman, and the name of this institution unfortunately gives too much empty hope. The Ombudsman gives EU citizens the opportunity to complain about infringements by European institutions, but unfortunately many more infringements occur in member states' institutions. When state institutions violate human rights and the rule of law, EU citizens must contact the Council of Europe institution, the Strasbourg court. The EU cannot help them. I therefore believe that the EU must find a common language and, in the area of justice, to greatly strengthen cooperation, inter alia, so that the European Ombudsman can respond to many serious violations in the Member States. Thus, the EU will truly be founded on the values of democracy, equality, the rule of law and respect for human rights, as enshrined at the beginning of the EU Treaty.

name: Neena GILL
text: Mr President, I supported this resolution because I believe a sustainable solution to the crisis in Libya is long overdue and I sincerely hope that the new round of talks launched yesterday in Geneva will allow all major stakeholders to reach a sustainable agreement on political transition and bring an end to the appalling humanitarian crisis. However, I believe that just voicing our support is not enough. It is crucial that we start working on a coordinated EU strategy that will allow us to assist a future united Libyan Government in bringing back stability, especially as terrorist groups are increasingly finding a fertile breeding ground in Libya, posing a threat to citizens all over the world, including the EU.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: Mr President, I completely agree, and I voted for this resolution because of the statement that the solution must be political and not military, based on dialogue between all parties carried out through mediation by the UN and more involvement of the European Union, as the situation in Libya has a considerable influence on Europe’s security. We Europeans must step up our efforts to help stabilise the region; we must underline the need to implement a ceasefire and secure the withdrawal of forces; we must push for the establishment of a transitional government that is inclusive of all factions and tribes in order to prevent the spread of terrorism and to weaken and disarm local armed groups. The situation in Libya continues to deteriorate, violence is escalating and the territory is not under government control. Restoring stability in Libya will not be possible without broad-based reconciliation of the Libyans. This must be our goal.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: Mr President, I voted in favour of this resolution because, for me, the attacks on civilians that we are now seeing are unacceptable. Libya's long-term instability and numbers of immigrants have a major impact on the stability of the European Union, especially southern states. For me, it is important that Libya remains whole and that the European Union also makes a contribution to preventing the parties to the conflict from supplying arms to Libya.

name: Daniel HANNAN
text: Mr President, unremarked and unreported, the Libyan state is decomposing. We have all the classic ingredients of a failed state there – rival governments commanding rival structures, militiamen, closed airports – and it has all happened out of the media eye. It is a quite extraordinary thing: the way in which we seem capable of focusing only on one part of the world at any given time. It is as though we are controlled by that malicious demon of Descartes that dictates our reality by controlling our senses. I hope that the denouement in Libya has taught us the limits of our power. It was not long ago that the British and French Heads of Government were boasting about having averted catastrophe and put that country on the road to stability and democracy. If nothing else, maybe we will have been taught a lesson in modesty. There is a limit to what we can do outside our own area.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. "Libya is a virtually failed chaotic state. The Socialists and Democrats call on the EU to do everything it can to support stabilisation in Libya and UN-led talks in Geneva, to bring all factions together in the country and to end what could become a full-throttle civil war. It is essential that there be security in the country again in order to restore the process of democratic transition that the Libyan people need and mobilized for. I voted in favour of the Resolution on the situation in Libya because we cannot afford in Libya another scenario of war, suffering and destruction, which can lead to the disintegration of the country. We cannot allow the proliferation of weapons or the country to become a sanctuary for terrorist organizations. European and region security is under threat in Libya. The EU must contribute to UN-ordered intervention in the country, in cooperation with the African Union and the Arab League, to achieve security conditions and return to the democratic transition process.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. — The Resolution on the situation in Libya contains assertions with which we do not disagree and which, at this point, are obvious. Thus, it recalls that "there is no military solution to the current conflict" and supports the negotiations sponsored by the United Nations. However, I believe that Parliament's position should be more forceful and critical. The military solution is not admissible, but the text does not recall – let alone condemned – the fact that the current situation is also a consequence of NATO intervention, which not only failed to meet its stated objective, but contributed to the increase in violence and, in passing, destroyed Libyan state structures. On the other hand, I believe that support for the United Nations negotiations must accompany initiatives such as that promoted by neighbouring countries, mainly Algeria, to initiate a dialogue between rival factions, which, in fact, have created two parallel state structures. The shortcomings of the proposed resolution for the vote forced me to abstain in the vote.

name: Louis ALIOT
text: In writing. — The current high-voltage situation in Libya is largely the responsibility of European leaders who allowed internal conflicts to flourish after armed interventions to eliminate the leader of a country in civil war. France has shown rapid interference but without measuring its consequences, especially with regard to the development of radical Islam, which was previously contained. Therefore, I have spoken out against this resolution, which evades part of the reality of Libya's internal problems.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. — The deterioration of the situation in Libya, as well as the use of force, must not go unanswered on our part. The European Parliament must ensure that democracy is re-established in Libya. I therefore welcome the adoption of this motion for a resolution.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. — In 2011, the UN Security Council voted to establish a no-fly zone over Libya, which is embroered in a civil war between forces loyal to Colonel Khadafi and armed rebel groups, often backed by Qatar and Saudi Arabia. Far beyond the terms of the resolution, some Western countries have worked to overthrow Colonel Khadafi's Libyan government by providing material, financial and military assistance to armed rebel groups. The National Front denounced the foreseeable consequences of this assistance: proliferation of weapons in the region, reinforcement of radical Islamist armed groups, destabilization of the entire region. Four years later, these predictions proved to be accurate, so much so that France had to go to Mali to fight the same Islamists it had helped and armed in Libya.  I voted against this resolution which places the European Parliament in the role of the arsonist. It is too easy to condemn in statements of principle a situation that one has contributed to create.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. — I deplore the human rights abuses in Libya. I am concerned about the potential consequences of military intervention. In the light of recent human rights abuses, I support the principle of this motion, although I am unable to vote for it as a UKIP MEP because of the nature of the requests for Commission action, which has proved to be counterproductive in the past. Consequently, I felt that I had no choice but to abstain.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text because, in the aftermath of the military interventions of a few States in Libya, the situation in the country showed the shortcomings of European diplomacy. I call for a true comprehensive strategic vision of the diplomacy of the European Union.

name: Inés AYALA SENDER
text: in writing. "Libya is a virtually failed chaotic state. The Socialists and Democrats call on the EU to do everything it can to support stabilisation in Libya and UN-led talks in Geneva, to bring all factions together in the country and to end what could become a full-throttle civil war. It is essential that there be security in the country again in order to restore the process of democratic transition that the Libyan people need and mobilized for. I voted in favour of the Resolution on the situation in Libya because we cannot afford in Libya another scenario of war, suffering and destruction, which can lead to the disintegration of the country. We cannot allow the proliferation of weapons or the country to become a sanctuary for terrorist organizations. European and region security is under threat in Libya. The EU must contribute to UN-ordered intervention in the country, in cooperation with the African Union and the Arab League, to achieve security conditions and return to the democratic transition process.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. — Libya is now a country in chaos where civilians are the first victims of violence. The European Union must contribute, in coordination with the United Nations, to the stabilisation of the country, to the fight against the humanitarian crisis and to the relaunch of the democratic transition process.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. — The dramatic situation of violence in Libya needs to be denounced, but the United Nations-driven process needs to be supported in order for all parties to be required to accept the paralysis of military operations, as well as respect for unconditional ceasefire. But it is necessary to give all the support from the European Union and the international community in order for the process to move forward.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. After the Gaddafi regime and the aftermath of the Arab Spring, Libya is now in a situation of extreme instability. Two different governments coexist in Libya, one in Tripoli and one in Tobruk (from the 2014 elections) and the incessant wars continue to cause harm to the suffering civilian population and, in the end, find themselves less well off than during the previous regime. This situation is all the more disastrous because it leads thousands of Libyans to immigrate to Malta or Italy. The French intervention, at the time under President Sarkozy, to support the rebels against the regime in place has thus enabled today to finance Islamic terrorism and to encourage mass immigration to Europe, which no longer has the means to take in refugees.  This motion for a resolution sums up the paradox of the EU and the leaders of the system who are trying to make themselves aware while they are the instigators of the chaos that is currently taking place in Libya. So I voted against it.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. "Libya is a virtually failed chaotic state. The Socialists and Democrats call on the EU to do everything it can to support stabilisation in Libya and UN-led talks in Geneva, to bring all factions together in the country and to end what could become a full-throttle civil war. It is essential that there be security in the country again in order to restore the process of democratic transition that the Libyan people need and mobilized for. I voted in favour of the Resolution on the situation in Libya because we cannot afford in Libya another scenario of war, suffering and destruction, which can lead to the disintegration of the country. We cannot allow the proliferation of weapons or the country to become a sanctuary for terrorist organizations. European and region security is under threat in Libya. The EU must contribute to UN-ordered intervention in the country, in cooperation with the African Union and the Arab League, to achieve security conditions and return to the democratic transition process.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution, in which Parliament expresses its solidarity with libyan citizens and strongly condemns the recent military action and violence and human rights violations and abuses resulting from ongoing fighting and military operations. We express our deep concern about the suffering of libyan civilians and all the migrants and refugees who have been in a desperate situation in Libya. It is important to express concern about the impact of general insecurity and deteriorating governance in Libya on regional and European security. Fighting has spread dramatically, causing chaos, the deaths of many people and the destruction of strategic infrastructure. In addition, the proliferation of weapons, ammunition and explosives and the smuggling of weapons, which pose a threat to the population, the stability of Libya and the region, are also of concern. Parliament welcomes the fact that Tunisia has accepted some 1.5 million people. Libyan citizens who are fleeing violence and are asking the EU Tunisian Government to provide financial and logistical support to this task. We also call on the EU and the international community to provide additional humanitarian, financial and political assistance to address the humanitarian situation in Libya, internally displaced persons and refugees and citizens who are unable to access basic services.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: in writing. — The intensification of the violence we are witnessing on a daily basis in Libya hampers the international community's joint efforts to achieve a peaceful solution to the war and its dramatic repercussions, first and first and all the massive and constant violation of human rights, the growing extremist threat and the political instability of the entire North African region. The European Parliament reiterates that the efforts of the official Government of Tobruk, international diplomacy and UN mediation led by Special Representative Bernardino Léon support a transparent and inclusive political dialogue, the only instrument to try to initiate a credible democratic transition. There is no alternative to dialogue: the participation of all parties involved in Libya is the first, fundamental step towards a constructive peace process in the country. We therefore reiterate the need for an immediate ceasefire, and we support a renewed commitment to coordinate EU action, aid and cooperation from neighbouring countries and the United Nations. Once an agreement has been reached, we hope that real, united and effective action will be taken by the European security and defence policy in support of the Libyan people in ensuring unity, governability and stability. That is why I wholeheartedly support the motion for a resolution we are voting on today.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. "I voted against the motion for a resolution on the situation in Libya.  Indeed, the current collapse of this country is a direct consequence of the mad policy pursued by France and the European Union, to the trailer of the United States. Delivered to armed groups, one can question the very existence of a Libyan state, in view of the conditions laid down by public international law.  The motion for a resolution thus notes that the country "is in the grip of political infighting that has turned into a violent balance of power between two competing government bodies and many rival factions (...)  nationalist, Islamist, tribal and regionalist forces." The Islamic State is settling in Libya and parts of its territory have become terrorist sanctuaries. We are passively witnessing a "somalisation" of the region and sending our ministers with bags of rice would not change much.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. — I voted yes on the motion for resolution because I consider fundamental the EU’s actions to combat international terrorism and achieve a peaceful solution to the conflict in Libya.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. — In a proposal for a resolution containing no less than twenty "considerants", the European Parliament is concerned about the escalation of violence in Libya and paints a bleak picture of a country in partition and in the grip of a real civil war. All this would not have been possible without the scandalous operation of military interference involving France, the United Kingdom, Canada, the United States, and aiming to overthrow the regime of Muammar Gaddafi. The European Union behaved like a real arsonist fireman and blew on the embers of the division, mechanically driving the rise of Islamist jihadism. Today, the Islamic State is preparing the development of local branches in the east of the country, Christians are abducted and massacred, the borders are no longer controlled thus facilitating the illegal migration of sub-Saharans. True to this maxim that "no one can avail himself of his own turpitude", I have of course voted against this draft resolution in order to deny the European Union any legitimacy to express himself on this subject.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. — The European Parliament's motion for a resolution on the dramatic situation in Libya, which has seen a successive series of political, institutional and security crises since Gaddafi's fall in 2011, wishes to draw attention to the recent events of the abduction of 20 Egyptian Christians and the violence of dozens of formed militias that have spiralled out of control. Unfortunately, the aspirations of the Libyan people, which arose after the 2011 Revolution, have been replaced by a vacuum of power and this situation has given rise to several militias running their own territories, and successive governments in Tripoli can barely impose their authority. Some of the dramas taking place in the Mediterranean, such as the proliferation of human trafficking in clandestine networks and where entire vessels with migrants are abandoned by initial crews, have their source in both the wars in Syria and Iraq and Libya's inability to control its borders. This call to the international community underlines once again that there is an imminent danger due to terrorist bases developing in Libya, both over the surrounding countries and on Europe.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. — Abstention: the solution to the present conflict cannot be military; it reiterates its condemnation of the military intervention in Libya in 2011, which led to the current situation of chaos and violence.

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: in writing. — The Libyan crisis, the result of violent internal political infighting, risks destabilising the entire region in the near future, both because of its humanitarian dimension and because of the increased risk of terrorism, as warned to the UN Security Council by Hiroute Guebre Sellessie, the UN Special Envoy for the Sahel region. I support the European Union's humanitarian, financial and political support for the Libyan people to build a stable and prosperous democratic state, in line with the commitments made in the Neighbourhood Policies with regard to the southern Mediterranean.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: in writing. "Libya is a virtually failed chaotic state. The Socialists and Democrats call on the EU to do everything it can to support stabilisation in Libya and UN-led talks in Geneva, to bring all factions together in the country and to end what could become a full-throttle civil war. It is essential that there be security in the country again in order to restore the process of democratic transition that the Libyan people need and mobilized for. I voted in favour of the Resolution on the situation in Libya because we cannot afford in Libya another scenario of war, suffering and destruction, which can lead to the disintegration of the country. We cannot allow the proliferation of weapons or the country to become a sanctuary for terrorist organizations. European and region security is under threat in Libya. The EU must contribute to UN-ordered intervention in the country, in cooperation with the African Union and the Arab League, to achieve security conditions and return to the democratic transition process.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. — The escalation of violence in Libya is a serious concern for the European Union. It is a real civil war there. Indeed, the country is now in the hands of militias of ex-rebels who are fighting for the territories. The conflict has also facilitated the establishment of terrorist groups such as the Islamic State. This poses a threat not only to the region but also to the European Union. I voted in favour of this resolution, which calls for targeted and strong sanctions against the Libyan leaders responsible for the violence.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. — (IT) Today I voted in favour of the resolution on the situation in Libya to call on the EU to step up its efforts to improve the conditions of a country that is becoming a non-state.  Bloody chaos in Tripoli, Benghazi and other Libyan cities in recent months has led to serious human rights violations, including indiscriminate attacks on civilians and the forced displacement of some 290,000 people inside the country, resulting in the flight of more than 100,000 citizens forced to flee to neighbouring countries. The second round of talks that took place in Geneva between Libyan factions had no tangible results, not least because key interlocutors such as the Islamists of the Libyan Dawn Coalition (Fajir) and the Misurata brigades did not participate in the discussions. The negotiations will only give rise to a government of national unity if it can count on broad support. I therefore call on the UN Special Envoy for Libya, Bernardino Leon, to extend participation in the talks, involving all the war-fighting parties.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. — The ever-worsening situation in Libya clearly shows us that the EU needs to assist Libya much more. Conflict resolution in Libya is first and foremost beneficial for the population at large as it will curb the ever-escalating violence and foster national unity. It is also beneficial for European states as large numbers of irregular immigrants start their journey into Europe from Libya. Peace and prosperity in Libya is best for all.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. — (IT) The political response in the case of Libya must involve moderate Islam in particular: a fundamentalist drift would be too dangerous for our security as a continent, especially after the very serious attacks on French.

name: Aymeric CHAUPRADE
text: In writing. "I voted against this resolution which proves once again that the European Union suffers from arsonist fireman's syndrome. MePs are surprised by the serious situation of civil war in Libya after supporting the country's destabilizing actions: the military intervention by the French, British, American and Canadian armed forces under the patronage of NATO is at the origin of the strengthening of terrorist groups in this part of the world. Therefore, I could not vote in favour of this text which calls for further interference by the European Union in the area: the arsonist is not sent to put out the fire he himself has caused.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. — (IT) The echo of the shootings in Libya is clear and distinguishable to our coasts, through the boats of migrants, endangering our security and the lives of these same people. The southern shore of the Mediterranean is a powder keg, and Libya, in spite of itself, is doing its part in making the situation incandescent. I voted in favour of this resolution in the hope that a solution will soon be found, in the interests of all. It remains the bitterness of knowing that this resolution is in addition to the rivers of ink already spilled and that it will not be able to make a real contribution, but within the limits of the powers of the European Parliament it is an absolutely due act.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. — I agree with the dramatic nature of the situation in Libya (2 governments, 2 armies) and the evidence that there is no military solution to the conflict. I support the pressure from the High Representative, who, on behalf of the EU, is passing on the message that this is the last chance for a negotiated and peaceful solution under the aegis of the UN. I agree with the suggestion that the African Union and the Arab League should be invited to play a more active and constructive role. I support specific sanctions, including the freezing of assets and the travel ban, against those responsible for armed violence and human rights abuses and violations, and the boycott of negotiations under the aegis of the UN. I also share the growing concern about the growing presence of terrorist groups linked to al-Qaeda or the militias of the self-designated Islamic State and other extremist organizations and movements in Libya.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution because Today Libya is a country torn apart by heavy armed clashes between militias of opposing factions and government forces. In the meantime, there have been suicide bombings and kidnappings of Westerners. Furthermore, the presence of Isis is very strong and is proving to be a real threat to European territory. I believe that europe needs an active presence in order to initiate and encourage all possible forms of dialogue that can promote a democratic and peaceful solution to the conflict. Furthermore, we must not forget that border control is absent in Libya and so the flow of illegal immigrants to European, especially Italian, coasts does not seem to have an end. Considering the situation in Libya, those arriving on our shores may no longer be just a 'refugee' trying to save their lives, but there could be possible infiltration of terrorist cells, which should be averted through a constant commitment by the European institutions.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. — I express my solidarity with the Libyan people and I am deeply concerned over the suffering of the civilian population in Libya. The ongoing fighting perpetuates the serious violation of human rights and causes a dramatic escalation of violence. Libya is in chaos, and this poses a risk to the stability of the entire region. The EU must clearly condemn all those who are responsible for violence and selective killings, kidnappings, torture and other grave human rights violations against civilians. There is an urgent need to find a negotiated political solution with the formation of a united and inclusive government, so the EU must continue to support the UNSM to move forward with the Ghadames process, which can bring the parties in the conflict together in an exclusive national dialogue. The EU has to assist Libya in building national dialogue, and the Member States must support Libya in state-building, institution-building and the reform of the justice system. The EU must assist Libya in resuming a democratic transition which promotes the rule of law and the protection of human rights.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. — (IT) The Libyan crisis is becoming increasingly critical because of the serious internal polarization and the continuing spiral of violence. Successive governments failed to rein in the armed militias that had filled the vacuum caused by the ouster of Gaddafi's government in 2011. There are serious violations of human rights and international humanitarian law on a daily basis, with disastrous consequences for civilians. The Libyan outbreak is the cause of much of the migratory flows. Solving the problem must be a priority for this Europe that acts only and always in emergency situations.   I am voting in favour of this resolution because the European Union must do everything in its power to help put an end to the violence in Libya and to place the perpetrators of these atrocities to its responsibilities, including by condemning the recent episodes of violence that undermine the prospects for a negotiated solution. The protection of civilians must be a priority, Libya cannot continue to sink into blood.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. — The Resolution on the situation in Libya contains assertions with which we do not disagree and which, at this point, are obvious. Thus, it recalls that "there is no military solution to the current conflict" and supports the negotiations sponsored by the United Nations. However, I believe that Parliament's position should be more forceful and critical. The military solution is not admissible, but the text does not recall – let alone condemned – the fact that the current situation is also a consequence of NATO intervention, which not only failed to meet its stated objective, but contributed to the increase in violence and, in passing, destroyed Libyan state structures. On the other hand, I believe that support for the United Nations negotiations must accompany initiatives such as that promoted by neighbouring countries, mainly Algeria, to initiate a dialogue between rival factions, which, in fact, have created two parallel state structures. The shortcomings of the proposed resolution for the vote forced me to abstain in the vote.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: in writing. — Four years after taking to the streets for dignity, freedom and democracy and the tragic experience of state repression which ultimately led to the ousting of the Gaddafi regime, Libyans find themselves today in a country characterised by political division and violence, with the risk of further escalation to an outright civil war. The intensification of the crisis has heavily affected the population, with civilian suffering, casualties, mass displacement and a spreading humanitarian crisis. The UN-brokered talks in Geneva represent a last chance. All parties to the conflict are called upon to make the only possible step for peace: that of freezing all military operations as proposed by UN Special Representative Leon in order to create an inclusive environment conducive to maximum restraint, national dialogue and reconciliation. There is no military solution to the current conflict, and an unconditional ceasefire is the only possible response to the suffering of the Libyan population. The European Union stands ready to provide the necessary support. It is the last opportunity for peace. This is the rationale of this week’s new round of political dialogue scheduled to take place in Geneva. This is the call the European Parliament makes by adopting this resolution.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. — Following the last resolution voted in plenary on 17 September 2014, this new resolution addresses the worsening of the situation in the country, supports the UN-led mediation efforts deployed by UNSG special representative Bernardino Leon and calls on neighbouring countries to refrain from actions. It also calls for a political dialogue and a solution to seek de-escalation and peace and for further humanitarian, financial and political assistance. These were also points which I proposed in my intervention during the plenary debate, where I also welcomed the support being extended to Malta’s proposal for a UN-authorised peacekeeping mission in Libya. Hence I voted in favour of this report.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. The political and security situation in Libya is worrying and requires a quick and lasting response. That is why I voted for the European Parliament's resolution calling on all parties to conclude a ceasefire and affirming its support for the UN mission in Libya. This Libyan crisis is primarily a tragedy for Libyans themselves and poses a threat not only to the stability of the region but also to European security. In addition, we must remain particularly attentive to the case of religious minorities, including Christians, who have recently been abducted by members of the Ansar al-Sharia militia. In addition, I voted on an amendment to call on multinational companies to refrain from entering into transactions involving Libyan oil that could finance the militias and asking European companies operating in Libya to disclose their financial transactions in the energy sector.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
