text: in writing. — In the light of recent events, I express my solidarity with the Libyan people and am against acts of violence and serious human rights violations in the context of the European Union's strong commitment to the protection of Libya's unity and territorial integrity, and I hope that a solution will be found to defuse the growing political crisis in Libya.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: in writing. — Less than four years after the NATO intervention which led to the removal of leader Muammar Gaddafi, the situation in Libya does not seem to show any signs of improvement. I supported this motion for a resolution because I believe it is necessary to find a solution to the conflict between the various parties fighting for power on Libyan territory.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: In writing. — The conflict between militias and armies in Libya is extremely worrying.  This deleterious climate that has allowed the proliferation of terrorist groups and extremist movements threatens not only the stability of the region but beyond, all countries today facing terrorism. We must avoid the exacerbation of this violence and put an end to the spread of the conflict especially towards the Sahel, an extremely sensitive area that experiences dangerous trafficking including that of arms.  The EU must adopt targeted sanctions against all those responsible for armed violence and human rights violations. The sanctions must also target leaders of armed groups who boycott UN-led negotiations and undermine the peace process. It must also work to ensure that the parties to the conflict immediately agree to the freezing of military operations in order to create an environment conducive to the exit from the crisis.  EEAS and national diplomacy must coordinate to address a critical humanitarian situation and help establish a democratic and stable state.  EUBAMLibye's mandate, currently suspended and transferred to Tunisia, must be reviewed to allow it to participate in a UN stabilization mission.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. — In 2011, the UN Security Council voted to establish a no-fly zone over Libya, which is embroered in a civil war between forces loyal to Colonel Khadafi and armed rebel groups, often backed by Qatar and Saudi Arabia. Far beyond the terms of the resolution, some Western countries have worked to overthrow Colonel Khadafi's Libyan government by providing material, financial and military assistance to armed rebel groups. At the time, the National Front denounced the foreseeable consequences of this assistance: the proliferation of weapons in the region, the strengthening of radical Islamist armed groups, and the destabilization of the entire region. Four years later, these predictions proved to be accurate, so much so that France had to go to Mali to fight the same Islamists it had helped and armed in Libya.  I voted against this resolution which places the European Parliament in the role of the arsonist. It is too easy to condemn in statements of principle a situation that one has contributed to create.

name: Pablo ECHENIQUE
text: in writing. —We abstained in the vote on the Resolution because, while it is true that the country's current situation in urging the parties to resolve the conflict peacefully condemns, it does not refer to the root causes of the conflict or to interference (NATO-sponsored France's intervention) as part of the problem.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. — NATO destroyed Libya. Libya was economically destroyed, suffered many property damage and counted many victims. It is therefore ironic that Europe, on the basis of neighbourhood policies, wants to help Libya ensure peace and order in the country.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. — Libya continues to face infighting in the face of a violent power struggle between two rival government offices and numerous competing factions of nationalist, Islamist, tribal and regional forces, causing an escalation of the suffering of the civilian population, deaths, mass displacement and a continuing humanitarian crisis. The latest wave of clashes has led to the internal displacement of at least 400,000 Libyans, and forced another 150,000 people, including many migrant workers, to leave the country, with an estimated more than one million Libyans already in Tunisia. I condemn this escalation of violence in Libya, in particular against civilians, by supporting un-mediated talks. It is essential that all parties involved in violent acts commit themselves to respecting an unconditional ceasefire and refraining from actions that generate new divisions.

name: Jonás FERNÁNDEZ
text: in writing. "Libya is a virtually failed chaotic state. The Socialists and Democrats call on the EU to do everything it can to support stabilisation in Libya and UN-led talks in Geneva, to bring all factions together in the country and to end what could become a full-throttle civil war. It is essential that there be security in the country again in order to restore the process of democratic transition that the Libyan people need and mobilized for. I voted in favour of the Resolution on the situation in Libya because we cannot afford in Libya another scenario of war, suffering and destruction, which can lead to the disintegration of the country. We cannot allow the proliferation of weapons or the country to become a sanctuary for terrorist organizations. European and region security is under threat in Libya. The EU must contribute to UN-ordered intervention in the country, in cooperation with the African Union and the Arab League, to achieve security conditions and return to the democratic transition process.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing — Libya is divided by the struggle between the secular and Islamist factions. The negotiations scheduled for next week are unlikely to resolve the deadlock in the country, which currently has two governments and two parliaments. The question mark also raises the benefits of NATO's Operation United Protector. Several figures show that more than 1000 civilians have already been killed in military operations. The international community must make greater efforts and strive to end the armed conflict between the internationally recognised government and parliament and the Islamists and their allies.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. — (IT) Nato's intervention has resulted in the deaths of innocent civilians, a humanitarian crisis and serious destruction, which have led to the complete destabilization of the Libyan State and an ongoing civil war. Libya is now completely unstable and the increasing violence has plunged Libya into a state of chaos and total war. Europe must assume its responsibilities.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. — NATO destroyed Libya. Libya was economically destroyed, suffered many property damage and counted many victims. It is therefore ironic that Europe, on the basis of neighbourhood policies, wants to help Libya ensure peace and order in the country. For these reasons my vote is against.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. "I voted in favour considering that, since the fall of Colonel Gaddafi, Libya has been going through great political instability and serious internal divisions, circumstances that have facilitated the growth of terrorist groups, seriously jeopardized the very security of the State. The growing humanitarian crisis and the political polarization of the conflict in Libya, which risks reaching the point of no return in dialogue between the parties to the conflict, are very worrying. Different Libyan factions must make every effort to re-conduct the situation and establish a roadmap leading to a ceasefire. The search for solutions through political dialogue is the only possible solution to the conflict. Reports showing that ISIS is training fighters in Libya and establishing a branch in the eastern part of the country are also of high concern, poseing a risk to the stability of the entire region. The international community must assist Libya in rebuilding the state as well as creating effective national forces that can ensure security, order and peace in the country, all of which are crucial elements for democratic governance.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: in writing. "Libya is a virtually failed chaotic state. The Socialists and Democrats call on the EU to do everything it can to support stabilisation in Libya and UN-led talks in Geneva, to bring all factions together in the country and to end what could become a full-throttle civil war. It is essential that there be security in the country again in order to restore the process of democratic transition that the Libyan people need and mobilized for. I voted in favour of the Resolution on the situation in Libya because we cannot afford in Libya another scenario of war, suffering and destruction, which can lead to the disintegration of the country. We cannot allow the proliferation of weapons or the country to become a sanctuary for terrorist organizations. European and region security is under threat in Libya. The EU must contribute to UN-ordered intervention in the country, in cooperation with the African Union and the Arab League, to achieve security conditions and return to the democratic transition process.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: in writing. "Libya is a virtually failed chaotic state. The Socialists and Democrats call on the EU to do everything it can to support stabilisation in Libya and UN-led talks in Geneva, to bring all factions together in the country and to end what could become a full-throttle civil war. It is essential that there be security in the country again in order to restore the process of democratic transition that the Libyan people need and mobilized for. I voted in favour of the Resolution on the situation in Libya because we cannot afford in Libya another scenario of war, suffering and destruction, which can lead to the disintegration of the country. We cannot allow the proliferation of weapons or the country to become a sanctuary for terrorist organizations. European and region security is under threat in Libya. The EU must contribute to UN-ordered intervention in the country, in cooperation with the African Union and the Arab League, to achieve security conditions and return to the democratic transition process.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: in writing. — (IT) I supported the motion for a resolution on the current situation in Libya in the light of the escalation of violence between armed groups, massive and systematic violations of human rights, the increase in the number of displaced persons, refugees and migrants seeking a safe haven on our coasts. The security of the entire region and of Mediterranean Europe cannot ignore the stability of a country so close to us that it is in danger of turning into a failed state. In this context, the European Parliament must support libya's legitimately elected House of Representatives and an inclusive national political dialogue process. We therefore declare our solidarity with the Libyan people

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. —We abstained in the vote on the Resolution because, while it is true that the country's current situation in urging the parties to resolve the conflict peacefully condemns, it does not refer to the root causes of the conflict or to interference (NATO-sponsored France's intervention) as part of the problem.

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: in writing. — I support this resolution of the European Parliament, as it appeals to political dialogue. All parties in Libya must commit to the protection of civilians at all times and to achieving peace that allows access to humanitarian and financial aid, as well as democratic stability in the country. In the Resolution we underline the EU's strong commitment to Libya's unity and territorial integrity, as well as the need to prevent the spread of terrorism. We also fully support the mediation efforts of the Special Representative of the Secretary-General of the United Nations, Bernardino León, to assist the Libyan people in the search for a negotiated solution to resolve the crisis and ensure unity, governance, stability and institution-building to achieve peace.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. — I voted in favour because I believe that there is a need to ensure accountability for all violations of human rights and international humanitarian law.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: in writing. "Libya is a virtually failed chaotic state. The Socialists and Democrats call on the EU to do everything it can to support stabilisation in Libya and UN-led talks in Geneva, to bring all factions together in the country and to end what could become a full-throttle civil war. It is essential that there be security in the country again in order to restore the process of democratic transition that the Libyan people need and mobilized for. I voted in favour of the Resolution on the situation in Libya because we cannot afford in Libya another scenario of war, suffering and destruction, which can lead to the disintegration of the country. We cannot allow the proliferation of weapons or the country to become a sanctuary for terrorist organizations. European and region security is under threat in Libya. The EU must contribute to UN-ordered intervention in the country, in cooperation with the African Union and the Arab League, to achieve security conditions and return to the democratic transition process.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. - We abstained in the vote on the Resolution because, while it is true that the country's current situation in urging the parties to resolve the conflict peacefully condemns, it does not refer to the root causes of the conflict or to interference (NATO-sponsored France's intervention) as part of the problem.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. — I voted for a resolution on the situation in Libya because it strongly condemns the escalation of violence in the country, which has a number of negative consequences, the worst of which is the taking of people's lives. Terrorist attacks by extremist organisations and movements that call into question the integrity of the Libyan state, but also the security of the entire region and Europe, are worrying. I support greater engagement between the European Union and the international community in countering terrorism in this area, which would ensure compliance with international law and stabilise a situation of great uncertainty. I therefore believe that it is necessary to support democratic processes in Libya, through political and financial support, in order to preserve the territorial integrity of the state and prevent the further spread of terrorism.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: in writing. — This week, the European Parliament voted on a motion for a resolution on the conflict in Libya in the context of the growing risk of the collapse of the basic functioning of the Libyan state. I voted in favour of this proposal because I consider it necessary for Parliament to draw attention to the deteriorating situation not only in this country, but also to the negative impact on the stability of the whole region, which is facing a dramatic increase in refugees and asylum seekers, the spread of terrorism and arms trafficking.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. "I voted in favour of the resolution on the situation in Libya. The text condemns the escalation of violence, particularly against civilians, and calls for an unconditional ceasefire between the various parties to the conflict. Parliament also supports Libya's official authorities following the June 2014 elections and calls on countries in the region to contribute to the peaceful resolution of the situation. The resolution was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. "I wanted to be a co-signer of the EPP resolution on the deteriorating security situation in Libya, which is bringing the country to the brink of implosion. The growing presence in Libya of al-Qaeda-linked terrorist groups, Islamic State-claiming militias and foreign fighters poses a very serious threat to the stability of the Maghreb and the Sahel region. It also poses a threat to security in Europe that should not be underestimated. For now, the EU must work to support a political settlement to the Libyan conflict. In addition, I particularly welcome the adoption of recital O and paragraph 14, which stress the persecution of Christians and the need for the EU to monitor the protection of the rights of religious minorities in bilateral agreements.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. — The situation for the Libyan people is exacerbated by the civil war, two rival parliaments in Tripoli and Tobruk and the war-torn factions of nationalists, Islamists, regionalists, various clans and tribes. All parties have committed human rights violations and sometimes even war crimes. 400 000 displaced persons and the political division of the country are leading to an escalation, which will increase the flow of refugees, exacerbate the suffering, strengthen terrorist organisations and shake political and economic stability. The situation seems deadlocked, neither side is talking to the other, and terrorist groups like ISIS and Al-Qaeda have already begun setting up bases. The European Parliament is taking the right step to condemn the escalation of violence and to call on all parties to accept a ceasefire. It is advisable to engage in dialogue and, if necessary, to push for it with targeted sanctions against those responsible. Stabilising Libya will help to reduce terrorist organisations and alleviate the plight of refugees in the Mediterranean. It is therefore also a question of The security of Europe, and that is why I support this motion for a resolution following an end to violence, a criminal investigation of human rights violations and a hard hand against terrorists.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. — I very much welcome the resolution calling on the EU to do its utmost to support stabilisation in Libya and for the UN-led talks in Geneva to bring together all factions in the country and halt what could become an all-out civil war. It is essential to bring back security within the country and to restore the democratic transition process, which is what the Libyan people are awaiting and yearning for.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: in writing. — The nine-month civil war, the intervention of external troops and the overthrow of the Gaddafi regime in 2011 have led to the chaos and destabilisation of Libya and the entire adjacent region. The libyan people's ambitions were thwarted by political division and violence, which gradually turned into an all-out civil war. The ill-conceived move to bomb the territory of Libya, which also involved some EU Member States, is now catching the eye. Apparently, no one has figured out how complicated the ethnic-tribal and religious situation represents a time bomb in this country and throughout the region. Whoever decided on this intervention should be punished in an international court. The lack of effective state power has led to an uncontrollable proliferation of weapons throughout the region, a rise in violence south of libya's borders. The instability of the whole region, the absence of a social system, the subverting of the economy and the vision of a better future have driven a growing wave of migration towards the EU, which we are facing with absolute disrepute and we are just looking at the growing tragedies. I must say that we have not learned anything from this situation, because even today there are calls on many sides for the deployment of armed forces from abroad to stabilise the situation. The motion for a joint resolution went a good way and contained, to a limited extent, fragments of the aforementioned criticism, but it still did not reflect sufficiently realistically the situation in this country, which is why I abstained.

name: Béla KOVÁCS
text: Writing. - The cynicism that the EU is now trying to resolve the situation in Libya, the crisis that looks intractable, is astonishing. Not to mention, meanwhile, that the once prosperous country has been bombarded with the current chaos by the air force of some EU countries, not to mention the EU being complicity in the brutal execution of a legitimate leader. All this, of course, was necessary for the dissemination of democracy. It could be a special democracy in which the country's oil has been in the hands of the multinationals, its gold reserves have disappeared, the civil war has been raging for three years, and thousands of refugees are heading to Europe. There is no shortage of good words now, the resolution argues against a military solution, calls for UN participation, action against terrorism, and therefore cannot be sosed, but cannot be supported, because it does not touch the root of the problems. It is interesting that the trampling of international law always only arises in other countries, not even by accident in the case of the EU.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: in writing. — (IT) The broad support of this House for the resolution is a reaffirmation of our full solidarity with the Libyan people.  The same people who took to the streets in 2011 to obtain civil and political rights and who in return obtained indiscriminate repression by the state. A people who are victims of al-Qaeda-linked terrorist groups, Islamic State militias and other extremist organisations and movements that are sowing terror and violence and are leading the country into destructive chaos.  In addition to the innocent victims of this war, there are the thousands of migrants and refugees fleeing the violence and persecution that have lost their lives in the Mediterranean in an attempt to reach Europe. And the millions of migrants located in neighboring countries, such as Tunisia, and in European territory, especially in Italy.  The work of international peace on an unconditional ceasefire must be supported without delay and a reconciliation process must be initiated with a view to bringing the rival groups together in an inclusive national political dialogue. The credibility of Europe and the international community as a whole is at stake.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. — (IT) I am voting in favour of the resolution proposed by My colleague, Mrs McKenna. Mr Gabriel called on the Eu ropean Union to implement, within a short time, sanctions aimed at preventing further armed violence, and human rights violations in Libya. I particularly agree with the reference to the need to support concrete actions, such as the freezing of assets against the perpetrators of terrorist acts, aimed at weakening their influence within the country. This strategy could also have positive effects on the migration phenomenon, which would undoubtedly be affected by the improvement in the situation in Libya.

name: Gabrielius LANDSBERGIS
text: Writing. — Although the failed Gaddafi regime was supposed to bring about change in Libya, political divisions and violence continue in the country. The political internal struggles between factions are undeniably a serious violation of human rights, outbreaks of violence leading to a humanitarian crisis. The tense situation in Libya threatens the countries of the region and European security. The EU must make every effort to stop the spread of terrorism to Libya and to resolve the conflict with the help of the international community at the negotiating table, as it is not possible to do so through military confrontation. The coordinated functioning of the EU External Relations Office and the United Nations organisation can therefore contribute to stabilising the situation in Libya. Especially when our communities, the EU Member State of Italy, are facing large flows of refugees and international terrorism has no borders. I fully support the solidarity expressed by the European Parliament for the Libyan people and support their desire to create a state based on democratic values that will contribute to the slow but ongoing stabilisation of the situation in the region.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. — Libya is moving towards a situation of chaos and total civil war. Unfortunately, this situation gives due reason to the analyses of the National Front, which from the beginning of the so-called "Arab Spring" warned of the dangers of a power grab by the Islamists, namely the dislocation of the country, the establishment of Sharia law and the disappearance of the Libyan state. Today we are seeing the establishment and strengthening in Libya of terrorist groups such as the Islamic State and Al Qaeda. This poses a serious threat to the security of the region and Europe. Another equally dramatic consequence is the explosion of illegal immigration to Europe and France, and its procession of human tragedies, particularly in the Mediterranean Sea. Incredibly, this joint resolution of the political groups in this Parliament is not self-critical, while the European Union, subservient in its foreign policy choices to the United States, has actively encouraged and supported the "Arab Spring" that has set Libya on fire.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. "I voted for this amendment because its purpose is to call on the international community to do everything possible to protect religious minorities in Libya, and in particular Christian minorities who are particularly victims of the serious unrest taking place there.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. "Libya is a virtually failed chaotic state. The Socialists and Democrats call on the EU to do everything it can to support stabilisation in Libya and UN-led talks in Geneva, to bring all factions together in the country and to end what could become a full-throttle civil war. It is essential that there be security in the country again in order to restore the process of democratic transition that the Libyan people need and mobilized for. I voted in favour of the Resolution on the situation in Libya because we cannot afford in Libya another scenario of war, suffering and destruction, which can lead to the disintegration of the country. We cannot allow the proliferation of weapons or the country to become a sanctuary for terrorist organizations. European and region security is under threat in Libya. The EU must contribute to UN-ordered intervention in the country, in cooperation with the African Union and the Arab League, to achieve security conditions and return to the democratic transition process.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: in writing. "Libya is a virtually failed chaotic state. The Socialists and Democrats call on the EU to do everything it can to support stabilisation in Libya and UN-led talks in Geneva, to bring all factions together in the country and to end what could become a full-throttle civil war. It is essential that there be security in the country again in order to restore the process of democratic transition that the Libyan people need and mobilized for. I voted in favour of the Resolution on the situation in Libya because we cannot afford in Libya another scenario of war, suffering and destruction, which can lead to the disintegration of the country. We cannot allow the proliferation of weapons or the country to become a sanctuary for terrorist organizations. European and region security is under threat in Libya. The EU must contribute to UN-ordered intervention in the country, in cooperation with the African Union and the Arab League, to achieve security conditions and return to the democratic transition process.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. — The Resolution on the situation in Libya contains assertions with which we do not disagree and which, at this point, are obvious. Thus, it recalls that "there is no military solution to the current conflict" and supports the negotiations sponsored by the United Nations. However, I believe that Parliament's position should be more forceful and critical. The military solution is not admissible, but the text does not recall – let alone condemned – the fact that the current situation is also a consequence of NATO intervention, which not only failed to meet its stated objective, but contributed to the increase in violence and, in passing, destroyed Libyan state structures. On the other hand, I believe that support for the United Nations negotiations must accompany initiatives such as that promoted by neighbouring countries, mainly Algeria, to initiate a dialogue between rival factions, which, in fact, have created two parallel state structures. The shortcomings of the proposed resolution for the vote forced me to abstain in the vote.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. — The current situation in Libya is caused by deep divisions between extremist groups and forces united with the Libyan Government. Continuing clashes between the two groups and the war have forced thousands of residents to leave the country and seek a home in one of the neighbouring countries or Europe.  Political division has also caused a deep economic crisis that has been compounded by the fall in the price of oil.   The European Union needs to provide strong support to Libya in its efforts to achieve a democratic and prosperous future. Strengthening extremism in any form poses a threat to all, so it is important that all actors contribute to the introduction of the rule of law and the development of a national dialogue.  I support this Resolution and hope to find a solution for Libya and the Middle East quickly.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. — In general, I voted in favour of the text of the resolution, as the situation in Libya is getting worse. The humanitarian crisis, thousands of refugees and orphans of children – this cannot be countered by the European Union or of some kind of help. Not to mention the atrocities carried out by the so-called 'Islamic State'. I abstained on the two amendments proposed by the other Members of the GUE/NGL Group because I could not vote against and thus disapprove of their thoughts on a certain nato responsibility for the current situation in Libya (2 and 3, amend. No 6), as well as with regard to the critical attitude towards the nato and British air strikes in 2011 (including the GUE/NGL amendment, recital A, amended. No 4). But in general, I supported my group's position.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. — I am voting in favour of the joint motion for a resolution because I believe that the Libyan people should be helped to fulfil their expectations of the creation of a democratic, stable and prosperous state, in accordance with the principles governing neighbourhood policies for the Southern Mediterranean.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution. I am deeply concerned by the increasing presence of al-Qaeda-linked terrorist groups, Islamic State militias and other extremist organisations and movements in Libya; I believe that the region risks ending in destructive chaos along the lines of what is happening in Syria and Iraq. I believe that these groups represent a major threat to the stability and security of the whole region, and also to the security of Europe. I welcome the fact that the resolution reaffirms the need to combat by all means – in accordance with the Charter of the United Nations and with international law, including applicable international human rights, refugee and humanitarian law – threats to international peace and security caused by terrorist acts.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. — The participation of all parties involved in Libya is the first and fundamental step towards a constructive peace process in the country.  There are serious violations of human rights and international humanitarian law on a daily basis, with disastrous consequences for civilians. Solving the problem must be a priority for the EU; we cannot continue to tolerate this wave of violence in Libya.

name: Jiří MAŠTÁLKA
text: Writing. - Chaos. This could one word mark the situation in Libya after the overthrow of Mohammad Gaddafi in 2011. This destabilisation has led to a proliferation of weapons throughout the region, a rise in violence south of the Libyan border. Social instability has led some of those who have lost hope to head north, to Europe. It's not just a growing migration wave that we don't know how to deal with. It may also be the cause of the horror recently warned by Pope Francis in the European Parliament – turning the Mediterranean into a cemetery. What ill-conceived strategy was behind the decision to bomb Libya? Did none of those responsible really know how difficult the ethnic and religious situation is in this country and in the region? Will no one really be punished for the tragedies he caused by his decision? Today we hear calls on many sides for armed forces from abroad to be deployed to stabilise the situation in Libya. There may be no other solution. However, I think we should listen carefully to those who want there to be no Europeans among these foreign soldiers. For african union troops to be needed. The African Union, the creation of which was initiated by Gaddafi. Although the draft common resolution contains some elements of this criticism, it does not reflect the situation in the country sufficiently real, which is why I abstained in the vote.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. — (IT) This resolution calls on the European Union to implement, within a short time, sanctions aimed at preventing the perpetration of further armed violence, and human rights violations, in Libya. I particularly agree with the reference to the need to support concrete actions, such as the freezing of assets against the perpetrators of terrorist acts, aimed at weakening their influence within the country. For all these reasons, I felt it necessary to express my agreement with this document.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. — Catastrophic conditions have been taking place in Libya since 2011. Violence and chaos have reigned since the fall of Gaddafi. The number of refugees from this country is appalling and is steadily increasing. In the first two quarters of 2014, 118,000 Libyan refugees were stranded in Europe. The number of refugees has doubled compared to 2013. Since strengthening Libya's democracy will ease this situation, I would have voted in favour of this report.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. — Libya is engaged in fighting between militias. Many civilians suffer abuses simply because of their tribal affiliation or for religious reasons. The extreme deterioration of living conditions forces hundreds of thousands of Libyans into exile. The resolution calls for a "political" solution to the ongoing conflict. But as is often the case, this text does not seek to establish any responsibility in the manufacture of this chaos. Not a word of NATO's intervention, which had exceeded the mandate of the United Nations (that of protecting the population) by bringing down the regime. Moreover, NATO is called to "cooperate" with the EU for "the creation of security forces" in the region. Nor is there a word about the control of natural resources and their current control by US and European firms. I am voting against this hypocritical text.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. — Since the fall of the Gaddafi regime, Libya has no longer found stability. Libya faces an escalation of fighting between armed groups, including attacks on civilians and private property, involving massive human rights violations.  I have to condemn the escalation of violence, especially directed against the population and civil institutions, the parties to the conflict must immediately put an end to all acts of violence and agree on a ceasefire in order to end the escalation of the suffering of the population and to initiate an inclusive national political dialogue, in order to create a State based on respect for human rights , democracy and the rule of law. It is in order to achieve this objective that the EU must make every effort.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution because it recognises the efforts of the UN Special Representative for Libya, Bernardino León, to initiate a political dialogue and secure an end to the conflict and instability. The resolution also calls on all sides involved in the violence to commit to an unconditional ceasefire, and on all political actors to participate in the UN’s talks in Geneva. The resolution references and recognises the regional destabilisation that has been caused by the conflict in Libya. One of the major repercussions of the conflict is the spiralling migration and refugee flow from North Africa, particularly from Libya. It is crucial that a political solution be reached between the key actors in the conflict, and this resolution clarifies Parliament’s position.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. I condemn in the strongest terms the escalation of violence in Libya and call on the parties to cease all hostilities in order to establish an inclusive political dialogue. In this regard, I reiterate my support for the Libyan institutions in place and call on them to act to enable the return to stability. In voting on this resolution, I support the civilian population and the mediation efforts of the Special Representative of the Secretary-General of the United Nations, Bernardino Leon, to ensure that human rights are respected and violence to end. I also call on the European Union and its Member States to act in a coordinated manner in order to provide an effective response to support institutions and to combat terrorist groups affiliated with Al-Qaeda and the Islamic State in the region.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. — I have co-signed and voted in favour of the joint motion for a resolution on Libya, which addresses the worsening of the situation in that country, supports the UN-led mediation efforts deployed by the UNSG special representative Bernardino Léon and calls on neighbouring countries to refrain from action. The resolution calls for political dialogue and a peaceful solution to seek de-escalation and peace, and for further humanitarian, financial and political assistance.

name: Sorin MOISĂ
text: in writing. — A Romanian citizen, Eduard Curduman, a sailor, fell victim to the conflict in Libya when a Libyan army missile was launched at his ship, located in the port of Derna, controlled by a rebel faction. This case shows how an area affected by a seemingly hopeless conflict can affect interests and citizens of any country around the globe. Any "no master" country, without "sovereign", is a space of risk, of unpredictability, a possible source of terrorism.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. — The political situation in Libya, after the so-called Arab Spring, has led to ongoing conflicts and violence that many already call civil war. The situation that opposes different factions and rival groups has led not only to an unprecedented humanitarian crisis in the country, but also to mass migration movements of Libyan citizens.  Currently, there is a real risk of a division of the country into three parts if a compromise is not reached between the parties involved in the conflict. An example of this is the emergence of two governments and two Parliaments in parallel. In addition, Tripoli and Benghazi are partly controlled by militias, with the confirmed presence of members of the Islamic State.  Among several other reasons, but above all for the reasons set out here, I support the UN Mission in Libya, and its efforts to reach a compromise and the immediate implementation of the sanctions already adopted by the Union. I believe it is essential for the Union to continue its humanitarian, financial and political aid and for Member States to support asylum seekers and refugees from Libya in every possible way.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. — In a proposal for a resolution containing no less than twenty "considerants", the European Parliament is concerned about the escalation of violence in Libya and paints a picture of a country in partition and subject to a real civil war. All this would not have been possible without the scandalous operation of military interference involving France, the United Kingdom, Canada, the United States, and aiming to overthrow the regime of Muammar Gaddafi. The European Union behaved like a real arsonist fireman and blew on the embers of the division, mechanically driving the rise of Islamist jihadism. Today, the Islamic State is preparing the development of local branches in the east of the country, Christians are abducted and massacred, the borders are no longer controlled thus facilitating the illegal migration of sub-Saharans. True to this maxim that "no one can avail himself of his own turpitude", I have of course voted against this draft resolution in order to deny the European Union any legitimacy to express himself on this subject.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. — I voted for the resolution as it is simply calling for a peaceful resolution of the on-going conflict in Libya.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of this text, which strongly condemns the recent abuses committed against civilians by the various Libyan political factions and welcomes the efforts of the United Nations to bring the warring parties together around the negotiating table. The text calls on the European Union to support joint peace efforts by the United Nations, the African Union and the League of Arab States, by punishing those responsible for the violence and by combating the development of terrorist movements on Libyan soil.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. — (IT) Today Libya is in a state of great chaos, with two different political authorities (only one democratically legitimised by national elections) and at the mercy of terrorists and other criminal groups. We strongly call for a cessation of all hostilities and for the parties involved to commit themselves to promoting constructive political dialogue at national level. We consider the role played by the UN Special Representative Bernadino Léon in promoting dialogue between the various warring factions in search of peaceful mediation of the conflict to be fundamental, and we deplore the unjustified postponement of the new round of peace negotiations that was set precisely for the beginning of January. We cannot underestimate the fact that armed violence and the lack of a single political authority, recognised by all sides, represent a serious danger not only to the stability of the entire region, but also to the security of Europe and all its neighbours. We therefore stress the need for joint diplomatic intervention by all the Member States, which have so far acted individually, under the aegis of our High Representative for Foreign Policy Federica Mogherini, who will certainly be able to play a key role in mediating the conflict.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. — I have recorded and voted on this resolution, which condemns the internal political struggles in Libya, which have arisen as a result of the fall of the Gaddafi regime, as the unity of the Libyan state is in danger, and there is a real risk of separation if a reconciliation process is not reached as soon as possible.  Unfortunately, also, disputes in the political plane are also reflected in the population, with several civilians, including Europeans, being killed in street fighting, but also in terrorist attacks. The resolution underlines the need for the 28 Member States to carry out joint and coordinated action under the supervision of the High Representative, together with the UN, NATO and various regional partners, to participate in the creation of security forces in the area to ensure peace and stability in Libya.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. — The situation in Libya has been a tragedy since autumn 2011. After the overthrow of Muammar el-Qaddafi, chaos reigns in the country. The number of boat refugees from Libya is steadily increasing. In the first half of 2014 alone, some 130,000 people crossed the Mediterranean to Europe – twice as many as in 2013. Of these, 118,000 refugees arrived in Italy alone from Libya. Europe's task is not only to support the work of the UN Special Envoy for Libya, but also to promote dialogue between different parties and to strengthen the legitimacy of the elected Libyan Parliament. That is because of this, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: In writing. Although this resolution refers to the situation of total chaos and the increase in violence in Libya, it ignores the place of European and American intervention in the current situation in that country. I abstained on this vote.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. — I supported the resolution because the violence in Libya must be put to an end quickly and all parties must start negotiations so that the situation in the country can stabilise. The Libyan people must have access and control over their land resources and the rights of each person must be protected. The European Commission urgently needs to do everything possible to help bring the humanitarian crisis to an end in Libya.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. — Ladies and gentlemen, in view of the previous decisions of the European Parliament on the situation in Libya and the Geneva Convention of 1949, with the obligation to respect international humanitarian law in all circumstances, in view of the demonstrations in February 2011 in which Libyan citizens demanded respect for and guarantee of their rights and which gave rise to nine months of internal conflict , in view of the increasing attacks on civilians and human rights violations, which in some cases are referred to as war crimes, and finally the call for an end to all armed conflict and the opening of a dialogue between the two sides, for these reasons I am voting in favour.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. "This resolution is a set of wishful thinking far from being up to the task. The consequences of the situation in Libya are disastrous, however, first for Libyans, victims of the violence of Islamists and criminals, but also for migrants from various countries who believe they are finding their salvation by seeking a passage to Europe in that country, enriching human flesh traffickers, and finally for the countries of the European Union, which do not have the means to receive so many refugees and who spend more and more to try in vain to deal with the consequences rather than the causes. I cannot therefore approve such a weak resolution under these conditions and I am against it.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: in writing. — Repression, violence and political divisions: we have been in the middle of civil war in Libya for far too long. First the conflict that led to the fall of Gaddafi, now the internal power struggles. I voted for this resolution because putting an end to this situation, which violates human rights and international humanitarian law, is a duty for Europe. More than 400 000 displaced persons and 150 000 Libyans leaving their country for neighbouring Tunisia paint an extremely worrying picture. Libya is now the scene of violent political clashes in a territory where, in fact, two rival parliaments and numerous opposing factions of nationalist, Islamic, tribal and regionalist forces operate. The European Union, by securing support for the Tobruk House of Representatives as the only legitimate body to come out of the 2014 elections, must play a central role in condemning these actions and imposing targeted sanctions on those responsible for the violence.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. — I supported the Resolution on the Situation in Libya as the human rights situation deteriorates across the country, including cases of unfounded detention, unlawful killings, torture, kidnapping and violence against officials, politicians, journalists and human rights defenders.  The state can no longer maintain internal and external peace and territorial integrity, and one of the biggest problems in Libya is precisely the influence of various armed groups, which provide their power and influence with weapons and violence. The situation is very dangerous, Libya is sinking in chaos, and the country is in danger of disintegration. I call on the EU and the international community to continue through the Geneva talks and the engagement of Special Representative Bernardino Leon to support efforts to fight terrorism and prevent its further spread and bring peace to Libya, as well as humanitarian, financial and political assistance. I would like to commend Tunisia for the immediate adoption of around 1.5 million Libyan refugees.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. — (IT) The Libyan crisis has become increasingly critical over time because of the serious internal polarization which has degenerated into a real civil war, resulting in the destructuring of any semblance of the state system and the deflagration of a serious humanitarian emergency.  I very much hope that the third session of dialogue, with the mediation of the UN, can take place as soon as possible, without further delay and postponement, and that the warring parties will be able to find common points on the planned agenda and on the main elements of this agenda: the establishment of a government of national unity, a ceasefire and the progressive withdrawal of the militias, safeguarding the path of the Constituent Assembly leading to the adoption of a Fundamental Charter through a referendum. I also hope that a new Super Partes Prime Minister will be identified at the head of a government of national unity that can put an end to the chaos and violence of this period. Also because the lack of a stable and fully controlling institutional interlocutor in the African country has led to serious immigration problems for Italy and Europe, while when an agreement was concluded with the Libyan authorities there was a decrease in migratory flows to the Italian and European coasts.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: in writing. — I am following the current situation in Libya with great concern. In this context, we must realise that the country, which is the de facto neighbour of the European Union, has come very close to the state of collapse. Let us therefore support the democratically elected government and parliament now based in Tobruk and help those who seek the return of stability and rule of law in this North African country. In the European Parliament, the resolution under discussion is based on these principles and therefore has my support.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. — The situation in Libya, not to mention its overall impact, is increasingly worrying, and it is now urgent that the European Union positions itself once and for all on the actors of the civil war in Libya.  I agree with such a recommendation. The European Union must set itself a long-term policy that corresponds to its means, promoting the stability and security of the area.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. — In February 2011, the outbreak of civil war led to the overthrow of the Gaddafi regime. Despite the fact that national legislative elections were held in June 2014, the truth is that the democratic aspirations of the Libyan people have been held by political division and violence. In fact, Libya continues to struggle with internal political struggles that have turned into a violent power struggle between two rival government groups and numerous competing factions, causing a worsening of the suffering of the civilian population, deaths, mass displacement and a humanitarian crisis. The Libyan crisis threatens to destabilise the entire region in the near future, also posing a threat to Europe's security. I therefore join in the call to the warring parties to commit themselves to an unconditional ceasefire and to participate in the efforts of the United Nations Special Representative for Libya, Bernardino León, to initiate an inclusive national political dialogue that could lead to reconciliation and the formation of a government of national unity. It is equally important to ensure accountability for all human rights violations and to ensure humanitarian, financial and political aid in order to respond to the humanitarian crisis and the suffering of the population.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. "Libya is a virtually failed chaotic state. The Socialists and Democrats call on the EU to do everything it can to support stabilisation in Libya and UN-led talks in Geneva, to bring all factions together in the country and to end what could become a full-throttle civil war. It is essential that there be security in the country again in order to restore the process of democratic transition that the Libyan people need and mobilized for. I voted in favour of the Resolution on the situation in Libya because we cannot afford in Libya another scenario of war, suffering and destruction, which can lead to the disintegration of the country. We cannot allow the proliferation of weapons or the country to become a sanctuary for terrorist organizations. European and region security is under threat in Libya. The EU must contribute to UN-ordered intervention in the country, in cooperation with the African Union and the Arab League, to achieve security conditions and return to the democratic transition process.

name: Teresa RODRIGUEZ-RUBIO
text: in writing. - We abstained in the vote on the Resolution because, while it is true that the country's current situation in urging the parties to resolve the conflict peacefully condemns, it does not refer to the root causes of the conflict or to interference (NATO-sponsored France's intervention) as part of the problem.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. In adopting this joint resolution, the European Parliament called on the European Union to take targeted sanctions (including asset freezes and travel bans) against all those responsible for armed violence and human rights violations in Libya and the boycott of negotiations under the auspices of the United Nations. Concerned about the growing presence of terrorist groups and extremist movements in Libya, I signed this resolution because I believe that such sanctions would support the efforts of the Un Special Representative for Libya, Bernardino Leon, to establish a political dialogue. I believe that there is no military solution to the current conflict and I fully support the Geneva talks which call on all parties to the conflict to accept the freeze on military operations proposed by Mr Leon, in order to create a favourable environment for an unconditional ceasefire. The resolution also calls on the Commission and the European External Action Service to order action by Member States. For the EU must help to establish a democratic, stable and prosperous state and remedy the humanitarian situation.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this joint motion for a resolution which strongly condemns the recent wave of attacks by militias and terrorist groups, which seriously undermine the possibility of a peaceful solution and the resumption of the transition to democracy by this country. The seriousness of the conflict is generating not only a worsening of political polarization, but also a profound humanitarian crisis, which requires the search for solutions based on political dialogue, preferably with the support of the UN Support Mission in Libya, in order to achieve a definitive ceasefire and concrete steps towards the implementation of an effective democracy in strict respect for the rule of law and the protection of the civic and human rights of the population. For this reason, I support the need for the European Union and the international community to continue with humanitarian, financial and political aid to this country, as well as to maintain support for efforts in the fight against terrorism, which poses a threat to stability and security, not only from Libya but also from the Maghreb, Middle East and even the entire Europe regions. , as evidenced by recent events in France and Belgium.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. "I voted for this resolution which reminds and stresses the urgency of the situation in Libya. It is essential that a solution is found and brings a lasting solution to this crisis. At a time when parties to the conflict are meeting in Geneva, it is important to reaffirm that dialogue between the parties is paramount.  The European Union must strengthen its support and assistance alongside the UN Special Representative for Libya, Bernardino Leon, in its actions built around the Ghadamès roadmap.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of the resolution tabled by my group, the GROUP of the European People's Party, on the situation in Libya, because I consider it to be a sincere and necessary statement at a sensitive time such as the one we are experiencing. We need to create effective security forces to ensure everyone's safety and to block the possibility of an escalation of attacks, as we are unfortunately witnessing these days.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. —We abstained in the vote on the Resolution because, while it is true that the country's current situation in urging the parties to resolve the conflict peacefully condemns, it does not refer to the root causes of the conflict or to interference (NATO-sponsored France's intervention) as part of the problem.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. — The Resolution on the situation in Libya contains assertions with which we do not disagree and which, at this point, are obvious. Thus, it recalls that "there is no military solution to the current conflict" and supports the negotiations sponsored by the United Nations. However, I believe that Parliament's position should be more forceful and critical. The military solution is not admissible, but the text does not recall – let alone condemned – the fact that the current situation is also a consequence of NATO intervention, which not only failed to meet its stated objective, but contributed to the increase in violence and, in passing, destroyed Libyan state structures. On the other hand, I believe that support for the United Nations negotiations must accompany initiatives such as that promoted by neighbouring countries, mainly Algeria, to initiate a dialogue between rival factions, which, in fact, have created two parallel state structures. The shortcomings of the proposed resolution for the vote forced me to abstain in the vote.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the situation in Libya on behalf of the S&D Group. The resolution calls on all Libyan parties to agree to an immediate ceasefire, end the fighting and engage in an inclusive national political dialogue. The vote passed today expresses the European Parliament’s solidarity with the Libyan people. We strongly condemn the recent military actions and violence and the human rights violations and abuses resulting from the ongoing fighting and military operations. The S&D Group is deeply concerned by the suffering of the Libyan civilian population and all migrants, expatriates and refugees stranded in Libya.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. — I express concern at the situation in Libya, which is escalating to an increasing extent. Violations of human rights and international humanitarian law do not contribute to the process of reconciliation and the continuation of the construction of neutral institutions of Libya. I am of the opinion that covert interference by regional actors can only lead to complete disintegration of the state and jeopardize the stability of the wider Mediterranean environment. I therefore call for an end to the destabilising crisis as soon as possible. I believe the EU needs to come up with and offer a clear and effective strategy to build peace and security while respecting democratic principles. Prolonging violence and destruction will only continue to further destroy already threatened infrastructure. They can cause profound ecological consequences and hamper the country's recovery in the future.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. — Since the reign of Moamer Gaddafi in Libya in 2011, the country has been facing a political, institutional and security crisis and internal unrest. In view of the fact that the EU and its Member States also intervened in the war in 2011, it is necessary to recognise that we, too, bear some responsibility for helping Libyan citizens. Above all, we have a responsibility in support of restoring peace and stability in the country. The turmoil and unrest has further divided the country over the past six months. The ongoing fighting has violated human rights, a huge number of civilians have been killed and the humanitarian crisis has spread across the country. Hundreds of migrants and refugees are fleeing violence from Libya and dying on boats carrying refugees across the Mediterranean Sea to Italy and Malta. I strongly condemn any violence and violations of international humanitarian law. For this reason, I call on the EU and its Member States to support the UN and other initiatives in resolving the situation. Above all, the EU should provide humanitarian aid. It is necessary to help Libya in this difficult period of transition, marked by unrest and war. For the reasons set out above, I signed the resolution and supported it in the vote.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. - I support all efforts to ensure a free and safe life in Libya, but it is evident that there are many more obstacles along the way. I condemn all forms of terrorism and urge that maximum efforts be made to raise the level of tolerance and create conditions for peaceful coexistence. The report mentions the activities of Islamic terrorist groups and should maximise their attacks and stop further arming. I welcome all peace-advocating activities and agree with the report's findings that we should support all pacifist activities and provide them with moral and financial assistance. The EU should support the building of institutions and the legal order in Libya and other countries in a similar situation. I express my support for the Libyan authorities in managing energy resources and we all need to help and not enter into relations with third parties. I would once again highlight concerns about the growing separation of society and the humanitarian crisis cited in the Commission's report. I commend Tunisia for taking in Libyan refugees and support providing assistance in professional, moral and financial form.

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: in writing. — I supported the resolution on the current situation in Libya because it rightly draws attention, inter alia, to the number of migrants trying to leave Libya, as there is no longer a functioning state in Libya that ensures at least basic security for its citizens. All Member States must participate in addressing this situation and provide effective assistance to refugees, which may include Coptic Christians.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. — The EU's intention should not be to plan actions to escalate the situation in Libya, but rather to promote bloodless and diplomatic solutions.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. "Of course I voted in favour of this resolution. The news has caught up with us. Libyan Prime Minister Abdallah Al-Thenni has just urged us to increase his support, including military support, to combat the growing threat of jihadists from the Islamic State group. "The international community is conducting an offensive against the jihadists in Syria and Iraq, but in Libya, only the state with the army is fighting terrorist groups and it is receiving no aid," said Abdallah Al-Thenni. The Prime Minister of the internationally recognized government made the call just days before a UN-sponsored meeting of the warring parties in Libya.  We are in for a political resolution, but we cannot decently remain deaf to the situation of civilians.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. — Following the June 2014 elections in Libya, a civil conflict burst out as rival governments and parliaments emerged. I voted in favour of the proposed resolution on the situation in Libya which equally condemns the violence on civilians resulting from this instable political situation, and the reluctance from both sides to engage in a peace process conducted by the UN. The conflict led to worrying mass displacement to Tunisia, undermining that country’s stability, and favours the growing influence of Islamist militias in certain parts of the country (ISIS and al-Qa’ida in the Islamic Maghreb). We are calling on the EU to place asset freezes and travel bans upon those responsible for human rights violations, and on those boycotting the UN negotiations.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. — I voted in favour. I call on the conflicting parties to immediately cease all armed hostilities and to engage in an inclusive political dialogue. I express my grave concern at the situation in Libya, which threatens to lead the country to chaos and all-out war and to further destabilise the wider region, and I reiterate my support for a political solution to the crisis as the only means to avoid the fragmentation of Libya. Moreover, I express my deep concern for and full solidarity with the suffering Libyan civilian population and institutions. I am deeply concerned at the growing presence of al-Qaeda-linked terrorist groups, Islamic State militias and individuals operating in Libya, and I reaffirm the need to combat these by all means, in accordance with the Charter of the United Nations and with international law.

name: Traian UNGUREANU
text: in writing. — We are looking with concern at this time towards Libya. This state is facing a serious and tense situation, as the authorities are hardly functioning at all. In recent times, violence in this country has escalated worryingly. There have been a number of attacks, with the presence of extremist movements, terrorist groups, Islamic State militias being a prominent reality. These groups pose a major threat both to stability and security across the region and to the security of Europe. An immediate ceasefire agreement and the adoption of a roadmap for the transition to democracy are essential for the restoration of stability in the area.  The UN special envoy's efforts to launch a dialogue between rival factions towards a reconciliation process and the formation of a national unity government are welcome. In turn, the European Union must act more firmly and quickly in this case, with the singular initiatives of some states to be avoided.  That is why, through this resolution, we have called, inter alia, for the European Union and the international community to continue to provide humanitarian, financial and political support in order to make it possible to resolve the humanitarian situation in Libya and to make the aspirations for the building of a democratic state a reality.

name: Viktor USPASKICH
text: Writing. — In my opinion, attacks on civilians in Libya are unjustified, and this has a serious impact on the flow of illegal and dangerous immigration into the European Union. In view of the dire disasters of the past, I congratulate Parliament on the position expressed today.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: in writing. " The Socialists and Democrats call on the EU to do everything it can to support stabilisation in Libya and UN-led talks in Geneva, to bring together all factions in the country and to end what could become a full-rule civil war. It is essential that there be security in the country again in order to restore the process of democratic transition that the Libyan people need and mobilized for. I voted in favour of the Resolution on the situation in Libya because we cannot afford in Libya another scenario of war, suffering and destruction, which can lead to the disintegration of the country. We cannot allow the proliferation of weapons or the country to become a sanctuary for terrorist organizations. European and region security is under threat in Libya. The EU must contribute to UN-ordered intervention in the country, in cooperation with the African Union and the Arab League, to achieve security conditions and return to the democratic transition process.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. — The Resolution on the situation in Libya contains assertions with which we do not disagree and which, at this point, are obvious. Thus, it recalls that "there is no military solution to the current conflict" and supports the negotiations sponsored by the United Nations. However, I believe that Parliament's position should be more forceful and critical. The military solution is not admissible, but the text does not recall – let alone condemned – the fact that the current situation is also a consequence of NATO intervention, which not only failed to meet its stated objective, but contributed to the increase in violence and, in passing, destroyed Libyan state structures. On the other hand, I believe that support for the United Nations negotiations must accompany initiatives such as that promoted by neighbouring countries, mainly Algeria, to initiate a dialogue between rival factions, which, in fact, have created two parallel state structures. The shortcomings of the proposed resolution for the vote forced me to abstain in the vote.

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: in writing. — This week I voted with the S&D to call on the EU to support the stabilisation of Libya. It is essential to bring back security within the country so as to restore the democratic transition process that the Libyan people await and yearn for. If we do not act in Libya then the entire region faces a credible security threat.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. — I strongly condemn the growing aggression and violence in Libya. I call on the fighting parties to cease hostilities and to start a political dialogue in a stable framework. I fully support the efforts of Special Envoy Bernardino Léon and hope that the violence will soon come to an end.  I call on the European Union and its Member States to work in a coordinated way in dealing with this crisis.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: In writing. "The situation in Libya is dramatic. In reality, there is no longer a Libyan state. The first victim of this situation is the Libyan people. Negotiations are under way under the aegis of the United Nations. With this resolution, the European Parliament encourages dialogue and supports the search for political solutions by excluding any military intervention. We can only rejoice. Peaceful solutions, however, must be preferred. But some doubts remain.   The resolution is totally flawed on previous interventions and their consequences, and therefore on each other's responsibilities in this area. Amendments tabled by the GUE/NGL on these responsibilities and NATO's role in the region were all rejected.  All of this is not up to the challenge. Nevertheless, I abstained, thinking first of all of the Libyan people.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. — The situation in Libya is catastrophic and reveals the true nature of the EU's foreign policy and western powers. For these, there is no human rights, there is no democracy. There are only their economic and geostrategic interests. For western powers, the scouting criterion used to measure democracy and human rights is based on greater or lesser submission to their interests. Although the Gaddafi regime was in power for several decades, it was only from the moment it ceased to serve the interests of the great powers that it became a dictator to overthrow. In the name of immoral values, a country was destroyed and an entire region was destabilized. It's the divide to be in. In the name of these interests, thousands of innocent people are still dying. Tens of thousands have left their lives destroyed and wander in luck, looking for assistance. Capitalism is not the end of history. One day, people will take their destinies into their hands and know how to build another system that will end exploitation and war.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. — Since the overthrow of Muammar El-Qaddafi, the number of Libyan boat refugees has been steadily increasing. In the first half of 2014 alone, some 130,000 people crossed the Mediterranean to Europe – twice as many as in 2013. Of these, 118,000 refugees arrived in Italy alone from Libya. Europe's task is not only to support the work of the UN Special Envoy for Libya, but also to promote dialogue between different parties and to strengthen the legitimacy of the elected Libyan Parliament.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. — Violence against Christians has been on the increase in Libya since the overthrow of Muammar el-Qaddafi. It was recently revealed that Islamists kidnapped 20 Coptic Christians there. I thank colleagues for agreeing to my oral amendment in plenary to call on all parties in Libya to guarantee the safety and freedom of Christians and other religious minorities facing increasing persecution and discrimination. In my motion today, we have also called on the EU and the Member States to ensure that future bilateral agreements include sensible mechanisms for protecting the human rights of Christians and religious minorities. I therefore agreed with this resolution. However, under the leadership of the Vice-Chairman of the Subcommittee on Human Rights Barbara Lochbihler (Greens), a blocking minority should be organised against this motion! Is it not remarkable that a so-called human rights politician from the Greens rejects concrete support for severely tormented people? The cross-party booing against this cold-hearted refusal should give the Greens and left-wing radicals food for thought.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: in writing — Although almost four years have passed since the Libyan uprising and the overthrow of the Gaddafi regime, the struggle for the power of opposing parties continues and grows into destructive chaos. The south of the country is becoming a place of free movement of Islamic State supporters, the rest of the country is divided between rival parties. The political situation is also opaque. The House of Representatives, elected in June last year, was dissolved by the Supreme Court in November. In fact, the government controls only part of the east of the country. Then there's Congress, elected in 2012, which people took to the streets against last year. The difficult political and economic situation is creating a breeding ground for the rise of extremism, not only domestically but also outside the country, also as a result of uncontrollable arms sales. It is estimated that there are up to 40 million available weapons in the country, which are also selling outside Libya. In particular, the country's ordinary population, including women trying to participate in political life, is the victim of this destabilisation. However, residents of other countries who are the target of terrorist attacks by Islamic State supporters may also be victims. I therefore fully support the resolution adopted to impose sanctions on those Lybian political leaders who are responsible for this situation.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. — It would be naïve to think that the forces that dominate the EP and who supported the implementation of the so-called no-fly zone in Libya, paving the way for NATO aggression in 2011, could shone their way. They can't. It is in its nature to promote interference in the internal affairs of countries and the violation of their sovereignty with the denial of the inalienable right of self-determination of peoples, to promote aggression and war, occupation, violation of international law and the UN charter, a character once again reiterated in this resolution. The record of crimes of which it is complicit is the deaths of thousands of innocent civilians, a humanitarian crisis, massive destruction of infrastructure, the total destabilisation of the State of Libya, a situation of chaos and an ongoing civil war. Libya is a country destroyed by the intestinal struggle of various far-right and obscurantist, racist and xenophobic groups, fomented and supported by NATO and the EU, the same as the majority of the EP warned hypocritically of the threat they pose to the EU, the same as yesterday they were their allies when it came to getting their hands on the oil resources of the one who was the first African producer.

name: Neena GILL
text: Mr President, the need to send a strong signal on the situation in Ukraine became clear once more when at least 11 people lost their lives on Tuesday as a passenger bus came under heavy fire in Eastern Ukraine. The fact that this week’s Kazakhstan summit had to be delayed because of failure to implement the ceasefire agreement is not only deeply worrying, it is also an insult to the thousands of people who have already fallen victim to this conflict, as well as to our own citizens, whose well-being is linked to the developments in Ukraine. The only option for a sustainable solution is one that respects Ukraine’s sovereignty and territorial integrity. We will be able to help bring this about only if we speak with a single, strong, coordinated voice. Ukraine will be a crucial first test for the Juncker Commission on improving foreign policy coordination. Failing is simply not an option.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: Mr President, I supported the motion for a resolution on Ukraine. I am glad that a resolution has passed in the form where the accused of the conflict, that is, Russia and the separatists, are clearly named. I am glad that we are saying this clearly here, even if it may seem pointless to some, but there are still politicians, even in Europe, who relativise the conflict and question who is the culprit and who is the victim. I am also glad that this resolution makes clear the need to maintain sanctions against Russia. If Russia does not change its policy and its policy is not realistically pro-peace, then there is no reason to tear down sanctions at the moment. And I am also glad that the resolution makes it clear that Ukraine needs our help. Ukraine is our eastern partner, its stability is also the stability of Europe, and we must help it economically, but also professionally and logistically. Ukraine needs the Marshall Plan and the European Union can help a lot.

name: Peter JAHR
text: Mr. President! I voted in favour of the resolution, and I have to say that it is, of course, particularly painful when you look at the situation in Ukraine. There is a country that wants to transform it democratically, wants to fight corruption. There is a country in the midst of an economic crisis. There is a country that is de facto insolvent and still has a de facto civil war to deal with in the country. First of all, I think it is good that we are committed to helping, that is right. Secondly, I think it is particularly good that we are then also clearly mentioning the responsibility of the neighbouring countries. I think it is simply too easy for Russia to keep saying that this is an intra-Ukrainian issue. This is not true, it is not true.  I call on Russia to shoulder its responsibilities. An important part of ending the war would be for Russia to finally live up to its responsibilities in the region.

name: Tatjana ŽDANOKA
