text: Mr President, I voted against this resolution. For me, not only the separate paragraphs but also the spirit of the resolution in general are unacceptable. It is a spirit of hatred to all and everything that does not agree with the policy of the present Kiev authorities. The resolution contains statements based on certain anonymous ‘credible sources’. How can this be combined with the principle of openness? How can the appeal to counter the Russian propaganda campaign (see paragraph 26), which is in fact an appeal for an information war, be combined with the principle of freedom of speech, which is extremely topical after the Paris attacks? Nevertheless, I do appreciate that the resolution contains a call for an effective investigation of all major moments of violence (paragraph 24) and of the tragic downing of the Malaysian Airlines flight (paragraph 27).

name: Seán KELLY
text: I was pleased to vote with my Group on all the amendments and, obviously, on the resolution here today. I think it is laudable what we have done in the European Parliament in the past few months in helping Ukraine, a country which is trying to move forward both democratically and also in economic terms. We have moved speedily and that is good. One thing I must say is that I was taken aback at the last part-session here in Strasbourg when one MEP suggested that by passing resolutions on Ukraine we were heckling or goading, or almost insulting, Russia. This is an absolute farce. Ukraine is an independent country, and it is no business of Russia or China or the USA or any other country what we do to help them. I hope we will continue to help them because they deserve it and we have resources that they may not have.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: Mr President, I firmly believe that Ukraine needs a strong committed Europe at its side in order to maintain the independence and integrity of its territory and to fulfil the Ukrainian people’s desire to live in a civilised democratic state that respects the rights of the national ethnic minorities and has been cleared of a corrupt élite and corrupt judiciary system. A united and sovereign Ukraine is fundamental to the stable democratic and prosperous future of the region. Today it is of vital importance that the Minsk Protocol be fully implemented, including by Russia. All threats to the lives of Ukrainian citizens are to be condemned. Obstacles to the work by the Special Monitoring Mission must be removed and then Ukraine must carry out the political, economic and social reform that the nation needs. It is my hope that the macro-financial assistance proposal for Ukraine will be approved.

name: Janice ATKINSON
text: Mr President, UKIP voted, unusually, for Amendment 12, as it calls for the repeal of the EU-Ukraine Association Agreement. The EU has no right to interfere in Ukraine. The EU shook a stick at the Russian bear and it reacted, and this led to brave young people’s deaths, directly encouraged by my colleagues here. Then this place voted to impose sanctions against Russia. Yet who did the sanctions harm? The nation states of the EU trying to sell goods and services to Russia. Everything that this place does has unintended consequences.

name: Daniel HANNAN
text: Mr President, European values, at least as understood in Ukraine, are not synonymous with the European Union. That may sound an obvious, even a banal, observation, but it is worth stressing the consequences. By European values, people mean the rule of the law, representative government, personal freedom, secure property and contract rights – essentially that the rulers do not get to change the rules as they go along but there is some judicial framework. Now I would argue that you find those values in plenty of places outside the European Union – in Norway, New Zealand or whatever – and in fact one place where you do not always find them is in the institutions of this Union. It is the old joke that, if the EU were a country applying to join itself, it would be turned down for being insufficiently democratic. Why do I say this? Because people in Ukraine, as well as yearning for westernisation, also have an aspiration to national independence. They understand – and we in this Chamber would do well to remember – that those values are not the same as EU membership.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. — The Socialists support Ukraine's sovereignty, territorial integrity, unity and independence. That is why we support the new Government of Ukraine, which is trying to reform the country. I voted on the resolution because I believe that the best defence of Ukraine's sovereignty and independence will be to carry out these reforms quickly, necessary to have a reliable and impartial judicial system, promote the rule of law, eradicate corruption, decentralize power and protect freedom of the press and the rights of minorities. The Minsk Protocol is the reference document for peace. We urge all parties to fully implement the Protocol. We stand alongside the innocent civilians who are suffering in the areas affected by the conflict in eastern Ukraine. We call for more humanitarian aid and urge all parties to immediately halt the fighting. There is no military solution to that crisis. A peaceful solution must be found through an inclusive national dialogue for reconciliation.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. — The Resolution on the situation in Ukraine under a vote brings together all the falsehoods that have been poured into the media about the conflict in Ukraine and makes an analysis whose sole objective is to justify, on the one hand, European trade policy towards Eastern Europe and, on the other hand, the geopolitical reasoning of the United States; which is why I voted against it with complete conviction. In this way, the text focuses on attacking Russophone militants, calling them "terrorists", and condemns their "criminal conduct", while the use of force by the Ukrainian authorities does not deserve the slightest reproach. Nowhere in the text does the existence of a coup d'a state be mentioned. On the other hand, the Resolution opens the door to Ukraine's accession to NATO and, on each occasion when the opportunity arises, Russia's attitude to the situation is blamed, while the United States, the country involved in the coup d'ore, is not mentioned in the entire text.

name: Louis ALIOT
text: In writing. — Louis Aliot spoke out against this resolution to the extent that it extends economic sanctions against Russia. This country must remain an ally and not the other way around, the framework of diplomatic relations between the EU and Russia must be carried out in a spirit of mutual understanding, of lasting partnership. Moreover, these sanctions have serious consequences for Russian households that are not responsible for the break-up of Ukraine.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. — As long as the situation in Ukraine does not stabilise, the European Union must continue to look for a political solution. As far as human rights violations are concerned, we in the European Parliament and as defenders of democratic values must not remain idle. That is why I welcome the adoption of this motion for a resolution.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. "I voted against a resolution contrary to the interests of France and the Member States of the Union. The extension of sanctions to the energy sector, particularly gas, is a serious damage to the energy policy of the EU Member States. It is a policy of exclusive service to the United States, the only beneficiaries of a deterioration in energy relations between the European Union and Russia.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. — I deplore the current situation in the Ukraine. The actions of Russia have been unacceptable, and it is right that the international community should take appropriate and proportionate actions such as sanctions (although I do not believe that this should be at EU level – rather a matter for individual nations and/or the UN to determine). I am concerned that European Union action may prove to be undue provocation due to the potential accession of the Ukraine to the EU. I note that an amendment which would have sought to rescind the Association Agreement failed. Consequently, I felt that I had no choice but to abstain on the motion for a resolution as a whole.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. " Through this resolution, we support Ukraine's sovereignty, territorial integrity and independence. The new government must implement reforms to promote the rule of law, establish a reliable and impartial judicial system and protect the rights of minorities. At the same time, all parties concerned must be urged to stop the violence in the east of the country, of which civilians are the first victims.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. The European Union, in the Ukrainian conflict, has only succeeded from the beginning in worsening the situation. By openly supporting Ukraine through its association agreements and refusing to recognise the referendum in Crimea, it has opened negotiations for Ukraine's accession to the EU and has fully opened its markets. All this without settling the situation on the spot which is always troubled. The EU claims to support Ukrainian independence and integrity, but has used its right to interfere since the beginning of the conflict and thus increases tensions with Russia in a more than sensitive situation. The EU is the area in the world with the highest unemployment and the lowest growth. There is no point in wanting to apply to other countries the bitter potion it inflicts on itself. That's why I voted against it.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: Written. — (SV) I voted in favour of the resolution, despite the fact that there are problems with it. These are above all about what is not included. Unfortunately, the resolution lacks proposals on how to achieve non-military solutions. It does not mention the UN in one word, even though the UN is a key player that has tried to stop the escalation, both the military and the verbal. The UN, together with the OSCE, can help get the parties to sit down at a negotiating table. Unfortunately, we must also read almost to the end before the humanitarian situation of the people of Ukraine is addressed. It is a failure, as is the fact that this resolution seeks to press for a common foreign and energy policy, which should be discussed in open debates and should be up to each Member State to decide on rather than being sealed in resolutions on a country in crisis. I am also opposed to the dominant focus on weapons and military solutions. Despite these objections, I believe it is extremely important to support Ukraine's path to democracy and to condemn Russia's actions with great clarity. I have therefore voted in favour of the resolution.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. — The Socialists support Ukraine's sovereignty, territorial integrity, unity and independence. That is why we support the new Government of Ukraine, which is trying to reform the country. I voted on the resolution because I believe that the best defence of Ukraine's sovereignty and independence will be to carry out these reforms quickly, necessary to have a reliable and impartial judicial system, promote the rule of law, eradicate corruption, decentralize power and protect freedom of the press and the rights of minorities. The Minsk Protocol is the reference document for peace. We urge all parties to fully implement the Protocol. We stand alongside the innocent civilians who are suffering in the areas affected by the conflict in eastern Ukraine. We call for more humanitarian aid and urge all parties to immediately halt the fighting. There is no military solution to that crisis. A peaceful solution must be found through an inclusive national dialogue for reconciliation.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution as the humanitarian situation in some regions of Ukraine remains a cause for concern. Unfortunately, but access to humanitarian aid remains limited and internally displaced people face huge problems, especially in the winter, the civilian population is suffering even more. Therefore, in order to avoid an emergency humanitarian situation, more international aid is needed, and Parliament therefore calls for further humanitarian aid and assistance to the people affected by the conflict. The resolution calls for the resumption of a national dialogue which would also enable the payment of social benefits and pensions to be resolved and the provision of humanitarian aid to the ukrainian government to the population of conflict zones.  The European Parliament regrets that international human rights law and international humanitarian law continue to be violated in eastern Ukraine and Crimea, and that the number of internally displaced persons has increased significantly since the ceasefire was announced on 5 September. It is necessary to condemn all cases of enforced disappearances, torture and ill-treatment and to urge careful investigation of information on the use of cluster bombs in both urban and rural areas. Parliament calls on the European Union to provide more support to civil society and believes that civil society organisations can play an important role in facilitating people-to-people contacts and understanding in Ukraine, promoting democratic change and respect for human rights.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. — I voted against the motion for a resolution on the situation in Ukraine It is doubtful, as the resolution suggests, that it would be useful for the European Union and the United States to cooperate more closely on Ukraine-related policies". Condemning "strongly the aggressive and expansionist policies of Russia" would only further inflame tensions. Mixing cases, from the point of view of public international law, Crimea and the Donetsk and Lugansk regions is approximate. I note the invitation to "Ukrainian leaders to eradicate systematic corruption by implementing, without further delay and effectively, the national anti-corruption strategy". Let's judge them on the results. We can see a change in the action of the High Representative. Few regret the blandness of Baroness Ashton's action.  Last week in Riga, the High Representative raised the possibility of lifting sanctions against Russia. She saw positive signs coming from Moscow. But, alas, the European Union and its allies are not sending gestures of appeasement. The search for a political and diplomatic solution, respectful of the population, is to be preferred. You should stop being at the fore of American diplomacy.  This fratricidal conflict has lasted far too long.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. — I supported the motion because I believe that the EU may find a solution to the critical situation in Ukraine and open a dialogue with Russia.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. — The European Parliament has proposed a unambiguous draft resolution, marked by anti-Russian ideology and showing manifest bad faith. The text clearly assumes the request for greater US involvement in a conflict that does not concern them at all. But above all, a sentence should be extracted from this text: "Share its full solidarity with Ukraine and its people; reiterates its commitment to independence, sovereignty, territorial integrity, the inviolability of borders and Ukraine's European choice." How can the European Union claim to defend sovereignty and territorial integrity when it has built itself on the dilution of the sovereignty of peoples and has rendered territorial integrity meaningless by imposing the principle of free movement. But the most shocking thing is that the European Union completely ignores the multiple human rights violations and massacres committed by the Ukrainian army, the latest being the deaths of 30 civilians in the Gorlovka district following shelling by the Ukrainian air force on Sunday 18 January 2015.  For all these reasons, I voted against this draft resolution.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. — The proposal for a joint resolution on the situation in Ukraine once again brings up the tense situation in Ukraine. It should be remembered that Russia regards the EU's Eastern Partnership as a threat to its own political and economic interests. The EU is trying to send a very obvious message: Russia would benefit from these trade and economic activities, and Russia's security can be strengthened by a stable neighbourhood. This resolution calls on the Commission to closely monitor the impact of so-called 'Russian sanctions' and to take swift action to support producers affected by Russia's trade restrictions and to examine how the EU can better cope with similar crises in the future.  I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution because all necessary measures must be taken to support concretely and in time the European producers affected by Russia's actions, which used trade as a tool to destabilise the region and introduced bans on imports of products from Ukraine and the Republic of Moldova, as well as the reintroduction of the most favoured nation's tariff on products from these countries.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. — 'No' vote: the coup d'état in Ukraine is strongly condemned and the promotion and support of the European Union, the United States and NATO is denounced; we denounce the conditions under which the subsequent elections took place, with an open violation of political and civil rights and widespread persecution and the repression of the Russian-speaking population.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: in writing. — The Socialists support Ukraine's sovereignty, territorial integrity, unity and independence. That is why we support the new Government of Ukraine, which is trying to reform the country. I voted on the resolution because I believe that the best defence of Ukraine's sovereignty and independence will be to carry out these reforms quickly, necessary to have a reliable and impartial judicial system, promote the rule of law, eradicate corruption, decentralize power and protect freedom of the press and the rights of minorities. The Minsk Protocol is the reference document for peace. We urge all parties to fully implement the Protocol. We stand alongside the innocent civilians who are suffering in the areas affected by the conflict in eastern Ukraine. We call for more humanitarian aid and urge all parties to immediately halt the fighting. There is no military solution to that crisis. A peaceful solution must be found through an inclusive national dialogue for reconciliation.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. — (IT) Today I voted in favour of the resolution on the situation in Ukraine in order to call on the EU to renew its support for ukraine's sovereignty, territorial integrity, unity and independence, and to condemn the continuing influx of arms and troops from Russia, which must be stopped immediately.  At the same time, Ukraine must demonstrate its commitment to the reform plan: fiscal consolidation, continued reforms in the banking and energy sectors, the fight against corruption, transparency and justice reform. The European strategy must be based on two guidelines: on the one hand, the process of association between the EU and Ukraine; on the other hand, the non-recognition of the annexation of Crimea and the progressive imposition against Russia of restrictive measures that can only be lifted if all the points of the Misk Agreement are fully fulfilled, provided that they are still far from happening. And I am convinced that the political instrument to be adopted is political dialogue with Russia.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. — I express my full solidarity with the people of Ukraine, and agree with the commitment to the independence, sovereignty, territorial integrity, inviolability of borders and European choice of Ukraine. Russia’s aggressive and expansionist policy through the use of cyber warfare, economic pressure and even energy blackmail remind us that Europe plays an important part in this situation, as these actions are not only in breach of international law, but also impinge on the European security situation.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. — Ukraine is a victim of the strategic choices of two opposing power blocs: on the one hand, the US-EU axis and, on the other, Vladimir Putin's Russia. The association agreement with the European Union was signed too hastily, placing all Ukrainians in the crossfire of the economic and territorial interests of both sides and creating a furrow between the European Union and Russia, although the former lacks a secure and credible energy strategy alternative to the import of hydrocarbons from the Russian Federation. A political solution is in the interests of all the Member States of the Union.

name: Aymeric CHAUPRADE
text: In writing. "I voted against this text which, once again, gives an ideological reading of the historical, political and geopolitical reality of the Ukrainian crisis. Not content with accusing Russia of being the only one responsible for the instability in the Donbass, the European parliamentarians gargle in this resolution of a quasi democratic centralism in Ukraine, welcoming the hegemony of the "pro-European" forces. When one is fundamentally committed to freedom and political pluralism as I am, one cannot decently vote in favour of a resolution which also admits that the medium-term objective is to integrate Ukraine into NATO to encircle Russia. I remain deeply committed to the principle of the sovereignty of nation states, which is why I refuse to endorse the fact that the EU Member States become only prefects of American policy.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. — If Ukraine were quiet, we would all benefit: ukrainian citizens first, because they could concentrate on their work to improve their situation; we, because we would have as our neighbour a reliable trading partner, both for export, both to import raw materials and semi-finished products, and to invest and allow our entrepreneurs to diversify their interests. It is in this spirit that I voted in favour of this resolution: we should focus on the work to be done to make things better, rather than picking on possible external agents.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. — The EU should be prepared to provide a strong and decisive answer to the Ukrainian crisis resulting from Russia’s waged aggression and occupation. It does a lot, but it is still not enough. We often do too little, too late, and in a shy manner. We are hiding behind the OSCE, the UN, the Red Cross, and some Member States. We are not calling things for what they are – war as war and terror as terror. By contributing to security in Ukraine, the EU is providing security for itself. Only determined and united EU and Ukraine actions and Russia’s return to the path of respect of the rights of its neighbours and of international law can offer a solution to the Ukrainian crisis. Russian terrorism on Ukrainian territory should be fought with the same determination as any other form of terrorism, like for example Islamic fundamentalism. At the same time, we should not close our communication channels with Russia, bearing in mind that diplomatic solutions should be sought to resolve the conflict. We therefore support meetings in Geneva or Normandy formats if tangible results can be achieved

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. — I agree that the European Parliament unequivocally expresses its solidarity with the Ukrainian people and supports their independence, sovereignty, territorial integrity, inviolability of borders and european option. I also condone the acts of terrorism and the criminal behaviour of the separatists as well as the presence of military forces outside Ukraine and operating on its territory in flagrant violation of its borders. I agree with the need to maintain the current EU sanctions regime until Russia fully respects and does not fulfil its minsk obligations. I endorse russia's non-recognition of Russia's illegal annexation of Crimea. I also support the international investigation into the circumstances in which the tragic crash of the malaysia airlines flight MH17 occurred so that its officers could be tried.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. — (IT) With reference to the motion for a resolution, the situation between Russia and Ukraine remains tense and unstable, with repercussions both at European and Italian level. The sanctions, created to reduce the disagreements between Russia and Ukraine, have blocked the import of many agricultural and food products from Italy, causing very serious economic damage. These have not only created negative consequences for the Member States and the European single market, but also for Russia itself on the verge of economic default. In addition, the decision by the Government of Kiev to stop payments of social benefits and pensions in those areas not controlled by the government is of grave concern. We need a shared solution between two democratic countries, Russia and Ukraine, with europe's mediation and commitment to resolving such a complex situation.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. — I agree with the importance of the implementation of Minsk agreements. It is important that sanctions are upheld or even broadened should Russia not change its course of action. I welcome the result of free and fair early parliamentary elections and call for the swift implementation of necessary reforms. Positive signals demonstrating a slight shift in Moscow’s approach to the Ukrainian situation are not enough.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. — On 26 October 2014, Ukraine held general elections which were conducted efficiently, orderly and peacefully and with general respect for fundamental freedoms, despite the ongoing conflict in the eastern regions and Russia's illegal annexation of Crimea. Considering that the new government, made up of pro-European forces, enjoys the constitutional majority necessary to carry out the reforms and has already adopted a coalition agreement laying the foundations for a rigorous reform process aimed at promoting greater European integration, modernising and developing the country, establishing genuine democracy and the rule of law, and drawing up the constitutional changes proposed by poroshenko's peace plan. However, I cannot vote in favour of the resolution because this calls for new sanctions on Russia. I believe that the best vote is abstention, because Russia also has serious faults.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. — The Resolution on the situation in Ukraine under a vote brings together all the falsehoods that have been poured into the media about the conflict in Ukraine and makes an analysis whose sole objective is to justify, on the one hand, European trade policy towards Eastern Europe and, on the other hand, the geopolitical reasoning of the United States; which is why I voted against it. In this way, the text focuses on attacking Russophone militants, calling them "terrorists", and condemns their "criminal conduct", while the use of force by the Ukrainian authorities deserves no reproach. Nowhere in the text does the existence of a coup d'a state be mentioned. On the other hand, the Resolution opens the door to Ukraine's accession to NATO and, on each occasion when the opportunity arises, Russia's attitude to the situation is blamed, while the United States, the country involved in the coup d'ore, is not mentioned in the entire text. At the same time, the role of the European Union is limited to helping Ukraine implement the Partnership Agreement.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: in writing. — Notwithstanding the 5 September ceasefire protocol and the memorandum of 19 September, agreed upon by all parties to the conflict, shooting and shelling continues in Eastern Ukraine. This week alone, hostilities claimed the life of ten innocent people when a bus was hit by a shell. Russia persists in its breach of international law and is thus target of a continued EU sanction regime. Only restraint, genuine commitment, national dialogue and reconciliation can contribute to a settlement of the conflict. Military confrontation will only escalate the current crisis, taking parties further away from a fair and sustainable political solution which respects Ukraine’s sovereignty and territorial integrity. A swift and effective implementation of priority reforms to address the country’s pressing political, security and socio-economic challenges can play a vital role to this end. Ambitious policies fostering higher living standards, effective and transparent institutions and Ukraine’s European path represent some of the measures required to ensure bold responses to citizens’ demands, needs and aspirations. A secure and prosperous Ukraine able to rely upon modern democratic institutions and an accountable rule of law system, notwithstanding the challenging security and political circumstances, is the spirit of this resolution and hence deserves this House’s support.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. — This resolution focuses on the need for the new Ukrainian Government to move forward with the reform agenda in the country, and points out that the European Union will continue to support the new government’s efforts to build a new Ukraine. To achieve this the following actions are highlighted: the most effective defence for Ukrainian sovereignty and independence is to rapidly implement reforms in order to obtain a reliable and impartial judicial system, the rule of law, the eradication of corruption, decentralisation, media freedom and minority rights. I voted in favour of this resolution, as I support the efforts to work out a sustainable peace settlement.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. — Taking into account developments in Ukraine, this resolution welcomes the positive organisation of the elections of 26 October, organised despite the ongoing conflict in the east of the country and the annexation of Crimea, and calls for the continuation of the European sanction regime against Russia. I am also pleased that the European Parliament is reminding us of its support and commitment to the independence, sovereignty, territorial integrity of Ukraine, and the inviolability of its borders. The Ukrainian government has made a clear choice to strengthen ties with the European Union, a choice that must be heard. It is therefore essential to support Ukraine in implementing the reforms necessary to address its current economic and political difficulties. I support the European Commission's decision to offer Ukraine macro-financial assistance of up to EUR 1.8 billion in the form of medium-term loans. For these reasons, I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the situation in Ukraine. This proposal aims to support Ukraine's sovereignty, territorial integrity, unity and independence. I very much hope that the new government and the Ukrainian Parliament will quickly implement the political and socio-economic reforms necessary to build a prosperous democratic state based on the rule of law.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: In writing. " Violence has intensified in Ukraine for several weeks. European diplomacy must mobilise and act.  The way out of the crisis in the region requires the meeting of all the protagonists around the table. We must be a mediation force and have a comprehensive approach to Russia: we must maintain the sanctions regime without closing the door to dialogue with Putin while making respect for Ukrainian sovereignty a prerequisite. This position should not prevent us from thinking, in Ukraine, of a more federal organisational solution. At the same time, it is important to settle the gas issue so that its price escapes context and political blackmail.  Finally, the European Union must remain with the Ukrainians. The crisis is far from over. We need to do more to help them through financial aid and emergency humanitarian assistance, but also with the reforms that the country needs.

name: Diane DODDS
text: in writing. — Mr President, it is right and proper that members of this Parliament do not shirk their responsibility to highlight the abuses of fundamental freedoms currently witnessed in Eastern Ukraine and Crimea. I am aware of several charitable and faith-based organisations from my own constituency, Northern Ireland, which have been working with people in communities ravaged by the current violence and unrest instigated by the Russian intervention. We cannot ignore the reports of intimidation and the wave of disappearances that has taken place in these communities. In many cases, this has impacted religious minorities, including Christians. The EU must reiterate full commitment to the independence, sovereignty and territorial integrity of Ukraine's borders. But, more importantly, it must ensure that help and support filters through, both in terms of assisting those worst affected through aid work and re-housing, and through allowing EU citizens who are working and living in conflict areas to access all necessary support to return home safely.

name: Pablo ECHENIQUE
text: in writing. — We voted against the Resolution on the situation in Ukraine because, in the face of the conflict that has been going on for months, as well as the current weakness of the ceasefire, it continues to regard Russia as solely responsible for the conflict, while maintaining a defiant position on the part of the European Union by insisting on sanctions on Russia, which so far have only led to a crisis in the agricultural sector with significant consequences for farmers.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. — The EU's hypocritical policy on Ukraine will not find our support. The expansionism of NATO and its followers has led a country to destabilize. EU support for Ukraine's coup d'government legitimises violence.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. — The situation in Ukraine remains uneasy with the constant violation of the ceasefire of 5 September 2014 by Russian separatists and forces, with Russia continuing to support separatist militias through a steady stream of regular Russian military equipment, mercenaries and units, including combat tanks, sophisticated anti-aircraft systems and artillery.  Thousands of civilian deaths have already resulted in thousands of deaths, a large number of wounded and several hundred thousand people have had to leave their homes, mostly bound for Russia, and the situation in the conflict zone is of great concern, both from a humanitarian and public health point of view. There are reports of widespread human rights abuses. The Ukrainian people therefore deserve my solidarity, and it is essential that European bodies condone the acts of terrorism and the criminal behaviour of separatists and other irregular forces present in eastern Ukraine as well as russia's aggressive and expansionist policy, which poses a threat to the unity and independence of Ukraine and the European Union itself.

name: Jonás FERNÁNDEZ
text: in writing. — The Socialists support Ukraine's sovereignty, territorial integrity, unity and independence. That is why we support the new Government of Ukraine, which is trying to reform the country. I voted on the resolution because I believe that the best defence of Ukraine's sovereignty and independence will be to carry out these reforms quickly, necessary to have a reliable and impartial judicial system, promote the rule of law, eradicate corruption, decentralize power and protect freedom of the press and the rights of minorities. The Minsk Protocol is the reference document for peace. We urge all parties to fully implement the Protocol. We stand alongside the innocent civilians who are suffering in the areas affected by the conflict in eastern Ukraine. We call for more humanitarian aid and urge all parties to immediately halt the fighting. There is no military solution to that crisis. A peaceful solution must be found through an inclusive national dialogue for reconciliation.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing — The conflict in eastern Ukraine has already claimed more than 4700 victims since the formation of the government forces' counter-terrorism operation against pro-Russian separatists. The fierce clashes around Donbass and the cancellation of the planned peace summit to be held in Astana do not give cause for optimism. The reason for the cancellation of the planned meeting of political leaders is the constant violation of the ceasefire for both parties and the resulting non-compliance with the Minsk peace agreement. At present, the fulfilment of one of the points of the Mins Memorandum on the departure of illegal armed groupings from the territory of the country is not real either. The newly elected Ukrainian Government must take radical steps and continue to implement reforms and ensure an early resolution of the conflict in the interests of the citizens.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. — (IT) Interference in the Ukrainian question and the myopic policy towards Russia is a symbol of the failure of European foreign policy.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. — Since the joint motion for a resolution condemns russia's policy, which it considers responsible for the situation in Ukraine and a threat to the unity of the entire European Union, as strongly aggressive and expansive, my vote is against it.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. — I voted in favour to show the European Parliament's willingness to contribute to the resolution of the conflict in eastern Ukraine. The situation of conflict, far from improving, continues to experience a relentless deterioration, a sign of which is the continuous drip of the dead that occur in the east of the country as a result of the clashes. According to a United Nations report, 4,317 people have lost their lives in eastern Ukraine, including nearly 1,000 since the Minsk ceasefire agreement of 5 September 2014, which remains unused months after its signing. Human rights violations in eastern Ukraine and Crimea, where Tatars and other minorities, particularly religious, are also of high concern are the subject of concrete human rights violations. Russia's illegal annexation of the Crimean peninsula is against international law and constitutes a violation of international treaties signed by Russia. The European Union must continue its diplomatic efforts to alleviate the conflict, as well as support the Ukrainian Government in the process of political and economic reforms undertaken.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: in writing. — The Socialists support Ukraine's sovereignty, territorial integrity, unity and independence. That is why we support the new Government of Ukraine, which is trying to reform the country. I voted on the resolution because I believe that the best defence of Ukraine's sovereignty and independence will be to carry out these reforms quickly, necessary to have a reliable and impartial judicial system, promote the rule of law, eradicate corruption, decentralize power and protect freedom of the press and the rights of minorities. The Minsk Protocol is the reference document for peace. We urge all parties to fully implement the Protocol. We stand alongside the innocent civilians who are suffering in the areas affected by the conflict in eastern Ukraine. We call for more humanitarian aid and urge all parties to immediately halt the fighting. There is no military solution to that crisis. A peaceful solution must be found through an inclusive national dialogue for reconciliation.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: in writing. — The Socialists support Ukraine's sovereignty, territorial integrity, unity and independence. That is why we support the new Government of Ukraine, which is trying to reform the country. I voted on the resolution because I believe that the best defence of Ukraine's sovereignty and independence will be to carry out these reforms quickly, necessary to have a reliable and impartial judicial system, promote the rule of law, eradicate corruption, decentralize power and protect freedom of the press and the rights of minorities. The Minsk Protocol is the reference document for peace. We urge all parties to fully implement the Protocol. We stand alongside the innocent civilians who are suffering in the areas affected by the conflict in eastern Ukraine. We call for more humanitarian aid and urge all parties to immediately halt the fighting. There is no military solution to that crisis. A peaceful solution must be found through an inclusive national dialogue for reconciliation.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: in writing. — (IT) I support the motion on the situation in Ukraine because Russia's aggressive and expansionist policy violates both Ukraine's independence and territorial integrity. Similarly, Russia's support for separatists in eastern Ukraine, by sending regular weapons, mercenaries and soldiers, violates international law and infringes the rights of the local civilian population. For this reason, I believe that the sanctions adopted are necessary in order to make clear to Russia the conditions on which the EU is not prepared to give in. This does not mean abandoning a diplomatic solution. The channels of dialogue must remain open and open to comparison

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. — We voted against the Resolution on the situation in Ukraine because, in the face of the conflict that has been going on for months, as well as the current weakness of the ceasefire, it continues to regard Russia as solely responsible for the conflict, while maintaining a defiant position on the part of the European Union by insisting on sanctions on Russia, which so far have only led to a crisis in the agricultural sector with significant consequences for farmers.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the resolution on Ukraine. The European Union has to stand together with the people of Ukraine, who chose a European future. I call for continued sanctions against this aggressive neighbour, Russia.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: in writing. — The Socialists support Ukraine's sovereignty, territorial integrity, unity and independence. That is why we support the new Government of Ukraine, which is trying to reform the country. I voted on the resolution because I believe that the best defence of Ukraine's sovereignty and independence will be to carry out these reforms quickly, necessary to have a reliable and impartial judicial system, promote the rule of law, eradicate corruption, decentralize power and protect freedom of the press and the rights of minorities. The Minsk Protocol is the reference document for peace. We urge all parties to fully implement the Protocol. We stand alongside the innocent civilians who are suffering in the areas affected by the conflict in eastern Ukraine. We call for more humanitarian aid and urge all parties to immediately halt the fighting. There is no military solution to that crisis. A peaceful solution must be found through an inclusive national dialogue for reconciliation.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution because I believe that Ukraine needs strong support from the European Union at this difficult time. Armed conflict is still ongoing in the eastern regions of the country and I believe that the EU must act in solidarity with the people of Ukraine and to protect its democratic sovereignty and independence.

name: Anja HAZEKAMP
text: Written. — I voted against this resolution on the situation in Ukraine because the text is unbalanced. On the one hand, where the role of Russia is rightly rejected, the role played by the EU in the escalation of the conflict in eastern Ukraine is not recognised. The one-sidedness of the text does not show any reflection and self-reflection on the part of the EU and will be more likely to backfire. This attitude of the European Union towards Ukraine has major geopolitical consequences. That is why restraint and care are of great importance.  Moreover, the Party for Animals voted against the conclusion of an ASSOCIATION agreement between the EU and Ukraine, because it did not guarantee human rights, the interests of animals and the protection of nature and the environment. International security, human rights, democracy and the protection of our environment are at all times more important than short-sighted trade policy.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. - We voted against the Resolution on the situation in Ukraine because, in the face of the conflict that has been going on for months, as well as the current weakness of the ceasefire, it continues to regard Russia as solely responsible for the conflict, remaining on the part of the European Union a defiant position by insisting on sanctions on Russia, which so far have only led to a crisis in the agricultural sector with significant consequences for farmers.

name: Robert Jarosław IWASZKIEWICZ
text: I would like to write to the Commission. — I voted against the resolutions on the situation in Ukraine because they lack some very important topics. Firstly, they do not take into account the current historical policy of the Ukrainian state and ukrainian voluntary troops. The Volynian genocide and the criminal organisations responsible for these murders cannot be the foundation of Ukrainian identity, and they are presented for such. Secondly, the resolutions did not take into account in the slightest the free will expressed in referendums by the peoples of Crimea, Doneck or Lugansk regarding autonomy towards the government in Kiev or even a return to their historical statehood. Thirdly, finally, the resolutions did not refer in any way to the socio-political and economic situation of the Ukrainian State, which led to the current state of affairs. A state digested by economic crises, corruption, the pathology of oligarchy rule, with a weak state apparatus, an unenforceable justice system has become, in the first place, an arena of internal struggles, which eventually turned into demands for autonomy supported by popular will.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. — I voted for a resolution on the situation in Ukraine as I support the international community's commitment to strengthen economic and political stability and to launch key reforms in Ukraine. I also believe that there is a need for reforms that will contribute to energy security and address the humanitarian crisis that has hit this country, with the help of the European Union and other international organisations. It is necessary to strengthen ukraine's core values, which should rely on democratic principles and the rule of justice. Therefore, Ukraine's European path implies a zero tolerance rate for corruption, which is still largely present and finding a peaceful solution to the crisis with Russia by contributing to the stabilisation of the area.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. "I voted against a resolution contrary to the interests of France and Europe. The extension of sanctions to the energy sector, particularly gas, is a serious damage to the continent's energy policy. It is a policy of exclusive service to the United States, benefiting from the deterioration of our energy relations with Russia.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. "I voted in favour of the resolution on the situation in Ukraine. The text renews the European Parliament's support for the legitimate Ukrainian government and condemns Russia's expansionist policy in Ukraine. As a result, Parliament supports the continuation of a sanction regime against Russia, while leaving the door open to discussions to resolve the conflict. The resolution was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of this new resolution on Ukraine, which calls for a political solution to a crisis that is bogged down and could turn into a frozen conflict in eastern Ukraine and Crimea. After nine months of fighting, more than 4,700 people have been killed, many of them civilians, and Ukrainians seem resigned to further clashes. The EU must remain firm towards Russia, but the diplomatic path must be strengthened to encourage it to actively participate in the search for a peaceful solution to the conflict. The Minsk ceasefire agreements concluded in September 2014, as well as the subsequent peace memorandum, must be strictly enforced to allow the creation of a 30 km wide demilitarized zone and a special status for the Donetsk Republic and Lugansk Republic.

name: Georgios KATROUGKALOS
text: Writing. — I also voted against this resolution on Ukraine because, like the previous one, it does not properly attribute responsibility for causing the crisis, in particular by removing the responsibilities of the EU and NATO. It is also unacceptable not to condemn the attempt to outlaw the Ukrainian KK, in violation of Europe's tradition of civil liberties.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. — I supported the resolution, as it stresses the need for the new Ukrainian Government to move forward the reform agenda and calls on all concerned parties to ensure a peaceful resolution of the crisis. The EU should assist the country to carry out reforms and to cope with its humanitarian and health emergency.

name: Béla KOVÁCS
text: Writing. - Someone among the EU leaders asked the people of his country whether the second world war would be a good time. Do you want to be part of another world war around the 70th anniversary of the end of World War II? Or are these esteemed leaders escalating the situation out of self-desperity? For whose sake? On whose behalf? One group offers real solutions to the problems, the other seeks to preserve the war situation and even deepen the conflict. With balanced amendments that respect all parties, the resolution would have been eligible, but not without their adoption. If both the OSCE and Amnesty International have uncovered war crimes committed by the Ukrainian army and Ukrainian free troops, why is the EU not sanctioning those responsible? How many thousands of civilian casualties do it take to reach the stimulus threshold of our democrats, who are so sensitive to human rights?

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. — The Socialists support Ukraine's sovereignty, territorial integrity, unity and independence. That is why we support the new Government of Ukraine, which is trying to reform the country. I voted in favour of the resolution because I believe that the best defence of Ukraine's sovereignty and independence will be to carry out these reforms quickly, necessary to have a reliable and impartial judicial system, promote the rule of law, eradicate corruption, decentralize power and protect press freedom and minority rights. The Minsk Protocol is the reference document for peace. We urge all parties to fully implement the Protocol. We stand alongside the innocent civilians who are suffering in the areas affected by the conflict in eastern Ukraine, and call for more humanitarian aid, while urging all parties to immediately halt the fighting. There is no military solution to that crisis. A peaceful solution must be found through an inclusive national dialogue for reconciliation.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: in writing. — The Socialists support Ukraine's sovereignty, territorial integrity, unity and independence. That is why we support the new Government of Ukraine, which is trying to reform the country. I voted on the resolution because I believe that the best defence of Ukraine's sovereignty and independence will be to carry out these reforms quickly, necessary to have a reliable and impartial judicial system, promote the rule of law, eradicate corruption, decentralize power and protect freedom of the press and the rights of minorities. The Minsk Protocol is the reference document for peace. We urge all parties to fully implement the Protocol. We stand alongside the innocent civilians who are suffering in the areas affected by the conflict in eastern Ukraine. We call for more humanitarian aid and urge all parties to immediately halt the fighting. There is no military solution to that crisis. A peaceful solution must be found through an inclusive national dialogue for reconciliation.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. — The Resolution on the situation in Ukraine under a vote brings together all the falsehoods that have been poured into the media about the conflict in Ukraine and makes an analysis whose sole objective is to justify, on the one hand, European trade policy towards Eastern Europe and, on the other hand, the geopolitical reasoning of the United States; which is why I voted against it with complete conviction. In this way, the text focuses on attacking Russophone militants, calling them "terrorists", and condemns their "criminal conduct", while the use of force by the Ukrainian authorities does not deserve the slightest reproach. Nowhere in the text does the existence of a coup d'a state be mentioned. On the other hand, the Resolution opens the door to Ukraine's accession to NATO. At the same time, the role of the European Union is limited to helping Ukraine implement the Association Agreement, which will undoubtedly contribute to the spread of inequalities in Ukraine and subjugate Ukraine to the interests of European powers.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. — The situation in Ukraine is still very sensitive today, and much work remains to ensure the positive resolution of the conflict in the area. Despite this situation, it is worth noting positively the strong political commitment of the democratically elected Ukrainian Government to peace on its territory and the planning of a process of stabilizing reforms for the country. The current Government must strive to re-launch its nation, thus ensuring the well-being of its citizens. To this end, it must carry out major reforms, including the need to create an independent anti-corruption office, which would serve to eradicate systematic corruption in the country. The European institutions must give their utmost support to the efforts of the new Government, as it will benefit both Ukrainians and their neighbours and other European citizens. In turn, Russia's continuity of its aggressive and expansionist policy is utterly reprehensible. The EU must continue to promote diplomatic channels, but also maintain existing sanctions and avoid Russia's abuses of power as much as possible. That is why I vote in favour of this proposal.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. — After pro-Russian separatists seized control of much of eastern Ukraine and Russia annexed Crimea at the beginning of 2014, tensions between Russia and the West rose. The United States, NATO and the European Union hold Russia responsible for separatism, hence the sanctions imposed on it.  The results of Ukraine's early parliamentary elections are a sign that the country wants to go down the path of European integration. Implementation of reforms is a necessary precondition for stabilising the situation. The European Union must assist Ukraine in every possible way in the peaceful reintegration of occupied territory as well as in returning illegally annexed Crimea to Ukraine's constitutional order.  I support this Resolution and call for an urgent solution to the crisis in Ukraine. I strongly condemn Russia's destabilizing of the situation in eastern Ukraine and call for the implementation of the Minsk agreements.

name: Svetoslav Hristov MALINOV
text: in writing. — In today's vote, 15 January 2015, a resolution on the situation in Ukraine by the European Parliament (EP) managed to unite around a common position of solidarity with the country and its citizens.  The resolution strongly condemns all acts of terrorism and criminal behavior of separatists and other illegal forces in eastern Ukraine. The subject of sharp criticism is Russia's aggressive expansionist policy, which poses a threat not only to the integrity and independence of Ukraine, but also to the European Union as a whole. I am particularly pleased that the resolution supports the current union sanctions regime and stands firm for adherence to it in the event that Russia continues to destabilise eastern Ukraine. The EP's message clearly states that the Association Agreement concluded between the EU and Ukraine does not constitute an end goal in their bilateral relations and reminds of the possibility, given the country's prominent European perspective, of applying for accession to the Union.  I welcome the strong signal of support for Ukraine's European aspirations, reflected in the full text of the resolution. I wish for the smooth and successful implementation of the necessary reforms that lie ahead for the country.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. - I voted against this resolution because it will only exacerbate the current situation in eastern Ukraine, will not benefit peace, nor will it help peace talks between all parties to the conflict. Despite the position of my S&D group to vote against all the amendments proposed by the GUE/NGL Group, I abstained and did not vote against them (as my other fellow Social Democrats did). These amendments are: after paragraph 1, amendment 8, Amendment 1: military repression against the Donbas protest movement, Amendment 9( criminalisation of communist ideology), Amendment 10 (withdrawal of Ukrainian aggression forces from Donbas), Amendment 11 ( military agressiveness of NATO), after paragraph 3, amendment 6 (english: insemination of attacks of attacks against the Communist party). I voted in favour of the amendment in paragraph 6, amendment. No 2 (stop sanctions against Russia) because I believe that sanctions do not have any effect and do not work. Also with regard to the amendments to this text, I voted against the original text of paragraph 13, which would allow EU Member States to supply arms to Ukraine. I repeat: in general, I voted against this resolution with my hand. There is only one way to go on the ukrainian crisis: diplomacy and negotiations.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. — I am voting against the joint motion for a resolution because I believe that it does not contribute to the consolidation of peace in the Ukraine region.

name: Jiří MAŠTÁLKA
text: Writing. - First of all, I would like to distance myself once again from the representatives of the EU and some statesmen of the Member States of the Union who have been involved in unleashing political passions in Ukraine. The passions that led first to overthrow a properly elected – albeit often rightly criticized – president and then into civil war. Organizing parliamentary elections in conditions of civil war, media and physical violence is the legitimization of a coup only for those who do not understand what freedom and democracy are. Democracy is not the "final solution to the Russian question" by shooting people in Oder or shelling donbas residential neighborhoods. Democracy is an agreement between different social groups, different ethnicities, different confessions. Not the victory of the oligarchs over the poor, not the victory of one language group over another, not one patriarchy over another. We must make it clear to statesmen in Kiev, Moscow and Washington that we see an immediate cessation of hostilities as the only possible beginning for a solution to the situation in Ukraine. In a pluralistic society like Ukraine's, diversity must also be reflected in constitutional order. Reforms must be prepared that strengthen self-government, protect ethnic and religious minorities, and ensure economic development. Since the joint resolution on this subject was moving in a completely unacceptable direction for me, I voted against it.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. — (IT) I have chosen to abstain from voting on this motion for a resolution, because I think it is still too early for the European Parliament to give a definitive view of the situation in Ukraine.  However, I agree with the reference made by the High Representative to the need to strengthen diplomatic dialogue with Russia.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. — (DE) I would have rejected this request because it reflects a misconception of reality. Instead of a sober presentation of the problem, the motion reflects the anti-Russian policy of the West and thus makes it impossible to engage constructively with this issue.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. — This text, in line with the precedents, aims to shift responsibility for the Ukrainian conflict to Russia alone. It ignores the various reports of international organizations or NGOs strongly condemning the barbaric acts of the Ukrainian army and its fascist militias. This text provides for European support for the Ukrainian army, by sending defensive weapons. The Donbass insurgents, who have strong local civilian support, are also labelled terrorists. The choice to deprive itself of energy trade with Russia is clearly assumed as an objective, despite its economic and diplomatic absurdity. Finally, the text plans to create a communication strategy to counter Russian propaganda and to "develop instruments that would enable the EU and its members to make its own propaganda at a European and national level". Thus, our media, already massively anti-Russian, are not enough, we must create propaganda instruments assumed at European level. Let us remember that propaganda is not information. Are we at war with Russia? I'm voting against it.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. " The situation in Ukraine is of particular concern to me. I consider it to be a strategic country in Europe, which has been successively undermined by Russia. The EU cannot ignore the escalation of the military conflict in eastern Ukraine, in which russian military personnel are known to be fighting Ukrainian forces alongside separatist rebels. The EU's foreign policy must be at the forefront of unequivocal support for Ukraine in drawing up a peace plan. We must support the Government and the President, who were elected in the last elections and help them keep Ukraine one and sovereign. The EU must maintain good neighbourly relations with Russia, but it must not be intimidated by its threats to Ukraine. We must be uncompromising in defending Ukraine's sovereignty, even if we have to extend the economic embargo measures on Russia.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution because it covers the multiple and complex issues that the conflict in Ukraine have raised. I support the resolution’s call for swifter and more substantial technical assistance by the Commission’s ‘Ukraine Support Group’ and the call for the international community to support the economic and political stabilisation of Ukraine. The Ukrainian people chose to move closer to Europe and we must therefore show full solidarity with them. The resolution also highlights the need to enhance the EU’s energy security, thus reducing the EU’s vulnerability to external pressure from actors that seek to use energy supplies as a bargaining tool.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. I strongly condemn the violence in eastern Ukraine and call for the implementation of the Minsk agreement. Its implementation is the prerequisite for political dialogue, which remains the only solution to the conflict. In this regard, I call on the parties to put an end to the belligerent comments in order to avoid radicalisation. This dialogue must be conducted in accordance with national, regional and local levels of governance - with respect for Ukraine's territorial integrity and sovereignty - in order to establish a decentralized Ukrainian state. I attach great importance to the provision of the resolution calling for the improvement of the Union's energy security, its independence and its resilience in the face of external pressures, notably through the establishment of a European Energy Union.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. — The resolution on Ukraine assesses the situation in the light of the formation of a new government in Kiev, the continuous violations of the ceasefire in eastern Ukraine, and the ongoing efforts for a peaceful resolution of the crisis. The resolution focuses on the need to move forward the reform agenda, calls on all parties, and in particular Russia, to fully respect the Minsk arrangements, and looks into the humanitarian aspect of the crisis. Therefore, I voted in favour of a resolution that stresses the need for the new Ukrainian Government to move forward the reform agenda and calls on all concerned parties to ensure a peaceful resolution of the crisis in eastern Ukraine.

name: Sorin MOISĂ
text: in writing. — The European Union does not seem as stable enough to effectively counter Russia's information war in Ukraine, Moldova and other vulnerable states in Eastern Europe. Among other things, this resolution calls on the European Commission to propose a coherent strategy, in two months, to counter propaganda based on much untruth and intimidation. The resolution also calls for further or increased sanctions against Russia in a manner commensurate with Russia's destabilizing actions. It is the only way in which we can actually defend ourselves from a stupefying, in continuous form, on international law and order.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. — Ukraine held parliamentary elections, giving way to a new government formed by pro-European forces with a constitutional majority. A coalition agreement has already been adopted laying the foundations for a rigorous reform process aimed at fostering further European integration. I believe that it is time for Russia to stop supporting the separatist forces in the easternmost territories, notably in Donetsk and Luhansk, and to leave Crimea permanently which they have clearly annexed illegally. I would like to support the sanctions measures adopted by the international community, stressing that the maintenance, strengthening or reversibility of EU restrictive measures must depend on Russia's own attitude and the situation in Ukraine. Finally, I would like to express my full solidarity and support for the Ukrainian people, as well as for the economic and political reforms that are being implemented to modernise the country.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. — The European Parliament has proposed a unambiguous draft resolution, marked by anti-Russian ideology and showing manifest bad faith. The text clearly assumes the request for greater US involvement in a conflict that does not concern them at all. But above all, a sentence should be extracted from this text: "Share its full solidarity with Ukraine and its people; reiterates its commitment to independence, sovereignty, territorial integrity, the inviolability of borders and Ukraine's European choice." How can the European Union claim to defend sovereignty and territorial integrity when it has built itself on the dilution of the sovereignty of peoples and has rendered territorial integrity meaningless by imposing the principle of free movement. But the most shocking thing is that the European Union completely ignores the multiple human rights violations and massacres committed by the Ukrainian army, the latest being the deaths of 30 civilians in the Gorlovka district as a result of bombing by the Ukrainian air force.  For all these reasons, I have obviously voted against this draft resolution.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. — I voted for this resolution as it reiterates support for non-recognition of Crimea and clarifies that the sanctions imposed on Russian individuals and industries is not directed against Russia or its people but are means to finding a peaceful solution to the conflict in the region.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. — I voted for this report and welcome its call for the resumption of a genuine and inclusive national dialogue that could also lead to a solution for the payment of social allowances and pensions and the provision of humanitarian assistance by the Ukrainian Government to the conflict-zone population; it takes the view that it is of crucial importance to impartially and effectively investigate all major moments of violence, including those of Maidan, Odesa, Mariupol, Slovyansk, Ilovaysk and Rymarska; it believes that civil society organisations can play an important role in facilitating people-to-people contacts and mutual understanding in Ukraine, as well as promoting democratic change and respect for human rights; it urges the EU to step up its support for civil society.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. — (IT) I supported the European Parliament resolution on the situation in Ukraine. The European Union has a duty to continue to support every effort by the Ukrainian Government to consolidate the process for achieving effective peace. Immediate action by international institutions and all parties to the conflict is a priority to support a rapid process of resolving its internal conflict.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. — (IT) The European Union has a duty to continue to support every effort by the Ukrainian Government to reassert its sovereignty and independence, through far-reaching reforms of its judicial system and through the adoption of new measures to guarantee the rule of law, combat corruption, protect the freedom of the press and the rights of its minorities. With this resolution we also wish to highlight the serious humanitarian situation that has arisen in recent months in the eastern territories of the country and which requires immediate action by international institutions (United Nations, Red Cross). We call on all parties to the conflict to facilitate the full implementation of the provisions of the Minsk Protocol and on the Member States to proceed as quickly as possible with the ratification of the EU-Ukraine Association Agreement, as a first step towards a rapid process of bringing Ukraine closer to democratic values and principles and supporting a rapid process of resolving its internal conflict.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. — It is very important for the European Parliament to stand up for Ukraine, which is why I voted in favour of this resolution. There is a war going on in Ukraine and more and more civilian casualties, so it is our duty to act vigorously and with unity. The other day, pro-Russian separatists killed 11 civilians in Donetsk, and fighting is raging for the airport. Meanwhile, Russia is in an extremely serious economic situation, and sanctions make it difficult for it to get out of the crisis. None of this motivated Putin to get ahead in peace talks with Ukraine, which reached freezing point in Berlin.  However, the war has effectively destroyed not only the people of Ukraine because of the weapons, but also the already weak economy. And the ukrainian oligarchs do not drink the juice of this, but the Ukrainian people. I trust that we will be able to achieve a unified position on the EU-Russia relationship. Since the signing of the Association Agreement with Ukraine, we have been more responsible for promoting peace. And that seems to be possible on an economic front after all.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. — I co-signed and voted for this resolution because it encourages the Ukrainian authorities to pursue the political and socio-economic reforms begun, with a view to building a prosperous and democratic state based on the rule of law. Also, in its text, the European Parliament resolution suggests that civil society organisations could play a greater role in social and civic dialogue in Ukraine, as well as in promoting democratic change and respect for human rights.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. — The situation in Ukraine is getting worse by the day. The country is still searching for its identity. Ways must be found to improve solidarity among the Member States if the crisis with Russia continues. Billions have already been invested in Ukraine, and there is talk of renewed financial support. So far, it is uncertain what exactly the money should be used for. Because of the many ambiguities, I voted against this motion.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: In writing. I voted against the joint resolution on the situation in Ukraine because it is clearly unilateral in favour of the Kiev government, while the situation on the ground does not allow us to take such a biased position, especially when we know that one of the causes of the current conflict in Ukraine was the EU's direct support for the rapprochement between Kiev and Brussels.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. — I supported the resolution. Problem number one is the ongoing conflict in eastern Ukraine and the annexation of Crimea by Russia. Yesterday and the day before yesterday, so-called separatists violated the arms of at least 84 people, including more than 10 people killed in a tour bus. However, russia has the key to ending the conflict. However, Ukraine itself can finally embark on a comprehensive fight against corruption and a thorough reform process. There's no time for that indefinitely.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution on the situation in Ukraine because I believe that Russia's illegal annexation of Crimea is the most serious violation of the principle of territorial sovereignty in Europe since the Second World War. Russia, through its policy, has repeatedly put pressure on former satellite countries to re-establish lost influence. The EU must adopt a decisive, coherent and comprehensive response in favour of independence, sovereignty, territorial integrity and the inviolability of borders, which will therefore result in a new strategy towards Russia. The difficult humanitarian situation linked to the conditions of internally displaced persons in Ukraine and Crimea requires a concrete commitment on the part of the Commission and the Commissioner for Humanitarian Aid. I therefore consider it essential to insist on the political line of non-recognition of the annexation of Crimea and the elections held in Donetsk and Luhansk on 2 November 2014. Only through a strong and unique voice from the 28 Member States of the European Union could the efforts made so far lead to concrete results.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. — Having regard to the previous conclusions of the European Council and the Resolutions of the European Parliament on Ukraine, in view of the socio-political problems which it continues to face and which undermine its stability and prosperity, in view of the need for greater border control and arms trafficking by Moscow, with a view to consolidating the process of achieving effective peace , given the need for effective assistance to the local population, especially for displaced persons and refugees, given the need for increased financial assistance to Ukraine in order to promote its entry into the Union, for these reasons I am voting in favour.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. " While accusing Russia of inflaming the situation, the European Parliament proposes to send arms to the Kiev government. The European Union once again fails to act as an intermediary for the construction of peace and leads a country towards civil war without even seeming to realize it. Such a little nuanced resolution, which is dependent on Russia alone, without any questioning the attitude of the Kiev government, is not acceptable. So I'm voting against it.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of this resolution because the serious situation which has arisen over the last year in Ukraine represents a threat not only to those territories but to europe as a whole. The hybrid and undeclared war that Russia is carrying out with the complicity of Ukrainian separatists is no longer tolerable. Acts of terrorism, intimidation, arms flows and energy blackmail must stop. For this reason, the European Union must act on two fronts: on the one hand, to continue the sanctions regime established for Russia, until Moscow respectes what is defined in the Minsk Protocol; on the other hand, to support president Porosenko's pro-European government, which emerged from regular elections in October 2014, in completing the reform process for the construction of a democratic state, in the protection of citizens' rights and needs.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. — (IT) Although I believe it is of the utmost importance that the EU, together with the Ukrainian authorities, intervene decisively, but in full respect of international law and the principles of neutrality, impartiality and independence, in order to alleviate the suffering of the people of Ukraine, who, as a result of the conflict, are paying a high price in humanitarian terms and in terms of the health emergency, I have chosen to abstain on the resolution pending the resumption of dialogue between the parties involved. This is in order to understand in greater depth what really needs to be done to ensure that the resumption of negotiations leads to a truly shared and stable political solution, so as to prevent the Balkanisation of the conflict in eastern Ukraine and Crimea.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. " Repeated violations of ceasefires by pro-Russian forces are a fact. I the united states thereby commending the courage of MePs in reporting on the situation in Ukraine. It is a great indignation that violations of the Minsk agreements undermine both relations between Russia and Ukraine, but above all harm the well-being of the people.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution on the Ukraine crisis and the state of relations between the EU and Russia because I believe that, in view of the fact that the ceasefire of 5 September 2014 is being systematically violated by separatists and Russian forces, an appeal should be made to the parties to make every effort to implement the Full and Good Faith implementation of the Minsk Protocol and to urge Russia to immediately withdraw all military means and all its forces from Ukraine and to put an end to any direct or indirect support for the actions of the separatist militias. In this sense, the current EU sanctions regime against Russia should continue until Moscow is willing to change its current policy and actively contribute to a peaceful solution to the Ukrainian crisis.  I also join in the show of solidarity with Ukraine and its people and i welcome the reformist commitment of the respective authorities to bring the EU closer to it.

name: Robert ROCHEFORT
text: In writing. "I voted in favour of this resolution which condemns russian actions in Ukraine and shows its full solidarity. In particular, we call on the European Council to put the subject on the table at the summit in March, and to adopt a strict framework for defining whether sanctions can be lifted or not. Furthermore, Ukraine needs external support to deal with the current situation: we call on the European Union to act urgently in the face of the current humanitarian crisis, and to provide more substantial technical assistance, including the removal of advisers to help it implement the reforms.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. — The Socialists support Ukraine's sovereignty, territorial integrity, unity and independence. That is why we support the new Government of Ukraine, which is trying to reform the country.
