I voted on the resolution because I believe that the best defence of Ukraine's sovereignty and independence will be to carry out these reforms quickly, necessary to have a reliable and impartial judicial system, promote the rule of law, eradicate corruption, decentralize power and protect freedom of the press and the rights of minorities. The Minsk Protocol is the reference document for peace. We urge all parties to fully implement the Protocol. We stand alongside the innocent civilians who are suffering in the areas affected by the conflict in eastern Ukraine. We call for more humanitarian aid and urge all parties to immediately halt the fighting. There is no military solution to that crisis. A peaceful solution must be found through an inclusive national dialogue for reconciliation.

name: Teresa RODRIGUEZ-RUBIO
text: in writing. - We voted against the Resolution on the situation in Ukraine because, in the face of the conflict that has been going on for months, as well as the current weakness of the ceasefire, it continues to regard Russia as solely responsible for the conflict, remaining on the part of the European Union a defiant position by insisting on sanctions on Russia, which so far have only led to a crisis in the agricultural sector with significant consequences for farmers.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. I welcome the vote of this resolution, which calls on all parties to implement the Minsk Protocol without further delay in its entirety and thus to show their true determination in favour of de-escalating the conflict. The resolution also calls on Russia to authorize international control of the Russian-Ukrainian border, use its influence with the separatists to ensure that they respect the ceasefire and work constructively to implement the Minsk agreement. The European Parliament also encouraged the adoption of confidence-building measures to support peace and reconciliation efforts and stressed, in this context, the importance of an inclusive political dialogue and an economic programme for the recovery of the Donbass economy.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. — On 26 October 2014, Ukrainians voted in favour of a government in favour of deepening relations with the EU in elections characterised by diversity of applications and respect for fundamental freedoms. The elected parliamentary majority is now in a position to introduce amendments to the constitution and implement the set of reforms needed to boost Ukraine's European vocation. Nevertheless, this objective has strong opposition from Russia and pro-Russian separatist movements. It is therefore urgent to respond effectively to this terrible conflict by condemning Russia's aggressive and expansionist policy, which poses a threat to Ukraine's unity and independence, demanding compliance with its obligations and the implementation of the Minsk agreements in their entirety, in accordance with the principles of good faith, the rule of law and under the applicable international provisions and with which Russia has committed itself. As far as the reforms to be initiated by Ukraine, I consider it essential that the Commission help to draw up a plan for Ukraine that includes a strong humanitarian action plan and priorities for the state's own consolidation actions, tangible criteria and a timetable for its implementation.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. — Given the difficult situation in Ukraine, the European Union must affirm its support for its neighbour, which has embarked on an important reform process.  We must encourage Ukraine to continue its efforts in the implementation of the EU-Ukraine Association Agreement, of which the achievement of a comprehensive and comprehensive free trade agreement is part. It is also imperative that Russia respect the ceasefire, withdraw Russian troops and illegally armed groups from Ukrainian territory and respect Ukraine's territorial integrity.  Finally, the European Parliament calls on the Commission to present a communication strategy in the near future in order to counter the various communication campaigns launched by Russia, particularly directed towards the EU.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. — We voted against the Resolution on the situation in Ukraine because, in the face of the conflict that has been going on for months, as well as the current weakness of the ceasefire, it continues to regard Russia as solely responsible for the conflict, while maintaining a defiant position on the part of the European Union by insisting on sanctions on Russia, which so far have only led to a crisis in the agricultural sector with significant consequences for farmers.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. — The Resolution on the situation in Ukraine under a vote brings together all the falsehoods that have been poured into the media about the conflict in Ukraine and makes an analysis whose sole objective is to justify, on the one hand, European trade policy towards Eastern Europe and, on the other hand, the geopolitical reasoning of the United States; which is why I voted against it with complete conviction. In this way, the text focuses on attacking Russophone militants, calling them "terrorists", and condemns their "criminal conduct", while the use of force by the Ukrainian authorities does not deserve the slightest reproach. Nowhere in the text does the existence of a coup d'a state be mentioned. On the other hand, the Resolution opens the door to Ukraine's accession to NATO and, on each occasion when the opportunity arises, Russia's attitude to the situation is blamed, while the United States, the country involved in the coup d'ore, is not mentioned in the entire text. At the same time, the role of the European Union is limited to helping Ukraine implement the Association Agreement, which will undoubtedly contribute to the spread of inequalities in Ukraine and subjugate Ukraine to the interests of European powers.

name: Czesław Adam SIEKIERSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. — Ukraine is currently facing a number of problems, which in a way can be reduced to two fundamental challenges: internal reforms and the end of the armed conflict in the east of the country. The current government has been able to achieve some success; however, the situation is difficult and the integrity and enduring sovereignty of the State are still not sufficiently guaranteed. Changes in the state should primarily concern constitutional reform and the pursuit of decentralisation, judicial reform, changes in the electoral law and improving the business climate and making it more transparent. Ukraine seeks and receives EU support, both financially, humanely and politically. However, the country's needs are much greater than the aid it receives, as Ukraine is weakened not only by the ongoing conflict, but also by the actions of the Russian Federation from the period before the current insuchation of relations. Any systemic changes are further complicated by the high level of corruption and the fact that hostilities are taking place in the country. Diplomatic solutions are needed to reduce the situation leading to many economic disadvantages. Ukraine's growing economic weakness further hampers reforms and reduces its ability to provide its citizens with protection, medical and other services, prospects for young people, etc.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the joint motion for a resolution on the situation in Ukraine. Today’s vote shows that the majority of Members of the European Parliament have expressed full solidarity with Ukraine and its people. Once again the European Parliament has reiterated its commitment to the independence, sovereignty, territorial integrity and European choice of Ukraine. Together we condemn the acts of terrorism and criminal behaviour of the separatists and other irregular forces in eastern Ukraine.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. — I did not support the resolution on Ukraine, as I think it is necessary to point out to Russia the possible sanctions it will have if it continues to violate human rights in Ukraine. However, I do not think it is fit for purpose to insist on further increasing sanctions.  The proposed sanctions were aimed at forcing the Russian government to change its current policy and highlight the need for a constructive resolution of the Ukrainian crisis. I see this as an ineffective way to resolve the crisis, as full reconciliation between the parties involved requires mutual consensus. A protracted political solution to the crisis is the only way to reconcile the party's swrying and strengthen the country's unity.  Also, the resolution called for stricter conditions for providing any financial assistance to Ukraine in the fight against corruption. Ukraine needs stronger support to help deal with current problems, including corruption and human rights abuses.  The European Union represents a strong support for Ukraine in its efforts to become an independent, democratic, sovereign and territorially complete country. I believe that the European Union can provide Ukraine with the necessary assistance and leadership, in order to implement the necessary reforms as soon as possible and to end the crisis situation it is currently in.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. — At the end of October 2014, parliamentary elections were held in Ukraine. Despite the unrest in the country, the elections were held peacefully and democratically. The new government, made up of pro-European forces, has a majority to pass the necessary reforms and agreements. The latter are important for faster European integration, modernisation and development of the country, the introduction of democracy and the rule of law. Nevertheless, we must not turn a blind eye to the fact that the situation is very serious. The armed conflict in eastern Ukraine has caused thousands of deaths, left scores injured and hundreds of thousands of people forced to leave their homes. In the occupied eastern part of crimea, human rights violations occur daily, including intimidation of the population and disappearance of persons. For this reason, I express my full solidarity with Ukraine and its citizens. I condemn any terrorist act or criminal conduct by separatists or other illegal forces in eastern Ukraine. At the same time, I warmly welcome the positively assessed October elections, which were held peacefully despite the difficult political situation in the country. At difficult times, ukraine must be provided with economic and political support so that the country stabilises as quickly as possible and the situation calms down. Above all, that citizens will have the opportunity to live a better life. In order to improve the situation, I supported the resolution and voted in favour of it.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. — Tuesday's attack on a Ukrainian bus must be condemned in the same way as the Paris events. President Putin, who cannot find enough political courage to stop supporting the separatists, bears the unequivocal blame for the deaths of 10 people. Only on this basis can the peace process kick-start.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. — I support this Resolution on the situation in Ukraine which strongly condemns Russia's aggressive policy, which poses a threat to the unity and independence of Ukraine, and its military intervention and capture of part of Ukrainian territory. I emphasise that the illegal annexation of Crimea is the first case of violent border change and the appropriation of part of the territory of another country in Europe after World War II. With this resolution, we call on the EU institutions to respond strongly and decisively to a crisis in which Russia is neglecting the freedom, democracy, sovereignty and territorial integrity of another country. I certainly stress that political and diplomatic channels towards Russia must remain open in order to find a solution to the conflict diplomatically. The European Parliament gives absolute support to a formed pro-European majority that lays the ground out for a rigorous reform process aimed at fostering further European integration.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. - I support the Commission Vice-President's statement on the situation in Ukraine and express concern about the situation in the country. The report supports the Ukrainian government in implementing reforms. The EU advocates the development of democratics, human freedoms, territorial integration and the rule of law in Ukraine, and criticises Russia's annexation of Crimea by other respected international institutions.  The EU also supports Ukraine's path towards Euro-Atlantic integration. He condemns all forms of military action by Russia and all pretensions to Ukrainian territory. I support the call on Ukrainian leaders to make maximum efforts to root out structural corruption and to support the development of an anti-corruption committee in Ukraine. The importance of stability and energy security in the EU neighbourhood was underlined. It highlighted the position of the Russian Energy Minister who considers the trilateral treaty between the EU, Russia and Ukraine to deliver Russian gas to Europe non-binding. The EU will do its um to restore peace and stability as soon as possible and for Ukraine to take a democratic path.

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: in writing. — I supported today's resolution on the situation in Ukraine, as there is still a need to emphasise the requirements to ensure ukraine's territorial integrity and to condemn the aggressive policy of the current leadership of the Russian Federation. I support the effort to set further conditions, the fulfilment of which will be a prerequisite for the further non-extension of sanctions against the Russian Federation. I also welcome the reference to the suspension of the supply of a French military ship to the Russian Federation, which I have also advocated here in the European Parliament.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: Writing. – The Resolution attempts to embellish and reverse the truth about the ongoing drama of the Ukrainian people. The truth is that in February 2014 a coup was carried out in the country, which actively involved far-right and neo-Nazi elements. Subsequently, the Ukrainian regime launched an operation to fiercely suppress popular resistance to the coup, while to this day the Ukrainian army continues to kill its people in Eastern Ukraine. The recent elections have taken place in conditions of violence and terrorization of every opposing voice, especially the communists and all those who disagree with the nationalist, neoliberal and pro-Western agenda of the current regime. NATO's aggression in Eastern Europe and the policy of EU sanctions against Russia undermine the peace and security of our continent while at the same time victimiseing our peoples. We call for: withdrawal of Ukrainian troops from Donbass, cancellation of NATO military plans in Eastern Europe, end of sanctions against Russia, disarmament of paramilitary far-right groups in Ukraine, lifting of the criminalisation of KK Ukraine, suspension of the EU-Ukraine Association Agreement and termination of unpopular EU-IMF-Poroshenko government policies (sweeping privatisations, austerity, abolition of labour rights) which exacerbate the impoverishment of the Ukrainian people.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. — The EU must diversify its attitude towards Russia and Ukraine. A more positive attitude towards Russia will produce more positive results.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. — In the coming period, the fate of Ukraine will be a real test of our common foreign and security policy and of the Eastern Partnership. The outcome of our efforts could prove decisive for the security and stability of the region and the continent as a whole. Consistency and unity are the key to the EU's successful engagement in Ukraine: consistency in our joint action to end violence, to fully comply with the Minsk agreement and, above all, to reject the illegal annexation of Crimea, clearly including the demand for the restoration of its original state. This is a matter of principle, which cannot be subject to the criteria of political pragmatism. Unity must be embodied in the policies of the Union and its Member States, in particular in our attitude towards Russia and on the issue of sanctions. Restoring cooperation with Moscow is desirable, but this can only be achieved through a genuine EU-Russian dialogue. Any attempt by a Member State to use vague special measures along the lines of party economic interests and individual political objectives will seriously harm the interests of Ukraine, the region and the Union. The High Representative, also relying on the full authority of the Commission and the European Council, must do everything possible to make sure that the government of a Member State does not further compromise EU unity in dealing with the Russian and Ukrainian issues. In view of the fact that the joint resolution adequately reflects on these issues, I voted in favour of it.

name: Dario TAMBURRANO
text: in writing. — (IT) I believe that democracy and the reconciliation of peoples who have waged war for centuries must be founding values of the EU, which does not need a pro-Russian or anti-Russian policy, but a policy of peace to prevent the threat of the outbreak on its borders of the Third World War. The text of this resolution only condemns pro-Russian separatists and Russia and forgets the massacres and refugees of Russian-speaking civilians taking place in Ukraine today. It also forgets that the Ukrainian Government: • has armed units such as the neo-Nazi-inspired Azov Battalion, whose emblem was already in use in SS departments; • includes three foreign ministers, including a former US State Department employee, chosen by an international recruiting agency sponsored by financier Soros, who by his own admission played a role in ukrainian affairs last year. I therefore voted against this resolution because: • it successfully repudiates the blood with which Europe has freed itself from Nazism and ethnic cleansing in the past - it does not, in my view, coincide with the interest, values and will of the majority of European citizens.

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: in writing. — The crisis in Ukraine, including Russia’s annexation of Crimea in March 2014, continues to cause a strategic shock for Europe. Russian aggression has threatened the European security order that we have taken for granted since the end of the Cold War. The sending of troops into Crimea and arming militants in eastern Ukraine has significantly heightened tensions in neighbouring countries, and it would seem that Russia’s actions imply that the Kremlin is no longer interested in a partnership with Europe. In response to this violation of international law, the EU has adopted a number of sanctions against Russia. Even though a new government has been formed in Ukraine, the situation in the east is still challenging, with the ceasefire constantly being broken by the Russian-led separatists in addition to an upsurge of regular Russian troops sent into the region. Whilst it has been suggested that Ukraine should attempt to compromise with Russia, this currently seems implausible, as Mr Poroshenko recently tweeted ‘we are prepared for a scenario of total war’. My Group wholeheartedly supports the territorial integrity of Ukraine and continues to loudly call for withdrawal of Russian troops from the eastern part of the region, and in Crimea, the control over which must be returned to Kiev.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. "I voted in favour of the resolution. The continuation of the Russian embargo is still relevant as the situation is still evolving against European values. On the other hand, we have decided to grant further "macro-financial" assistance to Ukraine, in the form of medium-term loans of up to EUR 1.8 billion.  This aid, which must be approved by the Council of Ministers and the European Parliament, must help Ukraine to cope with the major difficulties it faces, including its weak balance of payments and budgetary situation. "Our actions speak louder than our words. The European Union has already provided unprecedented financial support and today's proposal proves that we are ready to continue. This is European solidarity. However, there are conditions: the payment of the last tranche of EUR 250 million is due to take place shortly, subject to the successful implementation by Ukraine of the agreed measures. Because European aid is not unconditional: in order to benefit from it, Kiev must meet a set of criteria for reform, in terms of budget, banks, energy or the judicial system.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. — I have voted in favour of the draft resolution on the situation in Ukraine in order to keep the focus on this very issue and thus contribute to a peaceful resolution. I am glad that we could have once again expressed the solidarity with Ukraine and its people, many of whom live in continuously deteriorating conditions. I am satisfied by the explicit mention of the need to continue with the sanctions against Russia and with the call to have the sanctions as a part of a broader approach towards Russia. I equally welcome the condemnation of Russia’s aggressive and expansionist policy. On the other hand, the resolution rightly expects Ukraine to implement deep reforms.

name: Traian UNGUREANU
text: in writing. — I welcome the resolution adopted by the European Parliament on the situation in Ukraine. In the light of recent events, however, it becomes extremely important for the European Union to act uniformly in terms of its positioning towards Russia. More specifically, it is necessary that both the Member States and the European Union, through all its institutions, resist the temptation to address so-called 'flexible' positions in relation to Russia. There is a need to maintain decided positions and to stop giving in to concessions and diplomatic expressions to serious and obvious abuses. Equally important that the European Union does not make the mistake of accepting so-called positive signals from Russia to suspend sanctions imposed on Russia in March, when they expire. In the absence of changes in attitude and action, these sanctions must be prolonged and strengthened. At the same time, in the light of the new security threats to the European Union, which are facing an open conflict on its eastern border, it becomes extremely important for the EU to strengthen Atlantic cooperation and to support efforts to strengthen defensive capabilities on the eastern flank of the European Union, especially those in Romania and Ukraine.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: in writing. — The Socialists support Ukraine's sovereignty, territorial integrity, unity and independence. That is why we support the new Government of Ukraine, which is trying to reform the country. I voted on the resolution because I believe that the best defence of Ukraine's sovereignty and independence will be to carry out these reforms quickly, necessary to have a reliable and impartial judicial system, promote the rule of law, eradicate corruption, decentralize power and protect freedom of the press and the rights of minorities. The Minsk Protocol is the reference document for peace. We urge all parties to fully implement the Protocol. We stand alongside the innocent civilians who are suffering in the areas affected by the conflict in eastern Ukraine. We call for more humanitarian aid and urge all parties to immediately halt the fighting. There is no military solution to that crisis. A peaceful solution must be found through an inclusive national dialogue for reconciliation.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. — The Resolution on the situation in Ukraine under a vote brings together all the falsehoods that have been poured into the media about the conflict in Ukraine and makes an analysis whose sole objective is to justify, on the one hand, European trade policy towards Eastern Europe and, on the other hand, the geopolitical reasoning of the United States; which is why I voted against it with complete conviction. Nowhere in the text does the existence of a coup d'a state be mentioned. On the other hand, the Resolution opens the door to Ukraine's accession to NATO and, on each occasion when the opportunity arises, Russia's attitude to the situation is blamed, while the United States, the country involved in the coup d'ore, is not mentioned in the entire text. At the same time, the role of the European Union is limited to helping Ukraine implement the Association Agreement, which will undoubtedly contribute to the spread of inequalities in Ukraine and subjugate Ukraine to the interests of European powers.

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: in writing. — I voted with my S & D partners in support of the sovereignty, territorial integrity, unity and independence of Ukraine. The S&D Group will continue to support the new Ukrainian Government’s efforts to build a new country. The only way forward and most effective defence for Ukrainian sovereignty and independence is to rapidly implement reforms. These are needed in order to obtain a reliable and impartial judicial system, promote the rule of law, eradicate corruption, decentralise power and protect media freedom and minority rights.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. — The implementation of the Minsk agreement is, in my view, the only way out of this crisis at the moment. The two belligerents must cease the fight immediately and dialogue must be initiated. I call on Russia to withdraw his troops from Ukrainian territory. A solution to the Ukrainian conflict will allow european and Russian sanctions to lapse. This would greatly help European fruit growers, who are suffering greatly from the Russian ban on european fruit imports.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: In writing. — With this resolution, the European Parliament has once again lost an opportunity to live up to the European values of peace and dialogue between peoples. Contrary to the gue/NGL resolution which rejects any Manichaean vision, this resolution defends a pro-Ukrainian unilateral posture without nuance.  By demonizing Russian diplomacy and Ukrainian opposition forces, without ever mentioning other interference in the country, or even the participation of far-right ministers in Petro Poroshenko's government, this text clearly takes part in this conflict, when there is more need for mediation than ever. The European Union is at odds with its so-called values, and above all that of the right of self-determination of peoples. Ukraine must not be the centre of a new conflict between cold war-like imperialisms, both in the interests of its people and in the european and global geopolitical balance. Similarly, we must guard against self-fulfilling prophecies about a so-called war of civilizations. I therefore again opposed this resolution.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. — The situation in Ukraine reveals the EU's guiding position towards the United States and NATO. Without looking at European interests, the EU embarked on an adventure through which it staged an anti-constitutional coup and broke economic and cultural ties between Ukraine and Russia that had lasted for centuries. The result is in sight. The agents who exported to Russia are heavily penalized. We are importing unnecessarily the exports from Ukraine that were directed to Russia. We are paying the gas bills that Ukraine has stopped paying russian companies. Finally, we are already on the third loan to the Government of Ukraine that sinks from day to day. To top it off, we have a government where fascist parties are in place that is repeatedly violating civil and democratic rights. It persecutes activists, seeks to outlaw political parties and bombardes defenseless civilian populations. The balance sheet could not actually be worse.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. — The situation in Ukraine is deteriorating by the day. The fighting continues to flare up again and again, and the number of civilian casualties remains, unfortunately, constantly high. Several billion euros, which were to be channelled to the good of the Ukrainian people, have been leaked into incomprehensible channels. Because of these many inconsistencies, I was unable to vote in favour of the motion.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. — (DE) I cannot agree with the decision taken by Parliament in great unanimity. In particular, the resolution paves the way for Ukraine to establish full membership of the EU. The Ukrainian people may vote in favour of joining the EU in a referendum. However, it is the responsibility of the Member States whether Ukraine is to be included. Against the background of the INTERNAL organisational disorder of the EU, its lack of democratic feedback and the worrying transfer of powers in the structure of the separation of powers from parliaments to governments, any enlargement of the EU is excluded. This also prohibits any closer relationship between the EU and Ukraine, which can only be understood as a step towards accession. However, the resolution also thinks a lot is right. I very much share, among other things, the call for Ukraine to combat 'systematic corruption'. However, I cannot accept the desired tightening of sanctions against Russia, which only affect its people. Instead, we should seek free trade with Russia. Because where goods cross borders, armies will not.

name: Iuliu WINKLER
text: in writing. - The resolution on the situation in Ukraine adopted today in the Strasbourg plenary, which I also voted on, is just one of the results of the European Parliament's ongoing concern about developments in that state. In the context that the Russian Federation is not fully complying with the obligations under the Minsk agreement of September 2014, I welcome the European Parliament's call for the continuation of the sanctions regime imposed on it.  It is also important to call on the Commission to find ways to strengthen the solidarity of the Member States with regard to the continuation of these sanctions as long as Russia feeds the Ukrainian crisis. I also welcome the European Parliament's concern about respect for fundamental human and ethnic minority rights and freedoms in Ukraine. Consistency and coherence is needed in the policy of the EU and the Member States in relation to Ukraine and in the sanctions policies applied to the Russian Federation in strengthening the EU-NATO relationship. Our goal is peace and stability in the region and maintaining the level of ambition in terms of the objectives of the Eastern Partnership.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: in writing — Although the parliamentary elections held in Ukraine last October raised hopes of positive developments in our eastern neighbour, the current situation in this post-European country remains very serious. A volatile ceasefire, a growing humanitarian catastrophe, in which thousands of people are cut off from food, medicine or heat, as well as an escalating information war on the part of Russia, are the reality of the day. Therefore, in order to resolve the difficult situation beyond its eastern borders, the European Union has no choice but to maintain the sanctions imposed against Russia. Sanctions could only be eased or lifted if the ceasefire, the unconditional withdrawal of all Russian troops and illegal armed groups from Ukraine, the exchange of all prisoners and the restoration of Ukrainian control over all its territory, including Crimea, were respected. Before this happens, it is our moral duty to support the reform efforts of the Ukrainian Government, as well as the conflict-affected citizens of Ukraine.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. — This resolution diffuses a grossly manipulated view of the situation in Ukraine, an act of propaganda which, instead of helping to appease existing tensions and contribute to the resolution of the conflict in the Donbass region, comes to pour more firewood into the fire. And it launders the responsibilities of the EU, US and NATO in promoting aggression by the ultranationalist and fascist regime against popular and patriotic resistance and crimes perpetrated against populations and the destruction of fundamental civilian infrastructure. There is an urgent need to find a solution to the conflict, with direct dialogue between the parties, which must be passed through the recognition of the belligerent status of popular resistance, with a view to establishing a real and inclusive peace process, as well as the inalienable right of resistance to oppression.  In order to legitimise the coup regime in Ukraine and the actions of those who, like the EU, support and promote it - remember the signing of the EU-Ukraine Association Agreement - it is covered that the elections following the coup took place in the context of permanent violations of civil and political rights, with widespread persecution and repression of the population, particularly of the Communist Party of Ukraine , with an ongoing legal proceedings.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: Mr President, I voted in favour of this resolution, but I would like to use the opportunity of my explanation of vote to raise once again the issue of the continued detention of Ibrahim Halawa. Last July I raised this issue in the Parliament here in Strasbourg. and what we find in that period of time is that his trial has once again been postponed. It has now been postponed for the fourth time. He has been declared a prisoner of conscience by Amnesty International, and the Irish Minister for Foreign Affairs, Charlie Flanagan, has expressed his deep concern about his detention. Ibrahim Halawa is an Irish citizen. His detention, I believe, is a violation of the EU-Egypt Association Agreement and is a clear breach of his human rights. Furthermore, I believe Ibrahim should not be tried as part of a group trial which involves a large number of defendants. He is entitled to be tried as an individual.

name: Marek JUREK
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking We all heard Prime Minister Renzi speak in this Chamber yesterday when he was finishing the Italian Presidency and when he praised President Sisi's speech at cairo university. A speech in which the President of Egypt condemned rapes carried out in the name of Islam. Egypt has been waging a civil war for almost decades, in which the government has had to fight violence. With violence against Muslims, which extremists want to re-educate, and violence against Christians who are denied the right to live in peace, and often the right to life in general. The best way the Western world can help Christians in countries where they are persecuted is to work with governments that respect Christians. I therefore voted against this resolution.

name: Seán KELLY
text: A Uachtaráin, vótáil mé arís le mo ghrúpa sna vótaí go léir anseo agus glacadh leis an tuarascáil freisin.  Like my colleague Marian Harkin, I too spoke about the position of Ibrahim Halawa last July, and I want to reiterate it again today: his situation is not acceptable. This is basically a teenager who went to Egypt and got caught up in the protests there. His three sisters were with him; they were allowed to go home but he has been detained ever since. He is awaiting a mass trial, as Marian pointed out. We would again earnestly ask the Egyptian authorities to return him to Ireland so that he can pursue his studies, and let us watch his development from there. I think that would be the best course of action. Hopefully it can be done.

name: Daniel HANNAN
text: Mr President, the Egyptian army seized power in 1952 and has not relinquished it, and everything we are talking about needs to be seen against that background. We have had, in the current government, a more repressive regime than we had under Mubarak. Mubarak never ordered the gunning down of unarmed demonstrators. Yet all of the instances of repression, whether of journalists or of civil society or of opposition groups in Egypt, are things that we effectively turned a blind eye to when we sanctioned the coup in the first place and refused to call it a coup. This repression does not become justified simply because Sisi has made a good speech in Cairo about the need for reform of Islam, or simply because he has normalised relations with Israel. On the contrary, if we set up as the only antonym to Islamism a basically autocratic government then we kill the prospects for the development of moderate conservative democracy in the Muslim world. We give people the wretched choice between generals and mullahs, which has been the curse of that region for two generations now. The people of Egypt deserve better.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. " For European Socialists, Egypt's internal situation since the revolution, its process of democratization and stability are very important. Our group calls on the Egyptian authorities to release immediately and without conditions all persons detained for exercising their right to freedom of expression and peaceful assembly. I voted on the Resolution on the situation in Egypt because it is a key country for the European Union because of its regional role and its contribution always in the Israel-Palestine conflict, as has been shown so in the negotiation of the recent ceasefire in Gaza and also in cooperation and in the fight against islamic state and other regional threats. We want to see Egypt in the right direction for the democratic transition. We urge the Egyptian authorities to work in compliance with human rights and fundamental freedoms. Harassment, intimidation or censorship of political opponents, civil society representatives and minorities are not acceptable to the EU. The parliamentary elections convened for March are essential to give a real impetus to the democratic process, and must be ensured that they are free and fair.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. — The proposed resolution for voting in the case of Egypt contains fundamental issues, such as the denunciation of the introduction of new law on public policy which, inter alia, may cause a citizen to be prosecuted in military jurisdiction in the event of evidence of a crime committed in the public domain. The release of the 167 elected parliamentarians in 2011 who are currently in prison, sentences for mass death sentences and denounces the situation of the LGBT community, in which the government's crackdown has reached the point of passing a "law on debauchery" condemning the free expression of people's sexual orientation. However, the Resolution does not include an express request for the opening of the Rafah Pass, which prevents the communication of Gazans abroad, and is of marked interference, which is why I abstained.

name: Louis ALIOT
text: In writing. — In this resolution, Parliament is deeply concerned about the widespread violation of democratic rights in Egypt, once again condemns the military coup and the brutal repression carried out by the Egyptian army, deeply deplores the loss of life and so on. If everyone agrees unanimously on these beautiful phrasings, it is not enough to deplore, condemn and worry to solve problems, but to give our real support to those who are fighting to defend a democratic model for Egypt. This text refusing any external interference to promote democratic values and fight against persecution of all kinds (especially on women and Christians), I spoke out against it.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. - I abstained on this motion for resolution on Egypt. I was disappointed that reference to the case of Ibrahim Halawa was not included in the joint motion. Sinn Féin was successful in including his case in the GUE/NGL resolution and it is regrettable that the joint motion does not mention him. As a prisoner of conscience who was imprisoned as a child following protests in August 2013, his case is an important example of the brutal repression of human rights, including the freedom of expression. I also regret that there was an emphasis on Egypt as a strategic partner for trade and security for the European Union. Relations between the EU and third countries should not be predicated on trade issues – Egypt’s citizens are currently experiencing severe repressions of their democratic rights to freedom of expression, speech and association. Concern for the violation of their democratic rights should not be diluted by mentioning trade concerns.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. — I welcome the adoption of this motion for a resolution. The deterioration of the situation of freedom of expression must not be without our response. We must defend both the foundations of democracy and human rights worldwide and condemn any impetus.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. — After the overthrow of Marshal Mubarak in 2011, Egypt experienced a period of social and religious unrest that culminated in the coming to power of Mohammed Morsi, a member of the Muslim Brotherhood, an organization affiliated with the Emirate of Qatar. The government of the Muslim Brotherhood has constantly stried to transform Egypt into an Islamist society, to establish Sharia law as a single source of law and to discriminate against Christians, who yet represent 10% of the population, while turning a blind eye to the violence that against them. Since Marshal al-Sissi came to power, the Egyptian government has been fighting against attempts by the Muslim Brotherhood to radicalize Egyptian society in order to return to power. Egypt's new constitution is the most favourable for religious minorities egypt has ever had. President al-Sissi, a devout Muslim, himself attended the Christmas Mass celebrated by the Pope of the Orthodox Copts as a sign of solidarity with Egyptian Christians. For all these reasons, I believe that the European Parliament should support the reformist will of the Egyptian government rather than try to impose sanctions on it to prevent it from fighting the Muslim Brotherhood.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. — Egypt is a country rightly proud of its historical and cultural traditions. It is dependent upon tourism for the growth of its economy. But recent events, and the erosion of civil liberties and human rights, have led to a decline in the tourist industry.  In the light of recent human rights abuses, I support the principle of this motion although I am unable to vote for it as a UKIP MEP because of the nature of the requests for Commission action – which has proved to be counterproductive in the past. Consequently, I felt that I had no choice but to abstain.

name: Inés AYALA SENDER
text: in writing. " For European Socialists, Egypt's internal situation since the revolution, its process of democratization and stability are very important. Our group calls on the Egyptian authorities to release immediately and without conditions all persons detained for exercising their right to freedom of expression and peaceful assembly. I voted on the Resolution on the situation in Egypt because it is a key country for the European Union because of its regional role and its contribution always in the Israel-Palestine conflict, as has been shown so in the negotiation of the recent ceasefire in Gaza and also in cooperation and in the fight against islamic state and other regional threats. We want to see Egypt in the right direction for the democratic transition. We urge the Egyptian authorities to work in compliance with human rights and fundamental freedoms. Harassment, intimidation or censorship of political opponents, civil society representatives and minorities are not acceptable to the EU. The parliamentary elections convened for March are essential to give a real impetus to the democratic process, and must be ensured that they are free and fair.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. — Egypt plays a key role because of its regional importance. He is an important interlocutor for the European Union. It is imperative that the Egyptian authorities meet expectations regarding democratic transition and respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. Three years after the uprising of the Egyptian people and the resignation of Hosni Mubarak, and since the fall of the Morsi government led by the Muslim Brotherhood, Egypt is led by General Al-Sissi. The situation is catastrophic, with a permanent quasi-civil war, and repressive measures have been taken. The new constitution, however, was 98% validated by egyptians and President Al-Sissi elected with 96% of the vote (doubling the number of votes of former President Morsi). Faced with the rise of radical Islamism and Muslim fundamentalism in the Arab world, which have tried to surf the post-Arab Spring and the emptiness left, the situation is still not serene and it is clear that only stability will allow these countries like Egypt to return to the path of progress and democratization in order to avoid the grip of Sharia law.  I therefore voted against this text, which does not solve the situation in any way.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. — (IT) I did not support with my flight the resolution analysing the situation in Egypt because I do not share the positions it has taken.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. " For European Socialists, Egypt's internal situation since the revolution, its process of democratization and stability are very important. Our group calls on the Egyptian authorities to release immediately and without conditions all persons detained for exercising their right to freedom of expression and peaceful assembly. I voted on the Resolution on the situation in Egypt because it is a key country for the European Union because of its regional role and its contribution always in the Israel-Palestine conflict, as has been shown so in the negotiation of the recent ceasefire in Gaza and also in cooperation and in the fight against islamic state and other regional threats. We want to see Egypt in the right direction for the democratic transition. We urge the Egyptian authorities to work in compliance with human rights and fundamental freedoms. Harassment, intimidation or censorship of political opponents, civil society representatives and minorities are not acceptable to the EU. The parliamentary elections convened for March are essential to give a real impetus to the democratic process, and must be ensured that they are free and fair.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution because the European Parliament strongly condemns all acts of violence, incitement, hate speech, harassment, intimidation and censorship used by public authorities, security forces and services and other groups in Egypt against representatives of the political opposition, protesters, journalists, bloggers, trade unionists, women's rights defenders, civil society actors and minorities. Parliament calls for an immediate end to these actions and reminds the Egyptian Government of its duty to ensure the protection and security of all citizens, regardless of their political views, membership of political organisations or beliefs, and to guarantee that freedoms of assembly, association, expression and the press can be exercised in the country without any unlawful restrictions and censorship. It is also important that the Egyptian authorities maintain dialogue, do not resort to violence and guarantee citizens' rights and freedoms. The European Parliament is concerned about the loss of independence and impartiality of egypt's criminal justice system, which has become a tool for government repression.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. I voted against the motion for a resolution. It can be noted that the resolution "welcomes and encourages the measures adopted by the Egyptian government in favour of respecting the rights and freedoms of religious communities; recalls Article 235 of the Egyptian constitution, which stipulates that during its first legislature, the newly elected parliament must pass a law to organise the construction and renovation of churches, guaranteeing Christians the freedom to practice their worship; welcomes the unprecedented presence of an Egyptian president, President Al-Sissi at Mass in a Cairo church on the occasion of Coptic Christmas, and considers it an important symbolic gesture that is part of the efforts undertaken for the unity of Egyptian society." But European governments have destabilized the region's secular regimes. We are beginning to suffer the consequences. The result of European policies is catastrophic. The efforts of countries in the region fighting fundamentalism should be supported.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: in writing. — I abstained on this motion for resolution on Egypt. I was disappointed that reference to the case of Ibrahim Halawa was not included in the joint motion. Sinn Féin was successful in including his case in the GUE/NGL resolution and it is regrettable that the joint motion does not mention him. As a prisoner of conscience who was imprisoned as a child following protests in August 2013, his case is an important example of the brutal repression of human rights, including the freedom of expression. I also regret that there was an emphasis on Egypt as a strategic partner for trade and security for the European Union. Relations between the EU and third countries should not be predicated on trade issues – Egypt’s citizens are currently experiencing severe repressions of their democratic rights to freedom of expression, speech and association. Concern for the violation of their democratic rights should not be diluted by mentioning trade concerns.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the motion because I consider Egypt a strategic partner of the EU. Also, I consider a priority the establishment of democracy and ending the violation of human rights in that country.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. — The European Parliament is concerned in this draft resolution about the policy of repression against the Muslim brothers. Blinded by their right to homomism, MEPs do not understand that the regime of Marshal Al Sissi is one of the few to wage an unrelenting war on Islamist fundamentalism. Moreover, it becomes suspicious to see the condemnations of varying geometry on the part of the European Parliament. Indeed, when is a motion for a resolution to denounce the anti-Shiite policy pursued by Bahrain's ultra-minority regime? When is a resolution demanding that Qatar stop tolerating genuine slavery practices against Nepalese migrants? When is a firm condemnation of Saudi Arabia's laws that prohibit women from driving?  Pending clarification, I voted against this draft resolution

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. — The vote on the joint resolution on the situation in Egypt underlines the importance of this State as an international actor and strategic partner of the EU and hopes that the country will continue to have an active role in launching real peace negotiations that will end these conflicts and to campaign for the fight against terrorism. It should be remembered that freedom of conscience, thought and religion should be a fundamental, universally valid right, and the fact that you publicly show this right should be respected would be an important starting point for this state's transition to democracy. In this context, I regret the decision of the Egyptian court of 10 January 2015 in the province of Baharira in the Nile Delta, which sentenced Karim al-Banna, a 25-year-old student, to three years in prison for announcing on Facebook that he was an atheist and for insulting Islam. In view of the alarming situation in the Maghreb/Mashreq region, I would like to stress that the Egyptian authorities have legal, national and international obligations to protect and promote human rights through the Constitution adopted in 2014 as a priority through the independent and impartial administration of justice.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. — 'No' vote: it is insisted that Egypt's future remain firmly in the hands of the Egyptian people, without any outside interference; it reiterates that economic, political, social, cultural or any other relationship between the EU and the countries of the European Neighbourhood Policy must be based on equal treatment, non-interference, solidarity, dialogue and respect for the asymmetries and specific characteristics of each country.

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: in writing. — The Egyptian people faced a number of difficult political and social challenges since the 2011 Revolution and need support from the international community to continue the fight for respect for human rights and the democratisation of the state. Egypt is an important partner of the European Union in the southern neighbourhood. I support this resolution, firmly believing that the authorities in Egypt must make significant efforts to guarantee freedom of the press, protect all religious communities and return property seized abusively by the former dictatorial regimes.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: in writing. " For European Socialists, Egypt's internal situation since the revolution, its process of democratization and stability are very important. Our group calls on the Egyptian authorities to release immediately and without conditions all persons detained for exercising their right to freedom of expression and peaceful assembly. I voted on the Resolution on the situation in Egypt because it is a key country for the European Union because of its regional role and its contribution always in the Israel-Palestine conflict, as has been shown so in the negotiation of the recent ceasefire in Gaza and also in cooperation and in the fight against islamic state and other regional threats. We want to see Egypt in the right direction for the democratic transition. We urge the Egyptian authorities to work in compliance with human rights and fundamental freedoms. Harassment, intimidation or censorship of political opponents, civil society representatives and minorities are not acceptable to the EU. The parliamentary elections convened for March are essential to give a real impetus to the democratic process, and must be ensured that they are free and fair.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. — (IT) Today I voted in favour of the resolution on the events in Egypt, expressing my closeness to the aspirations of the Egyptian people. These aspirations, inherent in the deepest essence of every people, namely the free expression and protection of human rights, freedom of expression, association and assembly, political pluralism and the rule of law, pursued after the dismissal of President Hosni Mubarak in February 2011, were unfortunately inexorably mortified by the Egyptian authorities in the period following the military coup in 2013. The progressive loss of independence and impartiality of the criminal justice system in Egypt, an instrument of repression in the hands of the local government, requires a revision of the Law on Judicial Authority, in order to ensure an effective separation of powers that determines, in a stable and definitive way, the independence of the administration and impartiality of justice. I can only condemn the acts of violence, harassment, intimidation or censorship perpetrated against all political opponents, demonstrators, journalists, bloggers, or civil society actors by the state authorities, forces and security services in Egypt. It is essential that impartial and independent investigations are launched into human rights abuses.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. - I abstained on this motion for a resolution on Egypt. I was disappointed that reference to the case of Ibrahim Halawa was not included in the joint motion. Sinn Féin was successful in including his case in the GUE/NGL resolution and it is regrettable that the joint motion does not mention him. As a prisoner of conscience who was imprisoned as a child following protests in August 2013, his case is an important example of the brutal repression of human rights, including the freedom of expression. I also regret that there was an emphasis on Egypt as a strategic partner for trade and security for the European Union. Relations between the EU and third countries should not be predicated on trade issues – Egypt’s citizens are currently experiencing severe repression of their democratic rights to freedom of expression, speech and association. Concern for the violation of their democratic rights should not be diluted by mentioning trade concerns.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. — I have supported this resolution as, even though Egypt has advanced quite notably in its democratic principles and it is a key regional partner to the EU, legislation such as the Protest Law of November 2013 serve to diminish its democratic credentials. Egypt needs to better engage in dialogue with civil society to ensure maximum citizen participation and can help instil a fairer society for both males and females.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. — (IT) In recognizing Egypt's fundamental role in the conclusion of the truce between Israel and Palestine and in the fight against terrorism, we must also stress the violations of human rights against journalists and bloggers detained in the country.

name: Aymeric CHAUPRADE
text: In writing. "I voted against this resolution which, unrealistically, attacks the power of Marshal Al-Sissi, currently one of the only bulwarks of Islamist fundamentalism. The regimes on which we must rely are under considerable Islamist pressure. What would be the level of rule of law of France, in the Egyptian situation, when we see the state of astonishment of French power caused by 3 terrorists? I recall that Egypt and its security forces in particular have had more than 500 deaths in the last 18 months. Abdel Fatah al-Sissi made an exceptional appeal from the largest Arab country. He called for Islam itself to be purged of its violence. He called for a religious revolution. In these circumstances, it seemed unrealistic to me to vote in favour of a resolution which, once again through interference, puts in difficulty a regime, admittedly imperfect, but the only one capable of stemming the terrorist threat in Egypt and in that part of the world.

name: Nessa CHILDERS
text: in writing. — The ongoing restrictions of human rights in Egypt under the rule of Field Marshal Abdel Fattah al-Sisi are of serious concern to the EU and we call for the immediate release of those detained for exercising their freedom of speech. The EU must work to secure the release of 19-year old Dublin teenager Ibrahim Halawa, who has been imprisoned without trial since August 2013.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. — (IT) I think that, in the present very bad situation on the southern shore of the Mediterranean, Egypt is a cause for optimism. Of course, at the moment we cannot relax and let it drift, but we need to identify the priorities to be pursued in order to improve the main political and economic indicators so as to help build a model for the other countries in the area. That is why I wanted to vote in favour of this resolution, and I hope that the next European Parliament document on this subject will read 'welcomes the results achieved'.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. — Two years ago we were all very enthusiastic about the Arab Spring and excited about the birth of a new democracy, but I am afraid we are slipping back into an Islamist Winter. The transition is difficult and will take a long time in Egypt, therefore you need patience, determination and solidarity. In order to establish a good partnership between Egypt, the EPP Group and the European Union, we must share some basic values. The EU should not only give money for unclear purposes. We need to be attentive to what is going on in Egypt. The status of Christians is of particular interest; however, apart from that, the EU is looking to ensure the respect of human dignity for everybody, and the respect of minorities, which is based on this principle as well. We should be talking about a ‘Civilisational Dialogue’

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. — I believe that the Government of Egypt should pay more attention to the European Union and the International Community when we express deep concern about the current restrictions on fundamental democratic rights, in particular freedoms of expression, association and assembly, political pluralism and the rule of law in Egypt. We cannot fail to condemn clearly the use of excessive violence against demonstrators by public authorities, forces and security services. I urge Egypt to ratify the Rome Statute and become a member of the ICC and not hesitate to promote swift, impartial and independent judicial investigations into allegations of excessive use of force, ill-treatment and other human rights violations, including sexual abuse, committed by police forces during demonstrations. I agree with the EU-wide ban on exports to Egypt of intrusion and surveillance technologies that can be used for the purposes of spying and repression of citizens.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of motion for a resolution 2014/3017 because, in the last year, several cases of violation of human rights and fundamental freedoms have emerged in Egypt, such as, by way of example, the violation of freedom of expression, religious freedom and the right to a fair trial. I support the indications given by the European Union to the Egyptian Government regarding the adoption of a concrete security policy, capable of ensuring and promoting national and international provisions aimed at strengthening and defending human rights and promoting security and social justice. The Egyptian authorities are called upon to ensure the protection and promotion of fundamental rights referred to in the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights ratified by Egypt in 1982.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. — Egypt deserves support and assistance from the European Union to address its economic, political and security challenges. Although the adoption of the Egyptian Constitution in 2014 was an important step in the democratic process, Egypt still needs to strengthen its democratic institutions, promote social justice and security and better defend human rights. Egypt could be a good partner in establishing stability in the Mediterranean and in the Middle East. For these reasons I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. — The new Egyptian Constitution states that "freedom, human dignity and social justice are rights granted to every citizen" and that "dignity is a recognized right to every human being and cannot be violated". Since its entry into force, however, there have been very serious events contrary to these principles. Mass death sentences are immediately in mind, first in March 2014 of 1 212 people and then in December 2014 of 188 people. Furthermore, we are alarmed by the fact that 3 months ago, in October 2014, President Al-isi ordered that all 'necessary and public services' be subject to military jurisdiction. This determines the consequence that minors can also be examined by military judges. These judges are answerable to the Ministry of Defence and not to the Ministry of Justice. This can only give cause for concern for the large number of demonstrators, journalists, activists and trade unionists who have now been imprisoned without due process. In addition, a clear distinction of powers is desirable in order to ensure the peaceful conduct of the March 2015 elections. For all these reasons, I am voting in favour of this resolution.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. — The proposed resolution for voting in the case of Egypt contains fundamental issues, such as the denunciation of the introduction of new law on public policy which, inter alia, may cause a citizen to be prosecuted in military jurisdiction in the event of evidence of a crime committed in the public domain. The release of the 167 elected parliamentarians in 2011 who are currently in prison, sentences for mass death sentences and denounces the situation of the LGBT community, in which the government's crackdown has reached the point of passing a "law on debauchery" condemning the free expression of people's sexual orientation. However, the Resolution does not include an express request for the opening of the Rafah Pass, which prevents the communication of Gazans abroad, and is of marked interference, which is why I abstained.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. — I support the EP’s resolution that points out that the 2013 military takeover and the newly elected President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi have not brought the change that the people have been fighting for in Egypt. It also acknowledges that the country continues to play a key role in the regional context, as demonstrated by the mediation after the Gaza summer war; however, the internal situation is characterised by abuses against political opponents, protesters, freedom of expression, and by a worrying use of military courts against civilians. Finally, the resolution calls for an end to the human rights abuses, for respect for the new Constitution, for the restoration of political pluralism and for parliamentary elections which have been postponed.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: in writing. — Egypt is a key country for the European Union because of its important regional role. However, it is extremely important for the country to respect human rights and fundamental freedoms because protests cannot be crushed by violence and military courts cannot replace an independent judicial system. I supported this motion for a resolution calling on the Egyptian authorities to release immediately and unreservedly all detainees arrested on the other part of exercising their right to freedom of expression and peaceful assembly.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: In writing. — Very serious restrictions on human rights are currently taking place in Egypt. These include obstacles to freedom of expression, association and assembly, interference with political pluralism and the rule of law, and violence against women. The Egyptian authorities must immediately end repression of a peacefully exercising population and ensure that politically sensitive trials are fair and regular. Parliament strongly condemns the violence against journalists, protesters, political opponents and the detention of prisoners of conscience and calls on the external action services to exercise its vigilance. The EU and its Member States must also prohibit the export of military equipment or surveillance or intrusion technologies that can be used in defiance of the basic principles of law.

name: Diane DODDS
text: in writing. — Mr President, the current political climate in Egypt has offered a vacuum for an escalation in violence and persecution against religious minorities, including Christians living in that country. I would add my voice to those calling for a peaceful and democratic transition to a political system, an economy and a society that is inclusive and respectful of fundamental freedoms. Events in France this month have sent shockwaves across the world and carry a message that the freedom of the press is not something that is easily secured or which can be taken for granted. With this in mind, I would call on the High Representative to do all in her powers to seek the release of the three Al-Jazeera journalists currently awaiting trial in Egypt. The freedoms of expression, speech and the press, as well as the right to a fair trial, are principles that should be at the core of the EU’s policy dialogue with Egypt in the days ahead.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. — After the overthrow of Marshal Mubarak in 2011, Egypt experienced a period of social and religious unrest that culminated in the coming to power of Mohammed Morsi, a member of the Muslim Brotherhood, an organization affiliated with the Emirate of Qatar. The government of the Muslim Brotherhood has constantly stried to transform Egypt into an Islamist society, to establish Sharia law as a single source of law and to discriminate against Christians, who yet represent 10% of the population, while turning a blind eye to the violence that against them. Since Marshal al-Sissi came to power, the Egyptian government has been fighting against attempts by the Muslim Brotherhood to radicalize Egyptian society in order to return to power. Egypt's new constitution is the most favourable for religious minorities egypt has ever had. President al-Sissi, a devout Muslim, himself attended the Christmas Mass celebrated by the Pope of the Orthodox Copts as a sign of solidarity with Egyptian Christians. For all these reasons, I believe that the European Parliament should support the reformist will of the Egyptian government rather than try to impose sanctions on it to prevent it from fighting the Muslim Brotherhood.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. — I supported the draft resolution on the situation in Egypt because it is essential to support secular governance in one of the largest Arab states. The catastrophic consequences of the so-called The Arab Spring, which turned into an Islamist winter, led to civil war in Egypt, where the secular nature of the state is under the influence of "Muslim Brothers." The group is one of the oldest Islamist organizations, denies the secular nature of statehood and statehood and seeks through violence to establish a Sharia state. Islamists' control of political power in Egypt is a huge threat

name: Pablo ECHENIQUE
text: in writing. — We voted in favour of the Resolution because it expresses concern about the situation of widespread repression of democratic rights, calls on the Egyptian authorities to put an end to all acts of harassment and repression, and declares opposition to the restriction of fundamental rights.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. — My vote is in favour because Egypt must be supported to remain a force in the region and to ensure that its human rights are respected so that it can have an important role in the South-East Mediterranean.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. — Freedom of expression and freedom of assembly are essential pillars of a democratic and pluralistic society. Since the June 2013 military coup, the Egyptian government has carried out a campaign of arbitrary detentions, harassment, intimidation and large-scale censorship against government critics solely for exercising their rights to freedom of assembly, association and expression, which included journalists, human rights defenders and political opponents, notably the Muslim Brotherhood. More than 40,000 people have been arrested following an unprecedented wave of arrests, and some 1,400 demonstrators have been killed as a result of excessive use of security forces' force. The importance that the EU attaches to its cooperation with Egypt leads me to express my solidarity with the Egyptian people and to stress the commitment to give egypt continued support in the process of strengthening its democratic institutions, respect for and defence of human rights and the promotion of social justice and security. However, I cannot but express my deep concern at the current restrictions on fundamental democratic rights, in particular freedom of expression, association and assembly, political pluralism and the rule of law in Egypt.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing — The human rights situation in Egypt is still deteriorating following the armed coup in 2013. According to available reports and information, there are currently more than 40 000 000 political prisoners in the country, hundreds of whom are sentenced to death. They are mainly members of the Muslim Brotherhood - which has been branded a terrorist by government officials. Freedom of expression is significantly restricted. Abdulfattah Sísi's regime has also focused its attention on various population groups, such as the LGBT community, in order to score political points in a country that is deeply conservative. A big question mark hangs over the democratic parliamentary elections due by March 2015, as these elections are highly unlikely to meet at least minimum standards for democratic and free elections. The political regime in a country that persecutes the opposition and civil society does not bring prosperity and stability to the country in the long term, but instead opens the door to extremism and violence.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. — (IT) Europe and this Parliament - not all of them but by a large majority - rejoiced at the much-proclaimed Arab Spring. Here, too, the facts sadly agree with us, and this resolution reminds me of nothing more than the superficiality for which Europe is guilty.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. — My vote on the joint motion for a resolution on the situation in Egypt is positive, because Egypt, which is in a sensitive region, must be helped so that it can play an important stabilising role.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. " Since the revolt that overthrew Hosni Mubarak in January 2012, Egypt has experienced moments of great political turbulence, yet it remains one of the few countries in the region to enjoy political stability. In recent months, measures have been implemented in Egypt that have raised concerns about the human rights situation in the country. However, over the past week we have witnessed very positive elements; the call for legislative elections for March 21, the release of Jaled Al Qazzaz, former adviser to President Morsi, and the men who were arrested in a bathhouse in Cairo on 7 December are examples of this. I understand and share Parliament's concern about the future of events in Egypt, but similarly there are improvements in the human rights situation in the country in the light of recent developments, so while we must be allergic to the demand for enforcement of fundamental rights, at the same time we must encourage the steps that Egypt is taking in this direction.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: in writing. " For European Socialists, Egypt's internal situation since the revolution, its process of democratization and stability are very important. Our group calls on the Egyptian authorities to release immediately and without conditions all persons detained for exercising their right to freedom of expression and peaceful assembly. I voted on the Resolution on the situation in Egypt because it is a key country for the European Union because of its regional role and its contribution always in the Israel-Palestine conflict, as has been shown so in the negotiation of the recent ceasefire in Gaza and also in cooperation and in the fight against islamic state and other regional threats. We want to see Egypt in the right direction for the democratic transition. We urge the Egyptian authorities to work in compliance with human rights and fundamental freedoms. Harassment, intimidation or censorship of political opponents, civil society representatives and minorities are not acceptable to the EU. The parliamentary elections convened for March are essential to give a real impetus to the democratic process, and must be ensured that they are free and fair.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: in writing. " For European Socialists, Egypt's internal situation since the revolution, its process of democratization and stability are very important. Our group calls on the Egyptian authorities to release immediately and without conditions all persons detained for exercising their right to freedom of expression and peaceful assembly. I voted on the Resolution on the situation in Egypt because it is a key country for the European Union because of its regional role and its contribution always in the Israel-Palestine conflict, as has been shown so in the negotiation of the recent ceasefire in Gaza and also in cooperation and in the fight against islamic state and other regional threats. We want to see Egypt in the right direction for the democratic transition. We urge the Egyptian authorities to work in compliance with human rights and fundamental freedoms. Harassment, intimidation or censorship of political opponents, civil society representatives and minorities are not acceptable to the EU. The parliamentary elections convened for March are essential to give a real impetus to the democratic process, and must be ensured that they are free and fair.

name: Nathan GILL
text: in writing. — Egypt relies heavily on tourism, and any perception of instability or danger will ruin this industry. The government of Egypt is ranked as one of the worst societies in the world in terms of freedoms. Mubarak has recently been cleared of all charges and the government has an appalling record of working with its neighbours.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this resolution because we urgently need to send a strong signal to the Sisi government that the human rights situation in Egypt is unacceptable. 40 000 political activists have been made prisoners, hundreds are being sentenced to death in mass trials, civilians can be brought before military courts and NGOs are facing stiff repression. We cannot close our eyes to this. I am particularly baffled by the fact that no one has been made to answer for the killing of over 1 000 demonstrators at the Raba’a al-Adawiya and an-Nahda squares in August 2013. This crackdown will only be pushing greater numbers into the arms of terrorist organisations, and I find the potential role that could be played by Western technology and equipment in enabling the Egyptian authorities to repress its citizens deeply worrying. We need to take a strong stance, because our failure to act will not only jeopardize the lives of Egyptians, but those of citizens all over the world, including our own.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: in writing. — (IT) I supported the motion on the situation in Egypt because the violations of democratic principles and the rule of law within that country are becoming more worrying day after day. The Neighbourhood Policy should grant Egypt technical and financial assistance from the EU on the basis of conditions linked to respect for human rights, minorities and democratic pluralism. It is discouraging that this policy is not bringing the desired results. It is therefore essential to make the level of assistance conditional on the achievement of precise objectives, concerning respect for civil and political freedoms, reform of the judicial system, repeal of unconstitutional laws, the release of political opponents, journalists and peaceful demonstrators arbitrarily detained.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. - We abstained from the Resolution because it expresses concern about the situation of widespread repression of democratic rights, calls on the Egyptian authorities to put an end to all acts of harassment and repression, and condemns opposition to the restriction of fundamental rights. However, the Final Resolution does not stress the importance of the sovereignty of the Egyptian people in the future of the country, nor does it take into account that relations between the EU and any country must be based on equal treatment, non-interference, solidarity, dialogue and respect for the asymmetry and country-specific characteristics.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the resolution on the situation in Egypt.
