I support closer EU cooperation with Egypt by providing all the knowledge and experience we have to build democratic institutions, which would respect and defend human rights and promote social justice and security in this country.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: in writing. " For European Socialists, Egypt's internal situation since the revolution, its process of democratization and stability are very important. Our group calls on the Egyptian authorities to release immediately and without conditions all persons detained for exercising their right to freedom of expression and peaceful assembly. I voted on the Resolution on the situation in Egypt because it is a key country for the European Union because of its regional role and its contribution always in the Israel-Palestine conflict, as has been shown so in the negotiation of the recent ceasefire in Gaza and also in cooperation and in the fight against islamic state and other regional threats. We want to see Egypt in the right direction for the democratic transition. We urge the Egyptian authorities to work in compliance with human rights and fundamental freedoms. Harassment, intimidation or censorship of political opponents, civil society representatives and minorities are not acceptable to the EU. The parliamentary elections convened for March are essential to give a real impetus to the democratic process, and must be ensured that they are free and fair.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this joint motion for a resolution as I believe the EU has a responsibility to work to promote democracy and open society in Egypt. Although it was not included in the text of the joint motion, I believe that the EU should call for the immediate release of Irish teenager Ibrahim Halawa, who has been detained in Egypt without trial since August 2013.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. - We abstained from the Resolution because it expresses concern about the situation of widespread repression of democratic rights, calls on the Egyptian authorities to put an end to all acts of harassment and repression, and condemns opposition to the restriction of fundamental rights. However, the Final Resolution does not stress the importance of the sovereignty of the Egyptian people in the future of the country, nor does it take into account that relations between the EU and any country must be based on equal treatment, non-interference, solidarity, dialogue and respect for the asymmetry and country-specific characteristics.

name: Robert Jarosław IWASZKIEWICZ
text: I would like to write to the Commission. "There has been a real revolution in Egypt in recent years. Thanks to the intervention of the army, it was possible to stop the creeping Islamic revolution prepared by the Muslim Brotherhood. The new government quickly began to modernize the country, making it easier to run businesses and re-attracting foreign investors. The security of the country has increased, which, together with favourable business conditions, has led to economic growth. Government forces have actively cracked down on Islamic radicals, arresting more than 167 of them, regardless of their party credentials. Fighting continues against the chipping of the Muslim Brotherhood, which has moved to the Sinai Peninsula and is seeking to establish an Islamic State.  Contrary to concerns, military governments are very open to Egyptian Christians. Copts can finally breathe a sigh of relief. Churches and masses are secured by troops. A wide-ranging dialogue between the authorities and Christians has also been undertaken. That's a big plus. Unfortunately, there is little talk about this in the resolution voted on. It does not even express part of these demands. Its text shows that, once again, the European Parliament is not coping with foreign affairs commentary. He has never had a mandate to do so, and once again confirms the legitimacy of the citizens' decisions on this matter.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. — I voted for a resolution on the situation in Egypt, as this country occupies an important position and role in the Middle East and the Mediterranean, and represents a strategic partner for the European Union, with which it has significant trade relations. I believe that it is important to ensure the protection of all citizens regardless of their affiliation or religion, and that freedoms of the press and opinion represent fundamental democratic values for which the EU is fighting globally. Since there is a long-standing traditional relationship between Egypt and Europe, I believe that it is the European Union, in order to stabilise this part of the world, that can help the Egyptian authorities to strengthen a pluralistic society and calm tensions.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. "I voted in favour of the resolution on the situation in Egypt. The text condemns the repression of political opponents and the media and calls for the release of prisoners of conscience. Although Egypt is one of the European Union's main partners in the region and a stabilizing factor, the protection of human rights and freedom of opinion is not optional. The resolution was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Tunne KELAM
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution.  Egypt today is a troubled country. Basic human rights are under constant attack by extremist groups as well as authorities. The situation of Christians and women has worsened, regardless of new protective laws. Mass trials and death penalties passed are an indication of judicial partiality.  Whereas it is symbolically important gesture that President Abdel Fattah al-Sisi visited for the first time a Christian Copt church, on the occasion of Christmas Eve, Egypt needs to put real effort in protecting Christian minority against terrorist attacks by islamist extremists and people under their influence. Those responsible for attacks against religious minorities should be dealt with under the responsibility of the authorities and experience real punishments. Allowing freedom of expression and assembly is a test case for any country that has overcome a long history of repressive regimes. I also support the call to ban the export to Egypt of surveillance technologies which could be used to spy on and repress citizens and, in line with the Wassenaar Arrangement, to ban the export of security equipment or military aid that could be used in the suppression of peaceful protest.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. — I very much welcome the resolution. The EU cannot turn a blind eye to all the repressions and human rights abuses happening in Egypt. It must use all its available tools to stop this. Only by building a truly pluralistic society that is respectful of the diversity of views can one ensure long-term stability and security in Egypt.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of mr McKenna's motion for a resolution. Prey, because I believe that the European Union must take action to ensure that the conditions are created in Egypt for the definitive establishment of a pluralistic and fully democratic society. I believe that all forms of freedom expressed through freedom of expression, freedom of union, as well as freedom of the press, form the basis of any democratic society. The European Union should therefore support concrete actions to promote adequate protection of these rights within Egyptian territory, also in view of the strategic role that Egypt could play in the process of conflict resolution in the strategic Mediterranean region.

name: Gabrielius LANDSBERGIS
text: Writing. — Just after this year, on 10 January, an Egyptian court sentenced an Egyptian student to three years in prison for a statement on Facebook accusing him of atheism. Egyptian democracy, although enshrined in the constitution adopted in 2014, is still facing major challenges in the areas of fundamental freedoms, human rights and freedom of the media. Freedom house's ranking declares that freedom is not guaranteed in Egypt, but seeing Egypt as one of the leaders of the region, we must constantly look for ways to influence change, both in the region and in Egypt itself, with the help of the international community. Egypt is facing major institutional challenges in building a political, legal and economic system. Strengthening civil society is therefore one of the opportunities and starting points for change in the country. And these changes are unavoidable without compliance with international obligations and agreements, the freedom of the press, freedom of assembly, non-discrimination, terrorism and the prevention of corruption. Egypt, which was the flag during the Arab Revolution, must stabilise the situation and, together with our financial assistance, the European Union, to create a state based on democratic values.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. — Parliament's resolution rightly stresses the importance of Egypt as a neighbour and a major partner. Egypt plays an active and essential role for stability in the Mediterranean and the Middle East. The country has a long road to democratization, particularly in terms of freedom of expression and association, and in the fight against violence against women. However, President Al-Sissi's presence in a Coptic church in Cairo for Christmas Mass, and his commitment to protecting Christians and guaranteeing their freedom to worship, should be welcomed. Egypt must be helped to fight terrorism, especially in the Sinai Peninsula. The European Union and Member States must also welcome the parliamentary elections announced for 21 March and 25 April, and send an observation mission.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. " For European Socialists, Egypt's internal situation since the revolution, its process of democratization and stability are very important. Our group calls on the Egyptian authorities to release immediately and without conditions all persons detained for exercising their right to freedom of expression and peaceful assembly. I voted on the Resolution on the situation in Egypt because it is a key country for the European Union because of its regional role and its contribution always in the Israel-Palestine conflict, as has been shown so in the negotiation of the recent ceasefire in Gaza and also in cooperation and in the fight against islamic state and other regional threats. We want to see Egypt in the right direction for the democratic transition. We urge the Egyptian authorities to work in compliance with human rights and fundamental freedoms. Harassment, intimidation or censorship of political opponents, civil society representatives and minorities are not acceptable to the EU. The parliamentary elections convened for March are essential to give a real impetus to the democratic process, and must be ensured that they are free and fair.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: in writing. " For European Socialists, Egypt's internal situation since the revolution, its process of democratization and stability are very important. Our group calls on the Egyptian authorities to release immediately and without conditions all persons detained for exercising their right to freedom of expression and peaceful assembly. I voted on the Resolution on the situation in Egypt because it is a key country for the European Union because of its regional role and its contribution always in the Israel-Palestine conflict, as has been shown so in the negotiation of the recent ceasefire in Gaza and also in cooperation and in the fight against islamic state and other regional threats. We want to see Egypt in the right direction for the democratic transition. We urge the Egyptian authorities to work in compliance with human rights and fundamental freedoms. Harassment, intimidation or censorship of political opponents, civil society representatives and minorities are not acceptable to the EU. The parliamentary elections convened for March are essential to give a real impetus to the democratic process, and must be ensured that they are free and fair.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. — The proposed resolution for voting in the case of Egypt contains fundamental issues, such as the denunciation of the introduction of new law on public policy which, inter alia, may cause a citizen to be prosecuted in military jurisdiction in the event of evidence of a crime committed in the public domain. The release of the 167 elected parliamentarians in 2011 who are currently in prison, sentences for mass death sentences and denounces the situation of the LGBT community, in which the government's crackdown has reached the point of passing a "law on debauchery" condemning the free expression of people's sexual orientation. However, the Resolution does not include an express request for the opening of the Rafah Pass, which prevents the communication of Gazans abroad, and is of marked interference, which is why I abstained.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. — The European Union attaches great importance to its cooperation with Egypt because of its status as a neighbour and partner.  Recent terrorist attacks on the Sinai Peninsula and all other terrorist acts perpetrated against Egypt are strongly condemned. It is emphasized that the EU and the international community must stand firm and cooperate with Egypt in its fight against terrorism. In addition, the steps taken by the Egyptian Government for respect for the rights and freedoms of religious communities are welcomed. On the other hand, the Egyptian authorities are requested to fully implement the principles of international conventions, to address the shortcomings of the presidential elections in the preparation of the legislative elections announced for 21 March and 25 April 2015 and to make the protection and promotion of human rights a priority. That is why I supported this Resolution.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. — Egypt is undergoing a lengthy political transition process following the resignation of longtime President Hosni Mubarak in February 2011.  Egypt's military is currently the country's main political actor and decision-maker, and the fact that a large number of political opponents have been sentenced to the death penalty is worrying.  Political uncertainty is reflected in the continuing political protests, strikes, and clashes between Muslims and Christians.  I support this Resolution and call for dialogue between opposing parties. This is the only key to progress and a solution to the crisis that this country has been going through for many years.  Stabilising the situation in Egypt would set a good example for other countries in the Middle East, which is crucial at the moment, especially given the marked strengthening of terrorist groups in that part of the world.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. I voted in favour because the situation in Egypt is not normal, and my political group condemns it. The situation where elections are held under the barrels of the army, and when people die, is a great tragedy. It is a pity that an amendment was adopted where the number of deaths is around 600, because in fact the text concerned more than 1 100 deaths, as noted not by escperts close to the Egyptian Government, but by independent and reputable experts such as Human Rights Watch. I also supported all the amendments to the S&D Group.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. — I abstained because the resolution is not balanced. My firm belief is that, on the one hand, the important role played by Egypt in the Southern Mediterranean region must be recognised and, on the other hand, Egypt must give priority to the protection and promotion of human rights and take care to ensure accountability for human rights violations through an independent and impartial administration of justice.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. — I voted for this resolution which reminds the Egyptian Government that the long-term success of Egypt and its people depends on the protection of universal human rights and on the establishment and anchoring of democratic and transparent institutions also engaged in protecting citizens’ fundamental rights; it calls, therefore, on the Egyptian authorities to fully implement the principles of international conventions.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution on the situation in Egypt. I express my full solidarity with the Egyptian people in their fight against terrorism and my deep concern at the thirty-two journalists recently imprisoned in Turkey. Freedom of expression and freedom of peace assembly, which are essential elements for a healthy democracy, must be regarded as a priority of the Turkish Government, because they are an essential component for every democratic country.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. — Freedom of expression, freedom of union, as well as freedom of the press, are the foundations of any democratic and civilised society.  On this basis, I believe that the European Union should support concrete actions to promote adequate protection of these inalienable rights within Egyptian territory.  We must not lose sight of the fact that Egypt could play a key role in the process of conflict resolution in the Mediterranean region.  That is why it is more necessary than ever for the absolute principles laid down in the constitution to prevail within the country.  I offered my support for the resolution, because I believe that it effectively vehicles the message that the European Union must mobilise itself, as soon as possible, to create the conditions in Egypt for the definitive establishment of a pluralistic and fully democratic society.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. — Since I believe that this joint motion for a resolution would not improve the status quo in Egypt, I would have abstained.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. "This resolution holds a double discourse. On the one hand, it criticizes the general repression at work in Egypt: tens of thousands imprisoned after the military coup and hundreds of people sentenced to death in mass trials. But on the other hand, it supports the government of Al-Sissi, Egypt being a strategic partner of the EU (and the USA). It should be noted that at the same time, a free trade agreement is being negotiated with the EU. In these circumstances, I abstain.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. — Egypt is the largest Arab country, a crucial country in the southern Mediterranean region, an important EU trading partner and a major beneficiary of EU aid. Political, economic and social events in this country have important consequences for the whole region.  We have to condemn the clashes and the deaths that have happened. All actors must be called on to be aware that it is imperative to end the fighting so that Egypt returns to normality and that its populations are no longer affected. We must reiterate our deep solidarity with the people of Egypt and continue to support their legitimate democratic aspirations as well as their efforts to ensure a peaceful and democratic transition to political, economic and social reforms. Our efforts must bring the confrontations in Egypt to an end and a new path to peace and democracy begins.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. — It is my view that this resolution reaches a balance between the recognition of positive steps taken by the current Egyptian Government and the need for greater commitment to the safeguarding of human rights. The resolution also identifies the security challenges that Egypt is currently facing, not only in the Sinai Peninsula, but also on its border with Libya and the constant threat of terrorism. However, the shortcomings in the human rights sphere must also be addressed. There is a need to ensure freedoms of expression, association and assembly and political pluralism. Therefore, I voted in favour of this resolution in the hope that an appropriate balance between security enforcement and the protection of human rights can be found in Egypt.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. I condemn the ongoing violations of human rights committed by the Egyptian authorities since July 2013, particularly with regard to freedom of expression, and call on them to release those currently in prison for exercising this right. Freedom of expression and freedom of the press are part of the broader concept of governance, which is at the heart of the European Union's development strategy. A free and responsible press, which follows strong ethical principles, is an indispensable spring of democracy and the rule of law.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: in writing — I consider last year's adoption of a new constitution in Egypt that enshrines the fundamental rights and freedoms of citizens to be an important step towards the democratisation of Egyptian society. However, the real challenge remains how to translate noble legal principles into everyday life and, above all, into the functioning of the judiciary, which is intended to guarantee a fair trial and equality for all before the law. In this respect, I consider it highly worrying that mass arrests and mass trials with a high number of defendants cannot adequately guarantee their procedural rights, as well as the frequent sentencing of death sentences, a practice that the EU has long condemned as incompatible with the fundamental human right to life. I stress that Egypt's long-term stability, security and prosperity depend on the trust of its own citizens in the state establishment and its representatives. However, such trust cannot be gained without ensuring fundamental human rights and freedoms by transparent state authorities and institutions, led by an independent and impartial judiciary. I therefore encourage Egypt to fully apply the legal principles of international conventions, while respecting its international obligations.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. — After the first signs of signs of change, the so-called Arab Spring, which took place in 2011 in a number of countries in the Mediterranean and Middle East region, has not brought the desired rule of law to these fragile societies.  An example of this is Egypt. The 2013 coup d'état brought president Abdel Fattah al-Sissi to power, who has been accused of constant arbitrary detention, intimidation, violation of freedom of expression and assembly. The UN and several international voices have already condemned the lack of independence of the judicial system in the media case of the three al-Jazira television journalists arrested a year ago and convicted of supporting the Muslim Brotherhood - a political movement classified internally as a terrorist.  The persecution and permanent detention of homosexuals, the increasing number of cases of violence against women and the practice of female genital mutilation are clear signs of attacks on fundamental rights in an increasingly polarised society.  I am in favour of this motion for a resolution and the adoption of a common strategy for Egypt, supported by the principle of conditionality and the financial support needed for genuine democratic reform.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. — The European Parliament is concerned in this draft resolution about the policy of repression against the Muslim brothers. Blinded by their right to homomism, MEPs do not understand that the regime of Marshal Al Sissi is one of the few to wage an unrelenting war on Islamist fundamentalism. Moreover, it becomes suspicious to see the condemnations of varying geometry on the part of the European Parliament. When is a motion for a resolution to denounce the anti-Shiite policy pursued by Bahrain's ultra-minority regime? When is a resolution demanding that Qatar stop tolerating genuine slavery practices against Nepalese migrants? When is a firm condemnation of Saudi Arabia's laws that prohibit women from driving?  Pending clarification, I voted against this draft resolution

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the resolution as I believe that the human rights situation in Egypt as it stands is unacceptable.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. — (IT) Egypt continues to play a key role in the regional context, just think of the mediation work carried out in the context of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict following the clashes this summer. Unfortunately, the internal situation continues to be characterised by abuses against political opponents, by protests and demonstrations suppressed in blood, by the use of military courts against civilians. With this resolution, therefore, we call on the Egyptian authorities to release all those imprisoned for the sole reason that they have exercised their right to expression and demonstration: political opponents, bloggers, journalists, human rights activists, trade unionists, representatives of civil society and minorities. We call for the security of all citizens to be ensured regardless of their political affiliation or religious affiliation. Finally, we call for new actions to promote political pluralism, the impartiality of the judicial system and an end to all human rights violations.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. — I voted for this resolution because it comes, through the requests set out in its text, to stress the importance of respecting human rights, freedom of the press, but also the active role that this State can play in maintaining security and peace in the region.

name: Liadh NÍ RIADA
text: in writing. — I abstained on this motion for resolution on Egypt. I was disappointed that reference to the case of Ibrahim Halawa was not included in the joint motion. Sinn Féin was successful in including his case in the GUE/NGL resolution and it is regrettable that the joint motion does not mention him. As a prisoner of conscience who was imprisoned as a child following protests in August 2013, his case is an important example of the brutal repression of human rights, including the freedom of expression. I also regret that there was an emphasis on Egypt as a strategic partner for trade and security for the European Union. Relations between the EU and third countries should not be predicated on trade issues – Egypt’s citizens are currently experiencing severe repressions of their democratic rights to freedom of expression, speech and association. Concern for the violation of their democratic rights should not be diluted by mentioning trade concerns.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. — Egypt is in a difficult process. The EU's task should be to promote peace in order to achieve political and social peace. Terrorism must be combated and human rights protected. The European Union's duty is to support the Christian minority and to continue to cooperate in the spirit of protection. The situation of the Copts is still very difficult. They are constantly kidnapped and murdered. Furthermore, Christians are constantly discriminated against. I call for real change and effective improvements. Since I cannot find any real improvement in the motion, I voted against this motion.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: In writing. Despite the criticism expressed in this resolution against abusive police repression and the use of the death penalty in Egypt, the text continues to show support for the Al-Sissi regime as a strategic partner of the EU and the United States. I abstained on this text because I believe that the fight against extremism does not justify the forgetting of democratic rights, and I do not see why Europe should interfere in the political choices of the Egyptian people.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. — I supported the resolution because it supports democratic principles and the fundamental freedoms of the Egyptian people. Egyptian citizens must have the right to human dignity, social protection, better living conditions and a fair and just trial. Egypt should take a direction on democratisation.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. — Ladies and gentlemen, in view of the previous decisions of the European Parliament on the situation in Egypt, the resolutions of the Foreign Affairs Council (August 2013, February 2014) and the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, given the freedoms of expression and association, two essential pillars for a pluralistic and democratic society, given the 41 000 arrests since July 2013 in connection with peaceful demonstrations , the increasing violence against women, the suppression of human rights and all freedom of opinion and expression, given the call for the Egyptian Government to protect ethnic and religious minorities and to condemn any kind of attack on freedom, for these reasons I am voting in favour.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. "The proposed resolution is ridiculously below stake. To think that the urgency in Egypt is to establish a pluralistic society that spares the Muslim Brotherhood does not make sense at a time when the so-called Islamic State is expanding its grip. It is absolutely wrong to think that a pluralistic society is necessarily less confrontational, as can be seen with the rise of jihadist tensions and excesses in all the countries of the European Union. I am voting against this resolution.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. — I supported the Resolution on the Situation in Egypt because of the need for support from the international community and for easier and more successful resolution of political and economic crises and challenges.  Egypt has begun a process of political transformation accompanied by political instability. Profound political changes have caused numerous strikes, political protests and mistrust between the parties, and the judiciary has often imposed severe penalties on political opponents. There have been restrictions on freedoms and human rights, most notably freedom of expression of opinion, which was particularly noted in the 2014 presidential elections.  I believe that cooperation between the European Union and Egypt is of paramount importance for the uniqueness and stability of this area and that Egypt, with the help of the European Union, will regain the strength of democratic institutions that will promote solidarity, respect and protection of human rights and promote social sensitivity and justice. In order to achieve such objectives, it is necessary for the Egyptian authorities to fully apply the international convention.  I would like to point out that cooperation between the European Union and Egypt is necessary in the fight against terrorism and that we should jointly ensure accountability for human rights violations and violations.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. — Egypt is a partner country of strategic importance for cooperation with the EU in the southern Mediterranean region. It is vital that the EU supports it on the road to building its democratic institutions and that the Egyptian Government commits itself to complying with international agreements with the EU. I support the resolution and the financial support that the EU will give Egypt, provided that the political and democratic conditions set out in the text are met. The country needs, in order for its economy to develop, and the conditions of the people to improve, for the democratic transition to lead to a stable government based on the foundations of democracy and for it to guarantee all its citizens.  Only the creation of a pluralist society, which is respectful of minorities and differences of opinion and lifestyles, can guarantee the country's long-term stability.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: in writing. — The fact that we are currently discussing so many points at the European Parliament's deliberations on international and human rights issues shows how difficult the situation is currently in the world. This heading also includes the current situation in Egypt, which is dealt with in our resolution. I monitor the situation in Egypt and personally appreciate its role as an element of stability on a regional scale. However, in my opinion, this stability should not be reversed by restrictions on fundamental freedoms and human rights.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. The situation in Egypt is worrying in terms of fundamental rights and I share most of the considerations in this resolution. However, this vote does not seem relevant to me at this time. Egypt suffers from great instability and with less than two months to go before crucial parliamentary elections, this text is not addressed to any interlocutor. The assertions of this resolution will indeed be a dead letter pending the creation of a new government. Therefore, I abstain. The time for well-founded criticism will come when the leaders of this country have the means to respond, and they can be held accountable for their policies.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution, which is taking account of the serious situation in Egypt, where, since the military coup in June 2013, there has been a campaign of arbitrary arrests, intimidation and censorship against journalists, human rights defenders and political opponents. In this regard, it is important to call on the Egyptian government to put an end to these acts and to commit itself to ensuring respect for and defence of the rule of law, political pluralism and fundamental rights, including freedom of expression, association and assembly, as well as to ensure fair and impartial judgments, the swift investigation of allegations of excessive use of force , ill-treatment and other human rights violations and the punishment of their persons responsible. Egypt is a long-standing strategic partner of the EU, and its important role for stability in the region should be highlighted. The EU is therefore committed to continuously supporting Egypt in the process of strengthening its democratic institutions. Such support is, however, dependent on the cooperation of the Egyptian authorities, who cannot fail to ensure compliance with the necessary political and democratic obligations and conditions.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. " For European Socialists, Egypt's internal situation since the revolution, its process of democratization and stability are very important. Our group calls on the Egyptian authorities to release immediately and without conditions all persons detained for exercising their right to freedom of expression and peaceful assembly. I voted on the Resolution on the situation in Egypt because it is a key country for the European Union because of its regional role and its contribution always in the Israel-Palestine conflict, as has been shown so in the negotiation of the recent ceasefire in Gaza and also in cooperation and in the fight against islamic state and other regional threats. We want to see Egypt in the right direction for the democratic transition. We urge the Egyptian authorities to work in compliance with human rights and fundamental freedoms. Harassment, intimidation or censorship of political opponents, civil society representatives and minorities are not acceptable to the EU. The parliamentary elections convened for March are essential to give a real impetus to the democratic process, and must be ensured that they are free and fair.

name: Teresa RODRIGUEZ-RUBIO
text: in writing. - We abstained from the Resolution because it expresses concern about the situation of widespread repression of democratic rights, calls on the Egyptian authorities to put an end to all acts of harassment and repression, and condemns opposition to the restriction of fundamental rights.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. — Concerned about the human rights situation in Egypt, the European Parliament has spoken in favour of a ban on exports of security equipment or military aid that could be used in the repression of peaceful demonstrations or against the Union's strategic and security interests. In signing this joint resolution, I supported the European Union-wide ban on the export to Egypt of intrusion and surveillance technologies that could be used to spy and punish citizens. For, gravely concerned about the restrictions on fundamental rights, and in particular freedoms of expression, association and assembly, political pluralism and the rule of law, I call in this resolution for an end to all acts of violence against political opponents, demonstrators, journalists and civil society actors. And calls for the immediate and unconditional release of all prisoners of conscience, of all those detained for peacefully exercising their right to freedom of expression, assembly and association, as well as those detained for their alleged membership in the Muslim Brotherhood.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. — As I said in this debate, it is with concern and some concern that we look at the current situation in Egypt, because unfortunately the set of problems that led to the spring revolution of January 2011 prevail to a great extent in society, the economy and the political-administrative organization of this secular nation, namely: high youth and youth unemployment among women; persistent poverty; low literacy rate; religious tensions fostered by extremist groups; terrorist attacks; the doubts and serious concerns expressed by the international community about the general state of democracy, the conduct of mass trials and the use of the death penalty. I believe, however, that we can look to the future of Egypt and the Egyptians with some hope, because we will soon have legislative elections - which always means opening new windows of opportunity for the population and because there is an economic recovery that could lead the GDP of the most populous Arab Nation to grow by 3.5 % in 2015. A proactive attitude by the Egyptian authorities is now expected to comply with the recent constitutional changes adopted, and stresses that we will continue to pay attention, especially to the upcoming electoral process and in the context of the implementation on Egyptian territory of the concrete measures contained in the European Neighbourhood Policy.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. — We voted in favour of the Resolution because it expresses concern about the situation of widespread repression of democratic rights, calls on the Egyptian authorities to put an end to all acts of harassment and repression, and declares opposition to the restriction of fundamental rights.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. — The proposed resolution for voting in the case of Egypt contains fundamental issues, such as the denunciation of the introduction of new law on public policy which, inter alia, may cause a citizen to be prosecuted in military jurisdiction in the event of evidence of a crime committed in the public domain. The release of the 167 elected parliamentarians in 2011 who are currently in prison, sentences for mass death sentences and denounces the situation of the LGBT community, in which the government's crackdown has reached the point of passing a "law on debauchery" condemning the free expression of people's sexual orientation. However, the Resolution does not include an express request for the opening of the Rafah Pass, which prevents the communication of Gazans abroad, and is of marked interference, which is why I abstained.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. — Today alongside the S&D Group I voted in support of the motion for a resolution on the situation in Egypt. Freedom of expression and freedom of assembly are indispensable pillars of a democratic and pluralist society, and freedom of the press and media is a vital element for democracy and an open society. Since the military takeover of June 2013, the Egyptian Government has conducted a large-scale campaign of arbitrary detention, harassment, intimidation and censorship against government critics solely for exercising their rights to free assembly, association and expression, including journalists, students and human rights defenders, and against political opponents. This resolution calls for the immediate and unconditional release of all prisoners of conscience, all those detained for peacefully exercising their right to freedom of expression, assembly and association, as well as those detained for their alleged membership of the Muslim Brotherhood.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. — The situation in Egypt has reached its peak in non-compliance with fundamental human rights. The situation is getting worse by the day. A regime that does not allow freedom of speech and expression of opinion and mismanagement of the state further aggravate an already unenviable situation. Indeed, the Egyptian authorities do not guarantee the rule of law to its full extent, leading to a disregard for fundamental freedoms, and the civil society sector is not sufficiently developed to initiate positive change. Also, regarding freedom of expression, it is important to stress that some 1400 protesters have died in the past 18 months due to excessive use of force by Egyptian security forces. In addition, violence against women is escalating more and more, and a similar situation is with the LGBT community, which is being systematically shamed and persecuted. The big problem is eliminating the opposition from the political scene, opening up room for unlimited power for the ruling regime.  I sincerely hope that with the efforts and support of the European Union, Egypt will launch democratic processes that will guarantee the peace and security of its citizens and citizens.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. — Freedom of speech, expression, association and assembly are among the basic pillars of a democratic and pluralistic society. Trampling on these fundamental freedoms must be strongly condemned and the general public should be warned of the violations that are taking place in Egypt. For this reason, I also supported this resolution, as I believe that everything must be done in the power of the European Parliament to ensure that such violations do not occur in the 21st century. It is estimated that 41,000 people have been arrested since the army intervened in Egypt in July 2013 and around 1,400 have been killed. Among them are many who have been detained or killed solely and only because of peaceful protests or because they have expressed disagreement with the existing regime. Unfortunately, in addition to this violence, violence against women is also strongly present. LGBT groups and the people who support them are oppressed. The situation is also getting worse for NGOs, as the country persists and imposes increasing control over them. Freedom of speech, expression and work are being violated. People are oppressed and intimidated. The European Parliament must no longer stand idly by and watch the injustices and fears that are happening. These developments must be publicly condemned and everything to be done to prevent them.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. - I support the report on the situation in Egypt and express concern about the unfortunate events mentioned in the report. In the spirit of European values, I do not support any form of trial of innocents, political liquidation or prevent people from expressing their opinions. The report described several political crackdowns on dissidents. Islamist attacks against Christians are also highlighted and support is expressed for building democratic institutions in Egypt, one of the main stability factors in the region. The EU will continue to be happy to be a mediator in various peace talks and condemn all forms of terrorism in the strongest terms. We support the Egyptian government in fostering respect for human rights and as a promoter of peace in the Middle East. It urges that the electoral system be ed and that the death penalty be abolished. The EU expresses concern over obstruction of the media and numerous obstacles to building civil society. Once again, it alludes to the Egyptian government having an international obligation to respect human rights, the rule of law and build civil society and media freedom. I want to express my faith that the situation in Egypt will improve as soon as possible and will follow the paths of stable development based on a strong civil society and the rule of law.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. — The situation in Egypt must be resolved by diplomatic means and every effort must be in this direction.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. "I voted for this resolution. Egypt is in a complicated process to end the crisis following a period of great instability. We must help it in its transition process and the European Union could propose itself as an intermediary, if Egypt wished to do so, in order to work with all parties to achieve national political reconciliation. We should promote civil peace and holding parliamentary elections is a positive step. The objectives must enable social and political peace, counter terrorism and protect human rights. Egypt will hold its next parliamentary elections in March and April 2015. MEPs expressed concern about the rise of repression and physical attacks on the media and civil society in Egypt.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. — The worsening of the democratic situation in a long-standing partner like Egypt is worrying, and this is why I voted in favour of the proposed resolution on the situation in Egypt. The text is well balanced and on the one hand acknowledges the difficult socio-economic and political background in Egypt following the 2011 revolution and the military takeover in 2013, while on the other hand strongly condemning the numerous breaches in the rule of law that have led to mass arrests of political opponents and the banning of NGOs receiving foreign funding. It also denounces the climate of fear and insecurity placed upon civil society (protesters, journalists, women and LGBTI people). Egypt is an important partner for the EU, but it needs to urgently make deep democratic and economic reforms.

name: Josep-Maria TERRICABRAS
text: in writing. "Egypt has lived two revolutions in just over two years. The Government of Al Sisi has created the architecture to implement a legal framework of repression that attacks head-on fundamental freedoms of association, expression and the press, basic pieces of any democratic state, a fact that poses a serious obstacle to the consolidation of a democratic and legal state in Egypt. The interference of military courts in civil matters is another sign of the serious situation of violation of basic rights that the country is going through. Similarly, the discrimination faced by women and the LGBT collective is alarming. The Egyptian state has an obligation to protect all its fellow citizens, regardless of political ideology, gender, sexual orientation or religion.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. — I vote in favour and support this resolution fully. I express my grave concern about the on-going restrictions of fundamental democratic rights, notably the freedom of expression, association and assembly, political pluralism and rule of law in Egypt; I call for an end to all acts of violence, incitement, hate speech, harassment, intimidation or censorship against political opponents, protesters, journalists, bloggers, students, trade unionists, women’s rights activists, civil society actors and minorities by state authorities, security forces and services, and other groups in Egypt; I condemn the excessive use of violence against protesters. I want to emphasise that respect for freedom of the press, information and opinion (online and offline) and political pluralism are fundamental to democracy; I call on the Egyptian authorities to guarantee that those freedoms can be exercised without arbitrary limitations and censorship in the country, and I call on authorities to ensure freedom of expression. I call for the immediate and unconditional release of all those detained for peacefully exercising their rights to freedom of expression, assembly and association, including the journalists Mohammed Fahmy, Peter Greste and Baher Mohamed, as well as those detained for their alleged membership of the Muslim Brotherhood; I call on the Egyptian authorities to ensure the right to a fair trial in accordance with international standards.

name: Traian UNGUREANU
text: in writing. — Since the 2011 Revolution, Egypt has faced a number of difficult political challenges. The 2014 presidential election took place in a context where freedom of expression was greatly restricted. The upcoming parliamentary elections to be held in the spring of this year are long overdue and are essential to start the process of democratisation of the country.  The transition period to a strengthened democracy is not at all easy, so the government's efforts need to be stepped up to overcome it successfully. This State must make the protection and promotion of human rights a priority and ensure that all those who are guilty of violating fundamental rights are held accountable through the independent and impartial administration of justice. Egypt is a strategic partner of the European Union in the fight against terrorism and plays a key geopolitical role in the Near East peace process. The EU has been and will remain a reliable partner of Egypt and will continue to provide support to Egypt in the process of strengthening its institutions, respecting and defending human rights and promoting social justice and security.  I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: in writing. " For European Socialists, Egypt's internal situation since the revolution, its process of democratization and stability are very important. Our group calls on the Egyptian authorities to release immediately and without conditions all persons detained for exercising their right to freedom of expression and peaceful assembly. I voted on the Resolution on the situation in Egypt because it is a key country for the European Union because of its regional role and its contribution always in the Israel-Palestine conflict, as has been shown so in the negotiation of the recent ceasefire in Gaza and also in cooperation and in the fight against islamic state and other regional threats. We want to see Egypt in the right direction for the democratic transition. We urge the Egyptian authorities to work in compliance with human rights and fundamental freedoms. Harassment, intimidation or censorship of political opponents, civil society representatives and minorities are not acceptable to the EU. The parliamentary elections convened for March are essential to give a real impetus to the democratic process, and must be ensured that they are free and fair.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. — The proposed resolution for voting in the case of Egypt contains fundamental issues, such as the denunciation of the introduction of new law on public policy which, inter alia, may cause a citizen to be prosecuted in military jurisdiction in the event of evidence of a crime committed in the public domain. The release of the 167 elected parliamentarians in 2011 who are currently in prison, sentences for mass death sentences and denounces the situation of the LGBT community, in which the government's crackdown has reached the point of passing a "law on debauchery" condemning the free expression of people's sexual orientation. However, the Resolution does not include an express request for the opening of the Rafah Pass, which prevents the communication of Gazans abroad, and is of marked interference, which is why I abstained.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. — Freedom of expression and freedom of the press have been under heavy fire in Egypt since 2013. I strongly condemn the violations of these human rights. Both are foundations of the rule of law and, as the European Union, we must do everything we can to protect them, both inside and outside our borders.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: In writing. "The situation in Egypt is serious. Although one thinks of the Muslim Brotherhood, the army overthrew a democratically elected regime and even supported by popular jubilation, it was a military coup that was organized by General Al Sisi. The methods implemented since then by the Egyptian authorities can only reinforce this feeling. While I can welcome the recognition of the egyptian authorities' multiple human rights violations in the area of political pluralism, attacks on press freedom, and the use of coercive methods such as arbitrary arrests and detentions, harassment, intimidation and censorship against any large-scale opposition. , this resolution seems contradictory to me to say the least.  Under the guise of the European Union's strategic partnership in the region, it is above all a case to continue the support and assistance of the EU to carry out so-called economic and democratic reforms in line with the 'more for more', pillar of European neighbourhood policy, and we know what that means. In fact, we support the Egyptian government after a few "remonstrations". The Egyptian people deserve better, the priority is to restore democratic order.  So I chose to abstain.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. — After four years of illusions, with countless atrocities committed against the population, we again have at the head of the most populous Arab nation, those who in practice have never ceased to rule in Egypt. The Egyptian armed forces are in fact the most powerful institution in the country and the West knows this. It is no accident that the Egyptian regime was largely supported by the United States with an average annual subsidy of $1.8 billion that has lasted for decades. Only Israel and Colombia receive more. While the government goes shopping to supply its army, the people are hungry for bread and a place of democracy and social rights. Our appeal is to let that people decide on their future and stop supporting local oligarchies in the light of the geostrategic interests of the West.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. — The European Union must support the Christian minorities who experience daily discrimination and violence in Egypt. The difficult situation of the Copts, the ongoing kidnappings and murders and the general discrimination against the Christian community require concrete proposals for improvement, which I regret to see in the motion. That is why I did not agree with it.

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: Mr President, we voted for this resolution. We stress that the two Italian sailors must be repatriated because this is the violation of their freedom under international law. It also underlines the loss of sovereignty, in this case Italy. We regret the way in which the Italian governments, under the various presidencies Monti, Letta and Renzi, have handled this matter and offer our support to all parties involved who are seeking a reasonable and acceptable solution for all. We encourage the High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy to take all necessary measures for the release of the two Italian sailors.

name: Gerolf ANNEMANS
text: Vlaam's interest is in solidarity with Lega Norte's colleagues in this and I also underline our deep concern about the fate of those Italian marines. They must be able to return home immediately, without restricting their freedom of movement, which is totally unacceptable. We also regret the way in which the case has been handled by successive Italian governments. We do encourage Mrs Mogherini to take all necessary steps to achieve a swift and satisfactory outcome in this matter.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. " I voted on this resolution with the families of the two Italian Marines who have been imprisoned in India for more than two years. Its case is controversial from the point of view of international law and the law of the sea. But they went as military on an official mission to protect a ship in their country, with all the authorizations. Unfortunately, two Indian fishermen were killed in the performance of their mission. Responsibility must be for the Italian State, or the Italian Army or the superiors of the two sailors in prison. Or the shipowner of the ship they protected from the threat of piracy in the Indian Ocean. There must be a responsibility to be assumed and a reparation to the families of fishermen who were tragically victims of a misunderstanding between two boats.  The Government of India has not yet filed charges after two years. In order not to make the tragedy greater, the Marines must return to their homes in Italy. One of them seriously ill. And any dispute must be resolved as marked by international law.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. — The Resolution concerns the detention of two Marines of Italian nationality after being identified as responsible for the shootings that killed two Indian fishermen. I believe that the complexity of the case is not adequately reflected in the Resolution and goes beyond the EU's competence, so I did not vote in favour.

name: Louis ALIOT
text: In writing. "On this sad third anniversary of the case of the two Italian marine riflemen, I naturally voted in favour of the resolution to argue that the jurisdiction to try the facts should be left to either the Italian authorities or to international arbitration. To date, India maintains that it has jurisdiction to hear about this case, as the incident took place in coastal waters under its jurisdiction. These events linked to ad hoc diplomatic tensions should not call into question the achievements of the security of EU citizens in third countries.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. — On the evening of 15 February 2012, an accident occurred off the coast of Kerala (India) in which two Indian fishermen were killed by two Italian naval infantrymen (Maria). The latter were on board an Italian merchant ship to protect it from possible pirate attacks. Fearing that such an attack was imminent, they fired warning shots at an approaching fishing boat carrying the two fishermen who tragically died. The incident led to the arrest of the two Maro, without any charges ever being brought against them. I welcome the motion for a resolution because it supports the efforts of the Italian and Indian parties to work towards an appropriate and mutually acceptable solution in order to allow for a positive resolution of the case.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. "I voted for this resolution because any sign of the European Union is now a support that these two sailors need. We cannot turn a blind eye to the fate of these two Italian soldiers, one of whom has been living at the Italian Embassy in India since February 2012.  But let us not be fooled: the Union, by this declaration, shows a weakness which is unbearable to us. I will always support soldiers who protect Nationals of the Member States, especially against the scourge of piracy.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. — This was not the subject of a roll-call vote. I believe, in the interests of democracy, that my constituents have the right to know how I voted. I therefore formally confirm that I chose to abstain on this motion.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. "It was time for the European Union to be concerned about the fate of these two marines who could not be abandoned after sending them on a mission against piracy. I therefore voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. "We are first and foremost here faced with a sad case in which two Indian fishermen tragically died.  It is extremely worrying that the Italian marine guns remained in detention without charge three years after the events. The rule of law must be respected here by ensuring that the rights of the two alleged perpetrators are fully respected. Work must also be done towards a mutually acceptable solution in the interests of both families, Indian and Italian, and both countries.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. In February 2012, in the waters off India, an accident occurred when two local fishermen were killed and two Italian naval officers were found responsible and arrested. After more than 3 years in detention, they have still not gone to court and uncertainty remains in this case. It is vital for sailors and their families to find a quick and appropriate solution to allow them to be free and return to Italy. This resolution therefore commits support to the two Italian marine riflemen and I therefore voted for it like my Italian colleagues in the Northern League.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of the resolution analysing the case of the two Italian Maròs detained in India since 2012.  It is necessary and right for the European Parliament to give its opinion on this matter, asking India to entrust the case to the Judgment of the Italian authorities.  As long as European citizens continue to pay handsomely to maintain the seats of the Union's diplomatic representation in third countries, their security must also be guaranteed by these structures, which should take concrete action to defend the human rights of EU detainees throughout the world.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. " I voted on this resolution with the families of the two Italian Marines who have been imprisoned in India for more than two years. Its case is controversial from the point of view of international law and the law of the sea. But they went as military on an official mission to protect a ship in their country, with all the authorizations. Unfortunately, two Indian fishermen were killed in the performance of their mission. Responsibility must be for the Italian State, or the Italian Army or the superiors of the two sailors in prison. Or the shipowner of the ship they protected from the threat of piracy in the Indian Ocean. There must be a responsibility to be assumed and a reparation to the families of fishermen who were tragically victims of a misunderstanding between two boats.  The Government of India has not yet filed charges after two years. In order not to make the tragedy greater, the Marines must return to their homes in Italy. One of them seriously ill. And any dispute must be resolved as marked by international law.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution on the two marines arrested, who were found to be responsible for firing on a fishing vessel. The situation is such that these events have created diplomatic tensions, as this case of two Italian marines is characterised by legal uncertainty and even after three years the Indian authorities have still not raised the accusations. The European Parliament is deeply saddened by the tragic death of two Indian fishermen and expresses its condolences. Stresses, however, that, despite the consequences of the event three years ago, India should strictly respect the rule of law, with full respect for human rights and the legitimate rights of those who are believed to have been involved in this event. Parliament expresses its deep concern that Italian marines have been detained without charges against them. Long delays and restrictions on the freedom of movement of marines are unacceptable and seriously violate their human rights. The European Parliament therefore calls on the EU High Representative for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy to take all necessary steps to protect the two Italian marines in order to find a swift and satisfactory solution to the case.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted with conviction for the European Parliament resolution on the case of the two Italian marò Massimiliano Latorre and Salvatore Girone who, carrying out anti-piracy activities off the state of Kerala, are accused of the deaths of two Indian fishermen. Indeed, I share the concern expressed in the resolution about the restriction of freedom of movement to the two riflemen and their detention without charge, both of which point to a serious violation of human rights by the Indian authorities. I therefore consider it essential to make every effort to ensure a fair trial for the two countries, while fully respecting the fundamental rights of citizens of the European Union detained in a third country. In the light of what emerges from the incident, which took place in international waters, I hope that jurisdiction will be conferred on the Italian authority and/or an international arbitration. Lastly, Parliament strongly called for every possible measure to be taken to reach a peaceful and rapid solution to the case, in the interests of the Italian and Indian families involved.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. Federica Mogherini is no more effective as a high representative than before, at the head of Italian diplomacy, in freeing her compatriots, who can be considered hostages. It is high time to stress "the extreme slowness of the procedure". These two Italian marine riflemen acted as part of the international fight against piracy. Radar data on this incident should be studied with the utmost attention in order to establish possible responsibilities. But, as the resolution notes, "three years after the events, the Indian authorities have still not held charges".

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. — I voted ‘yes’ because I consider it fundamental for the principle of Italian sovereignty to bring back the two ‘Marò’ to Italy.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of the European Parliament's draft resolution calling for the repatriation of the two marine riflemen, and the handling of the case, either by an Italian court or by international arbitration. The conflict of interpretation as to the area of occurrence of the accident, testifies to the legal deficiencies that arise from the law of the sea arising from the Montego Bay Convention. As such, it is worth questioning the sustainability of the principle of freedom on the high seas, a principle increasingly threatened by the willingness of States to control their own area of maritime influence.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. — Positive vote: any initiative useful for the final repatriation to Italy of Salvatore Girone and Massimiliano Latorre can only be welcomed and supported.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: in writing. " I voted on this resolution with the families of the two Italian Marines who have been imprisoned in India for more than two years. Its case is controversial from the point of view of international law and the law of the sea. But they went as military on an official mission to protect a ship in their country, with all the authorizations. Unfortunately, two Indian fishermen were killed in the performance of their mission. Responsibility must be for the Italian State, or the Italian Army or the superiors of the two sailors in prison. Or the shipowner of the ship they protected from the threat of piracy in the Indian Ocean. There must be a responsibility to be assumed and a reparation to the families of fishermen who were tragically victims of a misunderstanding between two boats.  The Government of India has not yet filed charges after two years. In order not to make the tragedy greater, the Marines must return to their homes in Italy. One of them seriously ill. And any dispute must be resolved as marked by international law.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. — Two Italian mariners are being held in India for shooting two Indian fishermen when they believed it was a pirate attack. These marine riflemen are detained without charge, which is totally contrary to the principles of human rights. This situation is also a diplomatic problem because of the disagreement between the Indian and Italian authorities as to the course of events in international or national waters. I voted in favour of this resolution, which calls for an immediate calming of the situation and full respect for human rights.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. — (IT) Today I voted in favour of the resolution on the marò in order to express great concern about their present state of detention, implemented in a manner and for reasons which raise numerous questions about the maintenance of the protection of their rights, certainly compressed by delays and restrictions on fundamental freedoms of due process and defence. Complex questions arise as to the correct application, in the present case, of the basic principles of international maritime law with regard to criminal and disciplinary proceedings, normally brought before the authorities of the flag State of the vessel.  In addition, in the present case, there are clear limits to the exercise of competence, other than that of flag, to the exercise of acts of jurisdiction or investigations from other national authorities. I therefore call on the Indian authorities to release the marò, in accordance with the above principles of national jurisdiction and international law.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution as Europe cannot stand idle to the plight of these two Italian marines. International law should always serve to protect citizens and ensure that their human rights are safeguarded. The fact that, almost three years later, charges have not been brought forward by the Indian authorities sheds serious doubt on the reason for their incarceration. I urge that diplomacy be used to its full extent for the peaceful resolution of this situation.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. — (IT) Adopting a resolution on the case of the Italian marò Massimiliano Latorre and Salvatore Girone was an act due to the European Parliament, since the two navy riflemen are not only Italian soldiers but also European citizens, limited in their freedom of movement for more than three years although no charges have been laid against them. That is why we call on the High Representative to do everything possible to resolve the diplomatic crisis positively as soon as possible, including by putting economic and trade relations between India and the EU on the table in the event of further unfounded postponements by the Indian authorities.

name: Aymeric CHAUPRADE
text: In writing. "I voted for this resolution because I give my full support to the two Italian sailors, one of whom is still detained in India. These two Europeans deserve to be tried by a national court, given that the case took place in international waters and they were carrying out counter-piracy activities.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: in writing. — Almost three years after their arrest, the two Italian navy riflemen are still being remanded in custody in India without knowing what the charge against them is.   This delay, which is a clear violation of their fundamental rights, is no longer acceptable.  According to the international principle of functional immunity, the military of a State, acting abroad under a rule of national law, is subject, for acts carried out in the performance of its duties, exclusively to the jurisdiction of the sending country. For this legal reason too, I am convinced that the solution to the case must necessarily go through a trial before the Italian courts or to the limit through international arbitration under the Seventh Protocol to the Montego Bay Convention.  The resolution pushes in this direction, proposing new ideas for continuing the difficult negotiations.  For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. — (IT) This resolution is an important part of the mosaic of initiatives being taken to ensure that these two men return home. That is why I voted in favour: I would really like to see Latorre and Girone in Italy, pride of the nation! However, I have one problem: this resolution, like all the other mosaic initiatives I mentioned earlier, has nothing concrete. It is the Italian Government, in the name and on behalf of which the two marò were on that ship, that must bring them home safely, at all costs. They have already waited too long, and we have already wasted too much time.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of the motion concerning the case of the two Italian Navy riflemen Massimilano Latorre and Salvatore Girone. This motion, of which I was the driving force, saw the vote in favour of a plurality of Members from different Member States and of different political beliefs.   The broad consensus obtained stems from the fact that the Indian authorities are perpetrating a clear and continuous violation of human rights, both because, 3 years later, the Italian Marò are still waiting for a charge, and because they are subject to a regime having a restrictive regime of personal freedom without there being a valid reason for it. Furthermore, the initiative shown by the New Delhi judicial authority violates the principle of legal civility of legal certainty which is compatible with the existence of discretionary judicial powers provided that the exercise of these powers is based on at least partly cognitive and, therefore, objectively controllable elements.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. — The case of the two Italian ‘marò’ has the potential to impact overall EU-India relations. The EU plays a central role in the respect of human rights at an international level and is also expected to take any necessary steps to protect the rights of its citizens. The absolute uncertainty about the future of the two Italians after almost three years, and the incredible delay in the process is unacceptable. The EU needs to apply all necessary restrictive measures to facilitate a solution. I voted in favour.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. — (IT) The case must be dealt with at European level, because Europeans are the two citizens involved in the affair. The case must therefore involve the entire diplomacy of the old continent and not just the Italian one, since, moreover, the Italian diplomatic action on the case has proved to be absolutely unsuccessful. It is not the policy that should judge whether or not the marò are guilty, because it is a question of applying basic international conventions such as the one on civil and political rights. European citizens cannot therefore be allowed to be left in India without charge, and I am sure that if these two citizens had been British, French or German, they would not have been left to their fate in India for three years. Italy needs to feel europe's neighbour and united on this case. That is why I can only vote in favour of this resolution.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. — The Resolution concerns the detention of two Marines of Italian nationality after being identified as responsible for the shootings that killed two Indian fishermen. I believe that the complexity of the case is not adequately reflected in the Resolution and goes beyond the EU's competence, so I did not vote in favour.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. — In the resolution the EP expresses great sadness at the tragic death of the two fishermen and extends its condolences. However, the resolution also takes into account the position of Italy as a Member State that is arguing that jurisdiction should fall to either the Italian authorities or international arbitration. The resolution also expresses great concern at the detention without charge of the Italian marines and stresses that the marines must be repatriated. It also states that rights and security of EU citizens in third countries should be safeguarded by the EU diplomatic representation. Hence I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: in writing. — (IT) I strongly supported the adoption of the joint resolution on the case of the two Italian marò, to which I am also a co-signatory. I find it very significant that, with last night's debate in this House and the overwhelming adoption of the resolution in plenary today, the sad affair of the two marò has finally taken on a truly European dimension. The European Union, also through the contribution that The High Representative Federica Mogherini will certainly be able to make to the case, must and can help Italy to reach a definitive, fair and shared solution between the two parties to an international dispute that has been going on for too long. This solution cannot be separated from the release of the two marò and the identification of a suitable judicial framework. The unlawful detention for three years of two European citizens without any clearly worded charges does no credit to India: Europe must once again demonstrate that it is at the forefront of its action to defend human rights in the world.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. — Mr. Latorre and Mr. Girone have been detained in India for three years after killing two fishermen on 15 February 2012 whom they claim to have been pirates. Victims of the diplomatic tensions between Italy and India as well as the legal uncertainty applicable to maritime, territorial or international waters, in which the present case occurred, these two marine riflemen have still not been aware of the charges against them and no trial has yet been organized. With this resolution, the European Parliament recalls the inalienable nature of the right of European citizens to have a fair trial and within a reasonable time frame. The European Parliament also calls on the Italian State and India to find a mutually acceptable solution in the interests of the families of both the accused and the victims. Finally, the text instructs the High Representative of the European Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy to take all necessary measures to support the Italian State. I believed that european diplomatic representation had a role to play in resolving this matter and that it should guarantee the rights of Mr Latorre and Mr Girone, I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: in writing. — (IT) I fully voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the case of the two Italian marò, which aims to take all necessary action to protect the two riflemen with a view to reaching a rapid and satisfactory solution to the matter. I extend my deepest sympathy to the families for the tragic end of the two Indian fishermen, but I believe that the dispute should be handled in strict compliance with the principles of the rule of law, fully respecting the human and legal rights of those allegedly involved. I therefore hope that jurisdiction over the whole affair will be attributed to Italy or at least to international arbitration.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. — I supported the proposed resolution on the case of the two Italian Marines because I believe that the rule of law, human rights and suspects' rights must be respected and protected.  I believe that this case allows the EU to show its capacity and capacity to act in terms of protecting the rights of European citizens in third countries, because it is our citizens who mostly need to feel the support of the Union, to see that it protects their interests both in Europe and beyond.   I am of the opinion that the EU High Representative for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy should take the necessary action to protect the two Italian Marines in order to reach a swift and satisfactory solution to the case by ensuring an independent investigation and a fair process.

name: Pablo ECHENIQUE
text: in writing. — We abstained in the case of this Resolution.
