While understanding the importance of the common points that all the resolutions presented on this case had, such as that one of the Marines suffered a serious illness or who had been imprisoned without being charged for the three years since the two soldiers allegedly murdered two Indian fishermen by confusing them with pirates, the Delegation of Podemos had decided to vote abstention to point out that the process had been found to be absolutely lacking transparency, including the international dispute over the jurisdiction of the facts or the formal non-attribution of charges to Marines.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. — My vote is in favour because these soldiers were on a protection mission and were following orders. Europe must intervene for their release and for humanitarian reasons, since one of them is ill.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: in writing. — (IT) I am voting in favour of this resolution because, while it is not politics that should judge, it is certainly true that the task of politics and, above all, of the European Parliament is to defend the right of these two European citizens to have a fair trial and in a reasonable time frame as enshrined in Article 9 of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, which is also signed by India itself. I also believe it is necessary to guarantee the two Italians that it is a third judge to judge on the determination of jurisdiction in order to ensure the greatest possible impartiality. I also support this motion because I want human rights to always take precedence over any economic interests.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing — On 15 February 2012, two local fishermen were killed in international waters and two Italian naval officers, Massimiliano Latorre and Salvatore Giron, were charged. These European Union citizens have been detained in India for three years. In view of the location of the Italian oil tanker, the case should be referred to the Permanent Court of Arbitration established under the Hague Peace Conference and should be dealt with and treated as a matter of the utmost urgency. It is very regrettable that the Indian authorities are acting very inefficiently and slowly, and after three years we are still waiting for the outcome of the dispute.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. — (IT) The case of the two Italian marò is a subject on which careful consideration should be given. This resolution is a step in the right direction and commits the European Parliament to supporting the hitherto futile efforts of the last Italian governments.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. — The case of the two Italian Marines reflects a serious violation of international law since they are imprisoned without any specific charges being laid. Europe must intervene to free them, and I am therefore voting in favour.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. — I voted in favour to ask the Indian authorities for a solution to the case of the two Italian Marines arrested after being found guilty of the deaths of two fishermen on 15 February 2012, when an incident occurred in Indian waters. It should be noted that the two officers were in an Italian oil tanker in the framework of anti-piracy operations. On 10 May 2012, Parliament adopted a Resolution on maritime piracy in paragraph 30 of which stated that 'in accordance with international law, on the high seas, in all cases, including measures taken in the fight against piracy, it shall apply to the vessels concerned and to military personnel employed on board the national jurisdiction of the flag State' , and stated that 'no authority other than those of the flag State may order the arrest or detention of the vessel, even as an investigative measure'. In addition, delays in the process have led to an unofficial charge of the shootings not yet being made after nearly three years.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: in writing. " I voted on this resolution with the families of the two Italian Marines who have been imprisoned in India for more than two years. Its case is controversial from the point of view of international law and the law of the sea. But they went as military on an official mission to protect a ship in their country, with all the authorizations. Unfortunately, two Indian fishermen were killed in the performance of their mission. Responsibility must be for the Italian State, or the Italian Army or the superiors of the two sailors in prison. Or the shipowner of the ship they protected from the threat of piracy in the Indian Ocean. There must be a responsibility to be assumed and a reparation to the families of fishermen who were tragically victims of a misunderstanding between two boats.  The Government of India has not yet filed charges after two years. In order not to make the tragedy greater, the Marines must return to their homes in Italy. One of them seriously ill. And any dispute must be resolved as marked by international law.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: in writing. " I voted on this resolution with the families of the two Italian Marines who have been imprisoned in India for more than two years. Its case is controversial from the point of view of international law and the law of the sea. But they went as military on an official mission to protect a ship in their country, with all the authorizations. Unfortunately, two Indian fishermen were killed in the performance of their mission. Responsibility must be for the Italian State, or the Italian Army or the superiors of the two sailors in prison. Or the shipowner of the ship they protected from the threat of piracy in the Indian Ocean. There must be a responsibility to be assumed and a reparation to the families of fishermen who were tragically victims of a misunderstanding between two boats.  The Government of India has not yet filed charges after two years. In order not to make the tragedy greater, the Marines must return to their homes in Italy. One of them seriously ill. And any dispute must be resolved as marked by international law.

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: in writing. — I am sorry to note the deafening silence of the entire government on this matter during the Italian Presidency. The adoption of today's resolution represents a turning point in the marò affair and a great success for the Forza Italia delegation. For the first time, on the proposal of our delegation, which is shared by all the political groups, the European Parliament is taking a clear and clear position on this issue, firmly affirming the violation of the human rights of the two countries and giving a strong mandate to The High Representative Mogherini and all the other European bodies so that Latorre and Girone can finally and definitively return home.

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: in writing. - (IT) I voted in favour of the resolution on the case of the two Italian marò: Europe is proceeding decisively in the negotiations with India. Our fellow citizens, Latorre and Girone, found guilty of the deaths of two fishermen in Indian seas, will be released as soon as possible from the detention regime to which they have been forced since 15 February 2012, to be tried by international courts or the Italian authorities, safeguarding justice in the interest and respect for the good of the two countries and the common pain that the affair has entailed.  Europe reaffirms its role as guarantor of respect for peoples and peoples, with a view to a policy of defence and protection of the rights of its citizens. We have received the news that the Supreme Court has granted Latorre a three-month extension of his permit in Italy in order to undergo the medical treatment he needs. We hope, as Italian Foreign Minister Gentiloni says, that this will be the first sign of a dialogue that will finally lead to a real resolution of the negotiations with India which, as stated by the High Representative for Foreign and Security Policy Federica Mogherini, would otherwise risk having an impact on EU-India relations and on the global fight against piracy in which the EU is strongly committed.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. - As I already stated during the debate in the presence of High Representative Mogherini, I believe the adoption of a resolution on the Italian marines is premature and I hope that measures will be taken to make sure this initiative does not negatively influence EU-India relations at a time when the Commission is already struggling to kick-start relations with Delhi.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: in writing. — (IT) I fully supported the motion for a resolution on the case of the two 'maròs', Latorre and Girone, because the right to a fair trial is the foundation of any democratic system. I once again regret the death of Indian fishermen, however, I would like to stress that the jurisdiction competent to try the two riflemen rests with the Flag State of Enrica Lexie, Italy. The confusion over the case has only led to unjustified delays in the investigation of judicial proceedings and in the repatriation of the two defendants. Here, I would like to point out that this is a matter for the whole eu as a whole, because it is up to the EU diplomatic representations to ensure that the rights and security of European citizens detained in third countries are safeguarded.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. — We abstained in the case of this Resolution. While understanding the importance of the common points that all the resolutions presented on this case had, such as that one of the Marines suffered a serious illness or who had been imprisoned without being charged for the three years since the two soldiers allegedly murdered two Indian fishermen by confusing them with pirates, the Delegation of Podemos had decided to vote abstention to point out that the process had been found to be absolutely lacking transparency, including the international dispute over the jurisdiction of the facts or the formal non-attribution of charges to Marines.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the case of the two Italian ‘marò’. These two ‘marò’ have been waiting for three years to know their fate, and I therefore think that the European Union has to step in and help Italy protect the rights of its citizens.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. - We abstained in the case of this Resolution. While understanding the importance of the common points that all the resolutions presented on this case had, such as that one of the Marines suffered a serious illness or who had been imprisoned without being charged three years after the two soldiers allegedly murdered two Indian fishermen mistook them for pirates, the Delegation of Podemos had decided to abstain to highlight that the process had encountered an absolute lack of transparency , including international dispute over the jurisdiction of the facts or the formal non-attribution of charges to Marines.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. — I voted for a resolution on the case of two Italian Marines on the basis that this case led to a diplomatic crisis that needs to be resolved in as acceptable a way as possible for all families, but also for the Italian and Indian authorities. I believe that the unfortunate event, which took place on the high seas, should end before an Italian or international court.  I believe that the human rights of the Italian Marines are very much in jeopardy because even after three years the trial before the Indian authorities has not started. It is obvious to everyone now that the late Indian fishermen were not pirates nor did the Italian Marines think they were fishermen, but thought their life from a pirate attack was at risk and the tragedy occurred out of insatiable. It is known that in the meantime the marines' health has deteriorated significantly and therefore I think the case needs to be put an immediate end to the benefit of all interested parties because I am convinced that this is possible.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. "I voted for this resolution because any sign of the EU is now a support that these two sailors need. We cannot turn a blind eye to the fate of these two Italian soldiers, one of whom has been living at the Italian Embassy in India since February 2012.  But we are not fooled: the Union, by this declaration, shows a weakness which is unbearable to us. I will always support the soldiers who protect Europeans, especially against the scourge of piracy.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. — I supported the adoption by the European Parliament of a resolution on the case of the two Italian marines detained in India without charge. While I am naturally saddened by the tragic death of two Indian fishermen, I believe that the consequences of the events of 15 February 2012 must be considered from the strict point of view of the rule of law, ensuring that the rights of the alleged perpetrators are properly respected.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. — I supported the resolution calling for respect for the human and legal rights of the two Italian marine riflemen arrested and detained by the Indian authorities since February 2012. Accused of killing two Indian fishermen in the course of their duties to protect an Italian merchant navy vessel, these two marine riflemen remain in detention, unassped and severely restricted in their freedom of movement, which constitutes an infringement of their rights. This resolution calls on all parties, including the Eu High Representative for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy, to take the necessary steps to reach a swift resolution of this matter.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. — Although it is tragic that two fishermen have died as a result of a misunderstanding of warning shots against a possible pirate attack, it is by no means acceptable that the two sailors who fired these shots still do not know after three years (1) what charges are being made against them (2) in which country and (3) before which court. India's actions in this case not only run counter to the practice of international law, but undermine legal certainty in international trade and the Union's efforts to combat piracy. India must finally be ready to find a solution that complies with international maritime law that respects international legal practice. The principles of the rule of law and respect for human rights must also apply in India, especially since no charges have been brought against the two seafarers to date and all requests for repatriation to Italy have been rejected. The unnecessary delays and restrictions on the freedom of movement of seafarers amount to a serious violation of human rights. A solution must be found that is acceptable to all parties and which complies with the law of the sea. An indictment before an Italian or international court is a prerequisite. That is why I support the joint motion for a resolution in the hope that a solution can be found soon.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. — I extend my condolences over the tragic death of the two Indian fishermen. The consequences of the event should nevertheless be treated strictly within the rule of law, fully respecting the fundamental rights of those allegedly involved. The Commission must stress the human rights situation in the framework of relations with India and consider further measures to facilitate a positive resolution to the case.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted with conviction in favour of this resolution, in the conviction of the seriousness of the case involving two Italian riflemen detained since February 2012 in India, without any charges having been brought since then. The fact that there have been no significant progress so far is frustrating and is shaking up the Italian public opinion. The resolution goes in the right direction: the prolonging of this situation is unacceptable, fundamental human rights are under discussion and violated. The riflemen, european citizens, must be repatriated, and jurisdiction over the facts involving them must be attributed to the Italian authorities or to international arbitrage. I trust, in the spirit of the resolution, that the High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy will relaunch diplomatic action so that the objectives of the resolution can be achieved, that is, by taking all necessary action and leaving no effort to reach a rapid and satisfactory solution. I am sure that will be the case: the renewed commitment of the new High Representative of the Union is a reassuring premise, as are the words of the spokesman for the Secretary-General of the United Nations, Ban Ki-moon. Let's take home the marò

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. - (IT) Today, thanks to an initiative by the Italian delegation of the EPP, supported by a very large majority of my fellow Members, the marò phenomenon has become a European issue and no longer just a national one. Unfortunately, to date, after three years, no diplomatic or political solution has succeeded in ensuring a positive outcome to this affair, which I believe must now find a shared solution at European level. I therefore strongly support the call for the European Commission and the Council to take this into account when negotiating new agreements with India.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. " I voted on this resolution with the families of the two Italian Marines who have been imprisoned in India for more than two years. Its case is controversial from the point of view of international law and the law of the sea. But they went as military on an official mission to protect a ship in their country, with all the authorizations. Unfortunately, two Indian fishermen were killed in the performance of their mission. Responsibility must be for the Italian State, or the Italian Army or the superiors of the two marines in prison. Or the shipowner of the ship they protected from the threat of piracy in the Indian Ocean. There must be an assumption of responsibility to be assumed and a reparation to the families of fishermen who were tragically victims of a misunderstanding between two boats.  The Government of India has not yet filed charges after two years. In order not to make the tragedy greater, sailors must return to their homes in Italy – one of them seriously ill. And the resolution of any dispute must be done according to international legality

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: in writing. " I voted on this resolution with the families of the two Italian Marines who have been imprisoned in India for more than two years. Its case is controversial from the point of view of international law and the law of the sea. But they went as military on an official mission to protect a ship in their country, with all the authorizations. Unfortunately, two Indian fishermen were killed in the performance of their mission. Responsibility must be for the Italian State, or the Italian Army or the superiors of the two sailors in prison. Or the shipowner of the ship they protected from the threat of piracy in the Indian Ocean. There must be a responsibility to be assumed and a reparation to the families of fishermen who were tragically victims of a misunderstanding between two boats.  The Government of India has not yet filed charges after two years. In order not to make the tragedy greater, the Marines must return to their homes in Italy. One of them seriously ill. And any dispute must be resolved as marked by international law.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. — The Resolution concerns the detention of two Marines of Italian nationality after being identified as responsible for the shootings that killed two Indian fishermen. I believe that the complexity of the case is not adequately reflected in the Resolution and goes beyond the EU's competence, so I did not vote in favour.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. " I regret the way the Indian authorities are handling the case of the two Italian sailors, who are still waiting to find out what their fate will be, after three years. Delays are human rights violations. In addition to supporting the Italian Government, I believe that the EU needs to intervene to protect the rights of its citizens by requesting the application of the national jurisdiction of the flag State under international law, as already requested in the Resolution of 10 May 2012, and by urging the VP/AR to take all necessary measures to protect them and to try to resolve this case urgently and satisfactorily. In addition, the Commission and the Council are requested to attach great importance to the case in the context of their bilateral relations with India and, if necessary, to consider restrictive measures to find a solution. That is why I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. — In 2012, two members of the Italian navy were charged with the murder of two Indian fishermen off the coast of the southern Indian state of Kerala. In their defence, members of the Italian navy outlined how they mistook fishermen for pirates. The incident sparked a major diplomatic row between the two countries.  As the judgment has not been delivered for two years, further delays may adversely affect Relations between the European Union and India, and the case also plays an important role in the global fight against piracy.  I support the Resolution in order to resolve the dispute between India and the European Union as soon as possible in accordance with the UN Convention on the Law of the Sea and international law.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. - This case is very strange and still incomprehensible. I voted in favour of this resolution because such situations may resupe that, when thousands of refugees try to sail to the southern shores of the European Union, more and more pseudo-captains will appear to take and take refugees on board ships, and their lives may be threatened later. The European Union must tackle migration policy by more actively protecting European interests, on the one hand, and by providing assistance to people in need, on the other.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. — I abstained because of the enormous ambiguity of the facts which did not allow me to establish a credible and objective understanding of the actual situation in order to judge, and indeed by my vote, the complex legal claims of both sides.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. — I voted for this resolution which encourages the EU High Representative for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy to take any necessary action to protect the two Italian marines in order to achieve a quick and satisfactory resolution to the case.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of the resolution on the marò case, the two Navy riflemen, Massimiliano Latorre and Salvatore Girone, who have been detained in India for three years pending the opening of a trial on charges of killing two fishermen during an anti-piracy operation off the Somali coast in the Indian Ocean. It is essential to take any action necessary to protect the two Italian riflemen. We are calling for the two marò to be repatriated, because their detention without charge is a serious violation of human rights. The EU must proceed decisively in its negotiations with India and honour its commitment to full and concrete protection of the fundamental rights of its citizens, of every European citizen in detention anywhere in the world.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. — We have been living with anguish in Italy for three years now with the two riflemen Latorre and Girone. No diplomatic or political solution has been able to guarantee a positive outcome to this affair.  I believe that the ineptitude of Indian justice has led to a serious and serious violation of human rights. On the basis of previous assessments, I have decided to support this motion for a resolution with a vote in favour. It effectively conveys the idea that, in the case of Italian marò, it should acquire a European dimension.   I strongly support the call for the European Commission and the Council to take this into account when negotiating new agreements with India.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. — Since I have already signed the question on this matter for oral reply, I would also have voted in favour of the motion for a resolution.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. — On 15 February 2012, off the coast of India and the port of Cochin, an Italian tanker escorted by members of an Italian military protection team (EPE) consisting of six marine riflemen crossed paths with an Indian fishing vessel, the St Antony. Two of the EPR commandos, Massimiliano Latorre and Salvatore Girone, identified the ship as a pirate boat, used their weapons and killed two fishermen. Since then, the two soldiers have been detained in India, first detained and then under house arrest at the Italian embassy where they are currently located. However, under international law, since the vessel being at the time of the events in international waters, the law of the "flag" applies rather than Indian law. As a result, the resolution calls for the repatriation of the two Italian sailors. However, the partiality of this resolution, which justifies the sailors opening fire, leads me to abstain.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. — I agree with the conclusions of this resolution. A fair solution must be found for the situation experienced by the two Italian Marines. India must respect the human rights of the two Italians and quickly find a way to give them back their freedom. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution. I hope that a mutually acceptable solution is reached that respects the interests of all the people, as well as of both countries, involved.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: written — Detention in custody of two Italian seamen in India following the incident in February 2012 continues despite the fact that no charges have been formally brought and internationally accepted standards for detention are not met. India proudly subscribes to the fact that it is the world's largest democracy. However, I stress that a democratic state is not only one that has formally adopted democratic principles, but one that is systematically making real efforts to fill them in practice for the well-being of its citizens. The rule of law lies at the heart of all democratic societies, and one of its fundamental pillars is legal certainty and a fair trial. Unfortunately, violations of the right to a fair trial are a frequent practice, and in most cases the indian citizens themselves are the victims, who will spend several decades in detention before being brought to justice and add sentencing. Two European citizens have been denied their fundamental rights for three years. They live in uncertainty about how many more years are still waiting in an Indian prison, with prison conditions described as deplorable, according to many law organisations. The evidence is perhaps that one of them has already suffered a heart attack and is in a serious condition. I therefore join the call for the fundamental procedural rights of these two citizens to be respected and this matter dealt with as a matter of priority.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. Two Italian marine riflemen operating on the enrica Lexie vessel were arrested by Indian authorities after opening fire on an Indian fishing vessel, killing two fishermen. The presence of the fusiliers on the ship of the Italian merchant navy was part of the fight against piracy. I regret that two people have died there and I extend my deepest condolences to the families and loved ones of the victims. It is essential, however, that the effectiveness of respect for fundamental rights be ensured for the two European nationals arrested by the Indian authorities and that a balanced diplomatic solution between the different parties is found in a short period of time. I invite the High Representative to take up the matter.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. — I gave my full support to, and also co-signed, the motion for a resolution on the case of the two Italian ‘marò’, calling for fair treatment strictly within the rule of law and fully respecting the human and legal rights of those allegedly involved.

name: Sorin MOISĂ
text: in writing. — If you respond to an injustice with another injustice, it is against the very idea of justice. This appears to be the case of two Italian Marines, charged without charge, of killing two Indian fishermen they believed to be part of a pirate attack. A dramatic case on both sides. The two Italians, Europeans, should be tried by a jurisdiction which has the right to do so without delay. But keeping them in a kind of administrative prisoner, without rules, is not fair. It's what's happening to them now in India.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. — In 2012, the Indian fishing vessel St. Anthony approached the Italian merchant vessel Enrica Lexie, which was sailing off the coast of the State of Kerala (India). Two of the six Marines on board opened fire to protect themselves from a possible piracy attack. However, two Indian fishermen were fatally shot and were later arrested and arrested by indian authorities. They are still awaiting prosecution today. Knowing that the two Marines are European citizens and were aboard an Italian merchant ship in international waters and fighting piracy, I believe that the circumstances surrounding the incident must be considered and studied. I also believe that jurisdiction must be conferred on the Italian authorities and/or to an international arbitration. I would also like to stress the importance of ending this conflict and I hope that maximum protection of European citizens will be guaranteed by their diplomatic services, especially when they are detained in any third country.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. — I voted in favour of the European Parliament's draft resolution calling for the repatriation of the two marine riflemen, and the handling of the case, either by an Italian court or by international arbitration. The conflict of interpretation as to the area of occurrence of the accident, testifies to the legal uncertainty surrounding the law of the sea a result of the Montego Bay Convention. As such, it is worth questioning the sustainability of the principle of freedom on the high seas, a principle increasingly called into question by the willingness of States to control their own maritime area of influence, given the new geopolitical challenges.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. "I voted in favour of this text, which encourages the resolution of a dispute between Italy and India.  In 2012, two Italian riflemen on an anti-piracy mission aboard an Italian merchant ship cruising off the coast of Kera fired warning shots at night at an approaching Indian trawler. Two Indian fishermen unfortunately lost their lives in the action. Since then, the Italian riflemen, one of whom is ill, have been held in detention in India without charge. The text calls for international law to prevail in this tragic case and to reach a reasonable solution for the parties as well as for Italian and Indian families.

name: Luigi MORGANO
text: in writing. — It is now almost three years since Massimiliano Latorre and Salvatore Girone, two riflemen of the Italian Navy, were detained in India without having yet been subjected to a proper trial, after the accident that occurred on board the Enrica Lexie, during which, in order to protect the ship from potential attacks, they mistook two Indian fishermen who were tragically killed in the collision for pirates. Despite numerous diplomatic efforts, the legal uncertainty surrounding this affair has not made it possible to clarify in what waters these tragic events have occurred and, consequently, no agreement on a consensual and definitive solution, in accordance with international law, has yet been reached. I would just like to remind you that on 15 February 2012, the two Italian marò, European citizens, were carrying out their task in the context of the activities to combat international piracy to which the European Union is strongly committed. Massimiliano Latorre and Salvatore Girone, must be urgently repatriated and subjected to a fair and rapid trial in Italy or, at the very end, under the competence of an international arbitration, which definitively establishes the circumstances of what happened and any responsibilities. We can no longer put off it: it is an ethical request, before it is a legal one, with which the European Parliament is finally associated today.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. — (IT) With this resolution we wish to draw attention to the serious situation of legal uncertainty, the slowness of the process and the consequent bureaucratic delays which in recent years have led to the long and unjustified detention, with the consequent restriction of freedom of movement, of our two riflemen. This is a serious violation of their human rights and of the major international conventions in this area. We regret the way in which the investigations have been carried out so far and we intend to support every effort to reach a solution acceptable to both countries. We call on Europe to intervene, specifically the EU High Representative for Foreign Policy, so that the issue of the problem of applicable jurisdiction and the possible use of the instrument of international arbitration can be resolved in particular. Let us remember that these are two European citizens, who are therefore entitled to EU diplomatic protection. The continued postponement by India risks having a major impact not only on relations between the European Union and India, but also on the global fight against piracy to which the European Union is strongly committed.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. — I voted for this resolution because it once again tresses the need to respect human rights in all situations. The resolution also underlines an important point, namely that the rights and security of Union citizens in third countries should be protected by EU diplomatic representations. The case of the two Italian Marines must not be repeated.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. — On February 19, 2012, the Italian Marines shot dead two Indian fishermen during an operation against pirates off the Indian coast. This was a serious error. The incident dates back three years and still weighs heavily on relations between Italy and India. The marines were arrested in India and charged with murder. The country has the death penalty, but is rarely carried out. The European Parliament is calling for the return of the naval soldiers to Italy, as this is an arrest without charge. Furthermore, as this is a serious violation of human rights, I supported this motion.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: In writing. I voted against this text because I find it unacceptable that a resolution of the European Parliament should be aimed at influencing an ongoing judicial procedure in India.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. — I supported the resolution because India must ensure the protection of fundamental rights and a fair trial. This issue also touches on Estonian citizens, who have been detained in India for more than a year. Although they have won in court, they cannot continue to leave the country. In addition to Italian citizens, the ship defenders detained in Estonia and Great Britain must be swiftly released and returned to their home countries.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution. Diplomatic tensions and legal uncertainty must be removed as soon as possible and a mutually acceptable solution has been taken. The case of these two Italian marines is of particular concern not only to the States of India and Italy, but also to the EU as a whole. This demonstrates once again that EU diplomatic missions should step up their defence of the fundamental human rights of EU citizens detained in third countries. These institutions must adequately guarantee the rights and security of EU citizens. I agree with the provision that events relating to this incident should fall within the jurisdiction of an Italian or international court. Every problem must be dealt with peacefully, legally, in accordance with international law standards and without respect for human rights. It should be noted that resolving the conflict can have an impact on the development of the EU's relations with India, in particular when negotiating a free trade agreement.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. — Ladies and gentlemen, in view of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and the UN Convention on the Law of the Sea, in view of the Resolution of 10 May 2012 of the European Parliament on maritime piracy, in view of the length of the trial and the total absence of an indictment against the two soldiers, given that the two navy riflemen are citizens of the European Union and that on 15 February 2012 they carried out their tasks of combating piracy. For these reasons, I am voting in favour.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. — It is quite normal for the institutions of the European Union to support the Italian state in defending the interests of the two sailors involved in the tragic misunderstanding that claimed the lives of two Indian fishermen. Every way must be done to ensure a speedy and fair trial. I therefore support this resolution.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. — I support the Resolution on the case of two Italian Marines 'marò' as this is a violation of the human rights of EU citizens by the institutions of India. Two Indian citizens were killed in a collision between an Italian tanker in the service of fighting piracy "Enrica Lexie" and the Indian fishing boat "St. Antony" in 2012. Taking into account that no formal indictment by Indian authorities against detained Italian marines Massimiliano La Torre and Salvatore Girone has been filed in the past three years, their human rights have been violated and illegally prevented from returning to Italy.  The European Parliament's Resolution on combating maritime pirates in 2012 states in Article 30 that under international law, in all cases of combating piracy on the high seas, in any court case, the national legislation under which the ship is flying, is responsible for the ship and the crew. In December 2014, FEDERICA Mogherini expressed concern about the impact of this case on bilateral relations between the European Union and India. With a view to preventing further disruption of relations, the European Parliament clearly requires the return of Italian Marines, EU nationals, to their home country in order to be prosecuted under Italian laws, in accordance with international law.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. — Through this recommendation, the European Parliament is looking into the tragic accident between an Italian commercial navy vessel and Indian fishermen. The consequences of this event must be judged according to the outlines of international law, the first requirements of the presumption of innocence and the conditions of detention. In this sense, diplomatic relations, which have since deteriorated between Italy and India, must be improved in order to enable an end to this conflict, and in particular through fair and effective legal channels.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. — On the evening of 15 February 2012, an Indian fishing vessel approached an Italian merchant vessel sailing off the coast of Kerala State, India. Six Italian Marines were on board, with the mission of protecting the ship from possible pirate attacks. At the approach and for fear of an attack, warning shots were fired at the Indian ship, with two Indian fishermen fatally hit. Following this incident, Indian authorities detained two Marines who were identified as being responsible for opening fire on the fishing vessel. The case has caused diplomatic tensions, and it is particularly worrying that after three years, the Indian authorities will keep the Italian Marines detained without any charges being filed. I therefore voted in favour of this resolution, which calls on the parties to make efforts to achieve a reasonable and mutually acceptable solution that ensures full respect for the human and legal rights of the alleged parties.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. — On the night of February 15, 2012, Italian oil tanker Enrica Lexie crossed the St. Anthony off the coast of Kerala, India. Fearing the pirate attack, the Italian military aboard the Enrica Lexie opened fire on the fishing vessel, resulting in two Indian fishermen dying. Four days later, two Italian sailors identified as the perpetrators of the shooting were arrested by the Indian authorities. Three years later, the Indian authorities have not yet filed charges and have denied the extension of the two detainees' stay permits in Italy. Since international law provides that criminal and disciplinary proceedings against a accused person must be followed before the authorities of the flag State — in this case the same as that of the accused — and that no other national authority has the right to exercise jurisdiction or carry out investigative tasks, the human rights of seafarers must be respected and the European Union External Action Service must ensure that they are reached to a swift and satisfactory resolution of the conflict, as set out in this resolution on which I voted favourably.

name: Teresa RODRIGUEZ-RUBIO
text: in writing. - We abstained in the case of this resolution. While understanding the importance of the common ground that all the resolutions presented in this case had, such as the fact that one of the Marines suffers from a serious illness or who have been imprisoned without being charged for three years since the two soldiers allegedly murdered two Indian fishermen by mistook them for pirates , the Delegation of Podemos had decided to abstain to point out that the process had encountered an absolute lack of transparency, including the international dispute over the jurisdiction of the facts or the formal non-attribution of charges to the Marines.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. — In this resolution, which was passed, the European Parliament stressed the need to ensure the repatriation of the two Italian soldiers accused of killing two Indian fishermen in 2012, whom they had mistaken for pirates. In adopting this joint resolution, MEPs expressed concern about their continued detention without charge, as well as the extreme slowness of the procedure and the restrictions imposed on the freedom of movement of marine riflemen. Regretting the treatment of this case, Parliament therefore agreed with the efforts made by all interested parties to seek a reasonable and acceptable solution by all parties without delay.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. — I agree with this joint motion for a resolution on the case of the two Italian Marines, as it seeks to find a swift and definitive solution, in the light of international law, to the deadlock of detention without charge to which they are subjected, in the light of the deadly incident that victimised two Indian fishermen on 15 February 2012. Deeply regretting and, from now on, the tragic death of the two Indian fishermen, to whom I send my heartfelt condolences, I consider that more than two years after the incident, it is urgent to find a definitive solution to the trial of these two Marines, which must go through their repatriation, because this impasse is an unacceptable and incomprehensible violation of their human rights. I also hope, and as can be read in today's report, that the jurisdiction to resolve this territorial conflict will be conferred on the Italian authorities or to international arbitration, with a view to achieving a reasonable, rapidly resolving and mutually accepted solution by the countries and families concerned and that, in the short term, the DIPLOMATIC representation of the EU will ensure the rights and security of these European citizens.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. — Since 2012, two Italian marine riflemen have been detained in India and accused of killing two Indian fishermen during an anti-piracy operation. I supported this resolution because it is important that a diplomatic solution to this conflict be found while respecting the principles of international law. Thus, the use of an international arbitration route or the Italian justice system in the case of the two marine riflemen could be considered.  With this resolution, Parliament calls on the Eu's Vice-President and High Representative to take all necessary measures and to connect all parties concerned to reach an acceptable solution.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of the resolution calling for the two Italian marò to be repatriated and for the italian authorities or for international arbitration to be given legal competence in the case. The resolution is heading in the right direction, but we Italian delegates are nonetheless astonished at the excessive caution, bordering on suspicion, that Parliament has shown. The proof is that in a match of this calibre, in the face of such flagrant human rights violations, Italian diplomacy was left alone. I hope that the too many dark and negative aspects of this affair will at least give us the opportunity to make serious reflection on the part of the European Parliament in order to guide our actions towards the achievement of effective unity, which is not only economic, but also cultural, social and political.

name: Matteo SALVINI
text: in writing. - (IT) I have chosen to vote in favour of this resolution because it calls for jurisdiction to be assigned to the Italian authorities and/or to international arbitration and also encourages the EU High Representative for Foreign Policy Federica Mogherini to take all necessary action to protect the two Italian riflemen in order to achieve a rapid and satisfactory solution to the case.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. — We abstained in the case of this Resolution. While understanding the importance of the common points that all the resolutions presented on this case had, such as that one of the Marines suffered a serious illness or who had been imprisoned without being charged for the three years since the two soldiers allegedly murdered two Indian fishermen by confusing them with pirates, the Delegation of Podemos had decided to vote abstention to point out that the process had been found to be absolutely lacking transparency, including the international dispute over the jurisdiction of the facts or the formal non-attribution of charges to Marines.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. — The Resolution concerns the detention of two Marines of Italian nationality after being identified as responsible for the shootings that killed two Indian fishermen. I believe that the complexity of the case is not adequately reflected in the Resolution and goes beyond the EU's competence, so I did not vote in favour.

name: Remo SERNAGIOTTO
text: in writing. — Let's bring our marò home! That is our strong appeal in the resolution adopted today by a very large majority. I hope that Europe will commit itself to finding a fair and rapid solution to the case of Massimiliano Latorre and Salvatore Girone. Since 2012, Italian riflemen have been detained in India without specific charges. This serious situation of legal uncertainty is a clear violation of human rights, and that is why we are calling for the relevant jurisdiction to be attributed to the Italian authorities or to international arbitration. We therefore call on the European High Representative Federica Mogherini to take all necessary measures to repatriate our children as soon as possible.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. — I voted to adopt the resolution on the case of the two Italian ‘marò. The consequences of the event of 15 February 2012, resulting in the death of the two Indian fishermen, should be treated strictly within the rule of law, fully respecting the human and legal rights of those allegedly involved. The European Parliament supports the efforts of all parties involved to work urgently towards a reasonable and mutually acceptable solution in the interest of all the families – Indian and Italian – involved, as well as of both countries.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. — I am concerned about the arrest of the Italian Marines, as this is a blatant violation of basic human rights. The Marines were detained without charge and denied access to the necessary legal assistance.  In addition to violations of rights and civil liberties, the lengthy process restricts access to their families as well as providing adequate medical assistance. Due to the inadequacy of the negotiating efforts between the Republic of India and the Republic of Italy, after three years the Indian authorities have not yet filed a formal indictment.  It is necessary to provide a fair trial as soon as possible that will guarantee the Marines respect for human rights. Also, it is necessary to end this inhumane situation as soon as possible and find a solution acceptable for both sides. I supported the resolution because I believe that respect for human rights should be a priority for the European Union and I call for a solution to the problem as soon as possible.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. —First of all, I would express my great sorrow at the tragic deaths of two Indian fishermen and send my condolences. The consequences of the case of 15 February 2012 should certainly be treated strictly in accordance with the rule of law, but also with full respect for the human and legal rights of those involved in the case. I express great concern for the Italian sailors in custody, and I stress that the Marines should be returned to their own Member State due to lengthy delays and restrictions on the freedom of movement of Marines which I believe are unacceptable and constitute a serious violation of their human rights. I would like to recall that the rights and security of EU citizens in third countries should be protected by the EU diplomatic representation, which should actively work to defend the fundamental human rights of EU citizens in detention in any third country. I also recall the statements and efforts of the previous High Representative Catherine Ashton and the current Federica Mogherini in resolving this case. In accordance with all of the above, I support this resolution.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. - I support the adoption of a resolution on italian marines, as this is a case with a number of obstacles and a too long process of clearing up the facts. Italian marines killed two Indian fishermen in Indian Waters. Marines escorted the ship under the Italian flag, as security guards in the area of danger from pirates. They thought they were fishermen pirates and acted in good faith, and it was later found to be an accident. India has requested that the Marines be tried in India, as the case took place in its territorial sea, while Italy argues that it should be tried in Italy, as it is an Italian flag ship and the case took place in international waters. For almost three years, Italy and India have been negotiating a place to try the Marines and by what law, because under Indian law they can be sentenced to the death penalty. The case has been marked by numerous political negotiations and disagreements, with the Marines still awaiting a decision on their fate at the Italian Embassy in New Delhi. This resolution would help the two Italians, and would be a good basis for possible future similar cases.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. — The EU must support the efforts of people carrying out missions to protect human life and safety.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. — The situation of the two Italian 'Maro' (marine riflemen) in India is scandalous. The Supreme Court of India refused to consider the two applications of the Italian Maro. "The investigation into the fishermen's deaths is not over. And the charges have not yet been presented," the court said, as cited by the Italian press. The Indian judges refused to extend Massimiliano Latorre's convalescent stay in Italy for a further four months; barring any other decision, he is expected to return to India on 13 January, the end of his leave. They also rejected Salvatore Girone's request for permission to return to Italy at Christmas. The decision was deemed "disappointing" by the EU's High Representative, Federica Mogherini, who regretted in a statement released on Tuesday evening that a "mutually agreed solution had not been made possible". The situation of these two European soldiers has been on hold for almost three years now. The European Union has always called for a mutually acceptable solution, in the interests of Italy and India, based on international law

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: in writing. " I voted on this resolution with the families of the two Italian Marines who have been imprisoned in India for more than two years. Its case is controversial from the point of view of international law and the law of the sea. But they went as military on an official mission to protect a ship in their country, with all the authorizations. Unfortunately, two Indian fishermen were killed in the performance of their mission. Responsibility must be for the Italian State, or the Italian Army or the superiors of the two sailors in prison. Or the shipowner of the ship they protected from the threat of piracy in the Indian Ocean. There must be a responsibility to be assumed and a reparation to the families of fishermen who were tragically victims of a misunderstanding between two boats.  The Government of India has not yet filed charges after two years. In order not to make the tragedy greater, the Marines must return to their homes in Italy. One of them seriously ill. And any dispute must be resolved as marked by international law.

name: Marco VALLI
text: in writing. - (IT) The adoption of the resolution on the two Italian marò is an act due to two European citizens, Massimiliano Latorre and Salvatore Girone, whose situation has been waiting for a response for more than three years. Through this resolution, the European Parliament has judged the restriction of their freedom and the long delays of the Indian authorities in the investigation of the procedure as a serious violation of human rights. These rights are enshrined in international treaties such as the International Convention on Civil and Political Rights, which has also been ratified by the Indian authorities themselves.  The European Parliament resolution called for jurisdiction to be assigned as soon as possible to the Italian authorities and/or international arbitration and called on the Commission and its High Representative for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy, Federica Mogherini, to take concrete political initiatives for a rapid and satisfactory solution to the case, including by sacrificing present and/or future trade agreements if necessary.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. — The Resolution concerns the detention of two Marines of Italian nationality after being identified as responsible for the shootings that killed two Indian fishermen. I believe that the complexity of the case is not adequately reflected in the Resolution and goes beyond the EU's competence, so I did not vote in favour.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. — Following the accident between the Italian oil tanker Enrica Lexie, with six Italian Marines deployed to protect against possible pirate attacks, and the Indian fishing vessel St. Anthony off the coast of Kerala (India), in which two weighers died, India confiscated the weapons and detained the two Marines responsible for opening fire on the fishing vessel. The Indian government considers that the fatality occurred in waters of Indian jurisdiction, so those responsible must answer in Indian court. Italy says the incident occurred in international waters and that the military should be tried in its country or in an international court. This resolution clearly supports the two Italian Marines, insisting that they must be repatriated, that restrictions on the freedom of movement of suspects are unacceptable and constitute a serious violation of human rights. The High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy is urged to take the necessary measures to protect the two Marines, putting virtually to the fore the crime allegedly committed by these military personnel.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. — On February 19, 2012, the Italian Marines shot dead two Indian fishermen during an operation against pirates off the Indian coast. This was a serious error. The incident dates back three years and still weighs heavily on relations between Italy and India. The marines were arrested in India and charged with murder. The country has the death penalty, but is rarely carried out. The European Parliament is calling for the return of the naval soldiers to Italy, as this is an arrest without charge. Furthermore, this is a serious violation of human rights.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: in writing. — Finally, the diplomatic dispute between Italy and India over the two Italian marò accused of killing two Indian fishermen has been brought to plenary. The two Italian riflemen, which we must not forget are also European citizens, were on board an Italian merchant ship on 15 February 2012 and were carrying out their duties in the context of international anti-piracy activities, which also see the European Union itself strongly committed. I hope that, in relation to the events related to the incident, jurisdiction will be conferred on the Italian authorities or in any case on international arbitration and that the High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy will do everything possible to take any action necessary to protect the two Italian riflemen in order to reach a rapid and satisfactory solution to the case.  Unfortunately, Italian diplomacy has been totally absent in this matter and the Italian Government is unable to work towards a definitive solution.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. — In February 2012, the Italian oil tanker Enrica Lexie, with six Italian Marines deployed to protect against possible pirate attacks, crossed paths with the Indian fishing vessel St. Anthony off the coast of Kerala (India). For fear of an attack, the Marines fired warning shots at the oncoming ship, with two Indian fishermen fatally hit.  India confiscated the weapons and detained the two Marines responsible. Italy says the incident occurred in international waters and that the military should be tried in its country or in an international court. The Indian government considers that the fatality occurred in waters of Indian jurisdiction, so those responsible must answer in Indian court. This resolution clearly supports the two Italian Marines, insisting that they must be repatriated, that restrictions on the freedom of movement of suspects are unacceptable and constitute a serious violation of human rights. The High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy is urged to take the necessary measures to protect the two Marines. This is clearly an issue that must be negotiated between the authorities of the two countries in order to reach an agreement, without interference or external positions.

name: Marco ZULLO
text: in writing. - (IT) I wholeheartedly support the resolution adopted by Parliament calling for a solution to be found as soon as possible to the situation of the two Italian marò, Girone and Latorre, who have been unjustly detained in India for many months, in clear violation of their internationally recognized rights. For far too long they have been the subject and victims of a diplomatic tug-of-war which seems to be of little interest in a real investigation of the facts. I fully agree with Parliament's call for the principles of the rule of law to be respected, recognising jurisdiction to the Italian authorities or, alternatively, to international arbitration. The detention of riflemen without clear charges is a serious and alarming fact. The arbitrary restriction of their freedom must be brought to an end, allowing them to be repatriated so that they are subject to a judgment that is respectful of internationally recognised rules. I particularly join in calling on the High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs, Mr Mogherini, to take all necessary action to protect the two gunmen, in view of the consideration that the rights and security of citizens should be safeguarded by the EU diplomatic representation.

name: Petr MACH
text: I voted against the proposal of the European People's Party and I would like to point out the hypocrisy of them saying, on the one hand, how they would like to reduce the bureaucracy of the European Union, and on the other hand they are the ones who support the establishment of a new Investment Fund of the European Commission. On this fund, I would like to say that this is a very hypocritical matter, it is said that the European Union will secure €315 billion of investment. In fact, they have €8 billion from the budget to serve as a guarantee. This means that, at best, the European Commission will only squeeze out private investment, it will not be extra investment, it will be investments instead of other private investments. And if not, if it attracts new investments, that's all the worse, it will be investments that would never actually be made on the market, because no investor would ever want to finance them, no bank would want to finance them, and only with this additional guarantee will they arise. I therefore voted against it.

name: Daniel HANNAN
text: Mr President, the Commission’s work programme contains a perfectly logical response to the crisis in the eurozone: more fiscal and economic harmonisation, including debt pooling, and common taxation and all of the other instruments of a common finance ministry. I completely understand that. But you must also see that it puts countries like mine in a very difficult position. Plainly we never signed up either for political or monetary union. Is there not a solution here that would leave all sides satisfied? Is it not plain that countries – possibly not limited to the United Kingdom, possibly other Member States – who are not part of this federal vocation could negotiate some kind of associate membership where we stay in the single market but withdraw from the other policies – on justice and home affairs, foreign policy, environmental protection and so on? Would that not take the sting out of our relations? You would be losing a bad tenant and you would be gaining a good neighbour.

name: Seán KELLY
text: A Uachtaráin, bhí sé suimiúil nár éirigh le haon ghrúpa tromlach a fháil dá rún anseo inniu ach bíodh sin mar atá, tá obair le déanamh againn agus tá plean againn ón Uachtarán Juncker. I must say that the Commission is going to be judged on the success of its plans, and there are three particularly strong areas. One: cutting red tape. Two: less legislation, particularly at the European level, that can best be done at national or local level under subsidiarity. Three: the investment plan. President Juncker and the Commission never said they were going to invest over EUR 300 billion themselves. It is all predicated on being able to leverage private investment. Some people are sceptical, some are not, but I think it behoves us all to try and give as much support as we can to try and make this happen so that Europe can become more competitive and we can get back to jobs and growth and a better quality of life for everybody.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: My party, the NVA, regrets that Parliament was unable to send a clear signal today about the Commission's 2015 work programme. Parliament thus misses an agreement with the future and at the same time it is shooting in its own foot. The limits of the so-called grand coalition were clearly reached. This artificial coalition is crippling Parliament and seriously challenges the house's unique freedom to form new coalitions on a dossier-by-case basis. We have supported the ECR resolution and stress that the work programme contains many positive points. Growth, jobs and competitiveness must indeed be central over the next five years. We strongly believe in smarter legislation and fully support the Commission's commitment to those areas where Europe has concrete added value. That is precisely why we believe it is crucial that efforts on the circular economy and air quality remain high on the agenda. Two packages, which, moreover, enjoy broad support, not only in this Parliament, but also in the Council and in the sectors and citizens concerned.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the European Mr With regard to the European Commission's work programme for 2015, one of the guiding questions in the vote for me was how one or another report on TTIP is viewed in one or another report on the ongoing free trade negotiations between the European Union and the US. I voted against the People's Party report because it generally welcomes the Commission's work programme and urges and supports the FREE TRADE AGREEMENT. It was a surprise to me that my Hungarian colleague is also noting this report, even though they are very critical of this free trade agreement at home, because they see that there is a lot behind it, even though appearances and reality are different. I was forced to vote for a left-wing programme or a left-wing report that expresses the opposite opinion and urges the immediate lifting of secrecy on TTIP.

name: Janice ATKINSON
text: Mr President, UKIP voted against Amendment 6 because it effectively calls for a change in EU taxation policy where the end game is harmonisation of individual and corporate tax rates. This will lead directly to companies leaving the EU because it will become uncompetitive and stop growth and innovation, leading to massive job losses. Let us be clear: we will stop you taking over the UK tax rates. Although if Labour wins the next general election, they get the keys to the Treasury, so you might as well.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. — Finally it could not be and, despite the efforts of the S&D Group, there was no common resolution with the other groups. The EU faces a period of low growth, high unemployment, social exclusion, inequality and a real risk of economic deflation.   The resolution submitted by the S&D Group calls on the Commission to address the following priorities: an investment plan to generate more jobs and growth, a fiscal context that favours Member States' investment in the European Fund for Strategic Investments or the inclusion of a social dimension. The Commission must also deal with achieving an energy union with a dominant role in renewable energy, tackling a European immigration policy and preventing tax evasion and tax havens.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. — The Commission's work programme delves into the strategies of deregulation, liberalisation and economic governance that have led to the current social, economic and environmental crisis and the deep emptying of European democracy. Only a change of course could restore the European folk classes to their hope. Instead, the Commission continues to act for the interests of finance and large enterprises: for example, with accelerated opening of the energy and financial markets; opaque trade agreement negotiations with the U.S.; with financial subsidies for the benefit of the privatization of industrial policy and the public initiative scovered by the Juncker plan; with the institutionalisation in the euro area of the 'permanent coup d'etate' involved in the action of the Commission and the ECB in the bailouts that followed the debt crisis. Nor does the Commission self-critical in migration and internal security: on the contrary, it is under serious deterioration of the human rights situation in the Member States. For all this, I voted against it.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. — The European Commission's work programme includes the measures it intends to take for the year now under way. In 2015, the focus will be on growth, employment and investment. The Commission has initially taken a number of concrete initiatives (digital single market, European Energy Union, migration policy, equitable fiscal framework, etc.) which can be fully effective, especially at EU level. It also means that the so-called 'REFIT programme' is used to re-examine and amend useless and burdensome legislation. Finally, it also intends to delete earlier legislative proposals whose objectives can be achieved in a better way. I welcome this work programme because it is fully in line with the principle of subsidiarity and is a major driver of the EU's red tape.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. — There were various motions by the political groups on this matter. As a UKIP MEP I believe in the principle of national sovereignty. Whilst the UK is in the EU, I believe that the European Parliament should have as little influence as possible in the lives of the British people so I voted against the motions, or abstained, as appropriate.

name: Janice ATKINSON
text: in writing. — I voted against this as it effectively gives a common EU asylum visa, an open corridor for migrants, an allocation of migrants for distribution across EU states, funding and entitlement to work permits and equal rights to all EU countries. David Cameron and his Conservatives have no hope of curbing current immigration numbers, this will lead to a tsunami of migration the likes of which we have never seen.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. — Faced with the socio-economic situation and the risk of deflation, the far too high level of unemployment and the unacceptable number of people living in poverty, the Commission has no choice but to implement a recovery strategy based on a broad private and public investment plan in order to create massive employment, especially for young people. These priorities, as well as the social dimension, should have been much more assertive in the Commission's 2015 work programme. Ditto the need for resolute action to combat tax evasion and evasion and aggressive tax planning at EU level and around the world. Europe cannot be built on social and fiscal injustices. I have supported the motion for a resolution, which highlights these absolute social and human priorities.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This Commission programme for 2015 proudly named 'A New Beginning for Europe' is simply to go ever further in ultraliberalism, the defence of the single currency and austerity at all costs that crushes the peoples of Europe. Nothing new in fact, other than the waltz of the European Commissioners last October.  With the recent "LuxLeaks" scandal, it is in any case clear that this Commission will not tackle the problem of tax evasion in Europe or unfair competition since its president is none other than the man who ruled Luxembourg for 19 years.  Since the entry into force of this new Commission, I have not seen any interesting topics emerge or when they are, they are emptied of their substance by Brussels technocrats subject to financial markets and lobbyists. I do not believe in the stimulus package that we are being touted for. The real renewal would be a radical change in policy and a return to a more modest Europe but based on cooperation between free and independent nation-states. So I voted against it.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. — (IT) The resolution is balanced and well thought out, it shares my critical views on the austerity and management of TTIP so far, which is why I supported it with my vote.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. — Finally, despite the efforts of the S&D Group, no joint resolution has been reached with the other Groups. The EU faces a period of low growth, high unemployment, social exclusion, inequality and a real risk of economic deflation.   The resolution submitted by the S&D Group calls on the Commission to address the following priorities: an investment plan to generate more jobs and growth, a fiscal context that favours Member States' investment in the European Fund for Strategic Investments or the inclusion of a social dimension. The Commission must also deal with achieving an energy union with a dominant role in renewable energy, tackling a European immigration policy and preventing tax evasion and tax havens.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. — I support the Social Democratic Group resolution, in which we call on us to remember that poverty and social exclusion have gained a scale that has never before been, and that is why the most vulnerable groups in society are suffering the most: women, young people, children, seniors, people with disabilities. We call on the Commission to urgently take measures to reduce social disparities between Member States or regions, discrimination in the labour market, poverty, because these are phenomena incompatible with European values that undermine the potential for growth and competitiveness. We call on the Commission, in addition to all the legislative projects being prepared, to present an assessment of how legislation, if adopted, would have an impact on the social aspects of European life. We support the truly ambitious investment programme proposed by the new Commission. However, we insist on ensuring that these investments are primarily geared towards creating quality and safe jobs, prioritising young people, as well as regions of the highest unemployment.  Although Juncker stressed, in presenting the Commission's future work, that the programme is man-oriented in order to regain Europeans' confidence in Europe. However, a more detailed examination of the programme presented shows that social policy among all other priorities seems only to be an addition. Worse still, social policy is presented as an administrative burden for the economic challenges of the single market. This should not be the case in today's Europe, where 126 million people are balancing on the poverty line, with 25 million unemployed and 5 million of them young people.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. — I voted for a motion for a resolution on the Commission's Work Programme for 2015, as the final appearance of the text through amendments from the Socialists and Democrats club was satisfactory. I am sorry that no agreement was reached with other political groups, as the resolution was the best way for the European Parliament to tell the Commission what it thought of their 2015 plan. By not ruling the resolution, we have in some way shown that we have no opinion, which is a bad political message.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. — The European Commission risks slipping by taking a "new impetus for jobs, growth and investment". It will lead to its downfall, alas, of the European peoples. Listening to Mr Juncker talk about the fight against tax evasion is quite surprising and could make you smile if it were not a theft to the detriment of other European states.  Its work programme for 2015 is merely a list of vague declarations of intent. As it announced in its introduction, the Commission does not go into detail about the mobilization of these so-called '315 billion'. It's smoke... Mr Timmermans, First Vice-President of the Commission, proudly announces "a balanced agenda for immigration: citizens are calling for better management of immigration in Europe while allowing Europe to remain an attractive destination for talent". It's about time. We've been saying this for forty years. We are delighted with this sudden conversion to a less lax immigration policy. But we doubt his ability to deal with the issue. But today, our citizens no longer want to suffer this mass extra-European immigration that is destroying our system of civilization.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. — I voted ‘no’ because I believe this motion does not help the implementation and execution of the work programme.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: in writing. — Finally it could not be and despite the efforts of the SD Group, there was no joint resolution with the other Groups. The EU faces a period of low growth, high unemployment, social exclusion, inequality and a real risk of economic deflation.   The Resolution submitted by the SD group calls on the EC to address the following priorities: an investment plan to generate more jobs and growth, a fiscal context that favours Member States' investment in the European Fund for Strategic Investments or the inclusion of a social dimension. The EC must also deal with achieving an energy union with a dominant role in renewable energy, tackling a European immigration policy, and preventing tax evasion and tax havens.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. — The Commission's 2015 programme is synonymous with progress and innovation.  In line with Jean-Claude Juncker's promise, the focus will be on growth, job creation and investment. The new Commission has already proposed legislation for the creation of a European fund for strategic investments.  Furthermore, as chairman of the Committee on Fisheries, I fully agree with the Commission when it points out the need for the reformed common fisheries policy. However, I insist that special attention be paid to the place of fishing in blue growth. There will be no resolution on the Commission's programme for 2015. This has been the wish since the departure of the EPP Group. Indeed, we support Mr Juncker in his programme and we do not believe that a resolution is necessary. I have, of course, voted in favour of the EPP Group resolution. The latter was clear and simple in the image of the Commission's programme for this year.

name: Enrique CALVET CHAMBON
text: in writing. — With regard to paragraph 4 of the European Parliament Resolution on the Commission's Work Programme for 2015 (2014/2829(RSP), it opens up interesting discussions in which the indispensable strengthening of the social dimension in the European Commission's work project should be deepened. However, it is drafted in a scandalous and accusatory way, in a scandalous and accusatory manner, with the Commission rejecting the negative intentions which they are about to demonstrate. Parliament will monitor the implementation of the programme and act accordingly to promote a social Europe. For all this, I have decided to abstain.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. — (IT) Today I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the Commission's work programme for 2015 proposed by the Socialists & Democrats, my group. It has had the merit of highlighting a number of points which I consider to be particularly important.  First, it brought attention to the social dimension of the European Union, pointing out that 25 million Europeans, including 5 million young people, are unemployed and that poverty and social exclusion have increased greatly in recent years. With regard to the environment, the resolution stressed the need to draw up legislative proposals that are important for the implementation of the 2030 climate and energy package and also emphasised that circular economy proposals must continue to be a priority on the Commission's agenda.
