Finally, the call to combat tax havens and the need for fair taxation that encourages the real economy has helped to define a resolution outlining a programme of Commission activities that is particularly responsive to the needs of the European Union.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. — The choice of ‘A New Start’ as a title for the Commission Work Programme 2015 shows the willingness for change the new Commission has. The focus placed on reducing administrative burdens on citizens and companies will serve as a much-needed change to the current situation. Measures to protect the Union’s financial interests through combatting tax fraud and tax evasion can help ensure that taxpayers’ money is used where needed most. For these reasons I have supported this resolution.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. — (IT) Europe is going through an extremely difficult period in which the Member States are struggling to adapt to the strict budgetary rules of the institutions, and we hope that the Commission will be aware of the urgent need for more flexible rules for public accounts.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. — (IT) The EPP resolution, which I voted in favour of, confirms to Mr Juncker the confidence already given in October. This work programme shows great differences from Mr Barroso and I, once again, would like to stress that I like to judge by facts more than statements. If Juncker has decided to reduce his activities in order to focus on a few acts to do them well, I will judge him by the quality of the legislative proposals he will present, and that is a good thing for me: it leaves Parliament more room for manoeuvre in the areas it does not deal with during 2015. Let's talk about it again in a year' s time.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. — I regret that it was not possible to obtain a compromise between the main political groups to vote on an opinion on the Commission's Work Programme for 2015. It is true that this exercise has a bit of inertia, as part of the measures and initiatives result from proposals from the previous Commission chaired by Mr Barroso. But it is no less true that many of the Juncker Commission's priorities are well evident in the document and that, due to lack of consensus, Parliament has not been able to vote on a position.   This is the Commission's legislative programme amputated with the greatest democratic legitimacy that only Parliament could grant and not because of the Commission but the sole responsibility of the Parliamentary Groups which have insisted on each one having their sole opinion approved (unsuccessfully).

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. — (IT) The European Commission's new work programme bodes well, following on from what President Junker said, that he has undertaken to 'lead an EU that is bigger and more ambitious on big things and smaller and more modest on small things', but I personally still have serious doubts about this. Unfortunately, too much bureaucracy still persists at all levels (regional, national and European), taxpayers' money is sometimes wasted on obsolete and inadequate actions and legislative proposals that do not meet the needs of our citizens and which cannot even tackle incisively the major socio-economic challenges such as combating unemployment, especially among young people, and improving the competitiveness of our businesses. We must aim for a substantial reduction in the bureaucratic burden, an impact assessment of the new proposals on SMEs, but above all an investment plan capable of boosting the economy and greater social equity with measures to combat tax evasion and fraud.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. — I welcome the readiness for change and simplicity of the Commission proposals, aimed at reducing bureaucracy and simplifying the lives of economic players. It is noted that the work programme contains 23 new initiatives for 2015, while it proposes to withdraw or amend 80 existing ones, thereby communicating that the EU needs to focus on major priorities instead of introducing burdensome legislation. I fully support the proposal to revise the Interinstitutional Agreement on Better Law-making so as to improve the efficiency of the legislative process.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. — The Commission's work programme delves into the strategies of deregulation, liberalisation and economic governance that have led to the current social, economic and environmental crisis and the deep emptying of European democracy. Only a change of course could restore the European folk classes to their hope. Instead, the Commission continues to act for the interests of finance and large enterprises: for example, with accelerated opening of the energy and financial markets; opaque trade agreement negotiations with the U.S.; with financial subsidies for the benefit of the privatization of industrial policy and the public initiative scovered by the Juncker plan; with the institutionalisation in the euro area of the 'permanent coup d'etate' involved in the action of the Commission and the ECB in the bailouts that followed the debt crisis. Nor does the Commission self-critical in migration and internal security: on the contrary, it is under serious deterioration of the human rights situation in the Member States. For all this, I voted against it.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: in writing. — The European Commission has adopted its 2015 work programme, defined actions to bring about a real change in employment, growth, investment and external challenges.  In terms of foreign policy, a stronger Europe is needed. The crisis in Ukraine, the worrying situation in the Middle East and the recent terrorist attacks in France show how important it is for Europe to be united externally.  In order for the common European foreign policy to function more effectively, better mechanisms must be put in place to anticipate events in advance and to quickly identify common responses, and we need to be more effective in bringing together Europe's external action instruments.   I believe that the European executive forum must also step up its engagement with its eastern neighbours, such as Ukraine, the Republic of Moldova and the Western Balkans, in order to continue negotiations to provide a European perspective, but also to promote closer cooperation, association and partnership that further strengthens our economic and political ties.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. — Although I have my personal reservations on the specific details of paragraphs 27 and 41 and on the potential outcomes of some of these measures at EU level, suggested in the motion for resolution tabled on behalf of S&D, I support the overall objective of the resolution, and find it highly important that the European Parliament and its members express their priorities for the Commission’s annual work programme.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: in writing. — I believe that the European Union's top priority must be to ensure sustainable economic growth and quality jobs for its citizens. When it comes to people, we need to look at the future of Europe in all its dimensions, but especially at the social dimension that I consider substantial, and I believe that the European Commission must include it in its work programme.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: in writing. — (IT) I think it is a serious matter that Parliament has not been able to express with a single voice a strong response to the work programme presented by the new Juncker Commission for 2015.  The absence of a joint motion for a resolution weighs even more heavily in the light of the Commission's inexplicable decision to withdraw a number of newly submitted legislative dossiers on which no compromise has yet been reached between Parliament and the Council. I believe that, where there has already been a legislative decision, the Commission must feel politically bound by inter-institutional consultation before withdrawing the legislative proposal by exercising its rights exclusively. Despite the shortcomings in the failure to provide for an adequate social dimension, there are strategically important initiatives in the 2015 programme to strengthen the cohesion of the European single market such as the Digital Single Market Package and the Internal Market Strategy for Goods and Services, which focuses particularly on the needs of SMEs.  Finally, I hope that the Commission will give concrete follow-up in its various legislative initiatives to the political change undertaken under the Italian Presidency in a sign of greater attention to flexibility in economic policy and to the needs of growth and the recovery of the real economy.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. — President Jean-Claude Juncker and the College of Commissioners presented the European Commission's work programme for 2015 at the December plenary session. In line with the commitments made during the European elections campaign last May, this programme of work translates President Juncker's policy guidelines into 23 legislative proposals for jobs, growth and investment. The work programme also proposes to reduce the administrative burden on citizens and businesses and presents a list of proposals withdrawn, deemed obsolete or inadequate. I am joining this new method of working, more in line with what citizens expect from the European Union, whose legislation they sometimes consider too complex. I therefore voted in favour of the resolution tabled by the Group of the European People's Party which supports this approach.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. As a member of the European People's Party (EPP), I voted in favour of my political group's resolution on the European Commission's work programme for 2015. Refusing, unlike other political groups, to produce a resolution that would have been a catalogue of laws, he could not find common ground with the other groups. Nevertheless, a short resolution, such as that of the EPP, was more than enough: the European Commission's programme is widely known since its inauguration by the European Parliament dates from October 2014. In particular, I am particularly in favour of the idea, which is present in the work programme, that the European Union should intervene only where it brings real added value. This was one of our campaign commitments during the European elections, it must be kept.

name: Pablo ECHENIQUE
text: in writing. — We voted against the resolutions tabled by the other groups on the Juncker Commission's work programme because none sufficiently reflects the fundamental vice affecting that programme: that it does not respond at all to the fundamental problems affecting the daily lives of Union citizens. This work programme provides no viable and effective solutions to address the macroeconomic problems of debt, corruption, tax evasion and unemployment, nor does it promote a renewable and sustainable energy policy, nor does it raise the deep democratisation that needs to be undertaken to ensure the viability of the European institutions, nor does it transform the main lines of a foreign and trade policy that does not seek the effective promotion of the fundamental values of the Union and rights of its citizens. We voted in favour of our group's resolution because we understand that it reflects a democratic, viable and sustainable political vision to provide solutions to the economic and social emergency that our peoples are suffering from austerity policies, social protection calls, and the lack of democracy of the political institutions that govern their destinies.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. — We consider the Commission's programme to treat the European as a number and the nation-states as enemies. The policy of austerity and economic contraction promoted by the Commission finds us opposed and we believe that its programme, instead of solving the existing problems, is gianting them.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. — The European Union's political priorities must be adequate to the available financial resources and have a real influence in helping citizens anticipate and react to a rapidly changing society. Therefore, in Europe the model of the social market economy is one that ensures sustainable growth, not least because it will provide jobs rather than debt to the next generation. Having said that, I welcome the Commission's work programme which has been promoting a significant reduction in the administrative burden on citizens and businesses and is committed to jobs, growth and investment with 23 concrete proposals. Reducing the cost of bureaucratic obligations and establishing independent assessments are measures that help to eliminate bureaucracy at all levels and for all economic actors and citizens in their daily lives.

name: Jonás FERNÁNDEZ
text: in writing. — Despite the efforts of the S&D Group, there was no common resolution with the other groups. Our group therefore voted on its own resolution, which in this context of low growth, high unemployment, social exclusion, inequality and real risk of economic deflation affirms as unplaceable priorities for 2015 the following: an investment plan to generate more jobs and greater growth, a fiscal context that favours the investment of Member States in the European Fund for Strategic Investments or the inclusion of a social dimension for EU policies. It is also essential to move forward in an energy union that overcomes energy dependence or the determined fight against tax evasion and tax havens.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. — (IT) As has been said on several occasions, this Commission has already got off on the wrong foot. Juncker and his commissioners are not giving the positive impetus that Europe in crisis would need, and the much-vaunted Juncker plan will be proof of this failure.

name: Vicky FORD
text: on behalf of the ECR Group, in writing. — In the votes on the seven group motions on the Commission work programme the ECR only voted for its own text.  The ECR motion offered a detailed and comprehensive assessment of the 2015 work programme. The motion gave a cautious welcome overall to the general approach taken by the Commission in focusing on the economy and seeking reductions of the legislative and bureaucratic burden on businesses and individuals. But the motion also highlighted areas of serious concern and emphasised the Group’s priorities on competitiveness and on respecting the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality. The motion covered all the issues raised in the work programme in detailed and precise language as a result of thorough collective discussion. For these reasons, the ECR did not vote for any parts of any other Group motions, even when the Group was sympathetic to some of the content, as the ECR stands by the carefully considered collective positions taken in its own piece of work.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. — On some issues such as the protection of citizens and the environment I agree with the Commission's Programme for 2015 and on others I disagree, since this programme is based on a tighter economic policy and presents objectives that cannot be achieved under the existing conditions.

name: Ashley FOX
text: in writing. — Mr President, I voted in favour of the ECR’s resolution on the Commission’s Work Programme for 2015. The ECR’s resolution was the only one which put forward core priorities, such as growth and prosperity, in order to benefit citizens. Furthermore, the emphasis on the prioritisation of the Digital Single Market is key to bringing jobs to Member States and to expanding our economies.

name: Eugen FREUND
text: Writing. — For the first time, the Commission has resorted to the European Parliament in drawing up its work programme. The S&D Group agrees that 2015 will be the year in which we implement the announced measures and investments. The Commission's Work Programme for 2015 needs concrete and ambitious strategies, including for new growth, the development of the Digital Single Market and a European Energy Union. However, there are still weaknesses in the programme. The social dimension is (still) too short. It is precisely in view of the high level of unemployment in Europe and the social cuts that citizens rightly expect the EU to address these problems. Transparency and proximity to the citizens are more important than ever in this respect. The revelations surrounding the tax trickery in Luxembourg have brought to our attention another urgent problem: we need a fair tax policy. Tax trickery distorts the internal market and undermines solidarity. Finally, we also need a holistic approach to an integral asylum and migration policy, fully respecting fundamental rights. In the light of the attacks in Paris, the programme needs to be extended to include a new security policy component. However, we will look very closely at one thing: values that make up the European Union, namely civil liberties and democracy, must not be restricted in this respect.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the Resolution after assessing the working priorities of the European Commission. It is a very positive development that the Commission has promptly presented its 2015 Work Programme, clearly geared towards employment, growth and investment, key factors in consolidating the economic recovery in Europe. Emphasis should be made on the need to fully implement existing legislation in areas such as the single market, environmental law, the financial and banking sectors, etc. Similarly, it is necessary to achieve a significant reduction in the administrative burden on citizens and businesses, reducing the number of legislative proposals and focusing on the main priorities, in order to help eliminate bureaucracy at all levels, as well as to continue the fight against tax evasion and evasion.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: in writing. — Finally it could not be and, despite the efforts of the S&D Group, there was no common resolution with the other groups. The EU faces a period of low growth, high unemployment, social exclusion, inequality and a real risk of economic deflation.   The resolution submitted by the S&D Group calls on the Commission to address the following priorities: an investment plan to generate more jobs and growth, a fiscal context that favours Member States' investment in the European Fund for Strategic Investments or the inclusion of a social dimension. The Commission must also deal with achieving an energy union with a dominant role in renewable energy, tackling a European immigration policy and preventing tax evasion and tax havens.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: in writing. — Finally it could not be and, despite the efforts of the S&D Group, there was no common resolution with the other groups. The EU faces a period of low growth, high unemployment, social exclusion, inequality and a real risk of economic deflation.   The resolution submitted by the S&D Group calls on the Commission to address the following priorities: an investment plan to generate more jobs and growth, a fiscal context that favours Member States' investment in the European Fund for Strategic Investments or the inclusion of a social dimension. The Commission must also deal with achieving an energy union with a dominant role in renewable energy, tackling a European immigration policy and preventing tax evasion and tax havens.

name: Lidia Joanna GERINGER DE OEDENBERG
text: I would like to write to the Commission. — Unfortunately, the European Parliament's political groups have not reached an agreement on the European Commission's 2015 work programme, despite its proposals, such as the Investment Plan, the European Energy Union and the Community digital market. Achieving the objectives of economic growth in the EU and combating unemployment will require financial resources. In order to obtain them, it is necessary, for example, to rapidly introduce new measures to combat tax fraud in the Union.  I am pleased that the plans for this year include a review of the Interinstitutional Agreement on Better Regulation, including the actions proposed jointly by the Commission and the Council to improve the effectiveness of the legislative process. The plan also includes a fairer division of responsibilities in the fight against irregular migration, as sought by eu border countries, in particular Greece and Italy.  I hope that the Commission will be able to create the basis for sustainable economic development and thus reduce unemployment, especially among young people. Furthermore, as Parliament, we look forward to working closely together in the TTIP negotiations so that our social, consumer and environmental standards are included in the new agreement.

name: Nathan GILL
text: in writing. — UKIP voted against paragraph 6 of the S&D resolution on the Commission Work Programme 2015. We of course oppose any illegal action in the realm of tax. However, we cannot call on the EU to do anything, as this is a step in the direction of further tax powers being handed over to the undemocratic and unaccountable institutions of the EU. The second half of the paragraph calls for more EU legislation on country-by-country reporting for all cross-border companies. UKIP will not support more EU legislation and EU red tape on businesses. UKIP voted against split 1 on paragraph 9 of the EPP resolution on the Commission Work Programme 2015. UKIP was elected to oppose all new EU legislation, get rid of existing EU laws, support powers to be returned to Member States and campaign to leave the EU. As this text concerns the withdrawal of EU proposals, we voted against opposing the withdrawal of the named legislative proposals. Only the unelected EU Commission can initiate new, start to amend existing, or begin repeal of, EU legislation. No one who the people can vote for can change EU laws. This is why the EU is not legitimate in creating laws that the UK is forced to abide by.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. - I am deeply disappointed that Parliament has failed to reach agreement on the Commission Work Programme for 2015, because this hampers Parliament in its most crucial role, which is making sure the Commission develops a programme that addresses citizens’ priorities, and holding the executive to account in the implementation of this programme. I believe our citizens deserve strong EU action that delivers growth, quality jobs and progress on tackling climate change. 25 million people in the EU do not have a job, over 224 000 of whom live in my region of the West Midlands. If we really want to address this, we need to kick-start action on tackling tax havens and develop a truly integrated strategy for job creation. This means finally realising that the economy cannot be fuelled without adopting strong policies on issues like affordable housing, energy poverty, and education. It is equally disappointing that the Commission has withdrawn the Air Quality Package, while the future of the Circular Economy Package is shrouded in clouds – pieces of legislation which have the potential to save lives and create hundreds of thousands of jobs. I hope the Commission will finally connect the dots on all these issues in 2015.

name: Julie GIRLING
text: in writing. — I strongly support the inclusion of the air and waste packages in the WP and voted as such in the specific votes today (paragraphs 16, 18, 21(1), 9(1) and 23). Air quality in particular is a hugely important issue for European citizens, and we cannot underestimate the benefits, both for the health of our nations and to the wider environment, that would be found with improved legislation in this area. Better regulation is of the utmost importance, and I welcome the Commission’s quest to weed out legislation that is ineffectual, intractable or just plain bad. It is, however, imperative that we do not sacrifice the potential benefits by scrapping legislation with potential in such a wholesale manner. I am confident that on the Air Quality Package the co-legislators can come up with a solution that delivers real value here without imposing unnecessary burdens on industry or Member States.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. — We voted against the resolutions tabled by the other groups on the Juncker Commission's work programme because none sufficiently reflects the fundamental vice affecting that programme: that it does not respond at all to the fundamental problems affecting the daily lives of Union citizens. This work programme provides no viable and effective solutions to address the macroeconomic problems of debt, corruption, tax evasion and unemployment, nor does it promote a renewable and sustainable energy policy, nor does it raise the deep democratisation that needs to be undertaken to ensure the viability of the European institutions, nor does it transform the main lines of a foreign and trade policy that does not seek the effective promotion of the fundamental values of the Union and rights of its citizens. We voted in favour of our group's resolution because we understand that it reflects a democratic, viable and sustainable political vision to provide solutions to the economic and social emergency that our peoples are suffering from austerity policies, social protection calls, and the lack of democracy of the political institutions that govern their destinies.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the resolution on the Commission Work Programme 2015. I support Commission’s focus on priorities, especially on the single digital market, which is of utmost importance for me and my country.

name: Jytte GUTELAND
text: Written. - (SV) We voted in favour of the S&D resolution on the Commission's work programme. The content of the resolution is for the most part good. At the same time, there are some wordings that we cannot fully support. For example, we do not want to see any expansion of the EU budget. On the issue of a common unemployment insurance system, we are not opposed to an impact assessment limited to the euro area countries. However, we do not support the creation of such a system for the whole of Europe.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: Writing. — (DE) There are many reasons why the European Commission's work programme has failed in the EP today. The mere fact that the research budget should be plundered to finance the Juncker investment programme makes it unacceptable in my view.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. - We voted against the resolutions tabled by the other groups on the Juncker Commission's work programme because none sufficiently reflects the fundamental vice affecting that programme: that it does not respond at all to the fundamental problems affecting the daily lives of Union citizens. This work programme provides no viable and effective solutions to address the macroeconomic problems of debt, corruption, tax evasion and unemployment, nor does it promote a renewable and sustainable energy policy, nor does it raise the deep democratisation that needs to be undertaken to ensure the viability of the European institutions, nor does it transform the main lines of a foreign and trade policy that does not seek the effective promotion of the fundamental values of the Union and rights of its citizens. We voted in favour of our group's resolution because we understand that it reflects a democratic, viable and sustainable political vision to provide solutions to the economic and social emergency that our peoples are suffering from austerity policies, social protection calls, and the lack of democracy of the political institutions that govern their destinies.

name: Robert Jarosław IWASZKIEWICZ
text: I would like to write to the Commission. — I voted in favour of resolutions aimed at reducing EU bureaucracy, replacing EU acts with Member States' laws, combating corruption and waste of funds, a responsible and firm migration policy. I am in favour of rethinking the current European climate and energy policy and condemning any EU legislation that imposes administrative burdens and introduces additional bureaucratic obstacles for SMEs, which are the main source of jobs and growth.  I firmly believe that the policies of all the EU institutions, led by the European Commission, must be redefined from building a bureaucratic economically weak empire to building a strong Europe of nation states with strong economies.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. — I voted for a resolution prepared by the ALDE political group, as it best expresses my view of the future work programme of the Juncker Commission. I voted AGAINST all other programs that offered other political options because I believe that each of these proposals does not contain a complete and consistent program as expressed in the document offered by the ALDE Group.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. — I voted against the resolution on the Commission's work programme for 2015. As the work programme had already been adopted by the Commission and had come into force, there was no legal and political interest for Parliament to make a resolution on the subject. Proposals from other political groups would have led to a work programme of more than 200 texts, which would have completely contradicted the idea of better legislating and reducing the level of bureaucracy by focusing on the major issues. This criticism of the EU's tendency to legislate on everything and everything was at the centre of discussions with citizens during the European elections last May. We can only be pleased in this regard that Jean-Claude Juncker has taken the decision to address this concern and to give priority to quality over quantity. I therefore welcome the rejection of this resolution.

name: Josu JUARISTI ABAUNZ
text: in writing. — In the absence of a joint motion for a resolution on the Commission Work Programme 2015, EH Bildu has voted against the motions for resolutions presented by the EPP, Greens/EFA, ALDE, S&D, ECR and EFDD, and in favour of the motions for resolution presented by our group, GUE/NGL. In our opinion, the CWP 2015 does not include legislative proposals worked out and discussed in the previous term, and we are deeply dissatisfied about that fact. Indeed, we strongly condemn the Commission’s principle of political discontinuity as it completely undermines the European Parliament’s rights as co-legislator; insisting that the decision to withdraw a legislative file must be the result of decision-making procedures. In that line, we strongly oppose the proposed withdrawal of the Waste Package, the Clean Air Policy Review, and the Circular Economy initiative, identified as crucial for sustainable growth and the well-being and health of EU citizens, as well as the Maternity Leave Proposal. It is true that the Commission’s Work Programme for 2015 is not the item to be voted, but no other motion than that proposed by GUE/NGL expresses the deep dissatisfaction that EH Bildu feels about the CWP 2015, and hence the direction of our vote.

name: Tunne KELAM
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the EPP Group resolution on the Commission Work Programme for 2015. I would like to underline the call to focus on key priorities and thus to enforce needed legislation and to remove obstacles.  The digital single market is both a short- and long term key priority, thus rapid progress is needed so that appropriate legislation is put in place. We need to accomplish the Data Protection Directive, Telecoms Single Market and Network and Information Society Directive this year!  I especially support the paragraph on cutting red tape that calls for reducing bureaucratic burdens by 25 % and establishing independent assessments in order to measure the administrative burden and related costs of new proposals, including a mandatory SME test.  Finalising TTIP talks this year is crucial for transatlantic relations; we cannot drag out these negotiations forever. We need to agree now and create the biggest free trade area based on democratic values and principles. Agreeing on an ambitious, balanced and comprehensive TTIP respecting EU social, environmental and consumer standards will give a new impetus to economic growth, but also set standards on a global scale that others could follow.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. — I do not believe the Work Programme is adequate in the areas of job creation and social protection and I think we need a strong line on tax havens and environmental policy. I therefore voted for the S&D resolution, which disagrees with the Commission’s intention to withdraw a number of legislative proposals, notably the Air Quality Package and the Maternity Leave Directive, calls to address the growing issue of precarious employment including zero hour contracts, asks for a full revision of the Posting of Workers Directive and for a radical and effective change in EU taxation policy, urging the Commission to make an unequivocal commitment to the fight against tax fraud.

name: Gabrielius LANDSBERGIS
text: Writing. — The EPP Group, in its resolution on the 2015 The Commission's work programmes have highlighted the reduction of administrative burdens for small and medium-sized enterprises, acceptance of job creation and innovation. I strongly support all measures to combat tax fraud and tax evasion, and I agree with the need for a more effective use of taxpayers' money and for further action to protect the Financial Interests of the European Union. And transparent, rational and reasonable financial use is a priority for planning both eu and Member State finances.

name: Constance LE GRIP
text: In writing. —I voted in favour of the resolution prepared by the EPP, which aimed to support the Commission's work programme as it stands. The other political groups have tried to amend this work programme by proposing their resolutions, which we thought was unnecessary since the European Commission has already, on several occasions, benefited from the confidence of the European Parliament. In the end, due to a lack of a majority, no resolution was adopted. In this way, we, as EPP Members, have somehow renewed our confidence in the European Commission, which we believe has the political courage to 'wake up Europe', boost growth and jobs and lift Europe out of its sluggishness.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: in writing. — Finally it could not be and despite the efforts of the SD Group, there was no joint resolution with the other Groups. The EU faces a period of low growth, high unemployment, social exclusion, inequality and a real risk of economic deflation.   The Resolution submitted by the SD group calls on the EC to address the following priorities: an investment plan to generate more jobs and growth, a fiscal context that favours Member States' investment in the European Fund for Strategic Investments or the inclusion of a social dimension. The EC must also deal with achieving an energy union with a dominant role in renewable energy, tackling a European immigration policy, and preventing tax evasion and tax havens.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. — The Commission's work programme delves into the strategies of deregulation, liberalisation and economic governance that have led to the current social, economic and environmental crisis and the deep emptying of European democracy. Only a change of course could restore the European folk classes to their hope. Instead, the Commission continues to act for the interests of finance and large enterprises: for example, with accelerated opening of the energy and financial markets; opaque trade agreement negotiations with the U.S.; with financial subsidies for the benefit of the privatization of industrial policy and the public initiative scovered by the Juncker plan; with the institutionalisation in the euro area of the 'permanent coup d'etate' involved in the action of the Commission and the ECB in the bailouts that followed the debt crisis. Nor does the Commission self-critical in migration and internal security: on the contrary, it is under serious deterioration of the human rights situation in the Member States. For all this, I voted against it.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. — I can argue that I am satisfied with the Commission's 2015 work programme for a number of reasons. The first is that it is consistent between political priorities and the availability of financial resources. The second, which proposes to reduce the number of legislative proposals, which allows us to focus on the main priorities for European citizens and avoids wasting resources on outdated or inadequate legislative proposals. Finally, I welcome the Commission's focus on employment, growth and investment in its work programme for 2015. Despite the above, I would remind the Commission that, in order for these good objectives to be carried out, it must not neglect the rapid and effective use of existing legislation in areas such as the single market, environmental law, the financial and banking sectors, cohesion policy and recently revised common agricultural and fisheries policies. It must also be especially firm with the fight against tax evasion and evasion.  I therefore vote in favour of this resolution and encourage the Commission not to give up on its full efforts.

name: Petr MACH
text: in writing. — I voted against paragraph 6 of the S&D resolution. However, I cannot call on the EU to act on this, because this is another step towards transferring additional tax powers to the undemocratic and irresponsible EU institutions. The second part of the point calls for further European legislation. The free cannot support the increase in EU legislation.  I voted against the first part of point 9 of the PPE resolution. I was elected to fight against new European legislation, to repeal existing European laws, to support the return of powers back to the Member States and to campaign for withdrawal from the EU. This text concerns the remission of EU proposals, I voted against criticising the remission of these proposals. Only an unelected Commission can initiate a new one, start amending or removing european legislation. None of those voted for can change EU laws. Therefore, the EU is not a legitimate legislator of the rules that the Czech Republic must abide by. I abstained from voting on the second part of paragraph 9 of the resolution. While, on the one hand, I strongly support the reduction and re-taking of EU legislation, I am not against maternity leave, and I could be mistakenly attacked by other political parties if I voted in favour. The Liberals believe that legislation on maternity leave should be decided at Member State level.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. — The European Commission is working in a hurry to establish a European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI). The aim is to mobilise as many private sources of financing as we can to finance riskier investments and investments in medium and small business. In addition to the legal and institutional establishment of EFSI, quality and prepared projects are key to the success of the new Juncker Investment Programme. The European Investment Advisory Centre (HUB) will be established at the European Investment Bank as a single point for receiving issues related to technical assistance for investments. The investment programme aims at economic growth and development of the European Union and job creation, and not only investments but a set of measures related to structural reforms and smart fiscal consolidation are sufficient.  In addition to the proposal for new regulations for the establishment of EFSI, the European Commission also presented new guidelines on the application of the existing rules of the Stability and Growth Pact in order to strengthen the link between structural reforms, investment and fiscal responsibility in boosting economic growth and creating new jobs.  The guidelines have three key objectives: to strengthen the successful implementation of structural reforms, to promote investment, especially in the context of the new EFSI, and to pay more attention to the economic cycle in the Member States.

name: Svetoslav Hristov MALINOV
text: in writing. — I support the programme submitted by President Juncker's team as well as the EPP motion for a resolution, because I believe that the measures proposed by the EC will help to restore Europe from the crisis faster. The new European Commission is tasked with high expectations of European citizens in addressing the significant economic and social problems facing Europe.  I am convinced that good and adequate legislation combined with its effective implementation can help create new jobs, increase growth and competitiveness. In an era of new technologies and communications, europe's digital internal market is key to its economic development.  Last but not least, events along the eastern border of the Union over the past year have demonstrated the need for new measures to ensure the EU's energy security. The creation of a European Energy Union would help to diversify and energy sustainability of a number of European countries, including Bulgaria.  Today in plenary we witnessed a sharp contradiction between the ambitions of the European Commission and the political will of the EP. I hope that the EPP and SID groups will be able to overcome their differences on important European issues and will ensure support for the work of the European Commission in its current mandate.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. — Of all the variants of the resolutions, I voted in favour of the draft resolution of the S&D Group, but this text, with a majority of the Members of the European Parliament, was unfortunately not adopted. It remains the most controversial question of how we will develop the economy after the crisis in the EU, how we will create jobs. The Social Democrats have their own vision, it is a pity that not all colleagues in the EP understand this.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: in writing - I support a massive investment programme that will put an end to the dramatic slump in investment and increase growth potential and employment. Europe urgently needs investment in transport, energy, telecommunications infrastructure, digital, cultural and creative industries, education, science, research and innovation. The Commission needs to ensure that private investment is also made in regions hard hit by the crisis. The Commission needs to prepare changes in tax policy that will lead to an effective fight against tax evasion, tax fraud and aggressive tax planning. We need the Commission to prepare legislative proposals for the creation of an Energy Union. The Commission cannot put its own role on the agenda in order to continue the agenda of the own resources system, which is essential for a better functioning Europe. This task must be given to it by the Council or by the European Parliament. Because nothing like this has come from the Council, it is necessary to approve such a task in our resolution.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. — I voted against all the motions for resolutions put to the vote on the Commission's Work Programme for 2015, because none of the above-mentioned Motions for Resolutions adequately and clearly condemned the Commission's insistence on the implementation of the merchatic austerity and the violent fiscal adjustment which has filled the European South with armies of the unemployed and the poor. At the same time, these Motions for Resolutions did not condemn the Commission's 2015 Work Programme, which does not have sufficient resources to increase employment, continues its policy of socialising bank losses, does not reduce regional disparities and continues to support the illegal policies of the Troika in Greece.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. — I regret that no Resolution on the Commission Work Programme 2015 was carried and therefore Parliament is silent in response to the Commission proposals.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the Commission's work programme for 2015. The EU expects decisive action to address major socio-economic challenges such as combating unemployment and improving competitiveness. Citizens also call on the Union to be more transparent about its initiatives and how it implements them.  The work programme adopted for 2015, which is divided into 23 initiatives, is a good starting point in this direction because it sets out the actions that the European Commission intends to implement over the next 12 months, in total transparency, in order to really change things in terms of employment, growth and investment and bring concrete benefits to citizens.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. — (IT) I believe that this motion for a resolution, the text of which is deliberately essential, contains references which we fully support. I particularly welcome the reference made by the European Commission to the need to reduce the number of proposals submitted, with the aim of making legislative activity as rational as possible, as well as the reference to the need to facilitate the rapid and complete implementation of existing legislation in key areas such as the single market, environmental law, the financial and banking sectors. , the common agricultural policy, the common fisheries policy and cohesion policy.  I also share the Commission's appreciation of the priorities identified by the Commission for 2015, namely employment, growth, and investment.  In the light of what has been said, I have decided to give my assent to this document.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. — (DE) I would have voted against the motions for resolutions by the PPE,EPPE, ALDE, S&D and EFDD, because, by and large, there is no criticism of the way in which we have taken action so far, but rather called for a continuation of the current policy. It called for regulation on issues that do not fall within the EU's remit. There has also been a call for greater centralisation and Turkey's accession. I strongly reject these points!

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of paragraph 23, B8-0035/2015, to register my concerns on poor air quality and health.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. — The right-wing resolution proposed to us welcomes the Commission's work programme, particularly in its fight against "the administrative burden on citizens and businesses". It therefore calls for "reducing the cost of bureaucratic burdens by 25% and setting up independent assessments to measure the administrative burden and costs associated with the new proposals", in order of course to "eliminate bureaucracy at all levels". Finally, it calls for the rapid conclusion of the large transatlantic market and other ongoing trade negotiations in order to further liberalise the European market. I'm voting against it.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. — I welcome the Commission's Work Programme (PtC) for 2015 and believe that a significant reduction in the administrative burden on citizens and businesses can only be achieved by reducing the number of legislative proposals, but emphasising the high priorities.  It is important that the Commission presents its Work Programme for 2015 as soon as possible, demonstrating its willingness to act quickly. I am pleased that it is oriented to jobs, growth and investment, reflecting in 23 concrete proposals the Policy Guidelines presented by the Commission in November 2014. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. — I support the Commission Work Programme (CWP) and its approach of focusing on a few major priorities rather than a larger number of less essential ones. This is a positive signal that this Commission is ready and willing to be effective in achieving the goals it has set for itself and in reacting to the concerns of the EU’s citizens. The Commission’s commitment to reducing red tape at the various levels of citizens’ day-to-day life is essential. This will lead to the EU’s institutions being able to better focus on effectively implementing existing legislation, especially with regard to the Common Agricultural Policy (CAP), Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) and the Cohesion Policy. Furthermore, the commitment to fight tax fraud and tax evasion in this CWP will also lead to better use of the taxpayer’s money and safeguard the EU’s financial interests. I have therefore voted for the EPP resolution on this matter.

name: Angelika MLINAR
text: in writing. — I am really disappointed at the missed opportunity to send a strong message to the Commission. The Commission stated in the work programme for 2015 that the college was asked ‘to do different things and to do things differently’. I welcome the Commission initiative on the Investment Plan that will unlock public and private investments in the real economy of at least EUR 315 billion over the next three years (2015-2017). At the same time the Commission sent us a clear message about the bilateral relationship with the Parliament. We cannot accept the attempt of the Commission to diminish Parliament’s legislative opportunities to shape EU policies through a deregulation agenda. The EU has, now more than ever, big challenges ahead and cooperation and transparency should be the guidelines to follow.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. — The Juncker Commission aims to focus on major initiatives and be less interfering in areas where Member States are most competent. I would like to congratulate the European Commission on this new approach and stress that it is necessary to legislate less frequently and in less circumstances, and therefore to focus on large social and economic areas that really matter deserves greater support at European level. I congratulate the Commission for intending to put forward 23 concrete proposals, directly related to the policy guidelines already presented in November 2014, simplifying 79 existing legislative initiatives and eliminating 80 proposals previously put forward and which do not meet Juncker's priorities or for which there is no agreement in the Council or Parliament. I am voting in favour of this EPP resolution (B8-0001/2015) for focusing in a very concrete way on the European Commission's priorities for 2015, in particular with regard to cutting red tape, adoption of the Investment Plan and progress in the TTIP negotiations, but also for advocating the rapid entry into force of cohesion policy, CAP or CFP funds that are so fundamental to Portugal's economic development and growth.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. — The EPLP have pushed to ensure that fighting zero hour contracts as well as tax evasion and strengthening environmental policy is a priority for the European Parliament.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. — (IT) We take note of the ambitious work programme focusing on growth and employment, but we call for a broader reflection on the future of Europe, with a view to achieving a genuine political union capable of restoring the necessary democratic legitimacy. We naturally welcome the planned investment programme, in the hope that they will also be able to encourage new private investment in those Regions of Europe most seriously affected by the economic crisis. Let us remember, in this regard, the importance of guaranteeing investment-friendly budgetary rules, so as to encourage member states' participation in the future European Fund for Strategic Investments through, for example, the neutralisation, in the context of the Stability and Growth Pact, of paid-in capital and public cofinancing of investment projects. We note the lack of an adequate and appropriate educational and cultural dimension: in this case, we call on the Commission to adopt new measures that take account of the growing inter-relationship between the development of the digital market, investment in vocational and cultural training and in the education of EU citizens. Finally, we call on the Commission to work towards a balanced trade agreement with the US, which will promote growth and employment, while protecting EU health, social and environmental standards.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. — I voted for the Commission's 2015 work programme because in strategic terms the elements set out by the Commission are correct. Focusing the agenda on investment, economic development and job creation is a positive thing that must be supported by European social measures and policies. It is important, however, that the Commission in future complies with the work programme approved by the European Parliament.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. — The work programme contained many positive responses, but was again marked by shortcomings in the area of verifiability of implementation. For me, the focus is on verifiability, traceability and transparency of action – also and especially in the area of the European institutions. That is why I voted against.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: In writing. I supported my group's legislative proposal by my vote, because it focuses on the priorities that the Commission must take into account, such as the development of a social component, strong commitments for the environment, a new fiscal policy and a more ambitious cohesion and solidarity policy. I also supported all the amendments which denounced the withdrawal by the European Commission of crucial texts such as the Maternity Directive, the Circular Economy Package or the Air Quality Directive.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. — I supported the Commission's work programme.  The European Commission's programme seeks to provide and implement solutions to tackle the current difficulties in the EU. It is important to delve into the various areas, including the further development of a coherent EU foreign policy.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. — UKIP voted against paragraph 6 of the S&D resolution on the Commission Work Programme. UKIP opposes any illegal action in the realm of tax. However, we cannot call on the EU to do anything, as this is a step in the direction of further tax powers being handed over to the unaccountable EU institutions. The second part calls for more EU legislation on country-by-country reporting for all cross-border companies. UKIP will not support more EU red tape on businesses.  UKIP voted against split 1 on paragraph 9 of the EPP resolution on the Commission Work Programme. UKIP was elected to oppose new EU legislation, get rid of existing EU laws, return powers to Member States and campaign to leave the EU. As this concerns the withdrawal of EU proposals, we voted to support the withdrawal.  UKIP abstained on split 2 on paragraph 9 of the EPP resolution on the Commission Work Programme concerning the withdrawal of the Maternity Leave Directive. While on the one hand we certainly support the reduction of EU legislation; we are not against maternity leave, which other parties would wrongfully attack us for if we voted in favour.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. — Whereas the Commission's proposal entitled "Commission work programme for 2015 – A new beginning" also builds on the conclusions of the European Council of 26-27 June 2014 and 18 December 2014, whereas EU policy and action, conducted in conjunction with the Member States in accordance with the principle of subsidiarity, can and must have an effective impact in helping citizens to anticipate and react to rapid changes in society , whereas Europe must commit itself to a model of a social market economy that guarantees sustainable growth in order to provide the generation with jobs rather than debts, for these reasons I am voting in favour.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. — We do not expect anything from the Commission chaired by Mr Juncker, whose LuxLeaks case revealed the complete lack of credibility on important issues such as taxation and unfair tax competition between the various EU states. As for the investment plan, its financing remains as vague as ever. It is therefore out of the question to vote in favour of this programme of work and I am speaking out against it.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. — Today's generations face the challenge of restoring the values underpinning the European Union, solidarity and equal opportunities for all. This challenge is all the more difficult if we take into account that the EU has been in its biggest crisis since its emergence, which is most clearly reflected in the percentages of unemployment, primarily unemployment of young people.  The EU must choose how it grows and responds further – by planning for a common future and new enlargements or by focusing on a more limited Union. There is also the euro crisis, which many in Europe believed was over, and unfortunately we are increasingly facing security challenges and crises.  While the proposed programme is not ideal because it largely omits topics such as environmental protection, I strongly support its core benchmark, which is the Investment Plan as one of the promises fulfilled. It remains to be seen what specific investment targets the Commission will propose at the end of the month. However, since the energy sector, transport connectivity and research were mentioned as areas of investment, I think that the possibilities of this Plan are great for Croatia regardless of which of the 77 submitted projects are accepted, which is why I once again express my support to it.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. — I support the proposal for a resolution tabled on behalf of the EPP Group by fellow MEP József Szájer following the Commission's statement on its 2015 Work Programme. When exposing President-elect Juncker, we supported his team and the new Commission's policy guidelines, which focus on jobs, growth, fairness and democratic change.  The work programme for 2015 just confirms that 2015 will be the year of major challenges for the European Union. I believe that the Commission's Work Programme with the announced Investment Plan worth €315 billion will make a significant contribution to growth and employment in the Member States, thereby restoring citizens' trust in the EU. I positively assess the announced establishment of a new European Fund for Strategic Investments, which will support long-term investment projects and an ambitious action plan that would attract Europe to attract investments that will strengthen the European economy and have a positive impact on the standard of citizens. EU citizens rightly expect the institutions to be more open, transparent, accountable, efficient while reducing administrative costs, and a new approach and new solutions to combating economic and social problems, which are actually guaranteed by concrete proposals from the Commission's Work Programme for 2015.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of the Commission's work programme and I agree with the attention given to employment, growth and investment. It is important that we focus on a well-defined number of key priorities, and that non-essential initiatives are also set aside. At a time of scarce resources, it is right that they should not be wasted on actions that are not of primary importance to EU citizens, that red tape should be reduced and that fraud and tax evasion should be combated, and taxpayers' money should be used more effectively. It is also essential that existing legislation is fully implemented in areas such as the single market, environmental law, the financial and banking sectors as well as the common agricultural policy, the common fisheries policy and cohesion policy.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of motion for a resolution B8-0001/2015, presented by the EPP Group on the Commission's Work Programme for 2015, as it considers that such a programme should be positively assessed, and in particular we welcome the fact that it proposes a significant reduction in the administrative burden on citizens and businesses, is geared towards jobs, growth and investment, includes measures to combat fraud and tax evasion and provides for the revision of the Interinstitutional Agreement To better legislate. I regret, however, that it has not been possible to reach an agreement between the various political groups to present a joint resolution in support of the Commission's Work Programme for 2015.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. — UKIP voted against paragraph 6 of the S&D resolution on the Commission Work Programme. UKIP opposes any illegal action in the realm of tax. However we cannot call on the EU to do anything, as this is a step in the direction of further tax powers being handed over to the unaccountable EU institutions. The second part calls for more EU legislation on country-by-country reporting for all cross-border companies. UKIP will not support more EU red tape on businesses. UKIP voted against split 1 on paragraph 9 of the EPP resolution on the Commission Work Programme. UKIP was elected to oppose new EU legislation, get rid of existing EU laws, return powers to Member States and campaign to leave the EU. As this concerns the withdrawal of EU proposals, we voted to support the withdrawal. UKIP abstained on split 2 on paragraph 9 of the EPP resolution on the Commission Work Programme concerning the withdrawal of the Maternity Leave Directive. While on the one hand we certainly support the reduction of EU legislation; we are not against maternity leave, which other parties would wrongfully attack us for if we voted in favour.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. — Finally it could not be and, despite the efforts of the S&D Group, there was no common resolution with the other groups. The EU faces a period of low growth, high unemployment, social exclusion, inequality and a real risk of economic deflation.   The resolution submitted by the S&D Group calls on the Commission to address the following priorities: an investment plan to generate more jobs and growth, a fiscal context that favours Member States' investment in the European Fund for Strategic Investments or the inclusion of a social dimension. The Commission must also deal with achieving an energy union with a dominant role in renewable energy, tackling a European immigration policy and preventing tax evasion and tax havens.

name: Teresa RODRIGUEZ-RUBIO
text: in writing. - We voted against the resolutions tabled by the other groups on the Juncker Commission's work programme because, in our view, none sufficiently reflects the fundamental vice affecting that programme: that it does not respond at all to the fundamental problems affecting the daily lives of the citizens of the Union. This work programme provides no viable and effective solutions to address the macroeconomic problems of debt, corruption, tax evasion and unemployment, nor does it promote a renewable and sustainable energy policy, nor does it raise the deep democratisation that needs to be undertaken to ensure the viability of the European institutions, nor does it transform the main lines of a foreign and trade policy that does not seek the effective promotion of the fundamental values of the Union and rights of its citizens. We voted in favour of our group's resolution because we understand that it reflects a democratic, viable and sustainable political vision to provide solutions to the economic and social emergency that our peoples are suffering from austerity policies, social protection calls and the lack of democracy of the political institutions that govern their destinies.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution, as this Work Programme presents a set of 23 concrete proposals on the political guidelines previously presented by President Juncker for the 2014-2019 Commission mandate. The proposals for 2015, which highlight the Investment Plan, which aims to inject EUR 315 billion between 2015 and 2017 into the European economy, are aimed at such essential issues as jobs, growth and investment, without neglecting sustainable development, environmental preservation and the social economy. I would also like to point out, as proposed in the document, that it is essential to avoid wasting resources with obsolete or inadequate legislative proposals, which are no longer able to respond to the priorities and concerns of European citizens, as well as to use taxpayers' money more efficiently by adopting measures to protect the Union's financial interests. Finally, I stress and endorse the need to fully, rapidly and effectively implement existing legislation on matters such as the single market, environmental law, the financial and banking sectors, as well as the recently revised Common Agricultural Policy, Common Fisheries Policy and Cohesion Policy.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. — I supported the EPP Group's resolution on the Commission's work programme for 2015.  Indeed, the EPP text supports the programme proposed by Jean-Claude Juncker's Commission, which aims to be effective and operational, with the aim of reducing all administrative or bureaucratic burdens and redirecting European actions to the Commission's priorities. This resolution also refers to EU trade policy and recalls in particular the objective of achieving a balanced and comprehensive EU-US transatlantic treaty (TTIP), in line with European social and environmental standards and those concerning consumer protection.  At the same time, the text also discusses the multilateral level of trade negotiations and the importance of implementing the Bali package.

name: Matteo SALVINI
text: in writing. - (IT) I have chosen to vote against Resolution B8-0007/2015 tabled by the Green Group on the Commission's work programme for 2015 as it calls for greater legislative activity for Europe on issues of fundamental importance by removing the competences of the Member States. I have chosen to vote against Resolution B8-0035/2015 tabled by the Group of the Party of European People's Party (S&D) on the Commission's work programme for 2015, as it seeks to remove more and more competences from Member States on key issues such as taxation. I have chosen to vote in favour of Resolution B8-0038/2015 tabled by the EFDD Group on the Commission's work programme for 2015 because on many issues, such as criticism of austerity, the euro and TTIP, it is close to my party's positions.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. — We voted against the resolutions tabled by the other groups on the Juncker Commission's work programme because none sufficiently reflects the fundamental vice affecting that programme: that it does not respond at all to the fundamental problems affecting the daily lives of Union citizens. This work programme provides no viable and effective solutions to address the macroeconomic problems of debt, corruption, tax evasion and unemployment, nor does it promote a renewable and sustainable energy policy, nor does it raise the deep democratisation that needs to be undertaken to ensure the viability of the European institutions, nor does it transform the main lines of a foreign and trade policy that does not seek the effective promotion of the fundamental values of the Union and rights of its citizens. We voted in favour of our group's resolution because we understand that it reflects a democratic, viable and sustainable political vision to provide solutions to the economic and social emergency that our peoples are suffering from austerity policies, social protection calls, and the lack of democracy of the political institutions that govern their destinies.

name: Alfred SANT
text: in writing. — My vote is conditioned by the following reservation: The European Commission work programme 2015 is condensed and to the point. As such, it can only be welcome. The programme also rightly acknowledges the need for urgent action to stimulate new investment. The question remains whether the proposal to set up a new strategic investment fund can make much difference. The fund is being built out of monies that have already been appropriated. They will be jacked up by private commitments, still to materialise, up to a total envelope of EUR 315 billion. In reality no fresh money is involved. Yet the need for a substantial injection of investment funds is most urgent. Contrast this with the USD 788 billion fund voted by the Obama administration in the US covering the years 2009 - 2011 under the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009. Of this amount, USD 224 billion went as grants to the states. Clearly, the strategic fund proposed in the Commission programme is too little, and comes too late. I hope that those of us who believe so will be proved wrong.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. — The Commission's work programme delves into the strategies of deregulation, liberalisation and economic governance that have led to the current social, economic and environmental crisis and the deep emptying of European democracy. Only a change of course could restore the European folk classes to their hope. Instead, the Commission continues to act for the interests of finance and large enterprises: for example, with accelerated opening of the energy and financial markets; opaque trade agreement negotiations with the U.S.; with financial subsidies for the benefit of the privatization of industrial policy and the public initiative scovered by the Juncker plan; with the institutionalisation in the euro area of the 'permanent coup d'etate' involved in the action of the Commission and the ECB in the bailouts that followed the debt crisis. Nor does the Commission self-critical in migration and internal security: on the contrary, it is under serious deterioration of the human rights situation in the Member States. For all this, I voted against it.

name: Czesław Adam SIEKIERSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. — One of the striking features of the Commission's 10-point list of priorities is, in my view, that it does not contain a single reference to agriculture and the CAP, which is surprising given the political and budgetary importance of this policy. Even if the basic legislative pillars of the new CAP are already in place, much remains to be done on implementation at both EU and national level, and the success or failure of the reform will depend to a large extent on its implementation. Another aspect that cannot be sufficiently emphasised is the exposure of the agricultural sector to crises that threatens EU farmers. This is now demonstrated by the damage suffered by the main segments of EU agriculture due to the Russian embargo, which could be followed by a major crisis in the dairy sector over the next few months following the expiry of the quota system. Another major issue that needs full attention in the following months is the agricultural component of the TTIP trade negotiations with the US and the protection of the European agricultural model as well as the EU's agricultural interest in these negotiations. I would therefore like to encourage the Commission to take these issues seriously when preparing the Commission's work programme for 2015 and to present initiatives and proposals that are appropriate to the challenges facing our sector.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. — Today I voted with the majority of the Members in support of the Commission Work Programme 2015. Labour MEPs have called for more action on workers’ rights and tackling tax dodging. Tory and UKIP MEPs voted against the S&D motion calling for the Commission to clamp down on large-scale tax avoidance. The S&D Group strongly supports the measures to fight tax fraud and tax evasion and stress the need for more efficient use of taxpayers’ money and for further steps to protect the Union’s financial interests.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. — I supported the Resolution of the Greens/ESS Group, as as shadow rapporteur for the legislative package on waste management – circular economy, I am extremely unhappy with its exclusion from the 2015 Programme.   The Commission's Programme demonstrates the worrying ignorance of the legislative institution of the European Union. All political groups supported the retention of the Circular Economy Package, which clearly indicates a broad political consensus to maintain it and implement it through the legislative procedure. As directly elected representatives of European citizens and citizens, we are obliged to defend their interests. During the previous Commission, significant public funds were invested in developing a legislative proposal on this Package. The omission of the Package from the Work Programme means the inevitable delay in establishing quality waste management. Better management of scarce resources in the European Union is the best solution to the current economic crisis in which it is located.  I therefore call on the Commission to withdraw its reckless decision to withdraw the Circular Economy Package and continue in its efforts to develop better waste management so far in the interests of all Union citizens.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. — In the January plenary session, MePs voted on the motion for a resolution on the Commission's 2015 work programme tabled by the Green/European Free Alliance Political Group. This proposal was a response to the fact that the work programme of the new Commission largely reflects Europe's pre-crisis priorities, as it maintains the traditional economic policy framework that led to the crisis and does not recognise what the European Union really needs and what its people actually demand. The motion for a resolution highlights, inter alia, the Commission's intention to withdraw the amendment to six parts of waste legislation (the 'circular economy') and encourages it to promote raising ambition as part of the ongoing legislative process and to supplement this process with additional initiatives if necessary. The area of waste is a major problem throughout the EU. In the past term, considerable efforts have been made to regulate this area, which would help to reduce landfilled waste, focus on recycling, incineration and re-use, thus reducing the risks of adverse impacts of waste on humans and the environment. As I believe it is necessary to maintain an amendment to six parts of waste legislation, I supported the motion for a resolution of the Green/European Free Alliance group.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing — I welcome the Commission's determination to bring about change and simplify proposals that are primarily aimed at cutting red tape and making life easier for economic operators. It is important that the economy comes first and includes building digital markets and creating better conditions for individual sectors of the economy, as well as increasing foreign trade. From the outset of its work, the Commission should also focus on improving the environment for job creation. The Commission's first working year is crucial for achieving the objectives expected by all EU citizens.

name: Jutta STEINRUCK
text: Writing. - I welcome the S&D resolution on the Commission's 2015 Work Programme as it addresses the strengthening and sustainability of European social policy. The European Commission is calling for the growing inequality between Member States, labour market discrimination, child poverty and social dumping to be brought into focus. Labour law and protection, social security, fair wages and equal treatment will also serve as the pillars of the Commission's new work programme. To this end, the creation of good, sustainable work is mentioned as the European Union's top priority. It also criticises the omission of all social policies in the Commission's previous draft.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. — I support the proposal for a resolution by my colleague Szájer on behalf of the European People's Party Group on the Commission's work programme for 2015, which certainly welcomes the Commission's decision to present its work programme for 2015 as soon as possible. This demonstrates its readiness to act swiftly and welcomes the fact that jobs, growth and investment are the focus of the Commission's work programmes. I also support a change in the method to prepare for action to avoid spending resources on outdated or inappropriate legislative proposals that can no longer address the priorities and concern of EU citizens, and calls for a 25% reduction in the cost of bureaucratic burdens, which contributes to cutting red tape at all levels and for all economic actors and citizens. I agree that rapid progress on the comprehensive transatlantic trade and investment partnership is essential to achieve new growth opportunities while respecting all EU standards. I firmly support measures to combat tax fraud and tax evasion and emphasise the need for more efficient use of taxpayers' money.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. - I support the Commission's work programme, as the programme contains all important topics such as tackling slow growth, reducing the unemployment rate, raising the competitiveness of European economies, boosting investment and the like, and highlighting the return of citizens' trust. Emphasis is placed on social protection, environmental protection and consumer rights protection. The need to break the policy of discontinuity has been underlined. The Commission will work to reduce bureaucratic barriers to the development of the single market. Exports will be encouraged and EU strength is also important for its neighbourhood. The Commission will encourage all Member States to achieve maximum growth of the economy, highlighting eco-investment, eco-innovation, fisheries, agriculture, finance and other objectives and creating a Digital Single Market without many barriers and constraints. The Commission will decide on the future of GMO food. Energy security has been highlighted as a precondition for stability and development, and small and medium-sized economies have been highlighted as symbols of a healthy economy. Monetary policy and bank regulation will be implemented responsibly and developmentally to ensure security and control, and tax policy will work to narrow the gap and prevent money laundering. The fight against all forms of discrimination and social exclusion, the fight against terrorism and all forms of violence continue resolutely. Defence and the Union's borders will be further strengthened due to increasing immigrant pressures and illegal immigration.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: in writing — the Commission talks about this year's programme as a 'new beginning'. However, although it is possible to see some differences from the previous European Commission, we will probably not see real changes. In fact, the European Commission is still wrong to believe that growth and employment can promote bureaucratic redistribution, not greater economic freedom and the market. That is also why the Juncker Investment Package is to be one of the most key measures of the current Commission.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. — The Commission's programme is more of a wish list than a well-structured development plan of the European Union. It does not promote ways of dealing with the causes of the economic crisis and does not approach the issue of illegal immigration on its proper basis.

name: József SZÁJER
text: in writing. - Since day one the EPP Group has supported the 10 priorities of the Juncker programme as they facilitate effective regulation. The other groups in the European Parliament wanted to water the proposals down by increasing them to more than 200. This would have adversely affected the successful implementation of the programme.
