Based on the framework agreement between the Commission and the Parliament and the Rules of Procedure, the programme has already been adopted and has entered into force. For this reason as well we have opposed the adoption of any resolution since the beginning. There is no legal or political obligation for the EP to adopt a resolution.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. — The Commission's work programme for 2015 set out very important but realistic targets. Of course, shortcomings can be identified in all such work programmes, but I was pleased to note, for example, that the Commission prioritises tax havens, tax fraud and tax avoidance. In the current situation, the European Union cannot allow tax havens to further damage its economy, so the proposal for companies to pay tax where they make their profits is certainly to be welcomed. With measures towards the tax union, we can achieve great results in all Member States. With uniform, predictable and transparent tax laws, we can encourage economic operators to assume their tax burden. The revitalised economic environment attracts "fresh money" to the system and encourages employment. I voted in favour of the S&D group's resolution, which draws attention to other important problems. For example, I trust that the problem of overtrawing will also be given special attention in the revision of tax laws. This is important not only for correcting systemic failures, but also for helping to restore social justice. In addition to economic development, these steps would be a very important result of regaining citizens' trust in the EU institutions. I remain confident in the Commission's openness, that it will continue to accept the proposals of the Socialists and Democrats, and that we can work constructively for the future of Europe.

name: Dario TAMBURRANO
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of the Resolutions of the EFDD and the Greens-EAA as they defend the legislative packages on the circular economy and air quality as strategic objectives of the European Union. I believe that the circular economy must remain an integral part of European policies as the only viable way to ensure that human development and prosperity coexist in the long term with a planet with: A) non-renewable resources with physical limits (metals, minerals, rare earths, arable land); B) ecosystems with endangered balances (biodiversity, climate); C) renewable resources with very long cycles and regeneration times (water, forests, soil fertility, fish stocks) or entire geological eras (oil, gas).  The withdrawal of the circular economy package and the questioning of the air quality package in the new Commission's proposal for a programme are a very bad sign of the reversing of European policies in the fields of environmental and climate protection, human health and ecosystems. Instead of pushing towards social, technological and productive innovation for responsible and scientific management of planetary resources, we want to give priority to a failed, anachronistic and irretrievable economic model based on the priority of the market, profit and growth.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. — The Commission Work Programme (CWP) for 2015 can be used as a powerful tool for tackling the current social, economic and political reality in Europe which is linked, to a large extent, to the years of austerity, rising unemployment – especially among young people – increasing inequality and lowering of social standards. Through the 23 proposals outlined in the Commission’s agenda, the Work Programme aims to deliver an investment plan for Europe, promote economic stability and advance the creation of a single digital market package. While an ambitious programme, I believe the CWP lacks a substantial social dimension that I view as essential for tackling Europe’s current needs. We need stronger proposals on creating more opportunities for young people, combating growing economic inequalities, fighting rising poverty, social dumping and labour market discrimination. Europe needs a new sustainable model where economic, social and environmental progress is equally assured and mutually reinforced. We need a broad reflection on the future of Europe to achieve a fully-fledged Political Union which would regain its democratic legitimacy and citizens’ trust. These elements are reflected in the S&D resolution, which I voted in favour of today.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. "I voted in favour of the socialist resolution and in favour of the Green amendments. To put it another way, I voted in favour of what I thought was progressive, calling on the European Commission to have a real roadmap. In this regard, I would like to point out the shortcomings of the Commission, which at no time sought Parliament's opinion in the preparatory work. At the time of writing these few words, it is always the fog around certain texts of which we do not know if they will be voted in 2015, but also around the motivations that sanctioned other texts. Zero transparency!

name: Isabelle THOMAS
text: In writing. We can certainly be satisfied that certain political priorities have been included in the Commission's work programme for 2015. This is particularly the case with the plan to boost investment in Europe and the fight against tax havens. Unfortunately, other priorities for the cohesion and sustainable development of the Union are missing. In particular, it is worth mentioning the weakness of the social aspect of the Commission's projects, which demonstrates its refusal to take into account the impact of the crisis on Europeans. Each political group proposed its own resolution on this work programme but failed to win the support of the majority of Members of Parliament. I am pleased that some socialist amendments have gathered a majority of MEPs, an encouraging sign for our future struggles. Those where we strongly opposed the Withdrawal by the Commission of ecological or social legislative proposals on air quality or measures on waste, and the maternity leave directive have won the majority.

name: Viktor USPASKICH
text: Writing. — I believe that the Commission's work programme must focus on three things: cutting red tape, promoting subsidiarity and, of course, the investment plan. I also believe that it is important that commissioners be judged on the basis of the results they have achieved, not on the declared objectives.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: in writing. — Despite the efforts of the Socialists, no joint resolution has been presented with the other groups. The EU faces a period of low growth, high unemployment, social exclusion, inequality and a real risk of economic deflation.   The resolution submitted by the S&D Group calls on the Commission to address the following priorities: an investment plan to generate more jobs and growth, a fiscal context that favours Member States' investment in the European Fund for Strategic Investments or the inclusion of a social dimension. The Commission must also deal with achieving an energy union with a dominant role in renewable energy, tackling a European immigration policy and preventing tax evasion and tax havens.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. — The Commission's work programme delves into the strategies of deregulation, liberalisation and economic governance that have led to the current social, economic and environmental crisis and the deep emptying of European democracy. Only a change of course could restore the European folk classes to their hope. Instead, the Commission continues to act for the interests of finance and large enterprises: for example, with accelerated opening of the energy and financial markets; opaque trade agreement negotiations with the U.S.; with financial subsidies for the benefit of the privatization of industrial policy and the public initiative scovered by the Juncker plan; with the institutionalisation in the euro area of the 'permanent coup d'etate' involved in the action of the Commission and the ECB in the bailouts that followed the debt crisis. Nor does the Commission self-critical in migration and internal security: on the contrary, it is under serious deterioration of the human rights situation in the Member States. For all this, I voted against it.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. — The European Commission's work programme represents more of the same. It is in direct continuity with all the wrong policies that are at the root of the current economic and social crisis. It proposes three pillars, an investment plan, fiscal responsibility and structural reforms, using new words but with the same logic as always.  On the investment side we have a mind-boggling exercise in creative accounting that is insufficient and lacking any empirical support base capable of being able to give a minimal light of enthusiasm or optimism. On the other hand, we will continue with austerity and attacks on the welfare state, adding more recession to the crisis. What Europe needs is to promote public investment capable of generating cohesion and development. It needs more tax justice and better income distribution that promotes consumption and investment. It needs, in a view, is another integration process centered on people and not on big capital.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. — I support the Commission's work programme for 2015. I consider the announced proposals, which are intended to create concrete benefits for citizens, to be quite positive. Examples of this are the planned improvement of the labour market situation, economic growth and planned investments.

name: Henna VIRKKUNEN
text: Written. — (FI) Mr President, the Commission's work programme for 2015 focuses heavily on growth, competitiveness and investment – all very important issues, including job creation. Every extra effort has been made to reduce and the objective of better regulation has now also been taken seriously.  I believe that it is a good and right direction for the Commission not to automatically continue the unfinished legislative projects initiated by its predecessor, but has proposed that some 80 pieces of legislation, regulations or directives be withdrawn or re-prepared. I strongly support this line. One of the key aspects of the investment programme is precisely the rationalisation of regulation and the creation of political predictability within the European Union. This is essential if companies are to have the courage to invest in our region. Only then will we get the whole of Europe back on an upward path.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. — The Juncker Commission again fails to support its work programme: Juncker must resign. For the second year in a row, the EP cannot agree on a common position on the Juncker Commission's 2015 Work Programme. The political groups had already postponed the talks in December 2014. On 13 January 2015, negotiations on a joint motion for a resolution failed. No group prevailed in the vote with its own motion for a resolution. This means that the Work Programme of the European Commission does not receive parliament's approval. Mr Juncker has fallen through. The majority, which previously invented the non-contractual principle of the 'top candidates' and elected him to office, is now refusing to support him for his work programme. In doing so, it has in fact expressed its distrust of him. In a democracy, the government resigns when it no longer has support in parliament. If Juncker thought that he needed Parliament's democratic legitimacy for the work of the Commission, he would now have to take his hat off. But, of course, he does not, and so he shows that Parliament is only one thing for him: a large, pretty setting for the theatre he plays. And the vast majority in Parliament is playing along. Christian Democrats, Social Democrats, Liberals, Liberals, Left and Greens are not calling for a genuine, formal motion of censure to remove Juncker from office.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: in writing. — (IT) I do not believe that the European Commission led by Juncker is in a position to raise the tide of this increasingly troubleful Europe. Indeed, your work programme will continue along the path already mapped out by the two previous Barroso-led Commissions, and the changes that are so much trumpeted are, alas, only cosmetic. There is no greater flexibility in economic and fiscal rules, and this week's very poor communication is proof of this: they do not want to understand in Europe that if there is no radical change it will be the Union itself that is at risk. Juncker's team is the result of an agreement between the major European parties, that is, the people, socialists and liberals, which in the last European elections saw their consensus drastically reduced almost everywhere, to the detriment of forces that, in one way or another, want to change this Europe. This Commission, the expression of the governing parties in all the COUNTRIES of the EU, certainly cannot represent a turning point, and this can be clearly understood by his leadership, a politician who for over twenty years has participated and shared all the choices that have brought us to the brink where we are now.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: in writing — Political factions operating in the European Parliament have not been able to reach a common position on the work programme of the new Commission for 2015. All the factions submitted their own resolutions, which were voted on separately, neither of which won the votes of a majority of Members. The ECR welcomes the Commission's commitment to withdraw legislative proposals that have become outdated, redundant or where a political consensus cannot be reached. I personally share Commissioner Timmermans' statement that the fact that the Union considers a problem to be important does not mean that it must automatically adopt new legislation on it. In our resolution, we strongly draw attention to the need to eliminate the bureaucratic burden on small and medium-sized enterprises, in particular by regularly assessing the added value of individual policies so that they meet the needs of our time and its citizens. We are also critical of the Juncker Investment Package and will be watching its implementation closely. It is not clear how the Commission intends to mobilise private investment, nor on what criteria it intends to select and prioritise projects applying for support from this package.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. — The lack of a final resolution adopted by the majority of the EP with its own proposals - alternative or not - demonstrates contradictions in the direction of the eu and profound crisis, but does not erase the maintenance of convergence between right and social democracy in the EU's bottom options. The apparent inaction hides the choice for policies that will continue to exacerbate existing problems, notably the high levels of public debt in the countries on the periphery of the EU, a consequence of the asymmetric nature of the integration process whose measures being imposed on countries such as Portugal - supposed to address it - increase us, while serving as justification for destroying the fundamental rights and achievements of workers and peoples , including salaries, public and universal social security, public health and education. The solution to these problems remains debt renegotiation (with its restructuring and substantial reduction), the creation of a programme for the troika-intervened countries for which the stay in the euro has become unbearable, the start of a process of dissolution of EMU, the extinction of the Stability Pact, with its replacement by a pact of social progress and sustainable development.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: We supported this resolution on the attacks on free speech in Turkey, because it sends a strong signal that Turkey is losing more and more credit in Europe and in the free world. Since Erdogan began running the country in 2002, he has become the biggest oppressor of the free press.  Despite the massive international attention to this problem, journalism remains a life-threatening profession that can result in prison sentences of up to 166 years. Arrests of journalists and the brutality of this show to me that the Turkish rule of law has a huge problem. Democratic states respect freedom of expression in accordance with their constitution and with the European Convention on Human Rights. What's more, Erdogan's only answer is that more journalists will see, I quote, "the inside of a prison cell." We must draw conclusions from the growing authoritarian nature of this regime, not least in the accession negotiations. Because neither Turkey nor Europe, what is happening will improve credibility.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: Mr President, thank you also for the excellent pronunciation of my surname, which is admirable in this House. I would like to say one important thing on this issue. If we want to see Turkey as a democratic country, it must stop restricting and oppressing the press there. Any restrictions on social networks and their blocking, any restrictions on opposition journalists, leads to Turkey not being perceived as a partner. I come from a family that has a long tradition, whose members died in the First and Second World Wars, whose members were in concentration camps under both the Communist and Nazi regimes. And I firmly believe that Turkey has more to do and that Turkey will use its chance to show Europe that it is a truly democratic country and that it belongs in our space.

name: Daniel HANNAN
text: Mr President, for decades Turkey was the great democratic success story in the Muslim world. When the Arab Spring risings happened you heard the same sentiment expressed all across the region, from Morocco to Jordan. People would say: ‘We want to be like Turkey. We want to be a free-market, pluralist, multiparty, secular Muslim democracy.’ That places a particular burden on our Turkish allies to hold themselves to a higher standard. It may well be the case that there is, as Turks say, a parallel state, with supporters of the Gülen movement in parts of the security services. It may well be the case that they have sympathisers in the media. I think even the Gülen people themselves do not deny that they have a network in the security apparatus. Of course, we can see what journalists have said about it. But none of that justifies lowering your standards. On the contrary, it places you under an obligation to behave more cleanly than you otherwise would. Turks deserve better; we expect better.

name: Gerolf ANNEMANS
text: In my vote against this resolution, I wanted to protest, above all, that the majority here still did not want to clearly and explicitly acknowledge that Turkey cannot be a member of the European Union and, on the contrary, even the resolution is all about accession and pre-accession aid. My party says this from its vision of what European cooperation and European unity can be and in this case what it cannot be. We have not waited for the arrival of Erdogan and his Islamist party, which, year after year and again, has been grounded in the illusions that Turkey could be a source from which Islam and democracy could emerge as compatible. Yesterday, in full "Charlie Hebdo" crisis, we here in the centre of Europe received the news that the court in Diyarbakir has blocked all websites that published the offending cartoons. Through all the confusion, one thing must be made clear: Turkey is not a European country and has no European tradition of free speech and no human rights. The situation did not improve under Erdogan, on the contrary, membership of the European Union is not only problematic, but must be rejected on principle.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the motion for a Resolution on freedom of expression in Turkey because it condemns police raids and the detention of journalists and media representatives in December 2014 and points to a general trend in the decline of democracy and the Turkish Government's tolerance for public protests and critical media.

name: Louis ALIOT
text: In writing. "This resolution is once again a matter of great hypocrisy on the part of the European authorities. Indeed, while all the nations represented in the European Parliament denounced the attacks on press freedom and civil liberties, their leaders were all marching alongside the Turkish Prime Minister during demonstrations in support of the victims of the Charlie Hebdo attack in Paris. On the other hand, instead of yet another resolution, it would have been wiser to suspend the whole process of Turkey's accession into the EU The continuation of turkey's integration process into the EU is a very bad signal for our international partners.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. In recent years, freedom of expression has been abused in Turkey and we are seeing the true face of Erdogan appear. The government has resumed arresting people and accusing them of political crimes of all kinds, accusing writers, publishers and journalists of violating anti-terrorism laws, often because of links or sympathies for the Kurdish movement. Erdogan and his AKP party, which has been in power for 12 years, are increasing pressure against journalists. At the end of February 2014, audio recordings even appeared on the internet. It hears a corrupt, dishonest prime minister using his power to silence the press.  The solution is now simple for the European Union, which is facing a social and economic crisis: Turkey's accession negotiations must be stopped immediately, as I asked with six other colleagues in my motion for a resolution last December. That is why I voted against this text, which is only a declaration of good intentions.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe it is essential to continue to fight for consistency in European enlargement policy at last. I cannot accept that a country such as Turkey should join the EU, we certainly cannot continue to finance with our own funds countries that blatantly and with impunity continue to violate human rights: the pre-accession countries must commit themselves to respecting our rules if they want our money.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. On 14 December in Turkey, 27 people, mainly journalists, were arrested. This wave of arrests confirms the repression of the opposition media in Turkey today, while a large number of journalists are still imprisoned. With this resolution, the European Parliament wished to condemn these events and reaffirm its commitment to freedom of expression, at the heart of the values of the European Union and one example of which is the existence of a free, independent and diverse press.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this resolution because recent attacks on the media by the Turkish Government are deeply worrying. It is simply shocking that Turkey currently has one of the highest numbers of jailed journalists in the world. Turkey is an extremely important partner for the EU in many fields – not least for our economy and in the fight against terrorism – but it will only continue to be so if it returns to the path of democracy and respect for civil rights. It is in all our interests that we work together to make this happen. That is why, while we do need to make clear that this situation is in no way acceptable to us, it is also important not to allow parties on the right to use this as a pretext to call for halting accession negotiations. This will benefit neither EU citizens nor the Turkish, as it will only result in taking away the most important sticks and carrots we have for encouraging Istanbul to increase media freedom and improve collaboration with the EU in areas of common interest.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this motion for resolution as I believe it is vital that the European Parliament condemn actions that disregard the freedom of the media. Freedom of speech and freedom of the media are core democratic principles, ones which the EU is founded upon and ones which should be defended at all times. A free press is an essential part of any functioning democracy.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. - We voted in favour, because this Joint Resolution condemns the arrests of journalists in Turkey, as well as the persecution by the Government of Turkey of journalists and the media systematically and which has led to the self-at-censity of some media. It also requires trials with all the guarantees for detainees, as well as expressing concern about the lack of independence of justice in Turkey. The Joint Resolution also requires Turkey to respect fundamental rights and freedoms: the rule of law, international law, freedom of expression. The right to freedom of the press is reiterated, being a mechanism that guarantees plurality, necessary in democratic societies. It also emphasizes the importance of civil society organizations, as only a transparent society can foster trust between the different components of a democratic society.

name: Béla KOVÁCS
text: Writing. - I am touching by the endless concern that the European Parliament is constantly experiencing about the retraction of all media workers and journalists around the world. Most of all, of course, because of those who are working to implement scenarios such as the Arab Spring and Majdan, they are trying to destabilize the country, standing in the wages of global interests. We need real freedom of the press, not hypocrisy, so this resolution cannot be supported in this form. Today, Turkey is a prosperous, dynamically developing country that is not, of course, free from problems, but does not want to get to the fate of Libya and is therefore able to do so.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. — (IT) I am voting in favour of this resolution tabled by My colleague, Mrs McKenna. Sommer because I think it is right that the European Union should strongly condemn all actions that restrict citizens' rights, and the very idea of democracy. In Turkey, many journalists are in prison, or awaiting trial, for expressing critical positions towards their country's government. This shows that Turkey continues to carry out repressive actions against those who, on the basis of the inalienable right to freedom of expression, demonstrate their disagreement.

name: Gabrielius LANDSBERGIS
text: Writing. — Respect for the rule of law and fundamental rights, including freedom of expression, are fundamental values of the EU, which Turkey has formally committed itself to when applying for EU membership and in related negotiations. I support the call for more attention to be paid to independent media through the Instrument for Pre-Accession Assistance and to curb any government interference and pressure, and the arrests, intimidation or any censorship of journalists in 21st century democratic societies cannot be tolerated and justified in any case, especially in the context of the enlargement of the EU and the prospect of Turkish membership.

name: Constance LE GRIP
text: In writing. — We adopted a resolution against violations of freedom of expression in Turkey, following the recent arrests of journalists and media executives. We strongly condemned the systematic pressure on the media and insisted that the country must respect human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: in writing - The European Union is founded on the principles of freedom, democracy and respect for human rights and freedoms, so it must condemn any manifestation of human rights violations. The right to freedom of speech is one of the fundamental human rights that protects not only the laws of every democratic country, but also international treaties and conventions. All EU Member States guarantee these rights to their citizens. The European Union respects the identity not only of its Member States, but also of the other countries of the world. However, it cannot tolerate violations of fundamental human rights. The rule of law must not abuse the law to the detriment of its people.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of the resolution because I support freedom of expression in Turkey and condemn the recent arrests of journalists and the systematic pressure on the media by the Turkish authorities. Turkey must proceed with deep democratic reforms which should ensure full guarantees of freedom, including freedom of thought, expression and the media, democracy, equality, the rule of law and respect for human rights, in order to stop the persecution of press officers in Turkey and to ensure the unhindered free movement of ideas.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. — I voted for this Resolution which condemns the recent police raids and the detention of a number of journalists and media representatives in Turkey on 14 December 2014, and stresses that these actions call into question respect for the rule of law and freedom of the media, which is a core principle of democracy.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. — (IT) I supported the resolution on freedom of expression in Turkey. I am deeply concerned about the thirty-two journalists recently imprisoned in Turkey. Freedom of expression, a long-standing problem in Turkey, must be regarded as a priority of the Turkish Government because it is an essential component of any healthy democracy.

name: Jiří MAŠTÁLKA
text: Writing. - I deeply appreciate the results that Turkey has achieved in recent years in economic development, as well as some of its internal policy measures, such as limiting the military's role as an arbiter of democracy. On the other hand, it is high time to say that the EU-Turkey Association Agreement should be expelled by the European Union if the Turkish Government continues to violate freedom of speech and rejects the right to self-determination of the Kurdish people. I consider the policy towards Syria to be Ankara's most dangerous act at the moment. Turkey's support for various arms-fighting groups against the Syrian government, the creation of logistical facilities for them, the authorization of the transport of weapons and people from abroad for these militant groups, diplomatic and propaganda support for the war in Syria – all steps that have not been intended to destabilize Syria from the outset. Today, everyone has come to understand that this policy has resulted in the creation of fanatical fighting by the so-called Islamic State. It will destabilise the entire region, including Turkey. Ultimately, as the recent terrorist attacks in Paris have shown, it will also destabilise Europe. The European Union should be an organisation or institution in which problems are addressed by democratic instruments. Long-term violations of human rights and acts contrary to international law cannot be tolerated by the state with which we are linked by the Association Agreement. I supported a joint resolution today.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. — (IT) In Turkey, a large number of journalists are in prison, or awaiting trial, simply for expressing critical positions towards the Turkish Government. Although Turkey has declared itself formally prepared to guarantee respect for the rule of law, and fundamental rights, the Turkish Government continues to promote reactionary and repressive action against those who, on the basis of the inalienable right to freedom of expression, are at odds with their positions.  I voted in favour of this resolution because I think it is right that the European Union should strongly condemn all actions that castrate citizens' rights, and democracy.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. — As Turkey is undergoing a growing regression under its current Prime Minister, Mr Erdogan, while at the same time being transferred to Ankara with several billion euros in pre-accession aid, I would have voted in favour of this motion.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. — Recent arrests of journalists in Turkey remind us of the Erdogan regime's policy of repression of freedom of expression and the press. While the European Parliament voted last March on a complacent report on the "democratisation" of Turkey, it is clear today that we are far from the count. The resolution denounces the arrests of journalists and political or trade union activists. These are backed by a biased justice system where anti-terrorist laws are regularly used as a pretext to violate fundamental rights. I regret that the political context in Turkey, and in particular its foreign policy, is absent from this resolution. But as yesterday the Turkish police threatened to ban the broadcast of Cumhuriyet, the opposition daily, which then published some pages of Charlie Hebdo, I vote FOR.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. " The current situation in Turkey is worrying. The arrest of several journalists calls into question freedom of expression and the defence of human rights.  The EU must alert Turkish officials to this situation and help find solutions to stop arrests for the crime of opinion immediately. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. — The recent actions of the Turkish Government towards the independent media in its country are unacceptable. Turkey’s ongoing application for EU membership as well as its membership of the Council of Europe requires it to follow EU values, including those of freedom of expression and freedom of the media. I have therefore voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. In recent years, press freedom in Turkey has come under increasing pressure. Many journalists and media executives, including Ekrem Dumanl, editor-in-chief of the Zaman newspaper, and Hidayet Karaca, managing director of the Samanyolu broadcasting group, have been prosecuted, imprisoned or are still awaiting trial. I deeply regret that politicians are making statements of intimidation and using anti-terrorism laws to prosecute journalists who oppose certain government practices. Beyond the outrageous arrests, this also leads to widespread self-censorship. Turkey must reverse its trend and consolidate its efforts to strengthen democracy within it. Fundamental rights, such as freedom of the press, the presumption of innocence, the right to a fair trial and the rule of law must be effectively guaranteed.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: in writing — Turkey's 2014 Progress Report shows that Turkey is moving away from the principles set out in the European Convention on Human Rights by its actions, particularly in the key area of the judiciary and freedom of expression. The adoption of an action plan on breaches of the European Convention on Human Rights and the reduction of pre-trial detention only formally addresses the unfortunate situation, but the legislation adopted, which should implement the action plan, is of the opposite spirit I find it particularly worrying to consider the weakening of the independence and impartiality of the judiciary, which does not guarantee the right to a fair trial or respect for the rights of defendants. In conjunction with arbitrary raids and the arrest of journalists, the very foundations of the democratic functioning of the state, which is inherent to all developed countries, are thus undermined. I am therefore voting in favour of adopting the European Parliament resolution on freedom of expression in Turkey and calling on Turkey to fully guarantee the rule of law and fundamental human rights, including freedom of thought, expression and the media.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. — I gave my support to the resolution on freedom of expression in Turkey following the debate on the recent arrests of journalists and editors from the Turkish media. The resolution therefore takes a very critical stance regarding these latest attacks on freedom of the media and expression in Turkey. Freedom of the media is a key EU value, which any country willing to join should scrupulously respect.

name: Sorin MOISĂ
text: in writing. — Turkey is a crucial ally of the West in an extremely important part of the world and, in any case, vital to Europe and the United States. The destruction of the democratic and possibly laic Turkish project would be a drama for the West. This resolution is an important signal from the European Parliament to a friendly, allied, close country to remain within a liberal-democratic model. It is to be discussed, in historical perspective, to what extent the disappointments caused to Turkey by the European Union have contributed to this situation. In any case, Turkey must be a modern democracy primarily for itself, for its citizens, and not for some European conditionalities.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. — Recent events in Turkey, including the arrests of journalists and media officials, systematic pressure and harassment of them, restrictions on access to Twitter and Youtube, as well as growing intolerance of political opposition and public demonstrations, have called into question a whole political and judicial system, which has been consolidating.   I believe it is important that these events be explained and clearly framed in the pillars of a rule of law such as Turkey. This setback only reinforces the need for a continuous dialogue with Turkey, the country with which the Union has a strategic partnership.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. — The European Parliament proposes to condemn the recent arrest of journalists and the pressure exerted by the authorities on media disputes. It could also be concerned about the decline in freedom of expression and information in some EU Member States and particularly in France. But above all, this draft resolution is part of the negotiations on Turkey's accession to the Union, threatened by Turkey's refusal to comply with the European 'moral' framework. We must therefore draw the necessary conclusions and put an end to the accession negotiations with that country. That is why I voted against this unnecessary draft resolution.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. — I supported the resolution as I believe that there are worrying developments in Turkey. The resolution calls on the Turkish Government to follow through on its declared intention to reinvigorate the EU accession process with concrete actions, such as putting an immediate end to the harassment of the critical and independent media.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. "I voted in favour of this text, which condemns the arrests and detentions of journalists in Turkey for their views, whether Turkish or European. These recurrent violations of fundamental rights, coupled with regular attempts to block the internet and social networks, are all the more serious because freedom of expression is at the heart of the values of the European Union, to which Turkey intends to join.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. — (IT) With this resolution, we wish to express our deep concern at the large number of journalists recently imprisoned in Turkey and we call on the Turkish judicial authorities to review their detention measures as soon as possible. We believe that freedom of expression should be considered a priority for the Turkish Government, which should be able to guarantee a legal guarantee framework for all media operators in line with international standards. Freedom and pluralism of the press are an essential component of every democracy and form the basis of our European values. Therefore, we consider that they are basic principles of every enlargement process of the European Union and are fundamental to the successful continuation of negotiations on Turkey's accession to the European Union.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. — I voted for this resolution because freedom of the press and expression are important values of the European Union. Turkey is a partner state of the European Union, true to democratic values, and must be encouraged by European states in such a way as to stop possible abuses or undemocratic skids.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. — (DE) I voted in favour of this motion because a large number of journalists are already in detention or awaiting trial in Turkey and the pressure on the media has increased considerably in recent years. The EU has also been heavily criticised by Turkey over freedom of the press. They cannot identify with European values, nor can they befriend media freedom, which is a fundamental principle of democracy.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: In writing. This resolution focuses on the recent arrests of journalists in Turkey and the repression of press freedom. I, of course, voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. — I supported the resolution because I consider freedom of the media to be one of the fundamentals of democracy. In a democratic society, everyone must be able to express themselves freely. The Turkish Government must take steps and carry out reforms to ensure these fundamental freedoms for its citizens.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution. Media freedom is a fundamental principle of human rights. This is a very important principle of EU foreign policy. It is therefore essential that full respect for fundamental rights and freedoms is ensured on a permanent basis and that the importance of freedom of the press and respect for democratic values is emphasised. It should be noted that Turkey's actions, namely the recent arrests of journalists and media executives and systematic pressure on the media, are incompatible with European values and with media freedom. Without freedom of speech and the media, there will be no democratic and open society. It is therefore essential that the Turkish authorities take immediate action to replace the country's existing legal and political environment in order to ensure full respect for fundamental rights and freedoms. In order to achieve a coherent relationship between the parties, Turkey must respond to the concerns expressed by the EU, to implement its international commitments and to give priority to the issue of media freedom.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. — (IT) In view of the fact that thirty-two journalists have been arrested throughout Turkey, highlighting major issues in the country such as the lack of representation of minorities, the authoritarian nature of the government and the absence of a rule of law and good governance, and the absence of fair and fair trials, given that media freedom is a long-standing problem in Turkey and that this is a long-standing problem in Turkey. , combined with due process and the independence of the judiciary, are key elements for any healthy democracy and are enshrined in the Turkish Constitution, given that in 2013 Turkey received a budget of EUR 902.9 million through the Instrument for Pre-Accession Assistance (IPA) to support political and economic reforms, paving the way for rights and obligations related to accession to the European Union For these reasons, I am voting in favour.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. — Violations of freedom of expression in Turkey should not lead to small remonstrances without effect. Recent events have shown how threatened this freedom is and must be vigorously defended. It is time to stop Turkey's negotiations on Turkey's entry into the European Union and give a firm and negative response to Turkey. I therefore speak out against this resolution.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of the resolution on the worrying situation of the national and international media in Turkey. Freedom of expression is a fundamental value of the European Union and, as such, it is non-negotiable.  Free and pluralist information is a fundamental prerequisite for any democracy: there are a large number of journalists in Turkey who are in prison or awaiting trial, and recent news reports show how much pressure has increased in recent years against the media. These are also actions against publishers, executives and restrictions on the web and social media.  With a view to a process of enlarging the Union, the negotiations of which are already difficult, freedom of the press and the right to opposition, protest and criticism are fundamental values to be respected: I firmly believe that the Turkish Government must address this issue and propose a regulatory framework that guarantees media pluralism in line with European standards.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. — I supported the Resolution on Freedom of Expression in Turkey, regarding the recent arrests of journalists, media executives and the systematic pressure on the media. Following the arrests of the newspaper's editor-in-chief Zaman Ekrem Dumanli and the general manager of the Samanyola Broadcasting Group, Hidayet Karacae, the importance of good-minded relations between the European Union and Turkey, and the need to continue implementing reforms, in particular measures issued in September 2013 aimed at preventing abuses of the European Convention on Human Rights, are reiterated. I condemn the recent arrests and detention of journalists and media representatives in Turkey, a country in the process of accession negotiations with the European Union. Due to the recent attacks on the newsroom in Paris "Charlie Hebdo", I particularly emphasize the importance of media diversity and freedom of expression. Independent media should be encouraged and developed that enable citizens and journalists to be active participants in society and to work through freedom of expression and opinion to preserve European values; respect for human rights and the rule of law.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of the resolution because I consider the existence of a free and impartial press in every democratic state to be fundamental and a non-transient principle. I have the impression that at the moment in Turkey there is a stop to democratic reforms and little tolerance of the government towards the critical media and public protests. It is important for Turkish citizens to be able to express their consent, or dissent, in free and peaceful public demonstrations, and for the media to be equally free to express their thoughts directly and exercise the right of criticism. I also find unjustified the measures that restrict the use of the media on the web, social media and web forums. I hope that the necessary measures will be taken by the Turkish Government to have a system that guarantees freedom of thought and expression, freedom of the media, the rule of law and respect for the human rights of all citizens.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: in writing. — I consider myself a friend of Turkey, I have a very positive relationship with this country, all the more concerned about the situation that is the subject of this resolution. The unprecedented police crackdown, culminating in the frantic arrests of a number of journalists and media representatives, is, in my view, incompatible with media freedom and freedom of speech, the fundamental pillars of a democratic society. If the Turkish Government wants to lead its country closer to European democratic values, media freedom should be a priority issue for it and the provision of an adequate legal framework guaranteeing functional pluralism in line with international standards should be a matter of course. Government efforts to ban access to social media, restrictive access to freedom of expression, and pressure on the media and journalists cannot be tolerated. It is essential that Europe supports those states that share its values. Therefore, given that Turkey is an acceding candidate country, the Council should indeed clearly name these matters and ask Turkey for redress.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: in writing. — I consider Turkey to be a key partner of the European Union, especially in the situation in the region neighbouring it. Nevertheless, it is essential for the Union to monitor whether there are cases in Turkey that could constitute a suppression of media freedom. For this reason, I have decided to support the motion for a resolution on the events that took place in the country on 14 December 2014.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. "More than ever we learn the importance of press freedom as well as its power to provoke the wrath of the most determined politicians. In this regard, I welcome this European Parliament's resolution in the face of the attacks on freedom of expression that the press may suffer. This value is a foundation of a democratic society that needs to be reaffirmed.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. — This motion for a resolution of the European Parliament condemns the responses of the Turkish government, headed by President Erdogan, who, with the arrest of several journalists and media representatives, calls into question respect for the rule of law and freedom of the press. The rapporteur warns of signs of partiality of the judiciary and intolerance of political opposition, symptomatic of a regime affected by an imbalance of powers of the organs of sovereignty, which, despite their institutional interdependence, should necessarily observe a functional separation of powers. In this regard, the government's responses to allegations of corruption by some media have raised serious doubts as to the independence and impartiality of the judiciary. The exceptional number of detained journalists and journalists awaiting trial, following detention warrants based on scarce and untransparent information, indicates that a set of provisions of the Turkish legal framework and their interpretation by judges obstruct freedom of expression and the media, calling into question respect for the rule of law and freedom of the press , which is a core principle of democracy, at the heart of EU values. Considering the seriousness of the foregoing, I am voting in favour of this resolution.

name: Evelyn REGNER
text: Writing. — "In democratic states around the world, laws exist to protect journalists. There are laws in Turkey to punish journalists." This is how a Turkish writer, who himself was in custody, describes the freedom of the press in Turkey. Only today it was announced that the Prosecutor was investigating the Turkish newspaper Cumhuriyet for reprinting the pages of the current Charlie Hebdo edition. In recent years, Turkey has become one of the largest prisons for journalists. Even if parliamentary speeches by opposition leaders are quoted in anti-government newspapers, they face prison sentences of up to 17 years! At the same time, the "New Turkey" – as President Erdogan calls his era – is also paving the way for the end of freedom of the press and the media in Turkey! I therefore naturally voted in favour of Parliament's resolution, which strongly criticises the systematic violations of press freedom.

name: Robert ROCHEFORT
text: In writing. "I voted in favour of this resolution which condemns the recent obstacles to freedom of expression in Turkey. The police raids and the imprisonment of several journalists last December are a serious attack on this fundamental freedom to which we are deeply attached, an attachment that we have been living perhaps even more passionately since the attacks in Paris on 7 January. This House is concerned about the stagnation or even the decline of the reforms towards more democracy that have been undertaken by the Turkish Government so far, and recalls that they are essential for the granting of funding for the pre-accession aid instrument. We must stand firm on respect for the fundamental values of the European Union in our bilateral relations with Turkey.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. — Freedom of thought and expression are the very foundation of democracy. The media plays an essential role in ensuring a vigorous democracy, as an independent and plural press helps citizens participate in public affairs.  Therefore, the detention of several journalists last December in Turkey is of particular gravity, since it is not an isolated event, but is part of a process of increasing deterioration of freedom of expression, with attempts by the Government to prohibit access to social media, disproportionate bans on websites and increasing pressures on the media and journalists. As this resolution on which I voted in favour, it is therefore urgent that the judicial authorities in Turkey review and deal with these cases as soon as possible and that detainees are fully aware of the accusations made against them and full access to inculpatory evidence, as well as full guarantees for their defence and the impartiality of justice. And it is urgent that the EU strengthen dialogue and cooperation with Turkey, especially with regard to the rule of law and respect for the fundamental rights of citizens.

name: Teresa RODRIGUEZ-RUBIO
text: in writing. - We voted in favour, because this Joint Resolution condemns the arrests of journalists in Turkey, as well as the persecution by the Government of Turkey of journalists and the media systematically and which has led to the self-at-censity of some media. It also requires trials with all the guarantees for detainees, as well as expressing concern about the lack of independence of justice in Turkey. The Joint Resolution also requires Turkey to respect fundamental rights and freedoms: the rule of law, international law, freedom of expression. The right to freedom of the press is reiterated, being a mechanism that guarantees plurality, necessary in democratic societies. It also emphasizes the importance of civil society organizations, as only a transparent society can foster trust between the different components of a democratic society.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. — In this joint resolution, which I supported, the European Parliament condemns the police raids and the detention of several journalists that took place on 14 December in Turkey. Parliament also calls on the Turkish government to further defend media freedom and reiterates that "a free and plural press is an essential component of any democracy". And calls on the Turkish authorities "full and transparent information on the allegations against the defendants, to grant the defendants the right to unrestricted access to the evidence that accuses them and the rights of the defence, and to ensure proper handling of cases in order to establish the veracity of the charges without delay and beyond a reasonable doubt". As freedom of expression and freedom of the media are the centrepieces of a democratic and open society, I am very concerned about the decline of democratic reforms in Turkey and, in particular, the government's declining tolerance of public demonstrations and critical media. Freedom of the media must be a priority for Ankara, which must put in place the necessary legal structures to guarantee this freedom!

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. — I am against all forms of repression of freedom of expression and, in the present case of this motion for a resolution, we are facing a gross violation of freedom of the press, which is clearly attentive to the basic rights of a democratic rule of law and those which are the values at the heart of the European Union. I would like to like what I did in plenary, that the rule of law and the independence of the judicial system are, alongside the above-mentioned freedom of the press, three of the fundamental pillars on which European democracies are based and very specifically our rights, freedoms and guarantees as citizens. I also look forward to Turkey's candidate State for our Union conducting judicial investigations in an independent, transparent and scrutinising manner. As Turkey is a candidate country for accession, It seems clear to me that these principles are complied with. For these reasons, I support the content of this motion for a resolution, which I voted in favour of.

name: Matteo SALVINI
text: in writing. - (IT) I have chosen to vote in favour of this resolution because it condemns erdogan's government after the arrest of several journalists. Freedom of thought and speech is one of the fundamental pillars of any democracy.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. — I voted in favour, because this Joint Resolution condemns the arrests of journalists in Turkey, as well as the persecution by the Government of Turkey of journalists and the media systematically and which has led to the self-at-censity of some media. It also requires trials with all the guarantees for detainees, as well as expressing concern about the lack of independence of justice in Turkey. The Joint Resolution also requires Turkey to respect fundamental rights and freedoms: the rule of law, international law, freedom of expression. The right to freedom of the press is reiterated, being a mechanism that guarantees plurality, necessary in democratic societies. It also emphasizes the importance of civil society organizations, as only a transparent society can foster trust between the different components of a democratic society.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the motion for a Resolution on freedom of expression in Turkey because it condemns police raids and the detention of journalists and media representatives in December 2014 and points to a general trend in the decline of democracy and the Turkish Government's tolerance for public protests and critical media.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. — I voted alongside my S&D colleagues to support the resolution on freedom of expression in Turkey. The resolution focuses on recent arrests of journalists and media executives and systematic pressure against the media in December 2014. These actions call into question respect for the rule of law and freedom of the media, which is a core principle of democracy. Turkey should work on reforms to guarantee freedom of thought, of expression and of the media, democracy, equality, the rule of law and respect for human rights. At a time when freedom of expression is under threat everywhere, the motion underlines the importance of press freedom and respect for democratic values in terms of the EU enlargement process.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. — The Resolution on Freedom of Expression in Turkey should promote its standards beyond its borders and thus insist on building a tolerant society. The general concern over the failure to implement democratic reforms, especially the Turkish government, which does not tolerate public protests and free media, is a simultaneous call to address the priority issue of press freedom and to achieve a legal framework that will guarantee pluralism in line with international standards.  Recent police raids and arrests of journalists, attacks on media group owners and leading people, as well as online and social media platforms, are hampering Turkey's eu accession process.  The media plays an important role in establishing democracy and promoting human rights. With their engagement in the public sphere, they allow us to access public interest content and point to crucial problems in order to promote social fairness. As indispensable actors of democracy contributing to the public common good, the media should have the right to freedom of expression, and this also leads to a free and secure society.  The candidate country for eu accession must respect human rights and fundamental freedoms as a necessary precondition for advancing the implementation of the pre-accession strategy and the use of the funds.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. — At the end of last year, a significant number of journalists were arrested by Turkish security forces without any final reason. It is an undeniable fact that in recent years the pressure on the media, media outlets and persons employed in this industry has increased significantly in recent years. Turkey is one of the countries where media freedom is very limited. As many as 70 journalists are currently in custody in Turkish prisons. Based on the rule of law and fundamental human rights, freedom of speech is the most basic human right. As a candidate for full membership of the European Union, Turkey is obliged to take this into account. And not only that, it must give the media and its citizens the opportunity to free speech and writing. Unfortunately, the mass incarceration of journalists in December 2014 shows the opposite picture. I see this happening as a new attack on media freedom, the suppression of freedom of speech and the right to a different opinion. For this reason, I support the resolution and agree with the request for the immediate release of imprisoned journalists. If there is any evidence that the accused journalists did indeed break the law, let them prove it. Freedom of the media, speech and diverse debate is one of the basic and fundamental principles of a democratic state, so let Turkey act and act as a sovereign and democratic state.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: writing — Human rights and respect for them are among the EU's core values. As a candidate country, Turkey has long disregarded freedom of expression and freedom of the press and is cracking against critical media. There is a need to promote political dialogue, to revive efforts to reform the rule of law and, in particular, to respect fundamental human rights.

name: Jutta STEINRUCK
text: Writing. - I welcome the report on freedom of expression in Turkey, as it highlights the need for a guarantee of pluralism under state law. Freedom of expression is the cornerstone of our democracy and must not be affected by attempts at censorship, as has happened. It is precisely with regard to the prospect of membership of the European Union that the Turkish Government urgently needs to bring its legislation, which is abused to prohibit freedom of assembly and prosecute critics of the government, into line with European standards.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. — On 14 December 2014, Turkish police arrested journalists and media workers, Ekrem Dumanlıj, editor-in-chief of the newspaper "Zaman" and Hidayet Karac, editor-in-chief of the Samanyolu Group broadcasting. The arrest warrant was issued by a judge in Istanbul and said they were under criminal investigation on suspicion of forming an organisation that was "attempting to remove state power due to pressure, intimidation and threats", and that they did so through lies and falsification of documents and information. I believe that the Turkish Government should encourage media freedom as a matter of priority and ensure that the legal framework guarantees pluralism in line with international standards. I recall the government's efforts to ban access to social media, a restrictive approach to freedom of expression and pressure on media outlets and journalists.  I express concern about discrepancies in democratic reforms, especially the reduction of government tolerance for public protests and critical media. I would like to stress the importance of press freedom and respect for democratic values for the EU enlargement process, and I express my conviction for the need to continue accession negotiations with Turkey. Therefore, I support the resolution.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. - I support the adoption of a resolution on the situation in the Turkish media and the freedom of reporting in the country, as pressures on the media in Turkey have intensified again. Recently, dozens of journalists were brought in there on false charges, all because they did not report in accordance with the wishes of the ruling structures. This behaviour has long characterised the Turkish media space and jeopardised freedom of expression. Turkey, as a candidate for accession to the Union, must respect the freedoms and other values of the Union, so this behaviour of the authorities is completely unacceptable. Turkey has been an example of a secular state, but the ruling structure wants to stifle such values and create an environment of single-mindedness and submission. It should be noted that Turkey is under international investigation for mismanagement and human rights. According to Transparency International (TI), the situation has deteriorated the most in Turkey, with the latest developments only reinforcing the need for more democracy in Turkish politics.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. — Turkey has done and continues to commit crimes against humanity and any rapprochement between the European Union and that country at the moment must be stopped.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of this decision because I consider it important to maintain a critical dialogue with the important candidate partner Turkey. The decision is a serious warning to the Turkish Government that the EU will not accept a further roll-back of European democratic values, including a gross violation of press freedom, which is the most important guarantee of democracy. Such steps jeopardise the success of the accession process and point to the need to pay more attention to the rule of law, civil liberties and legality in the context of accession negotiations. The development of democratic relations in Turkey is also important for the European Union because it is an important point of alignment for many other countries in the region, thereby also affecting the chances of the EU's neighbourhood policy.  In addition, as a Hungarian politician, I am obliged to take into account the absurd and dangerous phenomenon that the head of the Hungarian Government recently named the authoritarian methods of the Turkish leadership as a model to follow, in addition to the practice of other seriously democratic states. I trust that the ep's recent strong resolution will also help the Turkish Government to recognise as soon as possible the serious consequences of the downsizing of democracy and to turn back from this dangerous path.

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: in writing. — Freedom of expression is a vital component of any democracy, as one of the key tools with which to hold government to account. This fundamental right faces increasing pressure in President Erdogan’s Turkey and I am pleased to see the topic on this week’s agenda. The number of journalists imprisoned in Turkey has long been of concern, but the past year has seen an increasing number of high-profile arrests as part of a clear assault on freedom of the press. Erdogan’s ill-fated attempt to block access to Twitter during last year’s Presidential election fits only too well into this narrative, and we should welcome the Constitutional Court’s ruling against that ban. Indeed, amidst the myriad of reports questioning the Turkish judiciary’s independence, particularly in light of the corruption scandal last year, I am only too pleased take advantage of this opportunity to offer praise to the judiciary. The assault on press freedom and expression are illustrative of the wider changes that we are witnessing in Turkey as it moves away from the shared values it was hoped it would have with the EU

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. — Violations of press freedom in Turkey are as numerous as they are unacceptable. Intimidation, arrests, violence, bullying: the Turkish government has far exceeded the limits and is outlawing itself under international law! However, I abstained on this vote in view of the fact that the original version, to which I fully adhered, were added paragraphs 7 and 8 which, for me, make the text heterogeneous. A resolution focusing mainly on violations of freedom of expression would have been more effective, without taking advantage of this text to convey other messages as the EPP wanted.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. — I have voted in favour of the draft resolution on ‘Freedom of expression in Turkey: Recent arrests of journalists, media executives and systematic pressure against media’. Turkey is a strategic partner of the EU and a candidate country for accession. The recent arrests and pressure on the media are therefore drawing major attention, and rightly so, and deserve a clear political message that such behaviour is unacceptable in any democratic country. We cannot make any exceptions when fundamental freedoms are in danger, in the EU or outside. Any progress in the accession negotiations is subject to deeper reforms in Turkey and respect for fundamental rights.

name: Josep-Maria TERRICABRAS
text: in writing. — Freedoms of expression and the press, especially in the wake of the brutal terrorist attack on Charlie Hebdo, must be defended as the basic pillar of any democratic state. Arresting journalists simply because they don't share President Erdogan's ideas is unacceptable and a clear conculcation of press freedom. Turkey, as a member of the Council of Europe, needs to make significant reforms and improvements in the areas of justice, the rule of law and human rights, which are certainly necessary to advance the process of accession to the European Union.

name: Viktor USPASKICH
text: Writing. — I voted in favour because I believe that the high sentences and frequent arrests of journalists are seriously damaging to Turkey's status as a partner in the European Union.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the motion for a Resolution on freedom of expression in Turkey because it condemns police raids and the detention of journalists and media representatives in December 2014 and points to a general trend in the decline of democracy and the Turkish Government's tolerance for public protests and critical media.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: In writing. — Ahmet Davotoglu, Turkish Prime Minister, dared to take part in the republican march on Sunday (January 11th) in Paris, following the attacks in France on Charlie Hebdo. A strange symbol when you consider that Turkey holds the world record for the number of journalists in prison.  The least that can be said is that freedom is variable for Mr. Erdogan and his government. Arbitrary and mass arrests of journalists continue, as was the case on 14 December, when Ekrem Dumanl, editor-in-chief of the Zaman newspaper, and Hidayet Karaca, managing director of the Samanyolu Group, were arrested. Pressure and restrictions on the press and media are growing. As recently as 14 January, the Turkish authorities ordered the blocking in Turkey of all web pages that reproduce the "One" of Charlie Hebdo, a newspaper to which Mr Davotoglu had supposedly paid tribute on 11 January. Within the GUE/NGL, we constantly denounce the attitude of the Turkish authorities and we continue to recall that a free and pluralistic press is an essential component of any democracy. That is what this resolution did, so I voted for it.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. — When the crisis tightens, it is the democratic freedoms that suffer in the first place. The situation in Turkey is complex. However, systematic attacks on freedom of the press can only be condemned, as well as other attacks on all those seeking to fight for social rights and other economic policies and for a fairer distribution of wealth. For these it also follows our solidarity. What we do not accept is the interference of the EU and the Western powers in the internal affairs of the countries. The EU lacks the moral and political legitimacy to lecture anyone. We condemn the repression in Turkey. But we also have the conviction that it is up to the Turkish people to decide their future and find their own ways of liberation.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. — Freedom of the press is virtually non-existent in Turkey. Many journalists are looking forward to their negotiations in the country's prisons, and the pressure on all those who point to this grievance is growing. However, a fundamental pillar of a functioning democracy is a lived freedom of the media. However, since Turkey cannot accept this principle and I have also voted in favour of this motion, also in the context of past events in that country.

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: in writing. — I have voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on freedom of expression in Turkey, concerning recent arrests of journalists and media executives and systematic pressure against the media. Oppression against journalists practicing critical journalism in Turkey is a disturbing sign of a practical withholding of the constitutional guarantees of freedom of the media and of a major threat to freedom of expression. These imprisonments and trials can only be viewed as violations of basic human rights and fundamental values, which are recognised as pillars of our European Community. I firmly believe that such actions cannot be overlooked and should be condemned. The Turkish Government’s commitment to silencing the public debate over major internal problems or politically sensitive issues is a clear sign of the crisis in Turkey’s democracy and growing radical tendencies. Even though Turkish integration with European Union is at risk now, more than ever before, the European Union cannot remain indifferent and must call for application of the rule of law and fundamental rights.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. — I welcome the adoption of this motion for a resolution. The deterioration of the situation of freedom of expression must not be without our response. We must defend the foundations of democracy, as well as human rights worldwide, and condemn any incitement.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. — Recep Tayyip Erdogan and his AKP party have ruled Turkey with an iron fist since 2003. Since then, he has repeatedly curtailed the prerogatives of the army and all the other bastions of Kemalism. In the name of democracy, the European Union has consistently supported its policy, even though Mr Erdogan's clearly stated objective is the establishment of an Islamic regime. The restoration of a neo-Ottoman caliphate has also been a constant in Turkish politics since 2003 and is manifested in particular by Turkey's support for terrorist armed groups operating in Syria. The Ankara government's recent attacks on the press are just one episode in the politics of the party that has been in power for the past decade. I voted against this resolution, which is only a declaration of intent to raise awareness, because I am waiting for the European Union to immediately halt Turkey's accession negotiations to the Union and strongly call on Turkey to cease its support for terrorist armed groups in the region.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. — Sadly, the EFDD amendment to this resolution was rejected.  The motion therefore encourages Turkish EU membership.  Whilst much of the rest of the sentiment of this motion is laudable, I could not vote in favour of a motion containing such text.   I therefore abstained on the resolution.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. "I voted in favour of this resolution because it is a good move. This text clearly condemns the restrictions on press freedom and the pressure on publishing houses and does not take a position on the accession process.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. — Freedom of thought and expression are the very foundation of democracy. The media plays an essential role in ensuring a vigorous democracy, as an independent and plural press helps citizens participate in public affairs.  Therefore, the detention of several journalists last December in Turkey is of particular gravity, since it is not an isolated event, but is part of a process of increasing deterioration of freedom of expression, with attempts by the Government to prohibit access to social media, disproportionate bans on websites and increasing pressures on the media and journalists. As this resolution on which I voted in favour, it is therefore urgent that the judicial authorities in Turkey review and deal with these cases as soon as possible and that detainees are fully aware of the accusations made against them and full access to inculpatory evidence, as well as full guarantees for their defence and the impartiality of justice. And it is urgent that the EU strengthen dialogue and cooperation with Turkey, especially with regard to the rule of law and respect for the fundamental rights of citizens.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution because the issue of media freedom in Turkey should be given priority and an appropriate legal framework should be established to ensure pluralism in accordance with international standards. Efforts to ban the use of social media, its restrictive approach to freedom of expression and the pressure on the media and journalists cannot be supported. The European Parliament condemns the recent police raids and the detention of many journalists and the media in Turkey, as a free and pluralistic press, proper judicial process and the independence of the judiciary are essential elements of any democracy. Parliament also stresses that judicial cases against journalists and writers and many forms of dismissal, intimidation, harassment and other forms of pressure on critical media and journalists must be abolished. Such actions restrict the ability of journalists to perform their professional duties, as well as to inform the public about important issues and issues and to exercise their freedom of expression.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. — The European Parliament proposes to condemn the recent arrest of journalists and the pressure exerted by the authorities on media disputes. It could also be concerned about the decline in freedom of expression and information in some EU Member States and particularly in France. But above all, this draft resolution is part of the negotiations on Turkey's accession to the Union, threatened by Turkey's refusal to comply with the European 'moral' framework. We must therefore draw the necessary conclusions and put an end to the accession negotiations with that country. That is why I voted against this unnecessary draft resolution.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. — I note with amazement that freedom of expression is being blatantly violated in Turkey. Although some progress has been made, the 2014 interim report reveals that there is continued pressure on the media, legal cases against journalists have multiplied, the media has fallen under the influence of interest groups, and censorship by the owners of media groups has increased. The tragic events that took place last week in France have clearly confirmed that freedom of expression is an essential value of a democratic state, and it cannot be restricted. The mass protest that followed on the streets of Paris reconfirmed the solidarity of European citizens and their allies that there is a general consensus for the sanctity of this right. I have expressed myself in favour of this resolution because I believe that the violation of an essential right, such as that of free expression, leads to the end of democracy. Turkish officials must understand that the revision of criminal law restricting the exercise of fundamental rights such as freedom of the press and equality must be an absolute priority.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. — (IT) Positive vote: totally opposed to pre-accession funds, especially for Turkey, but since they have already been allocated, at least we support the idea that there should be respect for human rights for the beneficiaries.

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
