text: in writing. — I stress the importance of freedom of the press and respect for democratic values for the EU enlargement process, as a number of provisions in the turkish legal framework and their interpretation by some representatives of the judiciary further limit freedom of expression, including freedom of the media, thus creating the framework in which the latest wave of arrests took place in Turkey , on 14 December 2014, when a number of journalists and media executives were arrested by Turkish police. I support freedom of expression and freedom of the press as essential values for the functioning of a democratic society, to this end I consider it necessary to respect procedural guarantees, the presumption of innocence and the independence of the judiciary. I support the calls on the Government of Turkey to put an end to the pressure and intimidation of journalists and media outlets.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. "The situation in Turkey is intolerable. We cannot accept that journalists and media executives should be arrested for doing their job. Freedom of expression is a fundamental European value. We have seen this with the recent attacks on Charlie Hebdo in Paris. The whole world has united to send a strong signal for freedom of expression. This mobilization must not be left marginal. The fight for freedom of expression and freedom of the press must be a daily struggle. With this resolution, the European Parliament is sending a message to Turkey. We do not tolerate a partner of the European Union being the instigator of such practices within his country. I voted in favour of this resolution which proves that Turkey cannot join the European Union.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. — (IT) Today I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on freedom of expression in Turkey following the recent arrest of journalists and media executives.  I believe that freedom of the press is a cornerstone of any democracy and I believe that the preventive detention measures to which a large number of Turkish journalists are subjected cannot but give cause for concern.  I am in favour of continuing accession negotiations between the Eu ropean Union and Turkey and I believe that freedom of the press plays a key role in the PROCESS of EU enlargement. I therefore hope that, following the resolution adopted by this Parliament, the Turkish authorities will review their position with regard to journalists and the media, which have been subject to restrictive measures.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. — Freedom of expression and freedom of the press are cornerstones of the European Union and can be taken as a prerequisite for participation in EU structures. Turkey has a very large number of jailed journalists, and pressure on the media has increased over the past few years. Political intimidation of critical journalists has led to widespread self-censorship by media owners and journalists. These actions show that there is a need for more action, and hence I have voted in favour.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. — (IT) The High Representative must take a firm and clear stand against Erdogan's Turkey, where every whisper uttered in opposition to the government is brutally suppressed. We cannot continue to have a weak dialogue with a key strategic partner which also aspires to become a member of the Union.

name: Aymeric CHAUPRADE
text: In writing. "I voted against this resolution, which once again enshrines the principle of interfering in the European Union's relations with the rest of the world.  I would like to reiterate my commitment to freedom in all its forms, and in particular to freedom of expression, which has been particularly threatened in recent weeks, as we have seen with the terrorist attacks in France. I denounce, however, the specious manoeuvre carried out by the European parliamentarians. The text relies on human rights to push Turkey to reform itself, but this, with a goal that can be read in the resolution: to make Turkey presentable in view of its future accession to the European Union. Because I am European, inheriting Greek thought, Roman law and Christian spirituality, but also because Europe has clear geographical, cultural and political boundaries, I voted against this text.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: in writing. — For more than ten years Turkey has been falling behind the ranking on freedom of the press and expression drawn up annually by "Reporters sans Frontière": emblematic in this regard the attacks on social media such as Facebook and Twitter, the lifeblood of movements that for years have opposed any limiting trend of freedom of expression. The violence and then the arrests of last December once again affect freedom of assembly, expression, the press and political and media pluralism, targeting journalists, communication professionals and members of the opposition. These are unacceptable violations of those fundamental rights on which, as has often been said, the European Union is founded: rights that we have a duty to protect and promote.  In order to do this, this Parliament and the other European institutions must not only recognise the progress of a country that has long aspired to join the Union, but above all highlight its critical issues and serious problems, exerting all its influence to ensure that these problems are resolved quickly and fully. The resolution moves in this direction and, for this reason, I voted in favour.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. — (IT) Turkey is a country with which we have a relationship based on a very delicate balance: I do not agree with the latest moves concerning freedom of the press, especially in the light of what happened in Paris, and that is why I voted in favour of the resolution.  However, I would like to stress that we have no authority to criticise behaviour in other sovereign states, especially if we have not managed in decades of diplomatic rapprochement to convey our values. Of course, these facts must be highlighted in turkey's application dossier for the EU, but that dossier will probably remain closed for a long time to come.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. — I feel that at this point in time, the intention of the Turkish authorities is no longer clear - do they still want to join the EU or not? Do they still want to build a democratic, free society? Those in the Turkish society that support EU accession, and particularly businessmen, are extremely worried about the independence of the judiciary and the freedom of the press. More than anything, this should raise the alarm about the recent events to all those who support the European future of this country. I call once again on the European Commission to establish clear benchmarks for the opening of negotiations on Chapters 23 and 24 on Justice and Fundamental Rights, because in doing so the European Union could contribute constructively to the debate on these issues in Turkey. We need the cooperation of the Turkish authorities for this to be successful.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. — Recent events have called into question freedom of thought, expression and the press in Turkey (candidate country for EU membership), values that are essential to the European Union and whose violation is incompatible with any enlargement process. I condone the recent police raids and the arrest of several journalists and media last December and the setback in the democratic reforms that had been achieved in Turkey and which are called into question with this new political approach.  A democratic society requires pluralwithout obliterating basic human rights such as freedom of thought and expression. As Paul Valéry wrote, it is proper to violent censorship to make credible the opinions they attack.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. — (IT) I voted in favour of the resolution on freedom of expression in Turkey for the recent raids by the Turkish police and the detention of journalists including Ekrem Dumanli and Hidayet Karaca. Human rights defenders, journalists and media representatives who continue to be harassed and pressured by the Turkish authorities and who are forced to serve long unjust sentences. As this is incompatible with freedom of the press and freedom of expression, the fundamental principles of democracy, I express my deep concern at the lack of controls and respect for fundamental rights that the Turkish judicial authorities should respect and protect in order to guarantee a state of democracy, equality and the rule of law.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. — I am concerned over the recent arrests of journalists in Turkey and condemn all actions against media freedom. These arrests are incompatible with the freedom of the media, which is a core principle of democracy. Freedom of expression is at the heart of European values, but in the field of human rights and freedom of expression in Turkey, there are many barriers which needed to be overcome. The new legislative reforms in Turkey should provide for necessary and adequate checks and balances guaranteeing democracy, rule of law, freedom of expression and human rights. I agree that the EU needs to stress the revision of all relevant law and the Criminal Code of Turkey as well. I voted in favour.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. — In December 2014, thirty-two journalists were arrested in retas throughout Turkey, including prominent journalists, media executives and screenwriters, accused of forming or leading an armed terrorist organisation, or belonging to it. Media freedom is a long-standing problem in Turkey, which has already led to waves of arrests of journalists in 2011, a ban on Twitter and the arrest of social media users. Media freedom, due process and the independence of the judiciary are key elements for any healthy democracy and are enshrined in the Turkish Constitution, in particular Article 26, which guarantees freedom of expression, and Articles 27 and 28, which protect 'freedom of expression' and 'free disclosure of thought'. I am voting in favour of this resolution in order to call for the immediate release of all journalists, social media activists and media workers currently detained. I am voting in favour of calling for the principle of the presumption of innocence to be applied. Through my vote in favour, I intend to contribute to independent and transparent investigations, and I insist that all detainees must be able to make free use of lawyers of their choice.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the motion for a Resolution on freedom of expression in Turkey because it condemns police raids and the detention of journalists and media representatives in December 2014 and points to a general trend in the decline of democracy and the Turkish Government's tolerance for public protests and critical media.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. — This resolution expresses concern over the backsliding in democratic reforms in Turkey, in particular the government’s diminishing tolerance of public protests and critical media. It recalls that the freedom of speech and media pluralism are at the heart of European values and that an independent press is crucial to a democratic society, as it enables citizens to take an active part in the collective decision-making processes on an informed basis and therefore strengthens democracy. Hence I voted in favour of this report.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. — In these hours of mourning and recollection following the violent attack on Charlie Hebdo, resulting in the deaths of journalists, cartoonists and editorial staff, we must remember that any restriction on freedom of expression, any arrest of journalists, media officials and any pressure on the press is intolerable. The European Union, through its values and history, guarantees and protects the freedom and independence of the press. For these reasons, I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: in writing. — (IT) I have adopted this motion for a resolution condemning the raids of the Turkish police against the media and the arrests of journalists on 14 December in Turkey. A free and pluralist press is an essential component of every democracy and principle of every rule of law. With this resolution, we call on the Turkish authorities to provide extensive and transparent information on the charges against the arrested defendants and to ensure that they have full access to the evidence against them and their full right to a defence.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: In writing. In December, Turkish police arrested Ekrem Dumanli, the editor-in-chief of one of the country's leading daily newspapers, Zaman, the president of the Samanyolu television channel, and 23 others in 13 cities across the country. And arrest warrants were issued for 32 people, accused among other things of "forming a gang to await the sovereignty of the state". These arrests are contrary to the values of the European Union and must be firmly condemned. The Turkish government must urgently take the necessary measures to ensure a free, plural press, a prerequisite for the exercise of democracy.  Such restrictions on fundamental rights and violations of the rule of law must lead the Union to react strongly, in particular by conditioning its aid to Istanbul on respect for democratic principles.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. — Recep Tayyip Erdogan and his AKP party have ruled Turkey with an iron fist since 2003. Since then, he has repeatedly curtailed the prerogatives of the army and all the other bastions of Kemalism. In the name of democracy, the European Union has consistently supported its policy, even though Mr Erdogan's clearly stated objective is the establishment of an Islamic regime. The restoration of a neo-Ottoman caliphate has also been a constant in Turkish politics since 2003 and is manifested in particular by Turkey's support for terrorist armed groups operating in Syria. The Ankara government's recent attacks on the press are just one episode in the politics of the party that has been in power for the past decade. I voted against this resolution, which is only a declaration of intent to raise awareness, because I am waiting for the European Union to immediately halt Turkey's accession negotiations to the Union and strongly call on Turkey to cease its support for terrorist armed groups in the region.

name: Pablo ECHENIQUE
text: in writing. — We voted in favour, because this Joint Resolution condemns the arrests of journalists in Turkey, as well as the persecution by the Government of Turkey of journalists and the media systematically and which has led to the self-at-censity of some media. It also requires trials with all the guarantees for detainees, as well as expressing concern about the lack of independence of justice in Turkey. The Joint Resolution also requires Turkey to respect fundamental rights and freedoms: the rule of law, international law, freedom of expression. The right to freedom of the press is reiterated, being a mechanism that guarantees plurality, necessary in democratic societies. It also emphasizes the importance of civil society organizations, as only a transparent society can foster trust between the different components of a democratic society.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. — We agree with the joint motion for a resolution. It is generally unacceptable for Turkey to receive EU funding, since it illegally holds almost half the territory of a Member State, Cyprus. We believe that Turkey proves every day that its position is outside and as far away from Europe as possible.

name: Rosa ESTARÀS FERRAGUT
text: in writing. — The European Union builds on democracy and respect for human rights and the rule of law. They are three basic pillars that make up the coexistence of any democratic society. That is why, in the potential contexts of violation of these principles, Europe must give a collective response and condemn any kind of act, threat or pressure that makes them at risk, whether at European level or in third countries. We have recently seen attacks on press freedom or human rights in countries close to Europe, and it has been found that, in the face of these events, members of different political groups expressed concern and expressed their condemnation. This response must continue to be maintained and, in this regard, by tools such as Article 135 of the Rules of Procedure of the European Parliament, debate, analysis and, where appropriate, the rejection and conviction of future cases of violation of these democratic principles should continue to be promoted.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: in writing. — (IT) I wish to support this motion in order to state forcefully that the violation of fundamental rights of freedom of expression runs counter to the very idea of a modern society and to the founding principles of the European Union. I would also like to point out that Turkey has received more than EUR 900 million from the pre-accession assistance instrument to encourage the creation of reforms that will lead it to be a civilised country guaranteeing political pluralism, freedom of the press and respect for the separation of powers, and it is therefore impossible not to notice that acts such as those in question constitute very serious obstacles to the process of democratization.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. — The Turkish police have been detaining journalists and local media officials, reinforcing the vast number of detained journalists and journalists awaiting trial and exerting strong pressure on the media with intimidating statements made by politicians and prosecutions of journalists who are critically speaking. A free and pluralist press is an essential element of any democracy, as with the fair process, the presumption of innocence and the independence of the judiciary, and therefore I believe that the Turkish authorities should be more careful in how they deal with the media and journalists, as freedoms of expression and the media remain essential for the functioning of a democratic society and Open.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: writing — In recent days, arrests have been made in Turkey of journalists and editors of turkish media, pointing to the increasing tendency of authoritarianism and intolerance of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan and his ruling AKP party. These attacks on freedom of expression and media freedom clearly indicate the Turkish government's interest in implementing democratic reforms. Media freedom is one of the fundamental values of the European Union, which Turkey, as a country that seeks to integrate into European structures, should respect. It is precisely such undemocratic actions on the part of the Turkish Government that may be responsible for stopping the association negotiations, which would be counterproductive for all parties involved and common interests, such as the fight against IS.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. — (IT) I support the joint resolution condemning the Government of Erdogan following the arrest of several journalists. We must remember, however, that the entry of this same Turkey, which arrests journalists, is supported by a large number of members present.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. — It is unacceptable for Turkey to receive EU funding, since it illegally holds almost half the territory of a Member State, Cyprus. Practices such as the recent arrests of journalists, media executives and systematic pressure on the media do not make it worthy of EU membership. So my vote is in favour of the joint motion for a resolution.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the Resolution having considered the previous Resolutions on Turkey as well as the latest developments, for example, the arrest in December 2014 of journalists and media executives on the premise that they were under criminal investigation for the formation of an organization in which "by pressure, intimidation and threats they tried to sees the power of the State". Turkey already has a large number of journalists critical of the government imprisoned pending trial, so there are doubts about the independence and impartiality of the judiciary. Respect for the rule of law and fundamental rights, including freedom of expression, is at the heart of EU values, which Turkey has formally committed itself to respect through its candidacy for EU accession negotiations. These arrests therefore call into question respect for the rule of law and freedom of the media, which is a basic principle of democracy.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: in writing. — (IT) I signed the motion for a resolution on freedom of expression in Turkey following the recent arrests of journalists and media executives on charges of terrorist activities. These arrests raise serious doubts about the independence and impartiality of the Turkish judicial system and push media owners to self-censorship. A State which is part of the Council of Europe and is in the process of negotiating accession to the EU, such as Turkey, cannot make arrests that are incompatible with fundamental values for every democracy: freedom of thought and expression

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. — We voted in favour, because this Joint Resolution condemns the arrests of journalists in Turkey, as well as the persecution by the Government of Turkey of journalists and the media systematically and which has led to the self-at-censity of some media. It also requires trials with all the guarantees for detainees, as well as expressing concern about the lack of independence of justice in Turkey. The Joint Resolution also requires Turkey to respect fundamental rights and freedoms: the rule of law, international law, freedom of expression. The right to freedom of the press is reiterated, being a mechanism that guarantees plurality, necessary in democratic societies. It also emphasizes the importance of civil society organizations, as only a transparent society can foster trust between the different components of a democratic society.

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: In writing. — On Thursday, 15 January, I voted in favour of a resolution on freedom of expression in Turkey following the arrest of 24 journalists by Turkish police last December. In this resolution, the European Parliament calls for an end to pressure and intimidation against Turkish media and journalists. For some time now, I have been observing a decline in democratic reforms in Turkey that is not acceptable! Last Wednesday, I was extremely shocked by the attack that claimed the lives of many people at the Charlie Hebdo newspaper in Paris. Today, more than ever, we must defend our democratic values and remember that they are by no means negotiable!

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the resolution on freedom of expression in Turkey. Freedom of speech is a supreme value of the European Union and it is our duty to protect and spread it all over the world.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. — I voted for a resolution on freedom of expression in Turkey because I consider freedom of expression and pluralism of the media to be among the key values of the European Union. Developments in Turkey call into question respect for human rights because media freedom and expression are the cornerstone of the democratic organisation of a single state. Also, in a time of digital age to which the whole world is turning, I believe that a ban on access to certain websites and social media, which do nothing to threaten human rights, is intolerable. This joint resolution reflects the views of all political group members and that is why I support it.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this common resolution on press and media freedom in Turkey, following the recent arrests of journalists. I strongly condemn any restriction of press freedom which is too often curtailed. The recent Paris attacks must represent a watershed moment in the struggle to protect this freedom globally.  We cannot turn a blind eye to the deterioration in the rule of law and fundamental rights in Turkey. A free and pluralistic press is an essential component of democracy, as are due process, the presumption of innocence and judicial independence. These rights urgently need to be treated as a matter of priority in Turkey.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. "I voted in favour of the resolution on freedom of expression in Turkey. Last December, Turkish police made multiple arrests against journalists and opponents. The resolution condemns this logic of lamentable pressure against the press and opponents and recalls that respect for the plurality of the media, freedom of the press and expression is a prerequisite for any entry into the Union. Turkey's actions clearly demonstrate that the continuation of any accession negotiations is therefore unnecessary at this stage. The resolution has been widely adopted, which I welcome.

name: Josu JUARISTI ABAUNZ
text: in writing. — EH Bildu voted against the European Parliament's Joint Resolution 'on freedom of expression in Turkey: recent arrests of journalists and media executives and systematic pressure against the media' not because the motion does not, as a whole, express positions that we do not share, but because it is inadmissible that when talking about the violation of fundamental rights exercised by the Turkish State, no mention should be made , also in the field of freedom of expression, to the serious oppression of the Kurdish people.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. —I wanted to vote in favour of this resolution, which condemns the recent police raids and the detention of several journalists in Turkey. These attacks on press and media freedom are of particular concern and are a sign of democratic decline. The resolution rightly stresses the need to strengthen the coherence between the financial assistance granted to Turkey by the EU and the real progress that Turkey is making, particularly in respect of fundamental freedoms and rights.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. — (DE) I can only agree with this motion for a resolution: the violation of freedom of the press and the media and freedom of expression in Turkey must be condemned in the strongest possible terms. Freedom of the press and freedom of expression are one of the cornerstones of any modern nation, and if Turkey wants to be seen as such, it must not interfere with the work of journalists, editors and the media through systematic action. Although this resolution is non-binding, it sends out an important signal against the repression currently being imposed by the Turkish state. It would therefore be appropriate, in addition to the written condemnation, to take concrete measures which make it clear how little these repressions have to do with the European values that Turkey claims to represent as a candidate country. Such measures could be: a suspension of accession negotiations, a cancellation of the pre-accession costs of around EUR 1 billion a year, and a review and publication of all human rights violations committed by Turkey under Prime Minister Erdogan.

name: Tunne KELAM
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution.  Free and pluralistic media are a cornerstone of democracy. Turkey has committed itself to democracy through the accession talks with the EU. Despite Ankara’s commitment, according to Reporters without Borders Turkey has become one of the biggest prisons for people representing media. In the 2013 Gezi park demonstrations, 39 journalists were detained and 153 were injured. Self-censorship was applied, so that the violent demonstrations were more present in European media than in Turkish.  Currently more than 70 journalists are subject to legal proceedings for having exposed and informed about corruption cases involving high level politicians, including the Prime Minister. The investigating parliamentary committee last week decided to drop its investigations.  It was rather ironic to see the Turkish foreign minister showing solidarity with French victims of free speech in Paris on January 11, when at home in Turkey, media freedom is constantly under threat.  I urge our Turkish neighbours to pledge for democratic values in their actions and not only in words. Turkey’s best guarantee for prosperity and European future is a vibrant democracy.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. — I supported the resolution, as I am very concerned over backsliding on democratic reforms in Turkey. The government should address media freedom as a matter of priority and provide an adequate legal framework to guarantee pluralism in line with international standards. These developments, however, call for more, not less, engagement with Turkey. Respect for fundamental freedoms is at the heart of the EU accession negotiation process. Opening new negotiating chapters on the rule of law and human rights could increase the pressure and help the country address the reforms needed.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: in writing. — Today I supported the joint resolution on Turkey. Perhaps the issue of the EU-Turkey relationship is a never-ending odyssey. On the one hand, it is the eastern gateway to the EU and the channel through which Europe has always been in contact with Middle Eastern culture and the state with which we have a common history. On the other hand, it is a state that, with its current culture, value ranking and way of life, is very different from what we are used to in the EU. Although Turkey has taken many steps over the last decade to improve its democracy and the state of human rights protection, it is currently aware of a significant shift back from the standards already reached. In this country, there is now a growing restriction on the independence and impartiality of the courts, increasing intolerance of the current government against any political opposition, public protests and critical media, and a rejection of the right to self-determination of the Kurdish people. I regret to say that if this development were to continue in this way, the EU-Turkey Association Agreement should be expelled by the European Union. I consider Ankara's most dangerous actions at the moment to be a policy of supporting various armed groups fighting the Syrian government. Long-term violations of human rights and acts contrary to international law cannot be tolerated by the state with which we are linked by the Association Agreement.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. On 14 December, Turkish police arrested several journalists and media executives, including the editor-in-chief of the Newspaper Zaman. These arrests have once again cast serious doubt on the impartiality and independence of the judiciary in Turkey. They only confirm that Turkey does not meet the criteria for membership of the European Union, particularly in respect of fundamental rights and freedom of expression, and freedom of the press in particular. The 14 December arrests are not isolated cases. This is a systematic intolerance towards the political opposition and critical journalists. Nowhere else are there so many journalists imprisoned. Turkey's accession process proved to be a complete failure, a failure that the National Front MPs had foreseen even before the start of the negotiations. For years we have been told that these negotiations can be interrupted in case Turkey does not meet the criteria blatantly, but this possibility is not even mentioned in the joint resolution that has just been voted on. The accession negotiations and the use of pre-accession must be put to a definitive end.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the motion for a Resolution on freedom of expression in Turkey because it condemns police raids and the detention of journalists and media representatives in December 2014 and points to a general trend in the decline of democracy and the Turkish Government's tolerance for public protests and critical media.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. — I consider freedom of expression and media pluralism to be the pillars of an independent press. This element is essential in any democratic society, since an uninformed citizen cannot consistently exercise his rights and obligations in decision-making processes.  I therefore consider it appropriate to condemn the recent police raids and the detention of journalists and media representatives in Turkey.  These actions undermine respect for freedom of the press and, therefore, I urge the Turkish authorities to make an effort to develop reforms that establish, within their legal framework, mechanisms and balances aimed at ensuring freedom of the press and expression. Again, I stress the importance of ensuring these guarantees in order to promote and defend democracy, and finally for these reasons I vote in favour of this proposal.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: in writing. — The recent police raids and detention of journalists and media representatives in Turkey are deplorable and must be condemned. It is unacceptable to harass and detain journalists. Increasing political pressure on the media restricts access to news for the people. Recently, opposition journalists, including Ekrem Dumanlı, editor-in chief of Zaman newspaper, and Hidayet Karaca, general manager of the Samanyolu Broadcasting Group, have been detained because of criticising the government in Turkey. A group of international journalists were harassed and deported for reporting on the Gezi Park and Kobane protests. Let us remind the Turkish authorities that journalism is not a crime, but a crucial instrument of democracy. I join my colleagues in calling on the Turkish authorities to respect, ensure and guarantee media freedom and implement the Action Plan on Violations of the European Convention on Human Rights adopted in 2014. The Turkish Government must ensure that such practices as political harassment and arbitrary detention due to freedom of expression are no longer tolerated. I strongly urge the government of Turkey to make every effort possible to release as soon as possible the detained journalists.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. — In December 2014, Turkish police arrested journalists and media outlet executives on charges of forming an organisation to try to take power in the country through pressure, threats and intimidation.  I support this Resolution in order to get Turkey back on the path of democracy and European values as soon as possible and I strongly condemn this behaviour of the Turkish authorities. The principles of democracy must be respected and their implementation must by no means be jeopardised especially given Turkey's desires to join the European Union.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. — To jail journalists for fulfilling their professional duties is unacceptable, all the more so if Turkey is still very much to be accepted into the European Union. Now, as we know, it has the status of an associative state. The Erdogan regime is becoming increasingly undemocratic and can only express regret in this regard. I voted in favour of the draft text on the problem of freedom of expression in Turkey, and it was adopted.

name: Iuliu WINKLER
text: in writing. - I voted for the Joint Resolution of the European Parliament on freedom of expression in Turkey, this document being one of the manifestations of our concern, of MEPs, about the accelerated degradation of journalist status in the EU neighbourcountry. The European Parliament condemns in the resolution adopted today the pressure exerted by the police and the detention, on 14 December 2014, of journalists and representatives of the media.  The European Parliament document states that these actions call into question respect for the principles of the rule of law and freedom of expression, which are the essence of democracy. In this resolution, concern is expressed about the setback in Turkey's democratisation reforms. The document also points out that the Instrument for Pre-accession Assistance (IPA II) for the period 2014-2020 provides for the introduction of more coherent principles aimed at providing financial assistance to Turkey and the overall progress made in implementing the pre-accession strategy and full respect for fundamental rights and freedoms, including freedom of expression.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: in writing. — (IT) On 14 December, following police raids, a number of Turkish journalists were arrested on charges of 'trying to seize state power through pressure, intimidation and threats', but in reality it is a question of striking at some of President Erdogan's opponents in this way. This is not the first time that Turkey has shown increasing intolerance towards the political opposition, public protests and the media expressing critical positions, but actions such as those in December call even more into question respect for the rule of law and the freedom of the media, which is a fundamental principle of democracy.  At a time like this, I regard the issue of media freedom as a priority and I hope that the Turkish Government will soon provide an adequate legal framework to guarantee pluralism in line with international standards. With this resolution, the EU has loudly called for an end to pressure and intimidation of the media and journalists expressing critical positions.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: Writing. — Although Turkey has been committed to democratic and developed countries in Europe for years and is seeking to be part of the Union, the situation in the area of freedom of expression and media freedom is more than alarming in that country. Three years ago, the European Federation of Journalists drew attention to the fact that up to 100 journalists are imprisoned for an alleged coup attempt, and writers and intellectuals who have decided to publicly express their critical political views are also being persecuted. Despite a number of mobilisation campaigns and warnings from Western countries, the situation in Turkey in this area has not improved in any way in recent years. Also in the past year, many journalists have been persecuted and detained in connection with reporting on the involvement of senior political officials in a major corruption scandal. In doing so, the public authority did not invoke the veracity or falseness of journalistic claims, but the injunction to provide any information about this corruption case in relation to the politicians in question. Such a practice, when journalists (acting in accordance with the public interest) are intimidated, their computers are seized, databases when they are not allowed to write freely is unacceptable, and I therefore fully support the resolution condemning this situation and calling on Turkish government officials to establish genuine freedom of speech and freedom of the media.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. — Once again, we express our concern at the arrests and campaigns against journalists, writers and editors and other critics of the government, including the opposition, secular, progressive and left-wing sectors, and call for their release, as well as all political prisoners. These actions of the Turkish authorities are inseparable from this being a NATO power, with an arrogant, bellicose and expansionist stance, as well as the systematic interference and violations of the sovereignty of neighbouring countries, such as their support, funding, training and equipment of far-right, racist and xenophobic groups, which continue to play an active role in destabilising Syria and Iraq and commit the most heinous crimes against their peoples and a brutal repression. Support totally contrary to international law and the UN Charter, contrary to peace and political and peaceful resolution of conflicts. A policy whose character is also manifested in the maintenance of the occupation of part of the territory of Cyprus and the new Navtex of Turkey, for which we demand its immediate revocation, as well as the withdrawal of all Turkish vessels from the Exclusive Economic Zone of the Republic of Cyprus.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. — I voted in favour of the resolution on freedom of expression in Turkey. The recent arrests of journalists in Turkey constitute an undemocratic interference with one of the fundamental human rights, namely the right to freedom of speech and expression. A government that does not nurture these rights is a government that acts contrary to the fundamental principles of the European Union. It is worrying that, in addition to the violence against representatives of the seventh force, the issue of independence and impartiality of the Turkish justice system also arises in the part of the Turkish public. However, the European Union, more specifically its full member Slovenia, also has major difficulties with the functioning of the judicial system and with the guarantee of fundamental human rights. Only 25% of people trust the judiciary, and in the last 10 years, courts have violated human rights and fundamental freedoms in as many as 422 cases. The most famous example is the case of political prisoner and SDS President Janez Janše, when the court convicted him of being unsecified on an unsheed day, in an unshealed communication mode and an unsupersonal place, accepting an uns found promise of reward. His wrong-law was only suspended by the Constitutional Court at the end of 2014. The European Union must help all countries, and especially its members. It must take measures to ensure that the remnants of undemocratic systems, which will establish an independent judiciary and ensure respect for fundamental human rights and freedoms, are abolished.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: That concludes the explanations of vote.

name: Marek JUREK
text: With regard to the vote on Kyrgyzstan, an explanation is registered.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: The Rules of Procedure do not provide for explanations of vote on the declarations of urgency adopted here under a separate procedure. I regret that, but it is, and it leaves me with no choice.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: I declare the session of the European Parliament adjourned. (The sitting was closed at 1.30 p.m.)
